name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Elisabetta Gardini, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy. public health and food safety, on the proposal for a Council decision amending Decision No 1313/2013/EU on a Union civil protection mechanism (COM(2017)0772 - C8-0409/2017 - 2017/0309(COD)) (A8-0180/2018).

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are writing a beautiful page of this European Union of ours, and I wanted to thank all the people who have worked on this result straight away, starting with our fellow rapporteurs, but also the whole Parliament, which has demonstrated with its flexibility, its ability to look at what was the concrete purpose of this mechanism. , of this strengthening of the European civil protection mechanism, has also managed to overcome some of the reservations and delays of some States that were a little concerned and saw this strengthening of civil protection as a kind of interference by the European institutions. This sensitivity is very different and distant from that of the citizens, who, with Eurobarometer, continue to say that civil protection wants it and want to see Europe and the European institutions by their side when they are facing a disaster that their local and national authorities cannot deal with on their own.  Experience has told us that this is the case. Unfortunately, we saw with the fires, especially in the summer in Portugal and Greece, where we suffered the loss of hundreds of human lives, in addition to the enormous economic damage, that Europe, despite having already had a civil protection mechanism, was unable to deal with multiple disasters at the same time.  And here we say today that we managed, just over a year after the Commission's communication – and I thank Commissioner Stylianides for that – to have the instrument we needed, we have RescEU. What Is RescEU? It is a new instrument that will consist of additional resources compared to those already existing and already belonging to the Member States, because the purpose of rescEU is precisely to strengthen and strengthen the response capacity where necessary.  Of course, it is not only this, because prevention and preparation are being strengthened, there is a European Union that stands shoulder to shoulder with its states to help them deal with disasters, whether they are natural or, as might unfortunately be the case, also accidents that also have to do with chemicals, biological, radiological and nuclear. I would like to point out that fire prevention is also something that is very good for the environment, because there are studies showing that fires cause 20 % of CO2 emissions in the world. So there are many aspects that we touch on with this strengthened mechanism. Let me also remind you, as an Italian, of a person who left us on 26 January last, Giuseppe Zamberletti, who for us Italians is the father of Italian civil protection, and somehow, in a translational sense, he also becomes a bit of the father of European civil protection. I would like to dedicate this day, this work, to him, if You will allow me, Commissioner, and since we have also set up, in addition to a kind of Erasmus – because it is important that the cooperation that already exists between the States is even more widespread and that there is a common European training standard, so this will also be an important tool – recognition for the people who will have , in the various countries of the Union, which are distinct from civil protection, I would not mind if we could begin by giving this great man this role. He never lacked his advice and support, and I think from heaven up there today, he also gives us a smile for this great achievement for all of us.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the DEVE committee. – Dear Chairman, Distinguished Commissioner, at the outset I would like to congratulate my colleague Elisabetti Gardini on a very well-developed report by the European Civil Protection Mechanism as well as the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid and Crisis Management of the European Union, Christos Stylianides. In my role as rapporteur for the opinion on behalf of the Development Committee, I participated in the preparation of this report on supporting the mechanism in which I stressed the need to strengthen national civil protection capacities, and to complement instruments at Eu level in the case of Union civil protection mechanisms. The new mechanism should not act in isolation, but should rely on the strength of other European instruments and focus on risk prevention. Faced with fires in the south of Europe, we could not remain passive. With extensive material damage and human casualties and numerous shortcomings in existing disaster mechanisms, we had to react.  I would like to point out that the report introduced a provision that allows Member States that are not able to participate in the pooled civil protection capacities, a co-financing rate not higher than 55 % of eligible transport costs, which is extremely important for the Republic of Croatia. Croatia is a crisis point bordering the rest of Southeast Europe and should be seen with special attention when allocating funds, so the focus should be on stepping up all preventive measures.  The adopted amendments in the Commission allow for the power to deploy Rescue capacity, while operational control in crisis areas remains under the control of Member States. I thank, the Chairman, and I thank once again all those who worked that this mechanism, which is the most beautiful thing we could do for the citizens of the European Union, gets its full strength and that citizens do not feel isolated, wherever they are.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I addressed this House a little more than a year ago to present our proposal, these proposals, to strengthen our European Union Civil Protection Mechanism. Today, after a year, Parliament is voting for the most ambitious European civil protection system that ever existed. And today, Parliament is voting for something that was really politically unthinkable a few years ago. Among friends, I have to be frank. It was really a very difficult and demanding job to persuade our Member States to accept this upgrade, but, at the end of the day, we managed together to get this very ambitious common purpose. Today, I am proud of being a European citizen. I would like to express, first of all, my sincere gratitude to the rapporteur, Elisabetta Gardini, for her leadership, and of course my thanks to all colleagues, my dear colleague Željana Zovko, my dear colleague Fernandes and all other rapporteurs from all political groups, and of course my thanks go to the parliamentary groups and to the European Parliament that supported overwhelmingly this ground-breaking initiative. Dear colleagues, with your political support, rescEU will be a reality ahead of the next forest fire season. And this is also thanks to your dedication to our common goal: to protect our citizens, to save lives and to save their livelihoods. You rightly insisted on a guarantee to have more disaster response means available immediately. Today, I can tell you this: we are working closely with our Member States to set in motion as soon as possible the so-called ‘rescEU transition phase’, so that disaster response capacities can be in place to respond to possible forest fires in Europe already this year, in 2019. The feedback from Member States so far is positive and I would also like to thank them here today for their positive approach.  Let us have no illusions. Natural disasters will not stop. On the contrary, they will become more frequent and more intense because of climate change. It is not fake news. It is happening now and we have to deal with this new phenomenon due to climate change. What we aim to do with rescEU is to better equip ourselves to face these disasters due to climate change. Dear colleagues, with this new legislation we are also putting more emphasis on prevention, on preparedness. The European Parliament made it very clear that this was a priority, and we have done our best to put in place a system that offers more support to Member States to exchange information and learn from each other. Today, modestly, we mark the beginning of a new era for European civil protection. This is about a Europe that protects. We owe this, as I said, to our citizens.  I would like to conclude by saying once again that we should all be proud because of this achievement, and I thank you so much for your dedication. Thank you for your attention.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, the Europe you protect is a necessity. The protection of human life must be our priority. In 2017, in Portugal, we had a huge tragedy where more than one hundred people lost their lives. It's something you can't repeat. This new mechanism proves the solidarity of the European Union, shows that the proudly alone is not a solution, the sharing, and the sharing of sovereignty in some areas, such as in the area of civil protection, reinforces that same sovereignty. There cannot be a relaxation of the Member States, they have to bet, to continue to bet on protection and protection is the solution. Here is another concern, which was a finding, there are finance ministers who did not want this agreement and who have been haggling two hundred million euros, ridiculous sum, for 2019 and 2020, something that we have to highlight here and also highlight the commitment of Commissioner Christos Stylianides, rapporteur Gardini, so that we could have an agreement that , effectively shows that the European Union saves lives and is worth it.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Europe is built through solidarity and brotherhood among its peoples, and it is a principle which, more than ever, we must remember in this Hemiiclo in Strasbourg. Solidarity among Europeans is built from the base and from the most basic outset, which is aid to the facts that we cannot foresee. We recently lived it in the serious fires that ravaged Portugal and Galicia in 2017. However, we must be equally honest with ourselves, and something fails when Europe is not the first to respond to a catastrophe like this. That is why I believe that the action of the Civil Protection Mechanism will be a good tool that can also be combined with the proposal of the European Solidarity Corps. And it will lead us to continue to feel proud of the Union, demonstrating that from unity we can better meet the challenges ahead. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Gardini, for the work done in this dossier, for the good results achieved and for the functionality and direct impact this mechanism will have in the future on European society.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in recent years, in many of the citizens of the European Union, institutions seem distant, even hostile. However, in our case, their anxiety about better protection from natural disasters has been the driving force in our efforts to make the European Civil Protection Mechanism a real tool of solidarity by creating the rescEU. Today, the humanity and support of the least powerful and environmental morality are winners. The reason for this proposal was the devastating fires in Portugal. But no one could have imagined that, just before the negotiations began, a new tragedy would struck Europe, this time in Mati, just outside Athens, with over 100 dead.  These events have made it clear to everyone that we must offer a meaningful response to citizens' concerns. In increasing natural disasters due to climate change or insufficient preparation by national authorities we do not remain observers, but we give a strong response. Together, with more organization, we can achieve more than anyone on their own. The road to political unification is long and full of the obstacles put by the devotees of a Europe in which solidarity is not an end in it own right, but an instrument at a cost that they do not want to bear.  The European Civil Protection Mechanism is a prime example of practical solidarity between Member States. We are creating the rescEU, a European pool of instruments, such as fire helicopters and planes, which will be bought with European funding for 80 to 90% of the total costs, ensuring that no country is left helpless again. At the same time, for the first time, up to 75% of European funding is available for the maintenance of national instruments. This assistance to countries such as Greece, where the inability to repair due to the economic crisis has severely limited the action of national instruments, is necessary.  Finally, we are strengthening prevention by keeping the characteristics of solidarity unadulted. We rejected the Council's proposal to introduce penalties for countries that often call for the mechanism to be activated. On the contrary, we give the Commission the power to examine the preventive measures of the State concerned and, where necessary, to intervene and to make recommendations to improve or strengthen national protection plans. All European citizens, regardless of the Member State in which they reside, must feel safe and know that the Union can help them in a practical and effective way in the event of an emergency.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the On behalf of the ECR, I would like to thank you, Mrs Gardini, and all my colleagues from Parliament, the Commission and the Council who have worked closely together in drawing up these interinstitutional agreements, which meet all our requirements. The rescEU will allow Member States to request special types of emergency services if their own resources are exhausted, as was the case, for example, with the wild fires last summer. Hopefully, by this summer, we will have special firefighting aircraft in place to fight the fires that are very likely to occur and will occur.  I believe that cooperation has been achieved here, as has rarely been the case in the past, that civil protection is a matter of best practice and that, as Europe in a special way, we also have global responsibilities.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Gardini, for his good work. It is excellent that the final responsibility or the end result in this matter is that the main responsibility for civil protection remains with the Member States. The EU's common resources are used only as a last and supportive option. No Member State can, and should not, outsource its civil protection mechanism to other Member States. That would be dangerous and irresponsible, because we know that when a disaster occurs, action must be taken immediately. The opening moments are the most important. If we have to wait for civil protection to come from the other side of Europe, then the damage will be many times 100. In other countries, the Member States have the main responsibility for combating the damage, but the EU also has a role to play. The EU has a supportive role and such prior cooperation, preparedness for disasters, must be made more effective and also compatibility of equipment. But each Member State must acquire civil protection equipment itself, and the compatibility of these instruments is important. We've already raised the issue of forest fires. Here, too, it is important to try to work in advance to avoid forest fires. That is also possible, not perfectly.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, this is one of the few positive news stories we have served as European institutions in recent times. We owe this to the pressure of the European Parliament, to the positive efforts of Commissioner Stylianides and to the cooperation of the European Parliament – Commission, which have raised the objections of some Member States. Because the facts came to help. The tragic events. The great fires in Portugal; deadly. The fires in my home country of Greece and the floods; deadly. The earthquakes in Italy, also with the dead, but also the large fires in Sweden, which have also made the northern Member States understand that climate change is not only threatening the South and that we need an auxiliary European force that will strengthen the efforts of the Member States. So this Euro-sting has ceased and we have a more and better Europe. The final proposal is improved, thanks to the insistence of the European Parliament, and is moving in a positive direction and that is why I think it also has wider support within Parliament.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The current winter in my own country, Austria, has shown that the volunteer fire brigades, the emergency services and other emergency services are excellently prepared for disaster situations, at local and regional level. We are the European Union, and we must have the strength not to rely on external aid when there are major disasters that are unpredictable and in which we have to respond at a supra-regional level. That is why I think it is right that the European Commission has relaunched an EU civil protection mechanism. I agree, as several Members have already said, that we in Parliament have significantly improved this proposal: it is less centralised and less bureaucratic. I am pleased that this has finally been a success in the Austrian Presidency and that we can now vote in Parliament on the final result. Because from the Commission's original proposal, which provided for command and control, i.e. command and control from the Union level, we now come to a package which provides for cooperation and promotion; Support, in particular, for regional and local provision. The red-white-red model from Austria already has a part to play in this, and of course the operational capability without having to rely on outside help.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, today another decisive step is being taken in the creation of the new Civil Protection Mechanism of the European Union, under which the Union will be able to provide better assistance in a coordinated and complementary way to the action of the Member States. The overwhelming disasters, which have occurred across Europe in recent years, have put the current European Civil Protection Mechanism based on voluntary contributions to the test. Let us recognize: in key moments solidarity was never lacking, what was often lacking were the resources needed for the required response. The creation of the European asset reserve, provided for in RescEU, is urgent, is essential, and the report under discussion makes it possible to implement it. Congratulations to the rapporteur! On the basis of the principles of solidarity and the sharing of responsibilities, the Union will be empowered to provide better assistance to its citizens.  Support for Member States will also be intensified to improve risk management and to strengthen existing national measures. But, Commissioner, the implementation of these policies cannot be postponed. The operationality of RescEU cannot be called into question by the political and bureaucratic difficulties resulting from the ongoing debate on the 2021–2027 Financial Perspective. As rapporteur appointed by the European Parliament in the context of the post-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, I recently asked the Commission for a priority written question on the timetable for the publication of the legislative proposal for financing this mechanism. If it were published today, it wouldn't be early. It will be intolerable if such publication does not take place in this parliamentary term. Disasters don't wait. European citizens need RescEU now.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is positive and it is desirable to increase cooperation in the field of disaster response, especially in the case of major disasters. Such cooperation may and should involve coordination of efforts, the lending of resources, and also the sharing of certain means of response.  The European Union has not done everything it can in this area. The situation in 2017 of the fires in Portugal demonstrated it to the evidence. Disaster prevention has also fallen short of what was desirable. Moreover, we are very concerned about the prospect of further cutting the funds for economic and social cohesion from which many of the resources to act on disaster prevention come from. Disasters are unjust, almost more and more hit states and people with the lowest means to defend themselves. But it is important that we are not going to go from a situation where you do not do everything you can for a situation where you want to do more than you should, and here, just a note to say that it is very important that chains of command remain at the national level. The usurpation of chains of command for a supranational plan, as provided for in the European Commission's initial proposal, would raise undespicient risks which, fortunately, could be avoided by correcting that part of the proposal and maintaining the chains of command at national level, where they must in fact be.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Mr President, I would like today to celebrate the implementation of this mechanism which is more Europe doing; more Europe from solidarity, preventing and minimizing the effects of the natural challenges facing the European Union. But I would particularly like to take this opportunity to once again demand the need to amend the European Union Solidarity Fund, which is facing the repair of these natural disasters. I believe that it is important — as we have already asked for — to introduce the environment: that it be economically posted and that a truly effective repair can be ensured. I also think it is particularly important that the calculation of the beneficiary regions be computed or done on the basis of criteria of real GDP, GDP per capita, not the overall GDP of the regions. We are seeing regions with a higher economic level benefit and are left out of this Solidarity Fund to deal with these major natural disasters regions with lower economic level. I am aware that this is not the specific Regulation, but there is a call here for this need to make synergy with these funds and, therefore, a revision of it is needed. Congratulations, Commissioner.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, natural disasters are unfortunately on the agenda in the European Union because of — of course — climate change. We have had enormous disasters: the deadly floods in Mandra, Attica, the deadly fires in Mati with 100 dead, fires — also deadly — in Portugal, earthquakes with dead in Italy. All this shows that the European Union must have a decisive civil protection mechanism that incorporates in practice the principle of solidarity. I think the steps that are being taken are in a positive direction. The Member States must understand that they cannot impose penalties on countries that would like to use this mechanism, because the use of this mechanism unfortunately results from natural disasters. I believe that we must take even more decisive measures and support the countries suffering from natural disasters, which are the countries of the European South in particular.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today's debate shows once again very clearly that we need to see this problem of civil protection multi-sectoral. This is about climate protection, it is about spatial planning, but it is also about education and training in advance – that is, prevention in all areas. We need to be prepared for these types of disasters, we need good monitoring. I believe that this Civil Protection Mechanism of the Union, which has been discussed today and hopefully also adopted, is a huge contribution to the fact that in future we can say to Europeans that in the event of a disaster, Europe will come together. This does not mean that the individual regions, the individual bodies, the Member States will be relieved of their responsibilities here, but it simply means that, in the event of a disaster, a Europe will be ready with financial resources, technical resources, know-how to alleviate the suffering where it has occurred as far as possible, as efficiently and as quickly as possible, where it has occurred as a result of natural disasters or even human-caused disasters.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Mr President, in fact, the issue is quite important and, on a case-by-case basis, one Member State cannot cope with the problems that arise, such as the Astravo nuclear power plant. It is already established today that the construction of this power plant has violated international conventions and in particular the selection of the site.  This nuclear power plant, which is of the Chernobyl type, is being built today without complying with international standards near the European Union, just twenty kilometres from the border, posing a potentially huge risk. I would like to ask the Commission whether these new rules will force the Belarusian State to fulfil all the obligations that are required, and the second is whether Belarus will insuse anyone who is potentially able to suffer or suffer from this, say, nuclear power plant.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after lengthy negotiations, the decision to strengthen the European Union's civil protection mechanism, which was put to the test in 2017 and 2018 by forest fires, storms and floods, finally comes to the vote.  At present, the European Civil Protection Mechanism is a voluntary system, through which the Union coordinates the voluntary contributions of participating states to a country that has requested assistance.  The new legislation will help Member States respond more quickly and more effectively to disasters, including through a more efficient sharing of civil protection means. The RescEU resource fund will be set up at Parliament's request, which will intervene if Member States do not have sufficient resources to respond to a disaster and will make available to states affected by the emergency air resources to combat forest fires, high-capacity pumping units, field hospitals and emergency medical teams.  I congratulate the rapporteur on her excellent work.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, when I started this initiative two years ago – frankly speaking, with a lot of reluctance from many of our Member States – I knew that having more capacities is important. I knew that having more financial means is also important. I knew that having a better disaster-risk management framework is really important. But for me – and as I realise, for you – the most important thing that we have achieved with REScEU is that we are making European solidarity stronger. We are making European solidarity more efficient, and we are making European solidarity more effective and more tangible, very close to our citizens. This is the most important thing. Especially at this time, at which our common European project is, unfortunately, being questioned by many people, and in particular with very important European elections coming up, we are delivering on our promise to build a Europe that protects and a Europe that saves lives. It is a really big achievement, and thank you so much again for this. But my advice, because of a lot of experience through this common effort, is that this the first big step. We have to continue in order to upgrade the Union Civil Protection Mechanism in other fields, in particular the medical field. This is the next big step.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was very pleased to hear everyone's speeches, the confirmation of a unity of purpose and cooperation between all the political groups and all the very important Members. I was also thinking about how far we have come since the last parliamentary term, when the concept of prevention was incorporated, which today is an integral, if not a priority, part of civil protection. We have done so much on the road, and that makes me optimistic, and I would like to thank the Commissioner, who also mentioned the efforts to convince some States.  There is also a kind of cultural modesty, let's say, in accepting that we need to be helped. I would like to remind you of the lesson we had unfortunately learned when Japan faced the Fukushima disaster: the country that was considered the most prepared in the world, was not ready to deal with that huge catastrophe. So there doesn't have to be this modesty. The Europe it protects, the Europe it protects, is an increasingly strong reality, because thanks to the Proposal of the Commissioner and the work of Parliament, and also of the Council, we finally have an instrument that makes this Europe safer. I am glad that we have also had the opportunity to implement this transitional period, which will allow us to be ready before next summer, because we have seen that the greatest disasters, those which have unfortunately recorded the number of incalculable human losses, take place during the summer with forest fires.  I would like to thank everyone once again, and I would like, after having dedicated this day to Zamberletti, to think of the hundreds of thousands of people who work in all the countries of Europe for the safety of all of us: those who work in civil protection, those who work in the fire brigade, the many, many volunteers who work for us in many countries. Civil protection has many forms – that is why we were unable to write the definition of civil protection during the last parliamentary term – but unity of purpose and feelings is the same and will certainly be an important brick in founding the Europe that we like, precisely the Europe that protects, protects, a Europe of solidarity alongside its citizens. Thank you all again and good work in that regard.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, February 12, 2019. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – In recent years Europe has been experiencing uncontrolled natural disasters. Greece mourned hundreds of deaths from the deadly fires in Mati Attica last summer, but also from the floods in Mandra, Attica. With the strengthened European Civil Protection Mechanism we are taking a step forward to help Member States respond more quickly and effectively to such disasters. It is undoubtedly an indispensable tool that strengthens cooperation between Member States, particularly in major natural disasters, in order to save more human lives in the future. Member States that do not have sufficient resources, such as Greece, can reap great benefits, as for the first time a reserve of resources is being created for emergencies. Above all and above all, however, the new mechanism transforms in practice the fundamental values of the European Union, is an expression of solidarity between member states and enhances the security of European citizens, satisfying their demand for more Europe. In this context, it is crucial to amend the rules of the European Solidarity Fund immediately, with a view to making allowances for those affected determined on the basis of the per capita GDP of the affected area and to avoid excluding large residential areas with low levels of wealth from the Fund.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – In Europe, but also around the world, natural disasters are increasing. They are becoming not only more frequent, but also more intense, posing a serious threat to our societies, economies and ecosystems. The European Union has developed a disaster response network, such as the Union Civil Protection Mechanism. This instrument has helped Member States to optimise their disaster prevention and risk reduction efforts. Unfortunately, recent disasters, such as forest fires in Greece or earthquakes in Italy, have highlighted the shortcomings of the mechanism.  I strongly support the rapporteur's position on the future mechanism. It should have its own capabilities at its disposal in addition to those made available by the Member States. These new resources would be intended to fill the gaps identified in national response systems. Lastly, I would like to stress the importance of an appropriate budget to ensure the efficiency and resilience of this much-needed European instrument.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Jytte Guteland, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the implementation of Directive 2009/128/EC on the sustainable use of pesticides (2017/2284(INI)) (A8-0045/2019)). Mr President, I would like to make a very important Mr Guteland is not here with us today and we are listening to Mr Guteland in his place. Dalli.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start straight away by thanking Jytte Guteland for the work she carried out on this report. As you mentioned, Jytte can’t be with us this morning, but I would like to acknowledge the great work she did, together with all her colleagues and the shadow rapporteurs, precisely on this matter. Colleagues, I am one of those who strongly believes that today's intensive pesticide use around Europe is no longer sustainable. The unsustainable use of pesticides poses a challenge not only to our environment, but also to people's health, and it can have a serious impact on both the farmers who use such products and the general public who can come into contact with hazardous chemicals found in pesticides in public areas such as parks and also school-yards. Now the Sustainable Use of Pesticides Directive provides for a range of actions that can help Europe achieve a sustainable use of pesticides. But it is amply clear that Member States are not implementing this legislation in the proper manner. Instead, we are seeing a situation where the use of pesticides in Europe has been steadily increasing, since the 1990s. And funnily enough, despite awareness around the sustainability of agriculture and despite the development of pesticides that can be used at low doses, on average, we are seeing the use of pesticides has not decreased at all in recent years.  Whilst some progress was registered vis-à-vis checks on spraying equipment and in developing training courses and certification schemes on how to best spray pesticides, little progress has been made in promoting the uptake of alternative techniques.  Moreover, there is a lack of clear and quantifiable targets in the different Member States’ national action plans and most of these plans do not specify as yet how the targets or objectives are to be achieved. We strongly feel that progress is also lacking in the field of integrated pest management.  Now, we need Member States to take this seriously, because European citizens are getting increasingly concerned and want dependency on pesticides to decrease.  Europe's farmers have every right to be able to use substances and techniques that do not put their own health at risk and that do not impact negatively on the environment and their farmland. We need incentives that can change things, incentives that can help farmers reduce the amount of pesticides they use and switch to more sustainable non-chemical options. For the S&D Group it is a priority that the European Union and all its Member States increase their efforts to help the sustainable use of pesticides. We need to continue working tirelessly to create non-toxic environments where we ensure that human health and ecosystems are fully protected against the impact of today's wide use of pesticides.  We have the tools. Now we need to make sure that Member States deliver, so that farmers, consumers, citizens and the environment, can all benefit from the existing sustainable alternative methods.  A better implementation of the Sustainable Use of Pesticides Directive is key in ensuring that this change actually happens.  Finally, I know that there was very good cooperation between the responsible shadow rapporteurs, and on behalf of Jytte, I would like to thank all the colleagues from the different political groups for their constructive approach and valuable support for Jytte’s work. Later on today, we as parliamentarians have the opportunity to send a clear and important signal to all the Member States, that we stand together with all citizens across the European Union and expect our countries to ramp up their actions and contribute concretely to a more sustainable use of pesticides around Europe.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Mr President, this issue requires a serious and non-demagogic discussion for the health of Europeans, the work of our farmers and the political seriousness of what we do here. It is clear that we can use pesticides more sustainably and it is also clear that farmers are the main ones interested in maintaining a clean and sustainable environment. Your livelihood depends on it. I therefore regret the general tone of this document which attributes to agriculture the main cause of the misuse of these products, when we know that their use is widespread by professionals and non-professionals also from other sectors. Climate change is triggering the emergence of new pests that must be tackled and thus protect our plants and productions. The way is not to eradicate pesticides, but to focus on the greater number of available low-risk active substances and the selectivity of the administration of these products. I again argue that the European Union has the safest agri-food system in the world and that in the most recent studies 97.2% of agricultural product samples have waste values well below the legal limit. On the contrary, recent research has shown a greater presence of pesticide residues in products of biological origin compared to conventional production. These are the facts.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am delighted to attend today’s plenary session and to discuss the implementation of the Directive on the sustainable use of pesticides. I welcome your own—initiative report, which will make a valuable contribution to our ongoing work on this very important topic. I want to start by stressing that we share common concerns and common goals – to protect citizens’ health, to safeguard the environment and to protect animal health – and we share these goals with Europeans, who are becoming increasingly interested and engaged in how we produce food and want to ensure this is done in a sustainable way. This is very much the debate at the moment. Let me remind all of us that the European Union has a comprehensive package of legislation to regulate plant protection products. To place a product on the market, the relevant active substance must first be approved at EU level – the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and so on – and then the product, the so—called concrete pesticide, must be authorised at Member State level. This is a rigorous and extensive process to demonstrate that products can be used in a manner which is safe for humans, animals and the environment. Nonetheless, as your report identifies, European citizens demand more. This is why the Directive on the sustainable use of pesticides was developed. It requires Member States to adopt national action plans outlining their quantitative objective: targets, measures and timetables to reduce the risks and impacts of pesticide use on human health and in the environment. The Commission has evaluated these national action plans. It summarised its findings in a report to the European Parliament and Council in 2017. You know that. This report concluded that, while national action plans represented a significant step towards the sustainable use of pesticides, there were also significant gaps in many, many areas. It indicated that Member States needed to improve the quality of their plans. Primarily, they need to establish specific and measurable targets and indicators as part of a longer-term strategy to reduce the risks and impact of pesticide use. The report also notes that, although integrated pest management is a cornerstone of the Directive, Member States have not set clear targets in this area or ensured its implementation. It is clear that we need to do more. Let me assure you that I will not stop asking Member States to do more in implementing this Directive. My services are engaged in a series of actions to ensure this takes place. Following the evaluation of the national action plans, my services wrote to all Member States detailing their weaknesses and inviting them to address these in the revision of their plans. The Commission has also conducted audits in Member States to verify that the Directive is being fully implemented. These audits serve two purposes. First, they are a tool to share good practices amongst Member States. Secondly, where Member States have not met their obligations under the Directive, they will help the Commission to consider further actions based on their concrete findings. I am pleased to report that last month, Member States voted in favour of a Commission implementing directive to establish harmonised risk indicators. This will show trends in the risks associated with plant protection products. This implementing measure is now subject to scrutiny by the Council and the European Parliament – by you. I encourage you to look upon it favourably. I expect that these indicators will be calculated and published by the end of 2019. However, I should stress that I do not see the two indicators established under this Directive as the end of a process. Rather, they are the start of a more comprehensive suite of indicators to reflect trends in the risks associated with plant protection products throughout the EU. Integrated pest management is a cornerstone of the Directive. As you have noted in your report, Member States to date have not converted integrated pest management principles into prescriptive and assessable criteria to monitor compliance. I am pleased to inform you that my services are organising a workshop in May to develop a toolbox to help Member States to check implementation of this essential element. Your report also notes the importance of low—risk active substances to achieve more sustainable agriculture. It is thanks to the combined efforts of the Commission, EFSA, Member States and industry that the number of low—risk active substances continues to increase. These substances give farmers a tool to control pests while producing high—quality food in a more sustainable manner. While their adoption may not reduce the total quantities of plant protection products used, they have a more favourable toxicological profile. This will certainly help reduce the risk associated with these products. I also share your view that the sustainable use of pesticides should be integrated into the common agricultural policy. You will have noticed that such provisions were included in the Commission’s proposal, and I would encourage your support. Finally, five years have passed since Member States adopted their first national action plans. They are now obliged to review and revise them where necessary. My services will present a second report to the European Parliament and Council on the implementation of the Sustainable Use Directive later this year. It will analyse the revised national action plans and determine if weaknesses have been addressed. It will also summarise the experience gained by Member States in implementing the national targets to reduce the risks and impacts of pesticides. Honourable Members, thank you once again for your report. I think we can all agree that the Directive on the sustainable use of pesticides is an important part of a broader sustainable agriculture policy. Two weeks ago we adopted a reflection paper on progress towards a sustainable Europe by 2030. It notably called for a genuine change in the way we produce, transform, distribute and consume food. The full implementation of the Directive on the sustainable use of pesticides would very much help in this respect. I can assure you that my services will look very closely at the recommendations listed in your report. In many areas, as you have just heard, the Commission has already taken action to address the issues raised. We are committed to ensure the full implementation of the Directive and we will continue to work with Member States so that this objective is achieved.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, Commissioner. We are now listening to the views of the political groups. We are a little late, so at this stage we will not accept blue card questions.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, thank you, I can only support your paper. I very much like the greatest tenor in this report. One point is very important here, namely the question of the training of those who drive these spraying machines. I just took part in such a course myself in December, although I still have three or four others on my company who did it. So further training on this issue is extraordinarily important. You have also mentioned the further development of plant protection technology. As a practical farmer, I can only recommend this. However, I would also like to thank the rapporteur. She has written a lot of heart and soul and has jumped a bit out of the grid here and there. So we are debating sustainable pesticide use here. We are not talking about THE CAP here, and we are not talking about groundwater pollution here. But if you want to talk to me about the pollution of groundwater, you can have it. I say to you: as long as you all want to buy cheap meat, and I do, you should not be surprised that the facts are quite simple. There were 80 pigs on my father's farm, on my 800, and with my neighbour – the next generation – there were 3,000. If you call this sustainability, then we are not on a course. Otherwise, Commissioner, good luck, and please stick hard with neonicotinoids. We have banned them, and that remains the case. If you now get 20 exemptions approved by you, then those countries that ban neonicotinoids will get lead shoes on their feet, and the others will run through this competition with sneakers. I cannot accept that.

name: Pavel POC
text: On the part of the S&D Group. The principles of integrated plant protection have been in force since 2014, but until the Member States start to play their part, we will still be telling stories about what they mean and why we must respect them. We do not want to take away the tools for plant protection for farmers, but rather we want to offer them ones that do not destroy their health or our health or harm the environment. After all, the use of chemical pesticides, as well as the use of antibiotics, should be a last resort and not the basis of our European agriculture. In this context, I am a little sorry that the Commission has not heard this Parliament's request to speed up the approval of biological and low-risk pesticides, which is probably what awaits us in the next period. In Europe, we talk a lot about security today, while we put a time bomb in our countryside every day that is going to go off around us and explode sooner or later. No wall or borders can protect us from it. Let us finally accept that the current way of farming is unsustainable in the long term. If we change this actively ourselves, it will be a managed process that will not harm either farmers, consumers, or the countryside. If this happens as a result of the collapse of the ecosystem, we will all take it away.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Thank you, Chairman. Dear Commissioner, this report on sustainable crop protection devotes a great deal of attention to integrated crop protection. I think this is important, because integrated crop protection is the result of preventing the occurrence of diseases and pests in crops. What emerges in the report is that the countries of the European Union are being fingered because they would not do enough. I would also like to point the finger at ourselves, because many European rules make integrated crop protection difficult. Let me give you a few examples. First, breeding. It is extremely important that we grow new crops that are more resilient to diseases and various pests. The breeding sector is very much on the move and there are several innovations to improve this breeding. Unfortunately, European laws and regulations do not allow these new innovations. A second point that is very important is soil health. I think it is ridiculous that the European Nitrates Directive encourages the use of fertilizers at the expense of the use of animal manure. Thirdly, initiatives are being taken in several countries, including the Netherlands, to improve soil quality – in mind the Veldleeuwerik Foundation – but these are not given enough space by the rigid greening measures in the current common agricultural policy. Furthermore, a poor and outdated authorisation procedure makes the authorisation and use of micro-organisms and low-risk agents more difficult. And finally, we should pay much more attention to precision farming in order to be able to detect diseases and pests more quickly and to be able to tackle them more adequately and precisely. Thank you very much.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Thank you, Chairman. Sustainability and pesticides, that are actually two words that do not belong in one sentence. Poison is not sustainable. Poison that was used in our grandparents' time is still in our environment, on our food and in our bodies. Agricultural poison pollutes our waters, it pollutes the soil, it poisons our health and affects biodiversity. A new study, published in the Journal of Biological Conservation, shows that 40% of all insects are threatened with extinction. Bees, butterflies and beetles are on the danger list. The disappearance of these insects, in turn, has a major impact on the rest of the biodiversity and all the animals that eat these insects. Think of meadow birds, fish, reptiles, amphibians and bats. The main cause of all this is the way we produce our food. Industrial intensive agriculture is destroying our ecosystems, the same research concludes. The use of agricultural poison is explicitly cited as one of the main causes of biodiversity loss. The question is therefore not how poison can be used sustainably. The question is how to shift to safe and truly sustainable production methods: organic production without agricultural poison. The current agricultural policy is still very far from that. That is also why I believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I find the name of this report misleading: there is no sustainable use of pesticides. What we need to look at is an exit scenario for pesticides. Commissioner, you were right to point out that the Member States should actually be supplying reduction plans for pesticides. Has anything happened? No. Quite the opposite. Only two Member States fulfil their reporting obligation at all and make reduction plans. What are the Member States doing instead? As my colleague said, neonicotinoids are used in a number of Member States, although there is a European ban. This is untenable. This is actually the scandal where I have to say: is this legislation worth anything if there are Member States that simply ignore it?  We still have a discussion about glyphosate and we will continue to have it. What conclusions do we draw from this? Yes, it would have to be reduced – but the use of glyphosate is still increasing in some Member States, although there are alternatives. After all, organic farming makes it possible to do it without chemicals. Glyphosate e.B. is dispensed with. We would simply have to resort to mechanical methods. We must make decent crop rotations. That would provide us with solutions. But it is not practiced because, on the other hand, there are, of course, powerful interests, an industry that wants to continue to sell pesticides and thus does very good business. That has to be made clear here. Yesterday, another study was published which shows that the decline in species is really dramatic. There is no time left to think about whether we are lowering a little somewhere. No, we have to get out. We cannot wait for more than 70% of the insects to disappear. This is an ecological disaster that is taking place out there.  The European Union must give answers and, unfortunately, it does not. That is why we do not need to talk about the little things, about precision farming; this is not a solution. This is basically a bit better technique. We really need to think about how we can get out of this pesticide trap in agriculture – for the benefit of the environment, for consumers, but also for the benefit of farmers.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Mr President, Commissioner, in France many farmers have been poisoned by pesticides. Many now accuse the state of having turned a blind eye to this unprecedented health hazard. Until recently, President Macron claimed that chlordecon was not carcinogenic. A counter-truth that shocked France enormously. To denounce the irresponsible positions of our leaders is good. Opening your eyes to the root causes of this system is better. The European objectives are crazy, starting with Article 39 of the FUE Treaty on the CAP, which makes no mention of the quality of production or the protection of health. If a farmer commits suicide every two days in France, it is obviously because of the short-term productivity imposed by the European Union, with paltry incomes, while the agrochemical giants earn billions. Changing European treaties is not possible, you know; Get out, yes.

name: Giancarlo SCOTTÀ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while I share the rapporteur's position on the need, on the one hand, to reduce the impact of pesticides on the environment and human beings and, on the other, to succeed in actively improving national action plans, I believe it is essential not to create a direct link between the objectives set out in Directive 2009/128/EC and the current new model for the implementation of the CAP. In fact, tying the target on reducing the use of pesticides is not the model for implementing the CAP. Still very uncertain in its application, it could in fact further damage the current state of effectiveness of the management systems established by Directive 128 of 2009. While the Member States could benefit from a system that is at first sight more flexible in the application of the CAP, my fear is that the hypothetical radical change will greatly increase the level of bureaucracy, with the Member States having to decline the objectives of the CAP into a strategy of intervention, and then measure results. In my opinion, therefore, every effort should be made to increase the usefulness and effectiveness of national action plans.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card question. – Mr Lins criticises my colleague Martin Häusling, and says that copper sulphate is a dangerous chemical. It is nothing compared to the sorts of toxic pesticides we’re talking about here, which are causing a decimation of wildlife in our countryside – 58% of butterflies and moths lost in the past several decades. Does he not understand that if we do not protect these pollinating insects, there will be no food supply for us? We’re next on the extinction list.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has A reliable authorisation procedure and the sustainable use of plant protection products go hand in hand. Having launched the special report on the authorisation procedure at the beginning of the year, we are now taking another step towards more sustainable use. I grew up on a farm myself, I have plant protection products and therefore know how important it is to use it properly. I am convinced that the responsible use of plant protection products must be the benchmark. The magic word here is innovation. New, more efficient and low-risk substances and products will promote the sustainable use of plant protection products. Training is the second important key. Our farmers need to know what they are doing and how they are doing it. At the same time, private use should be restricted. I don't see it being used just so that the owner of the house next door has an English turf without much effort. I do not think that should be the case. And unlike Mr Häusling, I believe that digitisation and technology will benefit agriculture and will also lead to lower consumption. Unfortunately, Mr Häusling does not talk so much about the fact that organic farming also has problems, for example copper use in organic farming, and that we still have significantly lower yields in organic farming. It is therefore also a question of ensuring the food of the population. We must also keep this in mind. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Norbert LINS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much. That was not really a question, but rather a remark. I believe that we must always distinguish between what we apply, how we apply it. The principle always applies: the dose makes the poison. It is a huge difference whether we are talking about neonicotinoids or glyphosate, insecticides, herbicides or even fungicides. There is a clear distinction to be made. I have the impression that not all Members always have this in mind.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, on 25 January, the Heads of State and Government finally agreed on the establishment of harmonised risk indicators. And that's a very good thing. But at the same time, on 25 January, representatives of the 28 Member States were unable to adopt the guidelines proposed by the European Commission to protect pollinators from pesticide damage. So where's the truth? The truth is that since 2013, the Commission has proposed to Member States 25 times a text to better protect bees from pesticides. The truth is that 40% of insects have disappeared in the last decade and the bee mortality rate is as high as 80% in some parts of the European Union. Intensive agriculture is the main driver of this decline and, with it, the excessive use of pesticides. The truth is that heads of state continue to hide behind pseudo-European decisions that are in reality no more or less than their own. This is because progress on the sustainable use of pesticides is largely insufficient, particularly in terms of alternatives. It is that these same heads of state must put an end to their hypocrisy on the issue of pesticides and stop rolling out the red carpet to multinational agrochemicals companies. It is time, Commissioner, for the European Commission to bang its fist on the table, demand that Member States be held to account and, if necessary, launch infringement procedures. The health of Europe's 500 million citizens is at stake.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Integrated crop protection is essential for sustainable agriculture and needs to be better implemented in the Member States. The report sends out a good and correct signal for this. But something bothers me. The method has been established to use a single study to blame agriculture alone for the insect decline. This is not in line with the level of this House here. I would ask colleagues to finally stick to the facts. The fact is that in this study, which had 63 measuring points over the period of 27 years, only 37 were measured once and 20 twice.  The statistical relevance of the study is therefore very questionable. It is also a fact that agricultural practices are mentioned only as a possible cause among the others. This is worrying and more research is urgently needed.  I believe that this task of protecting species must be done by all in society as a whole. This starts with the individual: for example, with a flower meadow instead of a low-maintenance stone garden.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Mr President, the 2009 directive, which dealt with the use of pesticides compatible with sustainable development, had relevant and coherent objectives and encouraged the reduction of pesticides and alternatives. You, the Commission, were three years behind before making that assessment. And what's more, we realize that it's a real failure. What for? Because when you look at the figures from the European Environment Agency, they show a 10-20% increase in the demand for pesticides. At the same time , and contrary to what my colleagues say, we see that in terms of biodiversity, there is a decrease in invertebrates, insects, ecosystems and also birds. So what do we want? The destruction of life? The Commission - and the report that has been given is very clear on this - must encourage alternatives, put money and develop sustainable agriculture. And sustainable agriculture is pesticide-free, chemical-free. That is what is important, Commissioner, and not the other way around.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we believe that this report is already good, because on the one hand it protects human health and, on the other, it protects the environment from the risks associated with the use of pesticides. However, it could be improved, because we cannot talk about the sustainable use of pesticides if we do not consider the entire life cycle of the pesticides themselves, from their placing on the market to the definition of the highest levels of residues in food.  If we do not combat the practice of illegal and counterfeit pesticides, if we do not tackle the problem of imported products treated with pesticides, we cannot allow legislation to be tightened up at the same time towards our producers, towards our farmers, and at the same time allow products treated with banned substances to be imported into the European Union, because this has a negative impact on our internal market and promotes unfair competition that destroys an entire production sector.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, we can split the fashionable objection to pesticides into two categories.  The first is human health and safety. There are now a cohort of individuals who have spent at least 30 years handling the concentrated material and being exposed to the vapour. Their exposure is perhaps as high as 1 000 times that of the ordinary citizen. Some of the products used 20 years ago have been banned on toxicity grounds. These workers, who include myself, should have all died long ago if the scare tactics of the green lobby are to be believed.  The second is environmental impact. It is quite true that overuse and misuse of pesticides will harm wildlife and pollute watercourses. Their use has, however, allowed world food production to keep pace with world demand, which organic farming methods could not hope to have done.  Nevertheless, the industry is not complacent about the situation and a big effort has been made to reduce dependency on pesticides by using modern plant-breeding methods to create varieties that require substantially less pesticide use. The reaction of the European green lobby to this successful technology is to ban it. You cannot have it both ways.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of pesticides is a regular issue in the plenary session. Once again, some are trying to oppose agriculture and the environment, playing on the legitimate fear of our fellow citizens. On the occasion of this report, I would like to reiterate, as I have been doing since the beginning of my mandate, that farmers are the first environmentalists. Our citizens need to be reassured about the use of plant protection products. As such, I am convinced that science must be the indisputable basis for all our decisions. We need to take a positive approach to the place of agriculture in the ecological transition and its relationship to environmental issues. For agricultural practices that are increasingly respectful of the environment, it is essential to accompany professionals. They must be able to have solutions adapted to each type of agriculture, whether these solutions are phytopharmaceutical, natural or synthetic, or they use alternative methods. If this text respects this approach, I would like to remind all of you, Commissioner, that the CAP is above all an agricultural policy and not an environmental policy. However, the CAP must support farmers towards dual economic and environmental performance. The ecological transition will be successful, if it is economically viable, or it will not.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has This is not about agriculture. This is simply about us recognising that plant protection is necessary for the European production of food, food and feed. It is only a question of how this protection takes place. And I believe that this report shows very clearly that it is not the only way to protect plants by using pesticides excessively. There are possibilities: there are alternative agricultural possibilities, there are physical possibilities, there are less dangerous pesticides; there are so many alternatives that are being used far too little today – and we have seen this – in the Member States that are not monitored, that are not monitored; and even if they are controlled and monitored, when violations of them do not in fact result in sanctions – that is what we are talking about today. What we want is that Member States do not create large-scale derogations, that pesticides, neonicotinoids, which are actually already banned, continue to be used with some emergency exceptions. We want to produce for Europe, we want food that is safe, that is healthy, that does not damage the environment. We need to counteract species extinction. I believe that this report shows many possibilities. It is a good thing for a new European agriculture, and of course it also means that we need a new common agricultural policy. This cannot be discussed separately.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, a new global scientific review into the perilous condition of our insects reports that over 40% of insect species are threatened with extinction while our insect populations are declining by 2.5% per year. The review clearly links this drastic decline to the overuse of pesticides. That is why our report on the sustainable use of pesticides is more crucial now than ever. It is being spelt out by the world’s scientists — we need to begin an urgent transition away from the use of these highly toxic pesticides. The report urges EU countries to step up to the mark and take action on pesticides instead of making the empty promises of recent years. We need to reduce the amount of pesticides farmers use, banning the most toxic ones immediately. We need to use integrated pest management and dedicate more of our farmland to organic production. Insects are essential for the proper functioning of all ecosystems as food for other creatures, pollinators and recyclers of nutrients. Unless we take drastic action now, insects as a whole will go down the path of extinction within a few decades and we can be quite sure that we would follow on closely behind.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we have to meet the objectives of Directive 2009/128/EC on the sustainable use of pesticides. In addition, we citizens want low-risk plant protection products, that they do not leave residues in food and that they do not affect the environment. In any case, we need to be aware that in the European Union we have the most restrictive legislation for the use of pesticides. And that's why farmers have many restrictions when it comes to using pesticides and are at a disadvantage compared to their third-country competitors, who use pesticides banned here, and then import the food they produce with these pesticides. Nor can we forget the great risk posed by the new pests. And I mean, for example, the annoying Xylella of olive trees or the black spot of citrus fruits, which have come from outside, to speak only of more recent situations. Finally, I welcome this report, but we must not compromise the work that is already being done to develop a sustainable use of pesticides, nor forget their need in agriculture.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, I think we are relatively in agreement on this: chemistry must be handled carefully. Incidentally, this does not only apply to agriculture, but also to medicine, for example. We could also have a debate about how careless we are with medicines. But it is sometimes easier to point the finger at others. Many things have rightly already been said today. We need better access to integrated plant protection. We need low-risk pesticides, that is, low-risk pesticides. Incidentally, I myself have made a report on this in this House and have also made proposals on how to speed up this. There is relatively little that has happened in the Commission in this respect.  We need more research and development, including in public institutions. We need better application technology and we need more resistant plants. However, I would like to draw attention to one last point which has not yet been raised. In recent years, we have repeatedly introduced pests from abroad. I am thinking, for example, of the marbled tree bug or the cherry vinegar fly, which then produce tons and tons of chemicals because they have to be combated. If we were sometimes a little more careful at Europe's borders, we would also spare ourselves a great deal.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption by the European Parliament of the resolution of the Pest Special Committee was a significant step towards the effective implementation of the regulation on the placing on the market of plant protection products, which provides for the authorisation only of harmless pesticides, that is, which do not cause any harm to humans, animals and the environment.  However, a high level of protection cannot be achieved without the correct application of the Sustainable Pesticides Directive, which must be the tool to help farmers reduce their dependence on them by replacing them with sustainable alternatives and agro-ecological practices.  Particular attention should be paid to the protection of vulnerable groups, given the current lack of protection for residents in rural areas. Amendments Nos 24 and 44, tabled following a round table organised by myself with Mr Guteland, Mr Andrieu and Mr Poc, call on the Commission and the Member States to immediately ban the use of pesticides near homes, schools, playgrounds, nurseries and hospitals.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I think that the debate has highlighted the huge problem that exists with the use of pesticides. A problem which, of course, concerns the health of both humans and animals.  I, Mr Andriukaitis, would like to raise another point. We are talking about the use of pesticides within the European Union, but we have a lot of imports of agricultural products from Turkey, in which the use of pesticides is uncontrolled. There are banned pesticides used in the cultivation of agricultural products in Turkey and yet these products are now imported into the European Union itself. So what protection is there for consumers themselves? There is a Greekization of milk imported from Albania. We don't have phytosanitary control there either. We have a great import of meat illegally from Skopje and we do not have control over what kind of substances are used there either. So we need to see what happens to imports of products from third countries.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think we have heard enough here today. In fact, the sustainable use of pesticides is very much in our hearts, both to the citizens and the farmers. The report before us today is important. We are evaluating the 2009 directive here and it shows very clearly that the Member States need to step up a notch. Progress has been made in the field of training and adjustment of spraying equipment. But the action plans are very clearly lacking measurable and concrete objectives. Moreover, it also seems clear to me that we need to invest more in integrated plant protection techniques. That's what we need to put first. Last but not least, as Mr Huitema said, we also have to dare to look in our own bosom. If we want to convince farmers, we need to move more towards precision farming and ensure that resources are available for this. I also think that we should also focus on crop breeding and improving soil quality. In that respect, we need to create openings. And so we need to provide more resources. If we want to improve our environment, ladies and gentlemen, we must work towards supporting farmers. They produce our healthy food. Thank you very much.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the unsustainable use of pesticides is the cause of serious environmental problems in public health and food safety. This unsustainable use is inextuly inthe inextorised by the existing production models favoured by the Common Agricultural Policy and the Trade Policies of the European Union. Productivist models, of an exporting nature, that leave food production, something with obvious strategic relevance in any society, in the hands of agribusiness. They are the same policies that have been, and continue to be, devastating for small and medium-sized agriculture and family farming, which are of crucial importance in the sustainable occupation of the territory and in the food sovereignty of states. Without a doubt, stricter procedures are needed to control the use of pesticides. Undoubtedly, the development of new products and processes that have fewer risks and less impacts on health and the environment is necessary. But it is also necessary to profoundly modify the current production models and the policies that enable them.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the role of pesticides in Europe's production is important because they help to tackle harmful organisms that affect plants and contribute to good plant health. However, some of them enter the aquifer, causing problems for ecosystems. Moreover, when pesticide residues remain on food, the health of people, those living in agricultural areas, consumers and even passers-by is at risk. Residues in feedingstuffs also pose a risk to animal health. It is also suspected that some pesticides are responsible for endocrinological disorders. All of this requires both nations and the European Union to cooperate and make efforts to rationally use pesticides. The use of pesticides should be restricted and not chemical, but biological methods selected. In addition, the European Union must protect consumers from pesticides imported from third countries.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, feeding a global population of more than seven billion people brings challenges to which the agri-food industry has responded with great effectiveness. However, we cannot let it be worth everything in the production game. On the one hand, we are restricting or reducing biodiversity and agrodiversity with the use of high toxicpesticides and with an unknown impact on human health. On the other hand, we continue to approve genetically modified organisms that are resistant to the pesticides we select for commercial convenience. Let us not be surprised, therefore, that there is a low availability of low-risk plant protection products, including organic products, and these are only thirteen out of a total of five hundred substances available on the market. The reality is that insufficient implementation of the Directive and discussions of approval by Member States create unequal conditions of competition in Europe. There is an impediment to the full implementation in the market of sustainable alternatives with a consequent reduction in attractiveness for farmers who obviously prefer the most profitable options in the short term.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, of course, we are debating a sensitive issue today and we need to be rational, in addition to sensitivity. It is very clear: we all want to protect people's health. At the same time, let us think and make a scenario: if we destroy farmers in the European Union, we will obviously import, as colleagues have said, products and we will never have a customs union that can control products that come in piece by piece and that are more dangerous than those produced in the European Union. Of course, as the Commissioner said, it is very important for the Member States to review their measures, but, Commissioner, I believe that we must have harmonised these measures and we must also have harmonised control because, within the internal market, of course the products are circulating and for nothing a Member State is very rigorous, if in other Member States it is not verified , as you said - products must be checked from the point of view of toxicology. I believe very much that we need investment in agriculture, we need research and innovation so that these used products do not attack people's health.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I am explaining here my approach, which is clearly on the side of protecting citizens' health, but we also need to think about producers of agricultural production for which the use of pesticides is still simply a necessity. Nevertheless, the pressure to reduce the use of pesticides and to ban certain pesticides containing carcinogenic substances makes sense, and this has also been demonstrated by a report by the European Food Safety Authority, which says that 96% of the samples tested complied with the permitted limits and even half of the samples did not contain any quantifiable residues. I therefore believe that it is clear that this pressure makes sense and makes sense to limit the use of the most dangerous pesticides, but there is a need to appeal for restrictions on imports of food that are being treated with pesticides and a ban on pesticide imports.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
