text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the use of pesticides plays a very important role in Europe's agricultural production by maintaining plant health and preventing their destruction due to disease and infestation. However, pesticides administered to crops may enter soil and surface waters by dissolution and leakage and enter groundwater at the risk of adversely affecting non-target species in both terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.  Commissioner, I cannot agree with the rapporteur's proposal not to grant derogations for the use of neonicotinoids. I think it is essential to take into account the specificity of agriculture in each Member State. Perhaps what is true in Germany is not the case in Bulgaria with regard to this specificity of agriculture and even pests.  Integrated pest management in the European agricultural sector aims to maintain the use of pesticides and forms of intervention at levels that are economically and environmentally justified and that reduce or minimise risks to human health and the environment, giving priority to sustainable biological methods, as well as physical and chemical methods for crop protection and pest deterrence.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Madam President! I am pleased that we in the European Parliament are very concerned with the use of pesticides. We have adopted the committee's special report, we are today ing the report on the sustainable use of pesticides.  As in human medicine, there is a clear objective here: as few pesticides as possible, as few as possible, which can harm health, the environment or even animals. And that is why I think that exactly what we are doing in the European Union to support integrated production is supported by cross-compliance, by screening sprinklers, on the other hand, by training those who use it, and also by focusing on organic farming.  There will certainly be some use of pesticides in agriculture for some time to come, so it is right that we also support methods of fine-veiled agriculture, where we can use clear sensory force to establish the state of diseases, the state of pests, the environmental impact, with the pursant application, and, as I have already said, let us continue to support, in future agricultural policy, measures that lead agriculture towards integrated production and into the organic production framework.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, once again I listened carefully to the honourable Members and I heard a lot of reasonable approaches. The main thing, as we all know, is that we need to strengthen our efforts in the sustainable use of pesticides and in the improvement of the Directive. Let me react to some specific points. I fully agree with Karl-Heinz Florenz when he raises questions about training. Especially now, as we see a lot of new agro—techniques, we need to encourage Member States to pay more attention to training needs when farmers are using new techniques and facing new issues with pesticides. Regarding derogations, derogation should mean derogation, and should not be the rule. The Commission is looking at this very carefully and we are now introducing strong measures, asking Member States for justifications and asking them to see what they can do and how we can regulate. As you know, we have permanent conversations with some Member States about derogations. But, of course, derogation is enshrined in law, so we need to pay greater attention to that. Some speakers mentioned the possibility of promoting more low—risk pesticides. As you know, we now have to hand a lot of improvements, and rules and procedures allowing the quickest possible authorisation of low-risk pesticides. Some speakers mentioned once again the role of organic farming and the message that organic farming is farming without chemicals. No: we know very well that in organic farming too people use certain chemicals. Copper sulphate is a very difficult question. You know that the carcinogenicity of copper sulphate is a big challenge and we need to address those issues. So do not mislead people. We know very well that different types of farming are using different methods, including chemicals. So do not simply create confrontation between conventional farming and organic farming. Once again, please tell the truth to society. From a regulatory point of view, we know what that is. We know who is who, and how different tools are used in different types of farming. Mr Andrieu rightly mentioned the Bee Guidance Document. We did not achieve a qualified majority on this at Standing Committee level because Member States are not capable of voting in favour. It’s now up to Parliament and the Council to conclude the so—called first reading on the comitology rules. We have proposed introducing transparency in risk management, changing the situation, with regard to the comitology rules, so as to have data publicly available to vote on. However, two years for the first-reading stage is not progress! May I encourage you once again to draw attention to this, because I am very happy that yesterday we concluded the General Food Law trilogue. I would like to thank Ms Ayuso for doing a very difficult job. We now have more transparency in the assessment of pesticides, and this is a big achievement for all of us.  I have outlined to you the comprehensive regulatory system for plant protection products in Europe and the Commission’s efforts to ensure their sustainable use. I also acknowledge that there is no perfect system. Ms D’Ornano mentioned cases of suicide in France. I was there, I met people and I discussed this with the French authorities. They should assess the situation in a very careful manner because it’s a complex one. Some use the word ‘poison’ when speaking about pesticides. I’m sorry, but sometimes, in some quantities, for some people, medicine is poison. So I would say, please, use the correct words and do not simply create rumours about pesticides.  The Commission is currently evaluating the implementation of the regulation that concerns the authorisation of plant protection products and the setting of maximum residue levels. It will also launch an evaluation of the Sustainable Use Directive in 2020 to determine if this legislation is fit for purpose. I call on the Member States to set ambitious targets, with clear timetables, in their revised national action plans. They must demonstrate their commitment to citizens to reduce the risk and impact of the use of pesticides on human health and the environment. Let me close by thanking the honourable Members for their interest in and support on this important issue. I look forward to the adoption of this important report by Parliament. Once again, I thank Jytte Guteland and the shadow rapporteurs for their very good, collaborative work and for this comprehensive report. We will take careful note of the recommendations, and together we will continue on the road towards more sustainable agriculture in Europe in order to protect our citizens’ health, the environment, consumers and sustainable agriculture.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Rapporteur supplimentari. – Smajna numru ta' punti validi imma ovvjament kif mistenni dan huwa dibattitu pjuttost kontroversjali għaliex l-użu tal-pestiikeida jiena nemmen li għandu rwol importanti fil-produzzjoni agrikola Ewropea. Għaliex wara kollox jgħina biex inżommu b'saħħithom il-pjanti anki l-frott għal tul akbar ta' żmien u jwaqqjonaf il-qerda u d-distruzzjoni ta' dawn il-pjanti u l-frott minħabba mard jew infestazzjonit liista jista' jkun hemm.  Imma, hawnhekk nerġa' ninsisti, l-użu mhux sostenibbli tal-pestiikeida, kif smajna anki llum, jista' jwassal għal telf tal-bijodiversità, jista' jikkontamina u jaffettwa l-ħamrija, jista' jikkontamina u jafettwa l-ilma u jista' jidħol anki fl-without ta' taħt l-art - il-ground tag waterħna. Għalhekk li hemm it-tħassib li pesti大ida jista' jwassal għal riskju serju għas-saħħa tal-bniedem. Għaliex jista' wkoll jispi大大a fl-ikel tagħna u fil-food chain tagħna. U din hija r-raġuni għaliex ħat ightt jitqanqal proprju meta jkollok persuni li huma esposti għal pesti大ida li jista' jkollhom dawk li huma magħrufa bħala endocrine disrupting properties.  Dan il-Parlament huwa mħasseb minħabba l-implimentazzjoni dgħajfa ta' din id-Direttiva f'numru ta' Stati Membri. Wara kollox id-dipendenza tal-pesti大ida u fuq il-pestiikeida hija kompletament inkompatibbli ma' agrikoltura sostenibbli. U aħna nemmnu li l-Unjoni Ewropea trid timbotta għal agrikoltura aktar sostenibbli li tippromwovi l-prevenzjoni, li tippromwovi methododi li mhumiex kimiikei, control bijoloġiikei u anki prodotti b'riskju baxx.  U biex intemm - ir-rapport li ddiskutejna llum, fl-opinjoni tiegħi, jibgħat messaġġ konkret u progressiv li nista' nagħmlu fil-qosor f'erba' punti ewlenin. L-ewwel punt: l-Istati Membri jridu jħaffu u jtejbu l-implimentazzjoni tal-integrated pest management practices tagħhom u jridu jippromwovu alternattvi mhux kimi大i u anki prodotti li jipproteġu l-pjanti li gandhomhom riskju baxx. It-tieni: il-pesti大idi f'erjas pubbli大i jridu jispi大大aw għaliex dawn jinkludu wkoll parks u postijiet fejn ikun hemm it-tfal tagħna u group vulnerabbli oħra bħal nisa tqal. It-tielet punt: id-data collection fuq l-użu tal-pestiikeida u anki dak li jifdal mill-pestiida fl-ambjent irid jitjieb. U fl-aħħar nett għandna bżonn miżuri aktar b'saħħithom li jistgħu jgħinu biex nippromwovu aktar l-organic farming. Għalhekk inħeġġeġ lil kulħadd, inħeġġeġ flower-group politi大i kollha biex permezz tal-vot tagħna llum nagħtu sinjal b'saħħtu favur dan ir-rapport.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, February 12, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. – Biodiversity is under threat all over the world! The rate of species extinction is extremely high, 100 to 1,000 times higher than the natural one. The decline in biodiversity, along with climate change, is the most serious threat to the environment, on which the economy and society depend!  I call on the Member States to implement this directive without any delay. A quarter of animal species face the risk of extinction. I welcome the work done by the rapporteur and support the directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the sustainable use of pesticides. Integrated pest management emphasizes the growth of healthy crops, using methods that affect agroecosystems as little as possible and encourage the most natural methods of combating harmful agents, and is one of the priorities of this report, which deserves all our attention and inclination!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Ivo Belet, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the implementation of the Directive on Cross-Border Health Care (2018/2108 (INI)) (A8-0046/2019).

name: Ivo BELET
text: Rapporteur. – Thank you, Chairman. A very good morning to all of you, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner. If there is one area where Europe can prove its added value, it is the area of health care. It is often more obvious and cheaper for patients, especially in border regions, to get medical help where she is closest, namely in a hospital just across the border. This applies a fortiori to patients with chronic or rare diseases who can be helped more efficiently in another European country because they need specific treatment. Today, patients are all too often faced with all kinds of annoying obstacles when choosing treatment abroad. Often there is administrative nuisance in the way. It is unclear when they can be reimbursed for the treatment they receive abroad, and it is unclear what costs they will have to pay. We are 2019 and it is high time we stopped tolerating these unacceptable obstacles and obstacles for patients. The Cross-Border Health Directive, which we are talking about here, dates back to 2011. That was over eight years ago. This directive was certainly a step in the right direction, but implementation in the field leaves a lot to be desired. We can't accept that. The report we have written on implementation contains a number of concrete proposals. We have consulted very well with the Commission services on how to continue to do this and how we can improve implementation. The first assignment is: information to the patients. Most patients don't really know what their rights are and they don't know where to get information, despite the fact that each country has at least one national information point. That is why we propose to set up a one-stop shop in each country where patients can go for all the information in the areas of health care, health insurance, reimbursement, administrative conditions, etc. Patients are entitled to clear and clear information, including cross-border care. Today, after all, they are faced with a complex administrative tangle. And that could be much better. Hence the explicit demand that the Commission continue to monitor the application of this Directive every year and also maintain close contact with the European Parliament and national authorities. Secondly, for patients with a rare or chronic disease, the best and most specialised help may be abroad. That is why we want to strengthen the existing European reference networks (ERN's). And we want to combine european efforts and the efforts of all Member States to set up specialised centres in the existing health institutions where expertise on rare diseases is gathered so that patients with rare diseases can go there. Furthermore, digitisation of health care is an excellent tool for taking care of patients even better. The initiative launched by the European Commission last week to further strengthen the digital network of cross-border healthcare is a great initiative. We fully support that. We hope it will be rolled out as soon as possible. One more point, finally. We very much want a robust and independent health programme to be included in the multiannual programme, which is not the case today. Our citizens deserve the best health care, and it can sometimes be found on the other side of the border, with the neighbours. Thank you very much.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, Commissioner, as rapporteur for the opinion on this report, I certainly support the report and say that it is very important to see how this directive on cross-border healthcare applies in the Member States.  Let us not forget that 40% of the citizens of the European Union are in cross-border areas. Let us not forget that there is a Eurobarometer study showing that less than 20% of European citizens know these rights. That is why, in the opinion of the IMCO Committee, we supported further measures to inform citizens, because it is very important to know their rights. It is also very important to have adequate funding and to maintain funding, as was the case in the third health package. Last but not least, I could say that what has been done is very important: the European health card, eHealth, it is very important. Also important are national information points for patients and, ultimately, the mobility of cross-border patients must be a real fact and not a theoretical one. That is why, Commissioner, I support the report and I hope that the situation will be improved in all the Member States because people's lives and health are very important.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the rapporteur, Mr Belet, for his very important report on the implementation of the Cross-border Healthcare Directive. You know I am a medical doctor and for me it is very close to my heart.  Each year, millions of Europeans travel to other EU countries, safe in the knowledge that they can access healthcare if necessary. At the same time, other citizens are planning treatment in different Member States. Why? Because EU law guarantees the right to access healthcare across borders and the right to reimbursement in their home country. So it is safe to say that cross-border healthcare is an issue of high importance for European citizens.  In this context, I welcome Parliament’s draft report and motion for a resolution on the implementation of a Cross-border Healthcare Directive. Let me stress that we fully agree with you. Action is necessary to improve the implementation of the Directive. In fact, your draft report is very much in line with the conclusions of the Commission’s own report on the Directive’s implementation, which we published last September, as you know.  I want to take a few moments to touch on what we are doing to improve implementation. The Commission has examined the transposition of the Directive into national law. We took swift action when elements were missing and launched 26 infringement proceedings on account of late or incomplete transposition. The first phase is now complete and all infringements relating to this phase have been closed.  The Commission has now moved to an in-depth assessment of compliance, carefully examining measures put in place in each Member State. This approach is delivering results. Many Member States have already changed their legislation for the benefit of patients. But I want to assure you that the Commission will continue its intensive dialogue with Member States to achieve the best possible transposition of the Directive.  A directive allows Member States room for manoeuvre when it comes to transposition. Unfortunately, we have evidence of discrimination against EU citizens seeking treatment in another European Union country. Patients often face very complex administrative procedures ahead of planned treatment abroad. We are taking action to put an end to any unjustified practices. On 23 January, the Commission launched infringement proceedings against two Member States regarding national rules on reimbursement tariffs. In light of this, I welcome the draft report’s focus on the reimbursement schemes. We will now discuss with Member States ways to simplify procedures for EU patients in line with the Directive.  The Commission will also continue to address the lack of awareness when it comes to citizens’ rights. We also fully agree with the Committee’s recommendation that the Member States provide sufficient funding for their national contact points. I can assure the honourable Members that the Commission will continue to support the national contact points. A toolbox to support the national contact points’ work will also be made public in the near future. Our goal here is to improve national contact points’ effectiveness so that the information provided will deliver practical benefits to patients. Of course, the Directive also encourages cross-border healthcare cooperation between Member States, especially in the border regions. In this context, the Commission provides support for a European network of regional and local health authorities through its health policy platform. Here I want to highlight two important points made by your report. Firstly, on the establishment of 24 European reference networks, which represent a major achievement in the field of healthcare cooperation on rare diseases. But these networks are also facing challenges involving their integration into national healthcare systems. I am thankful for your call on Member States to support healthcare providers that are European reference network members.  Secondly, I want to echo your position on digital solutions. In fact, only last week the Commission adopted a recommendation on a European electronic health record exchange format. The recommendation aims to make it possible for people to safely access their health records across borders.  I am very pleased to see that Finland and Estonia have recently begun to exchange e-prescriptions thanks to the European Union’s work. This is a significant step forward and will increase accessibility to services for patients. Honourable Members, your draft report makes an important contribution to the discussion on cross-border healthcare. I look forward to your final report and I assure you that the Commission will examine each recommendation very carefully. Our convergence on this issue means that we can move forward together, deliberately. Ultimately, this cooperation will benefit citizens and health systems across the European Union.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank and congratulate colleague Ivo Belet on his report. This legislative framework, which allows patients to benefit, under certain conditions, from reimbursement of medical services in any Member State, is one of the very practical and very important achievements of the European Union for the benefit of patients. I tabled amendments and supported this directive, as an MEP, in 2010-2011, and then I had the chance to implement this directive in my country, Romania, as President of the National Health Insurance House in 2013-2014. Contrary to the objectives of the Directive, however, some Member States have adopted administrative measures that substantially block cross-border healthcare, such as reimbursement limitations or pre-authorisation requirements, some unduly complicated. Furthermore, a large number of European patients are not aware of the rights conferred on them by this directive. As health is a fundamental right in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, I call on the European Commission to ensure that the Member States correctly implement this directive.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ivo Belet, for the very good cooperation. I believe that we all agree on the objective of this dossier: the best interests of European patients are paramount, and we want people to be able to be treated across borders. Unfortunately, the review of the current implementation has shown that cross-border supply is still not working properly. With the legislation on cross-border medical care, we really wanted to ensure that patients have access to high-quality and safe cross-border medical care and that the costs of treatment are then simply reimbursed. It is therefore disturbing, and it cannot be explained to any citizen or citizen, that 26 out of 28 Member States were so slow in implementing it that the European Commission had to open infringement proceedings. According to The Eurobarometer of May 2015, more than 20% of citizens did not even know that they had the opportunity to be treated across borders. So, two years after the directive came into force, almost no one knew his rights. Knowing his rights, however, is the basic prerequisite for being able to use them. In the area of health, the need for information is complex and, frankly, the current level is not satisfactory. National contact points in particular play a very important role here. These must be fully and, above all, comprehensible to everyone. A wide-ranging information campaign on the national contact points is therefore necessary for citizens. Obtaining accurate information is a prerequisite for the exercise of his rights. That is why we are right to call for this in the report. We also need more transparency and clarity for service providers in the interests of consumer protection. It is necessary to break down transparently which health services are offered and also reimbursed. The Commission's report has also shown that there is still considerable room for improvement in the reimbursement procedures. Let me make one final point: for my group, it is important that we also include vaccinations in the scope. The anti-vaccination is becoming more and more, and diseases that could actually be eradicated are coming back. This is a danger that we should no longer accept. That is why we should also supplement the report in this area.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Cross-border healthcare could be a great opportunity for patients in situations of problems in the Member States, especially as, according to the Treaty, a high level of protection of human health is ensured. However, the organisation, financing and provision of healthcare is the responsibility of the Member States, which means that cross-border care opportunities are mainly used by patients from the border regions of the 'old' Union or sick people from rich countries travelling to poorer countries where the cost of treatment is lower, while central European countries fear excessive budget capacity or patients do not have money for expensive foreign treatment.  Of course, patients must be informed about the possibilities and rights of a regulation or directive through information points. However, cross-border care could be a great opportunity for patients with rare diseases, affecting around 6% of all citizens, where a relatively small number of patients suffer from each of these diseases. Cross-border cooperation should play a role in the collection of information to combat rare diseases, the possible establishment of specialised reference centres and the search for new medicines, as current prices prevent treatment. Moreover, of course, cross-border care can play a huge role in cases of pandemies, although I would leave the problem of vaccination to the Member States.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I want to thank the rapporteur and the other shadow rapporteurs for their excellent work on this file. European cross-border healthcare is becoming much more important due to the free movement of Europeans. That is good. But that’s why we also have the obligation to improve it and make it function properly when it doesn’t. One of the major areas in which we have to improve is the transparency of health care providers and how they function. If I didn’t know whether I would be reimbursed or what type of care I had a right to, I would never dare go to a hospital in another country. Furthermore, the transparency mechanism and the right to compensation and reimbursement and the complaint mechanism has to be improved. People will never go to a hospital in other countries if they don’t know how well it functions. The Healthcare Directive can be a good European answer to the questions posed by globalisation, but it has to be improved if we want it to be a solution that works in reality.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, let me also thank my colleague Belet for, in my opinion, great news. For certain groups of patients, e.g. those with rare diseases, cross-border healthcare is simply the most appropriate and accessible care. I believe that the importance of sharing knowledge and resources needs to be constantly emphasised, particularly in the context of the treatment of rare diseases. Today, this issue is no longer easily solvable only at national level, but requires the involvement of material and mental resources across the EU. There is also a need for greater efforts in the area of mutual recognition of prescriptions from other Member States, reduction of administration and all artificial barriers to the reimbursement of cross-border care, greater use and use of the Insured Person's European Card and, last but not least, an increase in low patient awareness of the possibilities of using such care.  What I also welcome about the report is the call for greater unification of vaccination obligations across the EU. I believe that this is an extremely important step at a time when some regions are increasingly being destroyed by epidemics of diseases that we mistakenly thought were already eradicated. Last but not least, we must also address the negative externalities of cross-border care. I am talking again about the so-called parallel re-export of medicines. For several years, we have been asking both the Commission and the Member States to ban this practice, which benefits the health systems of less developed Member States. And nothing happens, patients in some countries lack medicines, others buy them cheaply.

name: Tilly METZ
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, thank you Mr Belet for your excellent work. Only 17% of Europeans are informed of their rights in cross-border health care. If we are to be serious about the implementation of cross-border health care, we must strengthen national contact points. Being able to act together, in cross-border cooperation, makes us stronger, for example, when it comes to research or treatment of rare diseases. That is why we are fighting to strengthen The European reference networks and to create specialist centres for the 30 million citizens living with rare diseases in the European Union. Yes, we also need control and data on the care and actions performed and billed to avoid all kinds of abuse. But one thing is certain: the patient must be at the centre of our concerns and he must be able to enjoy an inclusive environment, where he is informed of his rights and how he can benefit from them. In the European Union, in which I believe, everyone - including the homeless and undocumented - has the right to quality and affordable health care.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, cross-border mobility, in other words the possibility for regular European citizens to move more or less extended between Member States, when it is voluntary and voluntary, and not forced by economic stagnation and unemployment, must be done in the easiest way possible. This is why the analysis of the application of the 2011 Directive on Continuity of Care in Europe is important. While care and reimbursement are to remain a national matter, cooperation between states at all levels, including caregivers, is necessary to provide safe and equal quality care in all countries. The Europe of social protection and health has been around for two hundred years, and it must be strengthened. However, this should not be the occasion of uncontrolled immigration and, especially through online care and under the misguided and anxious pretext of rare diseases or vaccination, establish an additional computerized database or constraint. We will therefore exercise total vigilance to give full meaning to this directive and to combat its excesses.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Sur President, naħseb li wieħed mill-benefi大大大ji ewlenin ta' Unjoni Ewropea magħquda huwa d-dritt għall-aħ大大ess għall-kurat-saħa fi kwalunkwe pajjiż tal-Unjoni Ewropea liħittadini Ewropej għandhom, u dritt li jingħataw il-flus lura għal dik il-kura li jkunu ingħataw barra minn pajjiżhom. Imma dan id-dritt isir aktar importanti meta qegħdin ngħixu fi żmien ta' bidla kontinwa, meta qegħdin ngħixu fi żmien ta' żvilupp rapidu fejn inti gandeħk is-sistemi tas-saħħa li qħdin jiġu koni flimkien. Nemmen li hija r-responsabilità tagħna li na大大ħertaw li jkun hemm amm aħess ugwali għal kulħadd għal sistemi ta' kura tas-saħħa għa-ħaħiħi大ħdini kollha, qegħdin fejn qegħdin. Però biex dan verament jiġri rridu nkunu nkunu 大erti li għandna l-framework ġust f'postu. Irridu niffa大ilitaw kooperazzjoni akbar f'numru ta' erjas differenti li huma relatati mal-mediikeina u anki mal-kura tas-saħħa. U hawnhekk insemmi pereżempju l-ehealth u anki trattament għal mard rari. Però din mhijiex kwistjoni ta' Stat Membru wieħed jew ieħor imma hija kwistjoni li hija komuni għall-Istati Membri kollha, bl-Ingliż ngħidu "across boarder matter" fejn allura l-azzjoni tal-Unjoni Ewropea għandha painrż mijud. name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Madam President! I would like to thank my colleague Iu Beth for an excellently prepared report. It is an important file that our citizens understand and use, it is a good example of what, in practice, a Europe that is close to the people means. In order to adopt the directive, we needed clear judgments of the European Court of Justice, which confirmed that, under European rules, patients have the right to healthcare in other Member States and to reimbursement of the costs. We read and hear about cases where patients do not have access to treatment available in another country because of problems with insurance companies, or cases where treatment occurs, and then the home insurer refuses to reimburse the costs. Patients with rare forms of cancer mentioned in the report, among others, are well aware of such experiences, but they are not the only ones. We do not need a revision of the directive first, first of all we need its consistent implementation. A Europe without borders will live when we also have health care without borders. That's why health first.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, cross-border health care is, in any case, one of the basic rights of the citizens of the European Union. In the past, there were patients who were able to go to another European Union state for surgery when this care could not be provided in their country. This was the general trend, but — of course — there was a huge problem as to how patients would get back the amounts they had paid. Now the situation has changed and patients are going to countries where care itself is cheaper. I think the directive should be implemented.  However, I would like to ask you, Commissioner, Mr Andriukaitis, about the issue of the influenza epidemic in Greece. We have over 39 dead. There is a huge influenza epidemic and I would like to ask if the Greek government has been in contact with the competent authorities of the European Union, if it has asked you for help and what will happen to the lack of vaccines to deal with influenza. We want an answer to this question because it concerns the Greek population.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, cross-border healthcare services will be increasingly important in the future, both for patient well-being and for the limited resources available. In order to target the best skills for the very patients who need it, and the resources available to the very patients who need them, we need this flexibility, and the further health care develops, the more. I therefore thank the rapporteur and the Commission for their active efforts. I find it downright shameful that so many Member States have either failed to transpose the directive, inform their citizens, or have made it completely wrong, for example in terms of compensation. This is a flight of responsibility for the well-being of citizens and the rational use of resources, a small policy that we cannot accept. It is therefore necessary to take really swift, effective measures to sue the Member States in this matter if necessary.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, the implementation report shows that there has been a lot of progress in cross-border healthcare services. Within Europe, we can control its legacy. In cases of certain rare diseases, cross-border care is most appropriate and therefore should be promoted, with no bureaucracy against health rights. Therefore the international contact point is a vital item to inform citizens about their rights to cross-border health services under the directive. The Commission should start an information campaign to inform citizens about the existence of the national contact points.  These should also be improved with more relevant information. The Commission should develop a template for the national contact points of the kinds of information that are most useful to our citizens who want to avail of cross-border healthcare.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Madam President, to talk about cross-border health is to talk about free movement; after all, the fundamental principles of the European Union. The Eurobarometer clearly sets out how health is one of the main values for European citizenship. But we are also aware that health competences are divided, as well as the special connotations and sensitivity of the issue of health care. We have a directive, in my view, particularly ambitious; positive but, as I say, ambitious, the implementation of which has been uneven within the European Union by the Member States. I would like to begin by adding that, for the success of this directive, we first need a prior premise, which is a clear commitment on the part of the Member States to their public health systems, in order to strengthen them as guarantors of social cohesion. This Directive may never replace that necessary commitment of the Member States to their public health system. That is why I also believe that we should start implementing it step by step, objective by objective, and start with the European Health Insurance Card. We cannot detach cross-border health from harmonisation of this European Health Insurance Card, in order to avoid the discrimination that it entails today, and it should be made possible under the principle of universality, in which students, the unemployed, self-employed workers, all people, all European citizenship would have to be made possible. Secondly, the recipe, the recognition of the recipe. Thirdly, as the Directive points out and as one of the next objectives to be developed by the Commission with regard to digital health, I believe that Member States must be involved from the outset. I believe that public health systems are the only and best guarantors of data custody, patient privacy and equity in health systems. Therefore, in this great project which is beginning to be drawn by the European Commission, I would ask you to make the Member States particularly involved and protagonists of the public institutions.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has If someone has a birthday, or the New Year, what do we want people to do? Above all, we want health. That is why health should be more at the heart of policy – including in EU policy, as far as we are responsible. But these are a lot of points where we are responsible. This is a key issue for the PPE-DE. At the suggestion of our chairman, Manfred Weber, we recently prepared a paper on the fight against cancer. This also has very personal backgrounds, that this is so important to us. On the one hand, we write in this paper that we want to do everything in our power to ensure that no one in Europe will have to die of this terrible disease in 20 years' time. We have listed many points. I would also like to thank the Commission for making the issue of childhood cancer a mission, for example, in the Horizon Europe research framework programme.  But we also say that we want to better implement the directive on patients' rights. I would therefore like to thank Ivo Belet, who has drawn up this report. I hope that we will receive a very large vote in plenary for this report. The Member States must stop thinking in the short term, but the patient must be at the heart of the implementation of this directive. For this, the report is the right wake-up call to the Member States in the interests of patients.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Ivo Belet first of all for her excellent work.  Europe is made up of solidarity and cooperation. Unfortunately, health caught in the principle of subsidiarity is witness to the greatest asymmetries within the European Union. The hope of this directive on cross-border healthcare does not seem to have reached the fullest of its intention. Patients do not know it exists, health professionals do not know or use it and payers raise the greatest bureaucratic and administrative barriers. But we can't throw this directive on the shelf of the booklets of intentions. You have to get the directive up and running. It is crucial for patients and for Member States, especially for the people who gain the most from the European scale, who are citizens with rare diseases, including some of the cancer diseases. Cooperation through European reference networks must be encouraged to attract knowledge and must evolve in order to become genuine specialised centres within the Union. I would also like to mention the importance of e-health which may be the necessary bridge to bring together the distant margins of state bureaucracies, but there is one thing that eSaúde cannot do for us and which is to unite us in the different policies with regard to neonatal screening and vaccination programmes. This is another step that we still need to take for a fairer Europe.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Dear! I am pleased that the European Parliament has taken up the subject of implementing the directive on cross-border healthcare. I agree with the rapporteur that, unfortunately, even though it will soon be eight years since its adoption, public awareness of the possibility of reimbursement of medical expenses in the institutions of a neighbouring country is extremely low. This is a priority on which the EU institutions should work with Member States. I therefore support the call to increase the visibility and accessibility of national contact points, which are the main institutions providing information in this area. In addition, any remaining legal and administrative barriers identified in the report resulting from the poor transposition of the Directive should be removed so that patients can enjoy their rights without hindrance. Receiving reimbursement of medical expenses should be a standard, simple and – just as importantly – quick procedure.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I think we are discussing a very important point here today, namely cross-border health care. I would therefore like to thank my Limburg colleague, Ivo Belet, for his report. We all know that many citizens do not know their rights. A Eurobarometer survey from 2015 shows that 20% of European citizens do not actually know their rights. That is why I think we need to inform citizens about the rights they have to find the best health care. Because when you're sick, you only have one concern: get better. Europe must help its citizens in this area. Moreover, we all know that the administrative burden and the regulatory burden are far too great if we use health care elsewhere. So I would say: make that recommendation work and ensure a 'one-stop shop' as it is called here, one point of information per Member State, so that citizens get the right information quickly and correctly. Make it work. Make Europe efficient.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, there is no doubt that health is the most valuable commodity for man and must be protected in every way. At the same time, the development of medical science enables many patients to obtain healthcare, not only in their own country, but also in other Member States of the European Union, especially in neighbouring countries. States must therefore cooperate with each other in order to facilitate the smooth mobility of patients. A step in this direction is to deal with various bureaucratic methods, to simplify certain administrative measures, to fix compensation, as well as to try to tackle fraud, epidemics and, above all, the health care of illegal immigrants, which often accumulate, as is the case in Greece, in large numbers at the border with neighbouring countries.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I live in the border area of Eastern Belgium. This means that many people from Belgium go to the doctor in Germany naturally and quite simply, or were, and are no longer so. There was an agreement in this border area called IZOM. There, the Belgian patient was able to go to the German specialist without any formalities. This was then abolished in Belgium. What I would like to testify to is that the patient does not care what formalities have to be carried out between health insurance companies afterwards. The patient wants to be healthy, he wants to have the best doctor there is for himself, preferably in his language. That is what we need to achieve. We talk far too much between states about what is not possible, but we need to talk much more about what is possible. These patient zones, as we have had, are a wonderful example of how to do it. I would ask the European Commission to encourage this, and if it does not work, it should even be obliged. Because the patient wants to be healthy, and that's possible if you organize it that way.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, they say that health is wealth, and that is absolutely correct, because all the wealth in the world is no use to you if you haven’t got your health. It’s very important, in a modern society with a growing economy, that we do everything to ensure that our citizens can access healthcare as easily as possible, because it’s one thing to be accessing services when you are healthy, but when you’re sick, then any added bureaucracy makes it much more difficult. That’s why the trans-European Cross-Border Healthcare Directive is so important. I think people have asked for more information especially in relation to campaigns. I think that’s vitally important in reducing red tape, because a lot of access is available, a lot of help is available, but often it’s difficult for citizens to access it, so that has to be a primary aim. My colleague Mr Liese spoke about the good work that has been done in combating cancer. I am involved in that group here in the European Parliament, and at lunchtime I will be attending an event organised by the European Advocates for Epilepsy. So a lot is happening but we need to get it through to the citizens. Lastly, congratulations to the rapporteur, my great friend and a wonderful MEP, Ivo Belet.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am happy to have listened to the debate and I thank all the speakers for their valuable contributions. Let me repeat once again: now is a good time for all of us to have an awareness-raising campaign in the European Union because the European Parliament elections are ahead of us. Please, honourable Members, keep healthcare high on the agenda and please campaign on these issues, and I say that especially to those who are ready now to go and present their programmes to the public. Of course, I see a confrontation in terms of Member States’ understanding of what we call subsidiarity, and that is why we see such a low level of awareness. Mainly, if you ask Member States about healthcare and medical services, they will argue that these fall within national competences: ‘national competence’ has become a mantra. If you look just at health technology assessment, you will see, once again, resistance to doing more at European Union level in that area. Why? Because of a wrong understanding about subsidiarity. If you cannot offer people the chance of achieving the best possible healthcare, or a cure if they have some rare disease, then surely we should allow them to go across borders and achieve it in another country. How can we overcome the silo mentality? That is a question for all of us. It’s not just a matter of having templates and national contact points. It’s also about possibilities of changing the narrative, about understanding and about discussions with governments. I very much appreciate the fact that we share common goals when it comes to cross-border healthcare for European Union citizens. This convergence is crucial as we move forward and eliminate unjustified barriers to healthcare. The draft report outlines concrete measures around some of the directive’s major pillars in the areas of charging, reimbursement, access to and exchange of health data, administrative procedures and provision of information. There are many, many issues. Let me assure you that the Commission will carefully consider how to take this recommendation forward once the report has been adopted. I would like to stress once again that the Commission will take deliberate action wherever the spirit and letter of the directive is not upheld, and we strongly urge Member States to put in place measures to prevent discrimination among patients. In closing, I want to reiterate my thanks to the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) for its work on this issue. In particular, I want to recognise the contribution made by the Environment Committee Chair, Ms Vălean, the Vice-Chairs, Mr Jávor and Ms Sârbu, and the rapporteur, Mr Belet, as well as the shadow rapporteurs. You have made an important contribution to this debate and that can have a practical impact on the accessibility and sustainability of our healthcare systems.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you very much for this debate. On the final remark that has been made by Mr Marias, I would like to add that there are proposals to take vaccination on board of this directive and that the ECR Group of Mr Marias is objecting to that, so it would be useful to mention that. Dear colleagues, Commissioner, thank you for the input. I am convinced that we have broad support for this report for the implementation of the directive in a good way. Commissioner, I appreciate very much that you have referred to the fact that you will raise your efforts with regard to the simplification of the procedures on the one hand and secondly, also to strengthen the NCPs; the contact points, which is also crucial in this regard. We will support your efforts and I hope that everyone has heard your message, that indeed it is the role of the MEPs in the up-coming months to put it and keep it high on the agenda, not just in the election campaign, but also afterwards. It is indeed not our intention to stimulate patients to go abroad. On the contrary, in many cases, certainly in border regions, but also for patients with rare diseases or chronic diseases, a treatment in another country is often more effective and even cheaper and therefore the interests of our fellow citizens have to be our top priority. We have to make sure that Europe is at its best in serving the interests and the well-being of European citizens and these efforts — as has been said also by Peter Liese and others — do not cost money; it is about the correct implementation. So, let us use this instrument, this directive to prove that the extra value of European cooperation is really to be found here in this regard.  Finally, let me conclude Madam President, and allow me to send my sincere gratitude to Maria Grapini as a co-rapporteur for the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee, and also special thanks to the Shadow colleagues for their excellent input.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, February 12, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Mr President, the implementation of the Directive on cross-border healthcare is important for the safety of patients in need of specific and professional medical assistance. That is why it is necessary to establish an EU framework and a set of rights that gives Union citizens access to healthcare abroad, which is outside their permanent residence. To this end, national contact points should be set up and supported, providing information to patients and enabling them to make informed decisions on the use of foreign healthcare in the EU. The Commission and the Member States must establish a network of easily accessible and well-functioning national contact points and multilingual e-health platforms to provide patients and healthcare professionals with user-friendly, numerically accessible and barrier-free information on possible forms of treatment. In this process, it is particularly important to build on the actions already taken to raise public awareness and understanding, in particular about rare diseases and rare oncological diseases, which require more funding for research and the development of treatment methods. Please note that when creating new rules and regulations on treatment abroad, the patient's well-being and health must be paramount. The directive implemented must serve this purpose if it is to provide real and genuine assistance to patients.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Simona Bonafè's report, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the minimum requirements for water reuse (COM(2018)0337 - C8-0220/2018 - 2018/0169 COD (COD)) (A8-0044/2019).

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, First of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution to the important debate on these months of work.  I would start from one fact: in 2017 alone, global water withdrawals were about 6 000 cubic kilometers, and it is estimated that they can double by the end of the century. It is clear that there is a problem of increasing global competition for the supply and use of water resources, which will have an effect on the economy, communities and ecosystems on which these communities depend.  On the one hand, therefore, the increase in demand and, on the other, the increasingly obvious effects of climate change present us with the possibility that areas with drought problems could increase. That is why the issue of proper and efficient water management is becoming increasingly pressing, which is rightly increasingly considered a precious but scarce asset.  Mind you: Europe is not an arid continent, but security of supply is currently a cause for concern for at least half the population of the European Union. Here too, forgive me if I give you any data. Water scarcity is already a phenomenon that already affects at least 11 % of the European population and 17 % of the territory of the European Union. Since 1980, the number of droughts in Europe has increased and worsened, with costs estimated at EUR 100 billion over the last thirty years.  The drought of the summer of 2017 alone has once again highlighted the scale of the economic losses we are talking about. These, as underlined by the Commission's impact assessment for the Italian agricultural sector alone, for example, amounted to around EUR 2 billion. This trend is set to continue. Water scarcity is no longer confined to a small number of areas of the continent, particularly in the South, but is a concern for the whole territory of the Union. It is up to us to find appropriate solutions at European level to maintain the well-being of our citizens and clearly preserve the environment.  The starting point must be to extend the principles of the circular economy, on which we have set the new model of development in Europe, also to water resources, primarily by promoting their savings and re-use through a specific legislative instrument capable of creating the regulatory stability that favours investment in this sector, which is very important in order to make the system more efficient. The Water Framework Directive already exists, which mentions the reuse of urban waste water as an additional measure for efficient water resource management.  However, we must be clear that there is a lack of precise legislation and clear rules in order to be able to take full advantage of the benefits of this activity. According to data provided by the European Commission, the total potential for water reuse by 2025 is 6.6 billion cubic meters compared to the current 1.1 billion cubic meters per year. These are impressive figures, which show us the potential that we have in front of us.  For this reason, the ENVI Committee supported the regulation by a very large majority, as proposed by the Commission and placed in the context of the circular economy action plan. The Commission's proposal aims to achieve the objectives of the circular economy by establishing harmonised standards at European Union level that create the same high food safety conditions for agricultural products marketed in the Union's internal market.  As the ENVI Committee, we have supported the Commission's general structure, which enhances the experience gained from specific national legislations such as the Italian, French and also the Spanish legislation. However, as a Parliament, we felt it necessary to take action with some changes to make this legislation clearer, in particular on the definitions, roles and responsibilities of the various actors involved and on the main risk management activities.  Turning briefly to the specifics, we considered it important to define more precisely the main actors involved in urban waste water recovery operations. For this reason, in addition to the treatment plant operator, the recovery plant operator and the end user, the distribution network operator and the recovered water storage operator are inserted.  With regard to the minimum requirements for reclaimed water, we shared the parameters proposed by the Commission, based on the JRC study, but we felt it was necessary to further include the 'salmonella' parameter in order to ensure even greater food safety for citizens.  Particular attention will also have to be paid to the need for awareness-raising measures that highlight, firstly, how important it is to save water use and, secondly, how the reuse of urban waste water does not harm human and animal health. With today's vote, Parliament will close its first reading. I am sure that the Council will soon be able to find a common position which will enable the new Parliament to open negotiations as soon as possible and see this important legislation adopted.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like, first and foremost, to thank Ms Simona Bonafè and the shadow rapporteurs for the very hard work done on the proposal setting minimum requirements for water reuse. The European Parliament’s work will be instrumental. It is very important in taking this important dossier forward in the forthcoming negotiations.  As Simona already mentioned, water is a very precious resource. It is indispensable for all of us, whether it’s for industry, for agriculture or the many other uses. However, it is also an increasingly scarce resource. Today, one-third of the European Union territory already suffers from water stress all year round. As the summer of 2018 has dramatically shown, water stress is becoming a concern for many Member States, even for those that are not usually associated with water scarcity, even Member States that are not even associated with drought. These problems are likely to worsen, mainly due to climate change. Together with water savings and water efficiency measures, water reuse can play an important part in addressing such problems, also, in the framework of the integrated water management policy.  The proposal on water reuse, which we are debating today, promotes treated urban wastewater as a reliable alternative water supply for agricultural irrigation. It seeks to extend the lifecycle of water, turning a waste product into a resource and is fully in line with the circular economy concept that this Commission is actively promoting. The objective is to facilitate the uptake of water reuse for agricultural irrigation wherever this is relevant, wherever this is safe and wherever this is cost effective, in order to alleviate water stress whilst preserving the health of consumers and protecting the environment.  Moreover, the setting of harmonised minimum parameters will facilitate the smooth functioning of the internal market for agricultural produce and create new business opportunities for operators and also for technology providers.  The European Commission thanks the European Parliament for their engagement and for the swift progress made in the preparation of their opinion and the European Commission looks forward to a fruitful discussion.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the DEVE committee. – Dear Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, the aim of this legislative proposal is to fill the gap in EUROPEAN Union legislation. Water is our most valuable resource under pressure, both because of human activities and climate change. Wastewater treatment and reuse should therefore be linked to the implementation of Union policies, such as the circular economy policy. The scope of the originally envisaged reuse of water has been extended, except in agriculture, for other purposes. As rapporteur of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I would like to recall that farmers are already obliged to apply the strict rules laid down in the General Rules Regulation for food business operators. This Regulation should ensure that farmers receive reclaimed water from water treatment systems and water reuse plants in accordance with the criteria they must meet for their agriculture needs, in order to be able to guarantee the safety of their agricultural products.  The implementation of the Regulation in the Member States, in addition to bringing many benefits, should not lead to additional costs for our farmers.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank Mrs Bonafé for the work she has done on this report and for the good cooperation we have had among all the shadow rapporteurs. The Regulation we will vote on today should serve not only to advance sustainable water management, but also to address a new aspect of the circular economy. Although the Regulation is limited to agricultural uses of water, we must be clear that the extension of reused water uses must begin to be seen in other areas that make for comprehensive water consumption, such as industry. In this regard, I would like to highlight the co-financing, through a Life programme, of a water reuse project in industrial uses in Tarragona's petrochemical complex. And like this, other projects at Union level must be carried out taking into account, as the Commissioner rightly said, that estimates tell us that by 2030 half of the European population will suffer from water scarcity. That is why, although it may not seem like a problem today in some Member States, I call on the Council to understand that what affects the countries of southern Europe today will affect all Europeans tomorrow. That is why I believe it is necessary that, in the future, the Commission should consider reforming, transforming what is now a regulation into a directive so that, for once, we do not act in reaction to any problem, but that we do so in advance and foresight.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Bonaf, whose wisdom as an expert, as she has given us in her text on circular economy, is really to be thanked at the moment, in the field of reuse of used waters. In the case of Spain we find ourselves precisely with a long history of water need. We are the country with the greatest reuse of the waters, but at the same time we are aware of how fragile the need is that regulation can be flexible, especially considering that the Spanish basins are very different and with very different needs. That is why we also appreciate the readily available of Mrs Bonaf's to approach precisely those needs. This Regulation is going to be very important. We need that flexibility. But in any case, Mr Vella, we also need a Directive on contaminated soils. When is a Directive on contaminated soils in Europe? The water problem starts in the soils. By when, Mr. Vella?

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Thank you, Chairman. Ladies and gentlemen, this is an important report. As we saw last summer, fresh water is not a matter of course and large areas of the European Union have been affected by drought. That is why I also find it interesting to look at alternatives to irrigation, in addition to groundwater and surface water. Reuse of treated wastewater can make an important contribution to this. Up to 6.6 billion cubic meters may be available if we can start using purified wastewater. For me, it is very important that we have good criteria to ensure food safety and public health. In the spirit of sustainability, It seems to me important to see if we can reuse residual flows, such as water, for example. In addition, there is another indirect effect, namely that there are already Member States using purified wastewater. In the context of the internal market, it is important that we have European rules for this. The products that these countries are already producing with this purified waste water are also in the supermarkets of other Member States which do not yet use purified waste water. I therefore think it is important that we tackle this European in order to avoid problems with public health and problems with distorted competitiveness. Thank you very much.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, in principle we are not against water reuse, but this Commission proposal presents a number of problems. Firstly, water regeneration treatment will be in the hands of private operators – as the Commissioner has said, it is a new business opportunity – who will obviously look after their businesses and not our health. Therefore, we believe that such a sensitive activity has to be in public hands, just like the entire water cycle. Secondly, it is recognized that not all regenerated water will be able to be used to water all crops. So my question is: those waters that are not going to be used for a given crop and yes for others, how are you going to ensure that they are not going to contaminate the aquifers? Third. I don't think we can continue with the logic of hiding all our waste in rural areas. Everything that goes to earth comes back to us in the form of food, water or air. Therefore, I believe that we need to work on other development models.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Club. – Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioner Vella, respected colleagues, first of all I would like to thank MPs Bonafè for the excellent work on this report. Through joint efforts, we have achieved a balanced and high-quality report.  The dedicated reuse of waste purified water has an imminent impact on our environment. By using incorrect and unplanned use, we can easily question the water regeneration of common water flows. I'm glad the report recognizes these very challenges.  Climate impacts are beginning to have an increasingly powerful impact on our environment and increased stress, triggered by increasing droughts, is particularly reflected in agricultural production that can benefit most from the smart use of treated wastewater, especially on our islands.  Special attention should be paid to possible unwanted and human health extremely dangerous contamination of our land and agricultural products. Especially here I want to highlight the problem of microplastics and single-wing switches that can be in the system of our wastewater.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Madam President, Mrs Bonafè's report is an important report because it provides concrete solutions to the serious problem of water scarcity and the increase in droughts in the European Union. This particularly worrying phenomenon, due to warming and climate change, affects entire territories in southern Europe, territories that face water supply crises and intense water stress every year. Farmers are the first to pay the price for these crises when irrigation systems dry up. I am therefore very much in favour of the multiplication of good practices for collecting wastewater and the reuse of these waters, especially for irrigation purposes. On the other hand, we must be very firm on the quality of these waters and tighten the requirements on plastics and micropollutants. On this condition, we will be able to meet this triple requirement: to protect human and animal health, to protect the environment and to guarantee our water supplies.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this proposal for a regulation on the reuse of wastewater and treated, of domestic, industrial or agricultural origin, deals with a major subject and, in our view, for three main reasons. What constitutes, sorry, Madam rapporteur, the real infox is the assertion that drought or water stress is already affecting a third of the surface of the European Union. This is a fallacious observation that does not concern the lack of water stricto sensu but the inadequacy of its management structures. That is why we support the project carried out by this report, which opens the door to the management of the entire water chain, storage, distribution and reprocessing. There is no need to panic the population to propose a project that should have been done long ago, in the wake of the great works of the 19th century. The scarcity of water to justify the disappearance of herders and farmers and gradually impose artificial food - the future eldorado of the agrochemical giants - and finally the authentic commodification of water which, becoming a rare and therefore expensive good, will be able to be the subject of all financial or political speculation. As vital as CO2, H2O will become the alpha and omega of all the challenges and speculations of globalization.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which For good reason, we have very, very strict rules for drinking water. I believe that you do not need the same strict rules for all applications for which water is needed. That is why it makes sense for us to have a graduated option here. Water scarcity is an issue – not only in southern Europe. I come from an area where it usually rains a lot. And there is a funny saying: If you don't want sunburn on holiday, then go to sauerland – because there is rain rather than sun. We are the water reservoir for the Ruhr area: eight million inhabitants are supplied with water from my area.  This year, however, we had such a dry summer that the dams we have there were practically completely empty. In other words, the Member States and regions that say that water shortages will never be a problem and that is why we do not need regulation here, they should be a little careful. We are on climate change, and we can be prepared for the fact that we may be even more careful with this precious asset. That is why I believe that the text adopted by the committee is the right approach.  The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats would like to have a directive – not a regulation – so that we can respond a little more flexibly to the wishes of the Member States. But it is fundamentally good that we have other requirements – strict, proportionate requirements – for water used, for example, for irrigation, but not necessarily the same as for drinking water.  Thank you to all those who have worked, and the PPE-DE will support the text.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: – Madam President, water scarcity affects 11% of the European population and 17% of the territory of the European Union. Rational use of water is crucial, for obvious reasons: we need water to produce food, energy and consumer goods. Appropriate European solutions must be built to protect this resource. The Water Framework Directive mentions the reuse of urban waste water as an additional measure for efficient resource management, but the opportunity is not yet fully exploited in the absence of clear legislation. Unfortunately, the Commission's proposal is limited to recovered water used for agricultural irrigation. It is necessary to extend the areas and modalities of use of purified waste water, obviously in maximum safety. I support the rapporteur's position on the need for a regulation to establish harmonised criteria at European Union level for urban waste water reuse activities.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we must strive to protect the health of our citizens and the environment. We have a duty to leave a cleaner and better world for future generations. But this must be done with long-term thoughtful solutions, without resorting to sporadic witch-hunts and easy shortcuts that do not solve the problem and only damage the competitiveness of our companies.  One third of the territory of the European Union is subject to water stress. Water reuse is obviously not the solution to all problems, but it is a first step in this direction. It is possible to achieve a reuse of water for irrigation use of about 6.6 billion cubic meters per year.  The agricultural sector, which is fundamental for Europe and Italy, needs new measures and actions to ensure future sustainability without there being any increase in costs for farmers. We must act preventively, so that legislation on water reuse provides uniform rules for all countries and harmonised criteria at EU level. The safety of citizens and the increased dissemination of recovery activities must be guaranteed.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the territory of the European Union is subject to water stress due to human activities and climate change. In 2003 alone, the drought caused the European economy losses of at least EUR 8.7 billion, and between the 1980s and 2000s the number of people affected by drought increased by almost 20 %, resulting in total costs reaching the astronomical figure of EUR 100 billion.  Not only, as my fellow Members have also said, this is happening in the dry season and in the Mediterranean countries, but the extreme drought, which is increasingly intensified by climate change, is increasingly affecting northern Europe as well. There is therefore no doubt that water as a common good and a valuable resource must be managed more efficiently and that water saving must become a priority at every level. That is why common rules to stimulate the reuse of water in the circular economy can only be welcomed, and the regulation on the reuse of water is therefore an opportunity that Europe must not waste. We participated in the definition of the minimum requirements for the quality of recovered water by emphasising the need to ensure their safe reuse. For us there must never be any risk to the land and crops, no room for microplastics and endocrine disruptors. We have proposed decisive action on this, because they should be absent, both from the waters that flow into rivers and seas, in order to put an end once and for all to the enormous damage to biodiversity that we are perpetrating globally, and of course to the reclaimed waters that are the subject of this regulation, so that their reuse can be allowed. Finally, I would like to mention toxic and dangerous substances such as PFAS. They should never, ever be in the water spilled into the fields, nor should they enter the food chain, endangering the health of our citizens. In conclusion, therefore, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for this important regulation. In two words: yes to the reuse of water, no to risk factors for health and the environment.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the context of the circular economy logic, this report is particularly important and I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Bonafè, and my colleagues for the work that has been done. Beyond the issue of transparency, accountability and the need to support research and innovation, I would like to mention a particularly important point for me: the health status of crops should not be impacted by the quality of retired wastewater. Indeed, to ensure the efficient use of treated urban waste water resources, it is necessary to inform farmers so that they use these recycled water optimally on their production and do not risk having a health impact on them. This is also the case with consumers' acceptance of this reuse in the food chain. The key, for me, therefore, is the security, information and training of the actors, and I thank the rapporteur for taking these aspects into account.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, since 2008 the European Parliament has defined that the challenge of water scarcity and droughts in the European Union must have a systemic approach to water management, which includes less consumption of drinking water, especially for purposes where it is not necessary. More recently, through the Circular Economy Action Plan, we have touched this point again, but it is urgent to follow up through a Plan 2.0 by the Commission, so that it retains water resources as one of the priority areas of intervention. The reuse of recovered water properly treated for irrigation purposes must be respected for the environment and human and animal health. It is therefore clear that the water to be reused cannot lead to eutrophication of soils and groundwater and surface water, which would be disruptive to ecosystems and contribute to the reduction of biodiversity. It is also worth noting the role of competent authorities in cooperation with end-users in promoting the reuse of water. Finally, it is urgent to renew the water distribution infrastructures that are old and in poor condition, resulting daily in significant losses and other losses such as financial resources invested.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, while water itself is cyclical in its formation – it falls from the sky, flows into the sea, evaporates, vaporises and falls again – it is not an infinite resource. We have seen instances of drought from Australia indeed to my own country, which is renowned as a place for a lot of rainfalls. Last summer water had to be rationed, while at the same time in places like Dublin up to 50% of our pipe water is leaking. This is something that is being addressed, but will take some time to address in the future.  That’s why the reuse of water, where practical, is so important and I welcome the proposals here today. Simona Bonafè, Marijana Petir and Angélique Delahaye all referred to the circular economy and reuse of water is part of that circular economy. Therefore it is absolutely important that, when we can do so, we reuse water in terms of irrigation, agriculture, urban waste etc. because it is vital for us and we have to take care of it. A good proposal which, as Peter Liese said, we will be delighted to back.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, once again I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Bonafè, on her success in drafting this report, and also to welcome the support and the ideas expressed by the Members of this House. The Commission has closely followed the discussion and will examine in detail Parliament’s proposals with a view to the next steps in the legislative process. I would like, however, to make two or three points. With regard to the issue of polluted soil, we do have the Nitrates Directive to protect our soil, and the Commission is following the implementation of this directive very closely. It is, at least for me, hard to justify, or even to understand, how bad agricultural practices are still harming the very resources that sustainable agriculture depends on.
