Another point I would like to make is that I feel we are, at times, underestimating the problem when we say that the EU is facing water scarcity. It is the whole planet which is facing this problem, and that makes the necessity to act now even more urgent. With regard to the scope of the proposed law – whether it’s limited to agricultural irrigation – I would point out that, of the various possible areas for water reuse, agricultural irrigation is the most widely used worldwide. As demonstrated in the impact assessment undertaken, water reuse for agricultural irrigation also has great potential in the European Union but it is currently underutilised. While the Commission agrees on the desirability of using reclaimed water for other purposes, the proposed rules do not exclude the possibility of Member States’ using reclaimed waters for other purposes as well. We are confident that an agreement on the new rules can be found and that it will be possible swiftly to complete the legislative process for this very important proposal. Once it has entered into force, the new instrument will facilitate the uptake of water reuse, helping to fulfil the largely untapped potential of this practice and also to alleviate the pressure of abstraction on surface and groundwater bodies – thus benefitting farmers, consumers and the industry. The Commission looks forward to the forthcoming negotiations and stands ready to support the co—legislators in this process. I count, as I have always done, on your support in the vote, and I thank you once again for your commitment to this proposal.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Madam President, I would just like to ask if Mr Vella can tell us today what the current directive on contaminated soils is. I asked him the question yesterday, but he did not answer; it was another subject, which had nothing to do with the environment, but today I would like to have an answer.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Ms. Grapini, no one has seen you while you are used to on-demand interventions. As this phase is complete, I suggest that you make a written contribution.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, yes, I think the honourable Member has a point. I think various attempts were made to produce some sort of proposal on the way forward. We have been discussing this possibility. Unfortunately, so far, we have not reached a conclusion, but I promise that I will give it another try. I think the honourable Member is quite right on this.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the Commissioner for his words of attention to this issue, but I have to say that he has also spoken in recent months and since his term of office. I would also like to thank my fellow Members who have spoken, not only for the work they have done in recent months, but also because their words today bear witness to support, I think I can say, almost unanimously or at least very broadly, to the proposal we are debating. Because it has not escaped anyone's notice that water is a precious, indeed invaluable, asset, and we cannot afford to waste a single cubic meter of water. The extension of the principles of the circular economy on which we have based the development model in Europe, including water resources, is therefore a good thing. I would like to remind you that the principles of the circular economy stipulate, first of all, that there must be savings in the use of water resources, but then also reuse. Reuse in agriculture, reuse for civil uses – I am thinking of street cleaning – but reuse also for industrial uses. Of course, taking into account and bearing in mind compliance with the criteria for human health.  So we are faced with the phenomenon of climate change which, if we do not act quickly and decisively, will also pose great problems and serious difficulties for our economic system. So, go ahead with the efficient use of water resources, with clear rules such as those we want to approve as soon as possible, but also with investments in the sector, because the efficient use of water also needs important investments.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, February 12, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – Water quality and quantity should be carefully monitored because resources are limited. Sustainable use of water is a must. The redistribution of waste water must be done responsibly, so it is necessary to establish clearly, throughout the distribution chain - from the operator of the recovery facility to the user - concrete responsibilities and measures to verify the mode of application. In industrial and agricultural areas, especially where pollution is higher, there must be rigorous control. National water authorities shall organise specialised courses for employees and inform all employees of the danger and harmful effects of non-compliance with the established rules. People's lives also depend on how reused water is management, and therefore there is a need not only for precise regulations, but also for control and sanctionmeasures in case of violation of the established rules.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – Water is a finite resource. People seem to become aware of the validity of this claim only in the face of the callamites and the dry, which are becoming harsher and more often. I welcome the steps to help us in the wake of last year's dry-by-work measures by Member States and at EU level. There have been actions that have shown that European solidarity works.  I also welcome this report and the opinion of AGRI, for which I was rapporteur from the shadows. However, we know that Europe is diverse and the volume of water resources and water management differ from one state to another. We do indeed need European recommendations on water reuse, but the differences between regions and Member States must be taken into account. Europe is also diverse when it comes to the level of education and awareness of the need and safety of water reuse. I therefore believe that a fair balance must be struck between the ambitions of Brussels, on the one hand, and the realities of poorer peripheral regions. The sudden imposition of drastic conditions for water reuse may, in some regions, give rise to dramatic effects of social polarisation and, in the long term, developments contrary to today's laudable intentions.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – The issue of sound and efficient management of water resources is becoming increasingly important. Water is a precious and scarce resource, and increasing global competition in terms of its use brings an increasing risk to the economy, communities and ecosystems that depend on them. There is a rise in demand every year, coupled with the effects of climate change and the consequent increase in average temperatures, as the number of areas facing water shortages could increase.  That is why I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on minimum requirements for the reuse of water, as eu legislation, in particular the Water Framework Directive (2000/60/EC), elaborated a plan for the reuse of municipal waste water as an additional measure for efficient water management.  However, the benefits resulting from this activity have not yet been fully exploited due to a lack of clear laws and specific rules. According to the European Commission, the total potential for water reuse by 2025 is around 6.6 billion m3 compared to the current 1.1 billion m3 per year. The Commission proposal aims to achieve these objectives by setting harmonised rules at Union level in order to avoid that different requirements in the Member States adversely affect a level playing field and cause obstacles to the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Human Rights Watch warns us that we are about to vote on an EU-Morocco fisheries agreement which includes Western Sahara, in breach of international law. As MEPs are not above the law, it calls on us to ask first of all for the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union. If we really care about the rule of law, international law and human rights as much as we always say here, let us be consistent and ask for the first opinion of European justice.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Single Market Programme brings together six existing programmes and provides for substantial new resources to strengthen the functioning of the single market. We are talking about funding allocated at European level for the 2021-2027 programming period, in order to support the competitiveness of industry, in particular micro, medium-sized and small enterprises, to ensure the safety of the food chain and the health of people, animals and plants, greater consumer protection, and to establish the framework for financing European statistics. The position we have reached is very ambitious and provides for an overall increase in the total budget to EUR 6 billion, of which EUR 3 billion is dedicated to the COSME programme, aimed at small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backbone of the European economic and production system. Specific resources dedicated to strengthening market surveillance and product safety activities, with particular attention to products that are sold online. And finally, the introduction of delegated acts for the implementation of the programme for a stronger role of control and supervision of the European Parliament. With the text that we are going to approve, ladies and gentlemen, Parliament is taking a clear and ambitious position in favour of the European production system and the citizens of Europe. We hope that the Council will also be able to do the same.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, as European Parliament coordinator on children’s rights, I propose this oral amendment: ‘To explicitly consider children as a priority when programming and implementing the strategic National Roma Integration Strategy, reiterates the importance of protecting and promoting equal access to all rights for Roma children’.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the large majority of colleagues who voted for this report. I have asked, exceptionally, for the word because it happens to be the last report that I have the honour of presenting in plenary after twenty-seven years in the European Parliament. Thank you, colleagues. (The Assembly, standing, applauded the speaker). I'm going to take this opportunity to punish you with two more sentences. In 1989, I entered here, in what was a political forum limited to a part of Europe, west of the Iron Curtain. And the Parliament I am going to leave in a few weeks is a real Parliament, really European, with legislative capacity. I would like to thank all colleagues, starting with my group, of course, but beyond that, the employees of Parliament, the group staff and our assistants, for the work done together. Thanks to you, ladies and gentlemen, I have learned that listening, dialogue, mutual respect, the search for compromise, the obsession with the common interest are far more effective than the systematic confrontation that too often characterizes our national debates. Many of our national parliaments and a prestigious Capitol on the other side of the Atlantic would have a number of lessons to learn here. My honour will remain to have been an anonymous worker, humble but proud to have contributed his stone to a political construction that will forever mark the history of our continent. In the future parliament, of which I will no longer have the honour of being a part, I hope that the majority that has just spoken is united in adapting our union to the challenges of the new century. Thank you again.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Mr Lamassoure, you have felt the undivided support of the House for the important message that you have given. We have, of course, all seen your work over 30 years. The House wishes you all the best in your future endeavours. (Applause)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, I wanted to clarify my positive vote on this agreement. Fisheries agreements are all important for the countries with which they are signed and, of course, for the European fleet. But I would like to highlight this agreement with a small country, such as Ivory Coast, a country that has only twenty million inhabitants and more than sixty different ethnic groups, and has also gone through a turbulent period and civil war that has exacerbated its terrible social inequalities. I believe that this fact of signing an agreement with Ivory Coast, even if it does not have an important fisheries sector, is a positive aspect and of solidarity and joint work of the European Union with this country. In addition, that fishing sector consisting specifically of tuna, which will go fishing after this agreement, will benefit. Almost thirty years ago the signing of the same and is positive for both parties.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, it has been quite a busy few days for Côte d’Ivoire. The other day, because of a mix-up over flags, it was the recipient of a supportive tweet from the German Foreign Ministry, which expressed its total solidarity with Côte d’Ivoire over the issue of the Irish border – and now we have this Fisheries Agreement. Look, we’ve all voted on dozens, maybe hundreds, of these fisheries agreements with various African countries, and I have occasionally taken the opportunity to lament the fact that overfishing in Europe and the mismanagement of the common fisheries policy brought us to the point where we needed to do this. But I wonder whether we could consider a different aspect of it. Again, we are treating Côte d’Ivoire and the African continent generally as a kind of economic colony and a supplier of raw materials to our industries. Under EU tariff arrangements, you can export green coffee beans but not roasted coffee from Africa, you can export cocoa but not chocolate. In other words, we are encouraging, through our economic policy, an effect which not only keeps people poorer but also costs consumers in Europe more. The best thing we could do is scrap the common agricultural policy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I am pleased to support this agreement and particularly to highlight the important opportunities it brings for the EU and Côte d’Ivoire to work together in a sustainable way in the exploitation of fisheries resources. Sustainability is a crucial element of all fisheries policies, so I am pleased that this agreement pays due attention to that priority. The agreement marks an important step in the responsible development of Côte d’Ivoire’s blue economy, and I am pleased that the EU, through this partnership, will help to support this development. I also welcome the mutually beneficial nature of this partnership agreement in creating an opportunity for the exploitation of Côte d’Ivoire fisheries resources by fishers originating in EU Member States, ensuring at the same time, and as a priority, that the resources are used in an environmentally conscious way, protecting marine ecosystems, and in the interests of all involved. I congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on their important work in preparing for today’s vote.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In yesterday's debate, which was quite intense and short, I did not have time to express my positive opinion on the new proposal – the proposal for changes to IT programmes. I believe that this is one of the most important elements of this report. I believe that this does not increase bureaucracy for the bureaucracy itself, but also builds certain mechanisms to genuinely, very simply and cost-effectively eliminate what we call fraud. I would also like to point out that support for this report was therefore so high that a lot of amendments to improve the first version have been adopted, for which I would like to thank the rapporteur very warmly.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the fight against fraud at European Union level is an important action, which we must, of course, strengthen. What I have also highlighted in my speech is a special form of fraud related to Greekisations of agricultural and livestock products. In other words, dairy products, for example milk, are imported from Albania into Greece and are baptized Greek. At the same time, livestock products, e.g. meat, are imported into Greece from Skopje and are also baptized Greek. These Greekisations of agricultural and livestock products are a special form of fraud that must be tackled with determination by the European Union itself. Very specific measures are needed which are absent and penalties should be imposed on these neighbouring states, Albania and Skopje, within the framework of the European Union's pre-accession policy. Measures are needed to tackle illegal Greekisations of agricultural and livestock products.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, the recent report of the Court of Auditors gives us alarming figures. In 2017, fraudulent use of EU funds amounted to EUR 391 million but only 15% of the total volume of fraud was actually recovered. Some EU funds were misused by national politicians for their families, other funds were misused in the agricultural sector.  The economic interests and most importantly political credibility of the EU are seriously damaged because there is no truly European mechanism for fraud detection. Colleagues, it is here now that to combat fraud we cannot fully rely on national authorities who are sometimes themselves involved in fraud. I welcome the Commission’s proposal aiming at protecting the financial interest of the European Union and I welcome the amendments in the report of Mr Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra that call for major cooperation among the relevant agencies and bodies like OLAF, Eurojust, Europol, the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and so on. I voted in favour.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this report, I want to thank Parliament for ing amendments that improve the final version of the proposal. Unfortunately, the fight against financial fraud, fraud that affect the financial interests of the European Union, is not being sufficiently successful in all Member States, it is not doing well enough, and it is therefore logical that the European Parliament, the European institutions must have an interest in clearly saving and effectively addressing financial fraud, fraud against the Interests of the Union throughout the European Union. This programme also contributes to this, we are increasing funding for administrative authorities, for law enforcement authorities. Money is necessary for the institutions to have quality equipment in order to be able to effectively prosecute fraud that affect European money. I welcome the report and hope that it will contribute to the fact that future statistics on the prosecution of financial fraud will be more positive for us.

name: Rupert MATTHEWS
text: – Madam President, I was very pleased to vote for this report which is changing the way that fisheries are controlled in the Western Approaches. I think everyone here recognises the common fisheries policy over the years has been catastrophic for the European fishing industry, it has led to a collapse in stocks, it has led to unemployment, it has led to untold hardship.  Pushing control away from a centralised top-down approach to a regionalised approach has got to be the right idea. I’m very pleased to see this being brought in in the western oceans, where of course fishermen from Britain are very active. I think it is a shame, however, that the European Union still cannot quite bring itself to put control over the fisheries into the hands of smaller entities, of the nations themselves, because it is they who not only understand the fisheries but have a stake in making sure it is sustainable. I hope very much that after Brexit we at least will be able to achieve that in Britain.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, if there is one thing that is positive about this report , which has many aspects, it is that we are actually approving it, we have approved it in this House before Brexit. The western waters of the Atlantic will therefore be well regulated by a multi-year fisheries management plan and we have also managed to approve it on time. I think it has very positive aspects, such as giving greater stability to Western water pesqueria. It is true that, at first, we would have liked a division between north and south. But it is well as it has finally been, understanding that it will give stability to this fishing sector. We are talking about more than 4,000 vessels; therefore, it is a very important area. We would also have liked it to have included a greater limitation of recreational fishing compared to professional fishing, but, I stress, it is compliance with the CFP and, finally, this management plan will be good for the future of the Atlantic fisheries sector.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís, vótáil mé ar son an mholta seo mar is dóigh liom gur comhréiteach an-mhaith é agus cabhróidh sé lenár n-iascairí sna huiscí seo leanúint ar aghaidh ag iascaireacht. Ach, déanfar í ar shlí a chuireann an comhshaol san áireamh. Dá bhrí sin, tá sé sin an-thábhachtach mar ní féidir linn níos mó iasc nó na héisc go léir atá san fharraige a thógaint amach. Más mar sin a bhíonn, ní bheidh aon éisc ann sa todhchaí, agus dá bhrí sin, ní bheidh aon iascairí ann ach oiread. Dá bhrí sin, is maith an comhréiteach seo agus fáiltím roimis.  Freisin, fáiltím roimh an gcomhréiteach atá ann, go háirithe le daoine a bhíonn ag iascaireacht mar chaitheamh aimsire. Tá sé sin tábhachtach agus cabhróidh sé sin leo agus cabhróidh sé freisin leis an tionscal turasóireachta mar tagann a lán daoine ar saoire, go dtí mo thír féin go háirithe, chun breith ar chúpla iasc agus is maith é sin.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is important to emphasise an aspect that tends to leave me baffled by the European Union, and it is this total willingness towards the Roma ethnic group, especially as regards economic aid, in the face of a particularly delicate situation from the point of view of work, involving millions, tens of millions of unemployed throughout Europe and which, especially in the Mediterranean countries, is particularly sensitive from the point of view of employment, involving millions, tens of millions of unemployed throughout Europe and which, especially in the Mediterranean countries, is not enough. , in Italy in particular, sees situations at risk of real social revolt.  I believe that Parliament's attention, especially at this extremely sensitive time that Europe is experiencing, must be seen and devoted to those who represent the foundations of our Union, represent national identities, and this is the effort that I hope will go in the right direction and not above all in the right, but sometimes exaggerated, protection of minorities who have the right to dignity on our continent. But they certainly need to be integrated, because many times it is precisely from these minorities that there is no help, the desire to be able to do what we are asking for, namely the possibility of cooperation.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that more needs to be done by the European Union with regard to the coordination of the capacity to respond to the civil and humanitarian crises that the various Member States may face in the coming years. While I acknowledge the recent efforts explained by this mechanism in Portugal, I would like to stress that we are in a phase of negotiation crucial to its development and full implementation and for which more speed and less institutional impasse between Member States is required. For this reason, I believe that it is time to recognise that the European civil protection mechanism, by promoting a stronger European collective response, plays a decisive role in defining a common strategy capable of rapidly addressing the climate and humanitarian challenges we face today. In this regard, I reaffirm the need to do more and better, starting with the consolidation of RescEU as a reserve capacity complementary to the means that each Member State already has at its disposal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the European Union's civil protection mechanism is an important activity, because the European Union, and in particular the countries of the European South, have faced enormous problems as a result of natural disasters. In Greece, we have had the deadly floods in Mandra, Attica, the deadly fires in Mati with over 100 dead and, to date, those affected have not received their compensation. It is something that we should take very seriously. The government will have to deal with this issue, which, because of its incompetence, has not yet granted compensation to those affected. Of course, we must also provide for changes in the operating procedure of the famous Solidarity Fund, because the conditions must be made much more flexible so that compensation can be paid to those affected.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Madam President! So, water resources are practically all over Europe, and are under increasing pressure, so it doesn't matter what we do with water, and water scarcity can and is a major problem for europe's future. It is therefore important that we also deal with the possibility of reusing water with the so-called reuse of municipal water, for which we need, of course, adequate infrastructure, adequate mechanisms for the treatment of this water so that it can be reused, but this is an absolutely important resource for crops, for reuse for sanitation purposes and, of course, in a way that can also return to nature certain structures , in short, that it can be used for infrastructure and agricultural purposes. Above all, we must take care to also remove microplastics and drug residues.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab For more than eleven years I was president of Wrocław, so I have an idea not only about the municipal economy, but also about the complexity of this problem. I say this because there is something absolutely new but important about this report. I would remind you that the rapporteur, in agreement with the message mainly addressed to agriculture, pointed out that the regulation setting out at European Union level should also be harmonised with regard to the use of urban waste water. I note that the municipal economy in cities such as Helsinki, Madrid, Naples, Wroclaw are completely different economies, they are very different systems as well. Some are in private hands, some in the hands of local governments. It is important that, in pursuing this report, the opinion of the local authorities should be taken into account. In my opinion, this regulation will then be more secure, in short.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, water is a public good and must therefore be treated with this perspective and not exploited by business groups. On this basis, we should also look at how water resources are reused, because there is a huge restriction on water resources, while climate change exacerbates the problem. In this sense, we need to see how we can reuse the waters. Their reuse should contribute to the development of agriculture, to the protection of the environment and to the support of public health. Of course, the reuse of water resources means infrastructure and means that there must also be the corresponding funds for this operation, especially in a direction that will support the productive reconstruction of the countryside.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Water is no ordinary commercial product. Climate change shows that it is not an unlimited resource. Urban development, especially in major cities and capital cities, puts under considerable pressure the supply of fresh and quality water.  I supported today's report because I believe it is necessary to promote resource efficiency and reduce pressure on the aquatic environment. One such solution is to promote the development of safe reuse of treated waste water. Agriculture is an example of a sector where purified and safe waters can find excellent application and be a solution for the development of vegetable production.  A growing part of the scientific community is also paying attention to the so-called "microplastics" present in the water we use. Through it, they fall into the soil and the environment. This must necessarily be taken into account when finalising pan-European legislation on minimum requirements for water reuse.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from this point of view, I must repeat what has been said several times, and I believe that the integration of the Roma, which is necessary, often takes precedence over the logic of need that many millions of unemployed people in Europe have, particularly in areas of Italy where there is a risk of social revolt.  It is an endemic problem, it is a problem to which I believe Europe must pay extraordinary attention and which is often not considered in its full importance. The rights that these people often do not use in depth clash with duties, the duties that must take precedence over what integration requires.  So the economic resources that are made available must go in this direction. I believe that priority must be given without a shadow of a doubt to those who do not have a job at the moment, who are looking for it and who need to be able to find it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I supported this report on the roma population integration strategy. I think that integration needs to be promoted, and I also agree with the main objectives of integration, which are education, health, employment and housing. The European Parliament has added the topic of non-discrimination, which is of course very important to find the funds, projects, programmes by which we support roma integration. And also to use these means effectively, i.e. to control the use and control the development of indicators. I also appreciate the initiative for representatives of the Roma minority itself to participate in the development of national roma integration strategies. Colleagues, I have a great deal of experience in supporting the education of Roma children on the topic of Roma integration in the Czech Republic, I know that this is problematic, but I know that this is the main way to their successful and long-term integration.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, I have strongly voted against this resolution because it is high time to end the hypocritical and two-faced attitude on this very important issue. Continuous talk, strategies, writings of documents do not lead to anything real and nothing substantial. The real problems in these neighborhoods and in these neighborhoods stand. The neighborhood, the ghetto, they breed crime, they create a lack of education, they create tension, they create decay and degradation of societies. We need to finally make it clear what kind of problem there is in these neighborhoods and in these settlements. In my homeland, the number of attacks on police officers is increasing, the number of attacks on doctors who have come to assist in these settlements is increasing. This problem of declarations, resolutions, writing documents will not be solved. It will only be resolved when illegal buildings are removed; only where parents who create children at risk are criminally liable for what they have done; only when social benefits are stopped when they are abused, and only when the fake NGOs that actually siphon off these funds stop doing so.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Thank you very much, Madam President, I am pleased to be able to support this resolution on Roma inclusion in all areas of society in the European Union. These important groups of people face many challenges for the good lives of our societies, both in raising children, in employment, but also in terms of good housing. Major investments, major changes to redress have been made to alleviate the difficulties they face, and I am appealing to Roma representatives, with the encouragement to make good use of these opportunities and to fully engage with those entrusted institutions and organisations to improve their living conditions, as well as opportunities for work, employment, to improve the upbringing of their children. It is essential that they engage responsibly and effectively, so that they are not – i.e. not staying – passive beneficiaries of the European Union assistance that we have given them and are administering. This resolution is a sobering call for long-term strategies for change for the better in the Roma population, which lives in our Member States in the European Union, and I support it.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Contrary to what we are reading in this report, dislike of gypsies, to the Roma is not at all a specific form of racism – because it is not because people do not like Gypsies that they are Gypsies, but because of their specific culture, their way of life, which often drastically depreciates from the way of life of the societies in which they live. Racism, on the other hand, is precisely this motion for a resolution. This resolution makes helping The Roma dependent on being Roma precisely, i.e. proposing to set rights according to the origin of these people, not their specific situation. So, contrary to such anti-discrimination rhetoric, this is likely to result in an increase in dislike for roma, because if the rest of society has to pay for roma under duress, seeing especially the poor effects of such programmes – because in other countries millions have already drowned in such programmes and it's completely impossible– it will only exacerbate these bad moods. In addition, if they wanted to, they would be integrated into our society for a long time, and they are just running away from what you want to pack them into now.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I supported this report and, at the same time, wanted to say that I am very glad that it was tabled here and that it was voted in this way by a very significant majority. I fully share the view that no one should feel excluded, excluded from society or simply have no chance of applying. I support the objectives set out here, whether it be the objective of radically improving the education of the Roma community, of course the issue of employment is very poignant in many states, as is housing. In general, non-discriminatory access must affect every community, every part of society. At the same time, I would like to say that this group is, of course, facing new challenges, we need to bring all the actors and strategies to help this group. I think they're known to be described. It is only necessary to achieve synergative effects. And this group should be aware that they are not only rights, but also obligations that they should respect in a significant way, and their representatives should also lead them to do so.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: – Sinjura President, kif għadu kif ġie indikat, meta inti titkellem dwar dwar dwar y' Stat Membru tal-Unjoni Ewropea qed titkellem fuq itta大dinanza tal-Unjoni Ewropea koll kemham hi. Għalhekk huwa korrett li dan ir-rapport jirreferi wkoll għal skemi ta' bejgħ ta' passaporti. Meta inti tingħata, pereżempju fil-każ ta' Malta passaport ta' Malta, qed tingħata passaport tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Dan il-Parlament beauty sa mill-2014 jindika li ma jistax ikollok bejgħ bħal dan mingħajr ma' jkollok xi rabta reali mal-pajjiż li jkun qiegħed jagħti dak il-passaport. Għalija huwa tal-mistħija li l-Gvern ta' Malta jkompli jippersisti mingħajr trasparenza. Aħna sirna nafu biss mill-midja ftit ta' żmien beauty li kellek żewġ familji mill-Arabja Sawdija li bejniethom xtraw 62 passaport. U issa l-Gvern, għax jaf li għandek issue ta' reputazzjoni, qed jgħid imma nuża l-flus biex nagħmel il-housing so大jali, sitt snin tard wisq. Jiena nagħlaq billi ngħid hemm valuri Ewropej li rridu nħaddnu, hemm ukoll libertajiet tagħna, bħal-libertà tal-moviment liberu bejn pajjiż Ewropew u ieħor, ejja noqgħodu attenti minn skemi bħal dawn biex ma nqegħdux fil-periklu dak li tant issilitna għalih.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. As we know, in accordance with Article 9 of the Treaty on European Union and Article 20 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, every citizen of a Member State is also a citizen of the European Union. Unfortunately, most people in Europe do not know this, they are unaware of their powers. This is evidenced by various studies, such as those which show that as many as 54% admit only to some knowledge of the subject, but 45% of citizens of the Member States do not know at all what their rights and obligations are as a result of being a member of the European Union and of being a citizen of the European Union. This indicates the need for the European Parliament, the Institutions of the European Union, to undertake extensive promotional activities. After all, we need the integration of European citizens not only formally, not only on paper, but in the emotional, psychological sphere. This is a great and serious task for us.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, we must be careful with the tool of enhanced cooperation. First of all, by design it undermines the unity of the EU action and it has repercussions internally and externally. Second, the unanimity rule inside the coalition of the willing allows one Member State to sabotage the whole process, creating the conditions for a Trojan horse to undermine relations among Member States. Third, the real impact on enhanced cooperation is relative. Just take the example of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. It will not have jurisdiction over Hungary, Poland, Ireland, Sweden, Britain and Denmark, which opt out. As a result, combating fraud at EU level will have limited effect because these countries will be free riding. I was the shadow rapporteur of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ opinion to this report and I voted in favour, but I’m convinced that enhanced cooperation must aim for full cooperation, which is the ultimate goal.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, the protection of human rights is one of the fundamental values on which the European Union is founded. The adoption of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and its binding nature are thus a crucial step in sending a signal to the European Union that the protection of human rights is and will always be a guiding principle for all institutions, bodies and Member States in the application of EU law. Compliance with the charter must be unconditional. However, I would be very careful in its view as a strategic document according to which the internal rules of the institutions should be adapted. The institutions must be transparent, but if we introduce ongoing human rights impact assessments, numerous trainings and other bureaucratic processes in the name of the charter, then we will end up as an administrative juggern juggernth in which the true meaning of the charter as a catalogue of human rights drowns. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I welcome the report drafted by my colleague Barbara Spinelli. The task of the EU institutions is indeed not only to avoid violation of the Charter but rather to maximize its potential. Furthermore, it’s evident that some very important steps of decision making are simply falling outside the scope of the Charter. First of all, I’m speaking about the Council meetings, where it is believed that it is better for the public not to see how choices are made. I am glad that the Ombudsman has recently reported this practice. Secondly, I am talking about the so—called trilogues. You cannot find the word ‘trilogue’ in the Treaties and, because of their informal character, they are kept out of the public eye. Being committed to transparency and respect for fundamental rights, I specifically welcome the call to conduct separate fundamental-rights impact assessments, to be included in all items of legislation as a fundamental-rights review clause.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The appointment of the European Ombudsman is a great achievement of the European Union, but also an important competence of the European Parliament, because we choose a person for this very important, important function. Unfortunately, in recent years in Europe, in the Member States, we have seen an increase in human rights violations, violations of citizens' rights, but, worst of all, infringements, restrictions and, in some countries, even the dismantling of institutions, the independence of institutions and the rule of law. In this context, the European Ombudsman is revealing himself to us as an extremely important institution. But not everyone knows that this institution has no links with national institutions, with ombudsmans in the Member States. It is therefore difficult for it to cooperate and support its colleagues in these institutions of the Member States. I think it is time to consider whether or not to create a systemic solution that concerns the whole of the European Union.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, the comprehensive industrial policy on artificial intelligence and robotics is an own-initiative report. I have to say that on the one hand it is good, on the other hand it is wrong. It is good, because it has arises, badly, that it points to a certain gap in the European Commission's activity in an extremely complex and highly knowledgeable area, as well as responsibility for the letter of the law and for not lagging so much behind these new technologies. The report itself is full of various legitimate elements, such as those relating to responsibility, and less important – but I would not underestimate them – that is, ethical ones. It again rightly calls for cross-sectoral cooperation, but it contains, above all, a huge number of security, defence and accountability gaps for the various activities of this already artificial intelligence, this robotics, also for individual citizens. On this occasion, I call for more activity by the Commission, especially in the area of new technologies, because, unfortunately, we are still lagging behind in this area.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, last week I had the pleasure of visiting the Colchester-based business Above Surveying, which uses drones to inspect solar panels for faults and wear and tear, and then carries out analysis on the large amount of information collected. The company has already detected over 20 000 anomalies which, once fixed, boost the amount of green energy that solar panels can produce. Now Above Surveying are investing in AI machine learning and autonomous processes. This will speed up their analysis and aims to, and I quote their CEO here, ‘Take the human out of the loop.’ But far from this being the march of the robots dalek-like, exterminating all jobs before them, the use of AI means that the company can do more, better and quicker, in turn creating more jobs. Embracing the future can mean new opportunities for a skilled workforce.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab A quarter of industrial robots and half of the world's service robots are European Union products – EU, European. Unfortunately, if we look at the results and achievements of the race in research and development, but also in the production of artificial intelligence and robots, the European Union is not doing so well. China and the United States are at the fore front here. Why do I stress this? The point is that it seems – not only that, I am sure – that Artificial Intelligence is the inevitable future for the development of civilization, not only in terms of services, not only in terms of industry, but also in terms of our private lives. It should therefore become a policy priority – not just an industrial policy – of the European Union, and this is not the case. I therefore support this report and call for more dynamic action in this regard.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, in this report you acknowledge that European companies produce half of the world's highly specialised robots, so if something is not broken, let us not fix it. I remind you a few months ago of a report in which you acknowledged how EU regulations have properly destroyed organic crops in the European Union. In a situation of high demand for these products, Europe has slept through this period due to overregulation, as regulations have practically paralysed the development of this market. So we're on our way to do it again. As soon as there is an opportunity to push our toes somewhere, we immediately push them, politicize them, we already read here about fundamental rights, about preventing manipulation. We already know who is the best at manipulating, so I think we are on our way to making the European Union the tail of artificial intelligence through such regulations.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I am pleased to support this report and the work that has been done by Ashley Fox in securing a broad majority on this important and interesting issue. Artificial intelligence (AI) has huge potential to make our economies more efficient and reduce human error in various processes. But it comes with certain challenges that are well-documented. I therefore welcome this report’s emphasis on a system of transparency and accountability around the use of artificial intelligence, while aiming to ensure that the EU is at the cutting edge of technological development and EU citizens and businesses alike can make full use of its benefits.  Also, I would like to suggest that this report by Ashley Fox helps us to highlight the great work that so many United Kingdom MEPs have done here, in this file and in many, many other files, and that should be acknowledged. But I might also say that the House of Commons might benefit from some of Ashley Fox’s proposals in artificial intelligence, because human intelligence seems to be failing there in delivering a sensible and practical Brexit. So they might look at that.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, according to a study recently published in the journal Biological Conservation, insects could disappear from the planet within a hundred years, and this would be a terrible thing. In fact, today, about a third of insect species are endangered. The consequences of this disappearance would be catastrophic for both ecosystems and humanity itself. The authors of the study consider that the main cause of this species loss is clearly the use of pesticides associated with extensive agricultural practices. Therefore, it is already necessary to change our agricultural model by adopting a preventive approach, avoiding exposure to pesticides with the adoption of non-chemical and truly sustainable farming methods, such as crop rotation, physical and mechanical control or the management of natural predators. In the face of Monsanto, we must promote the sustainable solutions that peasants want to implement.

name: Rupert MATTHEWS
text: – Madam President, the use of pesticides in agriculture, horticulture, and indeed in gardening, is absolutely essential, but of course we all recognise that there are some hazards that go along with the use of these chemicals. This is an important report and when it started its progress through this Parliament I was intending to support it. Unfortunately, as it has progressed, various things have been changed and we have now reached a position where some of the targets, some of the figures that are being used, bear little relation to best scientific advice or indeed to any scientific advice. We are getting figures being plucked from the air by pressure groups, by NGOs, and by those with an axe to grind. We even have the situation where they want to control all chemicals that go onto land that might end up in groundwater – which is pretty much all chemicals.  Sadly, this is an example of the bad lawmaking, which so often characterises this place. It could have been great, it could have been worthwhile. Unfortunately, it isn’t, and I won’t be supporting it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I supported this report, which deals with the sustainable use of pesticides. I agree that Member States should rectify their shortcomings without further delay. I agree that we should support research on the secondary effects of pesticides. I am also in support of investment in research, which should develop more sparing and affordable alternatives to current pesticides. All this is as important as the availability of alternatives to maintaining the competitiveness of European agriculture. As for use, pesticides contain ingredients that are highly dangerous to the human body and the environment. There is a need for a strict ban on the use of these substances, this also applies to the import of banned pesticides into the European Union from third countries.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Madam President! We have already talked a lot about the harmfulness of pesticides and their impact on human health and life. Above all, it is important that, of course, we are aware that pesticide residues in food can pose a significant risk to human health, and residues in animal feed also pose a risk to animal health and, of course, enter the food chain. Even the latest meat-related affairs and the risks in this area are too great to sweep the matter under the carpet. There are other risks expressed in relation to endocrine disruptors, significant impacts on genetic changes, and that is why I think that we should invest a lot more resources and, of course, also invest research in so-called non-clinical methods and, above all, in these co-natural methods, which have historically been the driving source and method of farming.  And I think it's once again a rethink of how to encourage small and medium-sized farms to feed as many of our population as possible.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Madam President, the report we adopted today on the sustainable use of pesticides is of the utmost importance for the future of Europe. Agriculture is a sector that has the potential to create and maintain an economy in regions where there are no alternative activities. Unfortunately, however, it is pesticides that have a strong impact on the environment. They increase the crop in the short term, but in the medium and long term they can drain the soils, reduce the benefits of the beneficial organisms in them, the lowering of their fertility. As rapporteur of the Socialists for Bees, I would also like to express my strong concern about the use of a number of preparations that have a negative impact on the main pollinators – bees. I join the Commission's call for Member States to take all necessary measures to promote low-risk pesticides and to prioritise non-chemical options and methods that harm at least health and the natural environment. Stable and sustainable ecosystems are a precondition for a clean environment and hence a diverse and safe food for European citizens.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I have also supported this report, and I want to declare in advance that the long-term, mass use of pesticides has actually been controversial for many years. It is very good that we have taken this step today, because this mass use of pesticides has staggering environmental impacts. I have noticed a report that says that by the end of the century practically all insects are to disappear. These are really incredible impacts that the use of these substances has, to which these very organisms are very sensitive, and I am not talking, of course, about the effects on humans. We must invest resources in research and innovation. This is about our future, because nature pollution has actually reached massive proportions. I would also like to point out that it is precisely the environmental approach and the sustainability of the approach to the environment that should be reflected in other subsidy flows. We should also adapt our reform of the common agricultural policy to this. Sustainability must be our long-term goal.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the European Parliament Directive on the application of patients' rights in cross-border healthcare, which could play a huge role in cases of difficulties in providing care in individual Eu countries or border areas, but which requires authorisations and information on the possibilities of cross-border treatment as well as respect for the rights of patients. Although financial inequality between countries and bureaucracy, which Member States should tackle by organising contact points to provide information on possible reimbursements, can be a major problem. Cross-border care can provide a particular opportunity to treat people with rare diseases. EU-wide cooperation would also benefit from the diagnosis and search for medicines, which are very expensive for the time being, which prevents many patients from being treated. The huge role of cross-border care in cases of pandemics and vaccinations has also been highlighted.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, the right to cross-border care is one of the most important achievements in the EU. Especially in border regions, such as my own beautiful Limburg, residents suffer when access to care is limited by their own national borders. That right to cross-border care has not been without its difficulties. Ordinary people such as Mr Decker and Mr Kohll from Luxembourg have had to fight until the European Court of Justice to get their costs of care repaid abroad. They've done us all a tremendous service. But our work is far from finished. Patients should be helped as well as possible, as quickly as possible and as close to home as possible, even if it is on the other side of the border. So we need to do even more to make that easier. We need to do more to remove annoying bureaucratic obstacles and make cross-border care truly accessible to all. Thank you very much.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, the well-being of patients and the right to receive high-quality care across borders is important, which made it easy to vote in favour of the report. For example, the cross-border healthcare directive benefits tourists and exchange students travelling in other EU countries if they are forced to use medical services while outside their home country. There have been complications in the entry into force of the directive. The Commission was forced to initiate infringement proceedings against up to 26 Member States as a result of late or inadequate implementation. Now all the Member States have announced that they have taken the necessary measures. It is essential that citizens are aware of all their rights. According to a survey conducted in 2015, only less than 20% of citizens felt they knew enough about their rights in cross-border healthcare. As a result, it is important to improve the provision of information to both patients and healthcare professionals.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Madam President, cross-border regions represent 40% of the territory of the European Union and more than 30% of Europeans live in them. My country Bulgaria borders five countries, two of which are members of the European Union. Although less populated, border regions have no less need for adequate healthcare and care.  Given the ageing population in them, I find it irresponsible to close health centers. This, unfortunately, was also done by the government in Bulgaria. 19 health facilities have been closed in the last 3-4 years. There must be a special approach and financial resources to cross-border regions. They cannot be subject to the same market and economic requirements as other regions.  One aspect of cross-border healthcare also affects the lack of sufficient digital services in the sector. I call on the authorities, especially in Bulgaria, to take measures as soon as possible to introduce e-government in the sector, which will reduce red tape and help make it easier for citizens to benefit from healthcare.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. (The sitting was suspended at 2.35 p.m.)

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, the war in Syria has entered yet another new phase, particularly since the US announcement of troop withdrawal, but a political solution to the crisis is still not in sight. It should be clear that the only sustainable way out is a negotiated solution under the auspices of the United Nations (UN), and we will not tire of repeating this. Carving out spheres of influence in a partitioned Syria will not bring peace, security and stability to the country and the region. The north-east of Syria is now the subject of negotiations between the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, the USA, Russia, Turkey and the Syrian regime. Daesh is not defeated yet and it’s essential to prevent terrorists from making a comeback in the future.  We fully understand the security concerns of Turkey, but we also believe they can truly be addressed only if the sovereignty and integrity of the Syrian state is preserved. We hope that any security arrangement for the north will ensure protection for people of all ethnicities and religions, and that it will prevent new suffering and clashes on the ground. In the meantime, the al-Qaeda wing in Syria, formerly known as the al—Nusra Front or Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) is consolidating its control over the Idlib area in the north-west of Syria. This development has forced us to put on hold as a precautionary measure all the Commission programmes brokered in Idlib province. The same happened in the south of Syria, where it was not possible to continue our work. Unfortunately, the needs are dire. The sole positive note is the recent humanitarian delivery in Rukban Camp on the Jordan border where 60 000 Syrians are stranded, including many women and children. Humanitarian organisations need access to the whole country. All the crossing-points towards Syria must stay open, in particular those located in the north-west and the north-east of the country. This is even more urgent during winter, and especially for the hundreds of thousands of displaced people in camps, many of whom are children struggling to survive. We will continue to protect civilians in the event of any offensive and to advocate for the protection of humanitarian workers. In areas controlled by the regime, we hear reports of arbitrary arrests and forced conscription. There has been no progress on the liberation of political detainees. Corruption is mounting, and the war economy is the main source of subsistence for some people. There can be no European contribution to the reconstruction of Syria so long as there is not a political transition firmly on the way. While the Syrian regime does not engage in the UN-led process, and for as long as human rights continue to be violated, this will not change. As to the return of Syrian refugees to their land, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) continues to tell us that the conditions for safe, voluntary, sustainable and dignified return are not yet in place. We also need a system to monitor what happens to returnees, to ensure their protection and to influence conditions for return. We won’t ask Syrians to go back to a place where they risk arbitrary detention, forced conscription and torture. For all these reasons, we continue to support the political process in Geneva as the only just and realistic way to end the war. We cannot afford simply to freeze the conflict. That would be the perfect recipe for more suffering, more radicalisation, more regional instability and more violence. High Representative Federica Mogherini is in close touch with the new UN Special envoy for Syria, Geir Pedersen, about how best to support him in his efforts. He is currently meeting all stakeholders in order to restart the Geneva process. And it is precisely to support the Geneva process that, in mid-March, we will co-host the third Brussels Conference on Syria, with the UN. The conference will focus on three pillars: support for the political process, humanitarian aid, and the regional development component. Our aim will be to ensure pledges to meet the continuing needs of Syrians and of the countries that have welcomed so many refugees. This year we will also host, at the European Parliament in Brussels, a day of dialogue with Ministers, international NGOs and civil society representatives from Syria, Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey. The people of Syria are asking for a sustainable solution to the war. They demand a country where every Syrian can find a place, beyond all differences of faith, ethnicity, politics and social background. The people of Syria need a negotiated political solution that can lead to reconciliation, to reconstruction and to an inclusive and democratic Syria. This continues to be our goal as Europeans. I thank the European Parliament for its support in preparing for the envisaged Syria conference.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Syria (2019/2535 (RSP)."

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, again Syria on the agenda of our Parliament. We're going for the eighth year of conflict. The crisis that does not stop, with figures hitting us: 500 000 dead, 5 700 000 refugees, 12 000 000 people in humanitarian emergency, 6 000 000 of them children; egregious human rights violations, as the Commissioner has just reminded us, and a destroyed country. In a particularly disturbing environment: we have the withdrawal of the United States; a consolidation in the country of 65% of the territory with the Syrian president and his Iranian and Russian allies; tensions on the borders with Turkey and Iraq and therefore a very uncertain environment. An environment where all actors move in a new virtually cold war scenario: the United States has sent Israel to the National Security adviser; Presidents of Russia, Iran and Turkey meet next Thursday in Sochi; Syria is trying to rebuild its alliances with other partners such as the United Arab Emirates and Jordan. And as for the European Union, Commissioner, it is very difficult to go beyond our common strategy, to support international conferences and to mobilize the important resources that we have mobilized, to support the efforts of the special envoy of the Secretary-General of the United Nations and his roadmap. But, Commissioner, is this enough to alleviate the suffering and death of this martyred country which is Syria?

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, some are saying that the war in Syria has ended. I think such a statement is a total misconception. Although we can observe an apparent decrease in fighting, no progress has been made on the underlying causes of the conflict, and peace is still so far away. Yes, the Syrian-Russian-Iranian military alliance has retaken territories held by the opposition forces, including terrorist groups, but they have done so following attacks that involved indiscriminate air strikes and prohibited weapons. The war will end only when we find a way towards a genuine political transition, with full accountability and credible transitional justice; and when we can ensure that the six million refugees and the four million internally displaced Syrians will have a home to return to and will be protected by their state. Only then, can reconstruction start. Justice remains a key word. The Syrian conflict is marked by war crimes, ranging from systematic torture and detention by the Syrian security services, through the Government impeding humanitarian aid, to the consistent use of indiscriminate and prohibited weapons by the Syrian-Russian military alliance. If the Syrian justice system is not capable of providing independent and effective prosecution, we should find an international solution. And, Commissioner, one message for the Commission: the EU cannot accept a fait accompli imposed by Bashar al—Assad and his protectors.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, sadly the survival of the brutal Assad regime is now beyond doubt, and it appears that US troops will shortly leave Syria, which may well leave a security vacuum. With the reports of thousands of former ISIS fighters still scattered across Syria and Iraq, as well as the fact that the Al—Nusra Front successor organisation Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) has consolidated power in the province of Idlib, the threat of Islamist extremism is far from over. Russia’s and Turkey’s defence ministers met yesterday to discuss the situation in Idlib and both sides have agreed that decisive action is needed to curb the advances of HTS and ensure that the demilitarised zone is functioning and effective. With some 3.5 million civilians living in Idlib, we must spare a thought for the brutal conditions they are currently living under, made all the worse by the constant threat of greater bloodshed given the Assad regime’s ruthless determination to retake the province at whatever cost.  In what has increasingly become an international affair marred by various proxy wars, the EU looks on this tragedy as little more than an observer, although the EU’s long—term diplomatic relations with Damascus under Assad will be deeply problematic.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the promise of ‘never again’ dies in Syrian prisons. Those were the words of Josh Rogin in The Washington Post last week. He referenced the extraordinary evidence of the torture in Assad’s death facilities. A brave Syrian citizen called ‘Caesar’ smuggled exactly that evidence out at the risk of his and his family’s life. So now we must play our part, at last, because I agree with those who say that Europe is too much of a payer and not a player vis-à-vis the war in Syria, and it has to change, because we still lack a common EU strategy. And of course the sudden US change of direction in Syria has major consequences while ISIS is not defeated. And I hear a repetition of the words ‘no military solution to the war in Syria can be found’, but of course that doesn’t in and of itself change the fact that military moves do create realities on the ground that we must be realistic about. So I think we need to put pressure on the warring parties, particularly to protect civilians in and around Idlib, people who were forcibly displaced from other parts of the country in the first place; Aleppo and Homs now risk being trapped and targeted again.  We must also make sure that what we do in terms of adopting sanctions vis-à-vis Syria is also implemented. We have targeted sanctions, for example, to hold to account individuals without punishing the entire population, and we have to make sure that our broad package of sanctions is smart and that they are upheld. We heard of Belgian companies shipping tonnes of chemicals to Syria which may have been used to create weapons, and Italy rolled out the red carpet for Ali Mamlouk, a security official who is not supposed to enter the EU. We are not credible if we don’t live up to our own commitments. And lastly, briefly, in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, the pressure on local communities is growing and young and vulnerable people pay the price. It is very urgent to address sexual exploitation of girls and child labour, and avoid them falling into the hands of criminals and militias.

name: Michel REIMON
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Hahn, welcome to the Chamber. I am grateful that you are here and I would like to address you specifically. As we speak, syria may be the last fighting with the Islamic State; the last house battles of Kurdish troops and their allies could take over the last areas there in the next few hours. This is an achievement, a great achievement, and Europe should be grateful for it. Instead, we are once again abandoning the Kurds and their allies. The autonomous region in northeastern Syria is democratic, diverse, is not only Kurdish, but Christians live there, there live Yazidis, there are many Arabs, secular Arabs – the troops now have more Arab soldiers than Kurdish ones. These people are working together to establish an autonomous region democratically, and are very advanced in this. They have schools, they have hospitals, they invest there with little support from Europe. And now they are threatened by a Turkish invasion, by Erdogan, who is about to cross the border and enter. And Europe is doing nothing to protect them from it. I would like to call on you, as Commissioner for Neighbourhood, to put as much pressure as possible on Turkey. If this happens, if this project is destroyed in north-eastern Syria, in Kurdistan, Europe too has a problem. There are 900 European IS fighters in prisons – European citizens, guarded by the Kurds. The Kurds say: we will not kill them, we will release them if Erdogan invades. And these 900 people, 900 fighters, 900 terrorists will make their way to Europe. We have the utmost interest that there will be no invasion down there, that there will be peace. And we, as the European Union, should be grateful to our Kurdish allies and their allies.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, the clearest message that I brought back from my visit to Iraq in December was how the tragedy of Islamic State’s insurgency ultimately has brought all sides of a divided country together against this evil, helping to create a new national identity. Like Iraq, Syria is a deeply complicated problem and I do have concerns over President Trump’s recently announced intention to pull US forces out of Syria. I accept how the West’s recent history of intervention in the Middle East displayed fundamental flaws in our approach, but we must not allow any vacuum to develop that could possibly be exploited by those wishing to further their own agenda. People such as the Kurds must be allowed to remain an important balance in the region, especially in relation to the protection of the various faith groups and ethnic groups across Middle East society. We must, of course, be strict with the application of force overseas, acknowledging the clear risk but remembering, without the West and without America, what remains. We must be realistic in acknowledging the world in which we live. If we do not influence, others will, and we will be even less able to guarantee any eventual outcome. We must approach the future of Syria – both for the future prosperity of the Syrian people and for our own security and influence in the West – in a sensible and coherent manner.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the Atlanticist powers and the petromonarchies that supported and armed the Islamists are no longer the masters of the game in Syria, and I welcome that. It is time for the reconstruction and return of the refugees to their homes. But a sword of Damocles hangs over our countrymen because of the inadequacy of our governments, our lax laws and some of our ideologue judges. 450 radicalized inmates, including 50 jihadists, will be released from prison by the end of the year, according to French justice minister Belloubet. The Minister of the Interior, Christophe Castaner, has just announced the return to France of 130 other terrorist fighters. In Belgium, 182 Islamists have been released into the wild since the start of the Syrian conflict. We urgently need to review our legislation and be relentlessly rigorous. Let us remove the Islamists who have dual nationality from their nationality and expel them. As for the converts of our country who have only one nationality, let us restore for them the death penalty or the prison. They are traitors, let them be tried and condemned as such.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the United States is not actually leaving Syria. They're reording their forces in the area and upgrading their presence. With Iran always in the crosshairs, in a tangle of sharp contrasts, with the finger on the trigger and at the same time haggling with Russia, Israel, Gulf countries and Egypt, and with Turkey, of course, in an upgraded role, which intervenes undisturbed militarily in the region, post-war control of the entire Middle East and the South-East Mediterranean is planned. In the same direction — of course — the European Union, France, Britain, Germany and Italy are intervening militarily and in business. They patrone tripartite axes, such as Israel-Cyprus-Greece, with the latter under syriza government in the role of hinge and flag bearer, as well as their communication channel with Turkey when the haggling is difficult. Among other things, Cyprus is in imminent danger, with a method of dividing it under a NATO umbrella, in addition, of course, to Turkish claims against Greece. So the myth of the SYRIZA government is falling apart that the United States, NATO and the European Union are ensuring peace in the region; only competition, war and misery.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Speaking of the situation in long-running, murderous war-torn Syria, I would first and foremost like to focus on the fate of persecuted Christians. More than 70 countries are suffering extreme persecution of Christians, who are considered the most persecuted religions in the world, according to a report by Open Doors last year. Syria, which lost half of its Christian population during the war, ranks 11th in the disremity "leaderboard." It is commendable that since the outbreak of war, the European Union has provided more than EUR 10 billion in aid to victims of the humanitarian disaster in Syria. However, it is a fundamental matter of principle that it is not enough to 'deal' with the perpetuated crisis, but above all to eliminate the causes of the crisis, namely the end of the war in Syria.  With regard to asylum, the Hungarian model is worthy of follow-up, according to which the best alternative to humanitarian aid is not only to take in hundreds of thousands of refugees, but also to repatriation. According to Viktor Orban, it is not the trouble that needs to be imported into Europe, but the help that needs to be taken where there is trouble. Accordingly, Hungary has established an independent State Secretariat to help persecuted Christians and, to the extent of its strength and economic potential, provides effective support to Syrian Christians for reconstruction and repatriation.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President, can we really talk about the War in Syria as if it were the past? We have witnessed in our own European soil the human rivers of people fleeing from horror. It's a conflict that's still alive, therefore. It was a war of great deception. The new and old Cold War poles have operated in Syria as they please. Both the United States, Russia and China systematically annuling any agreement within the Security Council. Europe has, as always, been left with the feeling of responsibility, very close to guilt, to try to alleviate the exodus and suffering of the Syrian people. The point is that, after ten years of horror, millennial cities and people—thousands and thousands of people—have literally disappeared from the earth. Hundreds of thousands of children have been killed under Russian bombs or under the drones of the international coalition. What happens now? This can't end without those responsible paying. The war has covered up al-Assad's tyranny, but of the Syrian opposition, who tried to fight for democracy, there is not even the memory left. And even the Kurds are in danger. I believe that the third conference for the future of Syria comes when it comes to talking about responsibilities. We cannot sit down and talk about the future as if destruction had not happened. That is what we have to ask for from this Parliament: responsibility. We cannot go beyond this horror without asking for those responsibilities.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Madam President, the foreign policy of nominal accession candidate Turkey can leave the EU anything but untouched. This is certainly true of Ankara's interventions on the Syrian battlefield. Two Turkish military campaigns, in 2016 and 2018, have transformed the enclaves of Jarabulus and Afrin in northern Syria into Turkish military economic protectorates. Insiders speak eloquently of a "Turkish Republic of northern Syria in the making", thus a sequel to the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. Turkish statements in support of Syria's territorial integrity appear to be merely lip-language. Ankara's top priority is to contain the "Kurdish danger" at all costs. Meanwhile, Madam President, reaching out to me from the Christian side are raising cries of distress about northern Syria. Turkey would set out, with or not with militias, to clear the area of Christians. Commissioner, how do the EU's interests in Syria relate to Turkish interests and interventions there? You have already said something about it, but very concisely. Thank you.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, many colleagues have already said it. The conflict in Syria has lasted eight years. Eight years! What began with peaceful protests for democratic values culled in one of the bloodiest wars in the world. There were – we all remember the images – deadly gas attacks and people were slaughtered all over the country. More than 465 000 Syrians were killed, one million were injured and some 12 million people – half the population – were forced to flee. Meanwhile, the chaos trumps in Syria. The Syrian government is still fighting the rebels today. Israel, in turn, is using its weapons against the Iranian-backed forces. And the U.S. is trying to defeat IS. In addition, there are Kurds in the north who in turn are affected by Turkish bombardment.
