And at that moment, President Trump announces that he is withdrawing his troops because IS has been defeated, although specialists are reporting otherwise. Commissioner, I sometimes have the impression that the European Union is doing the talking, as it is here in the Hemisphere today. We are talking about one of the bloodiest conflicts in the world, in which people are chemically bombed and children have been living hopelessly in camps for eight years. And yet nothing happens. There's hardly a cat here. You hardly see anyone when we debate such a conflict! I can only hope that the Commission will do something. I really hope there will be sanctions. I really hope that we will tackle the problem at its root. You know, Commissioner, we were both born in a country of peace. Kids there don't have that luck. Let us finally do everything we can, put our fist on the table and try to end that conflict. I don't have the solution, because then I gave them to you. But you in the Commission are smarter. Bet on it. Give those kids a future again. Thank you very much.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, Syria is clearly an example of the failure of the international community, but it is also an example— another — of its hypocrisy. Those who have really ended the Islamic State have been the Kurdish people. And yet they are now being abandoned to their fate in the face of attacks by the government of Erdogan and Turkey. From here we are looking the other way at the attacks on the civilian population and at the point of exposing the resources of the Kurdish people, such as the tonnes of Afrín olives that are already illegally on the European market and, in particular, in Spain. The European Union should lead political dialogue, multilateral negotiating frameworks, the promotion of international law, to end the Syrian conflict. It is essential that the Kurdish people can secure their social and political conquests, such as gender equality, by ensuring that they are not wiped off the map, now threatened by the entry of the Turkish army into Kurdish territory. And in the meantime, the European Union should break preferential agreements with its partner, such as Turkey, which shears the Kurdish population, even outside Turkey. Everything else: summits, resolutions, beautiful words, will be buried under the economic and geopolitical interests that do not respond to the interests of the majority of the Kurdish or Syrian population. (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. - Colleague, thank you for accepting my blue card. I agree with you that Turkey, President Erdogan, is abusing the situation and attacking the Kurds. They're trying to take advantage of the situation and reduce the Kurdish minority. However, I do not agree with you that the international community is responsible for the conflict. I want to ask you: How is the international community responsible for the civil war that began in 2013?

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: "blue card" response. – Well, I think there would be several questions. The first is that when I was talking about the responsibility of the international community and the responsibility of the European Union, for example, I was referring to the preferential agreements we have with Turkey. Secondly, we are allowing Afrín olives, which are expoliated from the Kurdish people, to be sold by the Turkish government on the European market, to set an example. On the responsibility, too, of the international community, we would have to talk about the different interests that have entered into the war in Turkey and which were totally spurous interests for the Syrian people or the Kurdish people. That's what I was referring to.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The situation in northern Syria remains threatening. On the one hand, Turkey has repeatedly threatened to take military action against the Kurdish fighters in the Rojava region. The Syrian government also wants to regain control throughout the territory. This also applies to the province of Idlib, where about three million civilians live and where numerous armed groups are active. It is essential to prevent military advances in the north by Turkish or Syrian troops and their allies.  European diplomacy must continue to work for a resumption of peace negotiations between Turkey and the PKK. At the Brussels Donors' Conference on Syria, representatives of Syrian civil society must be adequately represented. And refugees from Syria must continue to be able to find protection in Europe through more generous settlement programmes and legal and safe access routes.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab If Syria were to lie elsewhere in the world, no one would be interested in it. There, power may not be the best, but it's not the worst. There are worse countries and they are not bombarded. Well, this is a problem not so much Syria as the Middle East. The Middle East is concentrate on aggression from outside many different centres, many different forces, and several countries have already been completely destroyed there: iraq before, Libya, Tunisia, Egypt. These countries have already been completely destroyed, and there are great human dramas, and this is forgotten. There is talk of Syria, which has not yet been completely destroyed. So if we want to understand what the Middle East is all about today, where these conflicts come from, then we need to know the truth, what are the real real causes of external, military interference in the region. Who fights there and for what, who destroys these countries from the outside and why it destroys. Then we will be able to think rationally about the situation and how to leave.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask Mr Epitideios if he agrees with me that that the example of Syria is a perfect example that when people begin from outside to start bombing and have taken military interventions, they say to support democracy and then the Russians say they intervene to attack Isis, and then someone else intervenes to attack someone else, that this opens the door, it opens up Pandora’s box of all of the problems that we now face and at least by Mr Trump acknowledging and going through with his election pledge of withdrawing, it might be an example to others to start leaving these people alone?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, following President Trump's surprise announcement of the withdrawal of US forces from Syria, the situation in the Middle East has changed and become more confusing. The decision to withdraw was taken without prior consultation with the other parties involved, resulting in a vacuum at the moment, which everyone is trying to fill in order to serve their interests. In the minimum amount of time available to me, I cannot do an in-depth analysis of the situation. But I would like to point out that, while on the Syrian chessboard all players gain advantages, the only one absent is the European Union. Having chosen to be the tail of United States politics since the beginning of the crisis and war, it currently faces two serious risks. One is from upgraded Turkey. You realize that Now Turkey's aggression and provocation will increase. The second danger is from ISIS fanatics, who, although defeated militarily, have been rescued and are preparing to return to their home countries in Europe in various ways to undertake terrorist activity. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: answer a question with a "blue card". – Thank you, Mr President, for your question and I fully agree with you. I do not want to go any further, I am just saying this: the reality is exactly as it is presented and this does not help the general policy, the credibility, but also the prestige of the European Union.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, the Syrian conflict is a very complex matter. You can't board in a few minutes. It is a polyeedric conflict, the sides concerned are many and the deep involvement of third States is also evident. In this context, I am concerned about the limited influence of the European Union, and also that of the United States, which is also now reduced by the announcement of the withdrawal of its troops. In recent times it is clear that, in addition to the Damascus regime, it is Russia, Iran and Turkey that decide. In addition to humanitarian aid to Syrian refugees, the European Union needs to have more influence. In Syria it is not just about the defeat of the Dáesh, it is also about promoting a political process that allows the future of the nation to be decided democratically by the majority of the Syrian people. It is a Mediterranean country, very close. What happens there affects us. I am thinking of the serious refugee crisis of 2015, its enormous impact on the borders of the European Union. We need to gain greater involvement and influence in Syria's present and future. And finally, Commissioner, I would like you to tell us if there were any results in the recent meeting of the High Representative with the Arab League.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Madam President, a few days ago, the former high representative for the CFSP of the European Union, Javier Solana, published an article entitled 'From The Asad to El Asad, through hell'. The single title already shows the absolute failure of a meaningless war. Hundreds of thousands of people have burned their lives in that hell and many more have lost their future. The fire of that hell is not extinguished, but the time has come to think about reconstruction. In material reconstruction, for sure. But above all in rebuilding the lives of the youngest, of these children, millions of children, who have lost their schooling, who have lost their future. The European Union needs to commit to a multi-year plan to educate these children not only in the humanitarian response but also in development cooperation. That is the fundamental objective that we must bring to the third conference of solidarity with Syria.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Madam President! The tragic situation in Syria is, of course, an example of what would happen if this Parliament had the power, as it had heeded, in foreign policy. We are seeing a situation where American interventionism has been condemned over and over and over again, and now we are in chaos with a Syria in our backyard.  Russia, Turkey and Iran - all the powers there, to put it mildly, have interests that are at odds with Those of Europe, are those that have won on the ground, while our closest ally, the Kurdish troops who have fought against Assad and against ISIS, are the ones left behind. It can be said that this is a logical consequence of the European criticism and isolationism towards the United States, which has been waged since Iraq and Afghanistan from large European Union countries, and it is perfectly natural that the Americans should no longer be able to deal with the problems of Europeans. Perhaps we should use the time to reflect on the fact that the transatlantic relationship is the most important security link for Europe, both in the past and in the future, and that the constant attacks on the United States do not make matters any better.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, at first glance, the situation in Syria seems to be stabilising, everything will be fine, but the situation is not good at all. The country is destroyed, the regime has won the war, but it does not have the legitimacy and support of its own people. The Assad regime is holding on to power by force with the help of Iran and Russia. Hundreds of thousands of refugees from Syria have nowhere to go back and cannot return because they would be persecuted. If there is an offensive in Idlíb, it will be another humanitarian disaster. The most worrying is the strengthening of Iran's influence, which, of course, is of particular concern to Israel. The positive news is that they are succeeding in destroying ISIS. The Kurds in the east of the country are fighting them with US support. The EU as a whole does not intervene, but some Member States are engaged in a particular way. I do not consider a single engagement to be happy, but otherwise it is not yet possible. The EU should be much stronger in diplomatic engagement. I agree with my colleague that the prospect for children who have nowhere to go to school is disastrous, because they are hostages to President Assad.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Syria is still a long way from being resolved and in a few weeks' time the third conference on Syria will be hosted by the High Representative.  We must support the need to relaunch the Geneva peace process on the basis of UN Resolution 2254 by establishing criminal responsibility for war crimes committed in recent years. At the same time, Europe must strengthen its role as a humanitarian actor by really investing in the long-term resilience of the Syrian people, as has not been done enough so far, by interacting more with civil society, by involving it more in the organisation of the conference, and by also supporting extraordinary projects such as 'Operation Dove', which creates humanitarian corridors and supports Syrian refugees in Lebanon. , for which it would be necessary to seriously organise a progressive system of safe gradual return. In conclusion, I would like to add a word on the question of Father Paolo Dall'Oglio, a renewed hope for his life. His work for interreligious dialogue is extraordinary and known all over the world. We call for a renewal of his commitment to his release so that he may soon return to deliver his great message of peace.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The situation in Syria is, of course, far from resolved. This can also be seen after this debate, after a variety of voices and, in particular, evaluations. However, I would like to draw attention to one very important fact from my point of view. Well, first of all, all those who deal with Syria institutionally lack consistency. There are no consequences in both these false, genuine or pretend international agreements. There is a lack of consistency in humanitarian aid, and there are no consequences in military action, especially in recent months, and above all in principle, in the gradation of the various problems that are to be solved. I draw this into account because, from this point of view, for these very reasons, we are not getting effective. We know perfectly well who is the player, the most important player, because it is Russia, Israel, Turkey and, of course, Assad – these are all those who, in the current circumstances of this certain mess, the lack of consequences, the lack of a value system, are getting the highest results, unfortunately not the best for the situation in this country.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, yesterday, US—backed Syrian forces launched an attack on Isis’s last stronghold. With fighting intensifying again, I welcome that the local authorities have agreed to set up a transit route near the town of Sour so that humanitarian aid can be provided to those in need faster. However, services in the camp of al—Hol are increasingly stretched. More critical healthcare services and expansion of water and sanitation facilities are urgently needed. Therefore, it’s good that, as the Commissioner announced, the EU is hosting a very timely conference to support the future of Syria and in the region in March. But I still have questions. How do we ensure that the conference will not just focus on humanitarian aid issues but also mobilises international and, in particular, regional support for a step towards a political solution? Secondly, a political transition to the conflict needs to remain a prerequisite to any larger EU investment supporting the Syrian reconstruction process. With President Trump’s decision to pull out of Syria, SDF forces seem forced to collaborate with the Syrian State. Do we then have to accept that Assad is staying, and what impact will this have on defining how the EU can support a political transition?

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Madam President, the war in Syria has claimed the lives of more than 300,000 people and led to 6.3 million refugees and 6.2 million internally displaced persons. It is the greatest humanitarian catastrophe, unparalleled in recent history. The Union can and must lead the peaceful resolution of the conflict, but it cannot do so alone. In this regard, it is good news that the third Conference of the Union and the United Nations on the future of Syria and its region will take place in March. Humanitarian support is needed in addition to the Madad Fund's EUR 1.4 billion, but also political support to accompany the negotiations to reach a peaceful and negotiated solution. The support of the United Nations is essential, in communion with resolution 2254 (2015). There is talk of territorial and definitive defeat of ISIS, but it will not be defeat, nor definitive, nor end of conflict. Syria will need the Union and the international community, but much more involved. Safe return is necessary. Up here we have had the peshmerga fighters and have received the support and unanimous applause of the House. They have the sympathy and support of all of us.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Just so that it is quite clear: if you want to get in touch with the spontaneous speeches (Catch the Eye), please do not use the blue card, but a white hand or hand, otherwise we believe that a question about the procedure of the "blue card" will be registered.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. In recent times, I have been given the right to travel to Syria twice, to visit Christian minorities, to visit Homs, Badula, Aleppo and Damascus. It was clear to me that international and European sanctions on the Syrian regime also affect millions of Syrian people. Syrian people are left without jobs and incomes, and unfortunately one of the root causes is to flee. We can do something to keep the Syrian people and syrian minorities in their home countries. A few weeks ago, the Hungarian government decided to provide significant health assistance to Syrians through humanitarian organizations. Hungary open hospitals project to help people in Aleppo and Homs, regardless of their denomination. Let's not forget, according to UN figures, there are now 36.4 million registered Syrian refugees ready to leave turkey. We need to help them to head home, not to Europe.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, we are talking about no-fly zones, humanitarian corridors, bringing the assad criminal to the ICC, but in fact there was no Europe to run into the Syrian people. And so Putin took advantage and Assad stands. Member States boycotted the Common Security and Defence Policy. In Syria, the results are disastrous for the credibility of the European Union, as the last Euromed survey shows, but especially for the security of Syrians and Europeans, because what we have been manufacturing in Syria is more generations offended and excluded to thicken the ranks of recruits for any terrorist groups. I am not even talking about the Europeans we call euphesively foreign fighters who have thickened the ranks of Daesh and who now our governments irresponsibly wash their hands.  To the betrayal of the Syrian people I add to the betrayal that Europeans and Americans once again play in relation to the Kurdish people, who have so fundamentally fought themselves as our ally against the terrorist forces of Daesh and other terrorist groups. The marriage of convenience between Putin and Erdogan will not last. The European Union cannot be enough to clear its conscience with humanitarian support, it has to demand that Trump not rush it, playing the game of Putin and Erdogan.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to thank Mr Freund for asking this really central question, namely the safety of Syrian citizens. I myself was in Gaziantep in the refugee camp because we from the Committee on Budgets organised refugee aid there. Most of the refugees wanted to return to their homeland. They stand there with their cars and are actually waiting for the starting shot, when it will go back to their villages.  Do you believe that the UN Security Council has a legitimate chance of creating a demilitarised zone in the future, possibly also with UN blue helmets, in order to enable this to return?

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Perhaps – big question mark, hopefully - big call sign – we now see something like the last uplift in Syria. We have also witnessed the effects of the war directly here. Of course, what is our so-called refugee drama compared to what the Syrians have been involved in! The misery of leaving everything lying and standing, of staying in the surrounding neighbouring states, if they have not died in the exchange of gunfire or bombings anyway. Let me take this opportunity to appeal once again: we must not stand by in future when a conflict breaks out in the region once again. Our opportunity, the OPPORTUNITY of the EU, lies in a common strong foreign policy that intervenes diplomatically – timely, self-confident, mediating. We can only do this if we depart from the principle of unanimity. This is too late for Syria, but Syria, I fear, will not be the last country. And we have to be prepared for that. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I believe that we are a long way ahead of the times. I cannot imagine that we are already in a position to assess that. However, it would, of course, be gratifying if we could actually get to a situation where there is something like a safe zone for Syrians. But, of course, I cannot judge that from my point of view here now.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Now we come to the spontaneous speeches. I have the problem that I have very, very, very many requests to speak. I will not be able to allow you all to speak – that is simply impossible. That is why I am now looking at the clock: we have 3.54 p.m., and at 4 p.m. I stop. In other words, if you do not get there, the previous speakers may be responsible for this, because they may have overstayed their speeches. I remind you: you have one minute. Spontaneous speeches

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Dear Chairman, Mr Commissioner, the World Watch list for 2019 will be presented in the European Parliament tomorrow. It is a survey conducted by Open Doors, which lists the 50 countries in the world where the most severe persecution of Christians takes place. Syria is 11th on that list. The year before, she was in 15th place.  We can't hope next year will be better than the last one. Although Daesh began to withdraw from Syria, the anti-Christian mentality remained in a space that is the cradle of Christianity and where Christianity has held up for centuries. We have a responsibility to Syria and Syrian Christians. Christians in Syria say they feel they have no rights and demand that we be their voice.  I am sorry that the Commission and the High Representative do not recognise this matter as a priority. I therefore call on national governments to provide concrete assistance through the Council and their foreign policy to persecuted Christians and to ask the Commission to protect Christians at risk of disappearing where Christianity originated.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, on 16 March it will be one year since the young British woman, Anna Campbell, was killed by Turkish forces whilst defending the city of Afrin with the YPJ.  Anna was a passionate campaigner for social justice who was so sickened by the terrible protracted war in Syria and the untold human suffering that she decided to dedicate her youthful energy to working with the democratic Kurdish forces in northern Syria, the same forces who mounted the only credible opposition to Daesh and Assad in the region. It is they who liberated the Yazidi people trapped on Mount Sinjar. It is they who changed the course of the war on a hilltop in Kobani. It is they who are now rebuilding society in Rojava with women at the heart of a new model of democracy. I know all this not because I read it in a book or a newspaper, but because I led a women’s peace mission there last May and saw the social and physical reconstruction with my own eyes. But, 11 months on, Anna’s body still lies under the rubble in Afrin and neither the British Government nor the Turkish authorities had the decency to repatriate her remains. I urge the EU to demand a compassionate response.

name: Patricia LALONDE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the situation in Syria is very complex and, above all, very urgent for the European Union. Today, the European Union is powerless with its Kurdish ally and will have no role in Syria in the near future if it persists in wanting to consider the reconstruction of Syria without working, like it or not, with the one who now controls 90% of the country: Bashar al-Assad, together with NGOs and civil society. Commissioner, if we want to help the Syrians, we must be able to consider the return of Syrian refugees to Syria as urged by Lebanon, which bears the immense burden of 1.5 million Syrian refugees on its territory, and reconnect, whether we like it or not- once again - with Bashar al-Assad. Therefore, if we want to address the considerable danger that threatens the internal security of the European Union and that is the return of thousands of jihadists imprisoned in the jails of Kurdish fighters and the Syrian regime, who can at any moment be released and come to carry out attacks on the soil of the Member States of the European Union, already bruised by many terrorist attacks , we will have to deal with Damascus, whether we like it or not. Commissioner, how do you intend to get the European Union to act on the basis of the geopolitical reality on the ground in Syria?

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Madam President, we are debating syria for the eighth year in a row and for the eighth time, and I do not know whether the word 'despair' can describe what a Member of the European Parliament feels after eight years of debate. But if the word "despair" doesn't even reflect what we feel, I don't know what word can reflect what Syrians themselves feel. Half a million dead; perhaps, by analogy, more than any state in Europe had during The Second World War. And if the European Union, Mr Hahn, may not have a lever towards Russia or the United States, it has a lever towards Turkey, which is preparing a second or even third invasion of Syria, and I do not know what new bloodshed this invasion can bring. Use whatever weapons the European Parliament and the European Union give your hands to protect the Kurdish population, a population that has fought against ISIS like no other, from a new attack by Turkey.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, yesterday in the House of Commons, the British Foreign Secretary said that Assad will remain in power. This is an admission, not only of the failure of British policy, but also an admission of the failure of the policy of the European Union as a whole which, unconditionally, has, since 2012, supported regime change. The European Union's strategy is now in ruins. In December, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain reopened their embassies in Damascus. The Arab League has probably reintegrated Syria, too. Russia and Iran emerge victorious from this conflict. By its illegal support for Islamist terrorists, the European Union has become permanently marginalized. Now she intends to make the same mistake again by following the Americans to Venezuela.  It is time for the Member States and the European Union to acknowledge their mistake and restore diplomatic relations with the legitimate government of Syria. The future transition will be without the European Union, and that is all the better.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for all their valuable contributions and I think it was a useful exchange. From this debate, I conclude that we are of one mind in terms of support for Syrians and the need to find solutions to the conflict to allow refugees to return to their homes. I also conclude that the European Union engagement needs to be maintained at the same level and under the same conditions. We will not grant legitimacy to the current regime, or its return to the international arena, without progress in Geneva and without changes on the ground in relation to respect for basic human rights and humanitarian laws. The Brussels III Conference will be, even more than the previous conferences, about people. More Syrian people will be present, more civil society representatives will come to talk to the Ministers and international organisations about their dreams, their concerns and the future. This conference will last, altogether, three days. It will include two days of opportunities to meet politicians and to give politicians, and also ordinary citizens and civil society organisations, the opportunity to talk to each other, to exchange views and to look at what could be done in order to improve the humanitarian situation and to help people on the ground. In particular, we will look more closely at the question of women’s empowerment and at ways to alleviate the pain of the most vulnerable Syrians, while continuing our long-term investment and accountability and providing necessary support inside Syria and also outside it, in particular to the host communities which still have a considerable burden in dealing with the Syrian refugees. On the other hand, we have to face the reality that, whether we like it or not, some, if not many, Syrian refugees will not return to Syria any time soon, and in that respect we also need to see how we can support host communities and countries in their efforts to deal with these ongoing challenges.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Here, as announced, I am interrupting the list of speakers with spontaneous speeches. (End of spontaneous speeches)

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Cristian Dan Preda on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the Commission's 2018 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina (2018/2148(INI)) (A8-0467/2018).

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to thank you for your work and your unwavering commitment to the European journey of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Here we are already presenting my fourth and final report of the current European Parliament, on the evolution of this country towards Europe. Having been on an upward trajectory since 2015, Bosnia and Herzegovina has been in a period of marked slowdown since 2017, as I know you are also concerned about it. When I became permanent rapporteur in 2014, my hope was that the country would be presented as a candidate country during this term. Despite our joint efforts to support Bosnia and Herzegovina, this goal has not yet been achieved. And in the run-up to the parliamentary elections on October 7, 2018, the old demons of political divisions and polarization on ethnic grounds have resurfaced. The country entered the campaign with a broken electoral law, several articles of which were invalidated by the Constitutional Court, and which could not be changed, for lack of agreement between the political actors. Four months and five days after the elections, the authorities are not constituted and the reform process has not restarted as desired. Of course, we can always find explanations for these delays: the complexity of the country, its painful past and the trauma of war, as well as the unfinished work of reconciliation, are very real problems that must indeed be taken into account. But make no mistake, what is at stake at the moment is not the overcoming of a new crisis, but indeed the European future of the country. And it is not to us that the political leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina are accountable, but to their own citizens. The people of Bosnia and Herzegovina have the right to a political and institutional system that works and does not discriminate 20. They have the right to live a decent life in their own country, rather than being forced into exile. They have the right to an independent judiciary that does its job without undue political interference. The citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina have the right to live in a society that is not plagued by corruption in every sector of their lives. They also have the right to an effective and depoliticized administration, which is at the service of citizens and not the other way around. Finally, they have the right to free media that inform them objectively and without political pressure.  Membership of the European Union can bring it to them. All this is, in fact, within reach, provided that the political elites abandon their little political games and stop using hatred towards others and division. The time has come for political actors to be responsible, to train the authorities without delay at all levels and to finally show determination in the pursuit of economic and political reforms geared towards the European Union. Coupled with the sending of responses to additional questions from the European Commission, these elements will give Bosnia and Herzegovina a chance to obtain candidate status. Why not this year? Finally, I would like to highlight the very important issue of cooperation with the European Parliament and urge you, Commissioner, to make it a political priority in the next steps in The European journey of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it’s a great pleasure for me to be here today and to discuss with you the Commission’s 2018 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. Let me express my gratitude for the work by Parliament’s rapporteur on Bosnia and Herzegovina, Cristian Dan Preda. Let me start by reiterating our strong commitment to Bosnia and Herzegovina’s identity as a single, united and sovereign country, with a strong European perspective. Following the elections on 7 October 2018 and recalling the conclusions of June 2018, the Council expects Bosnia and Herzegovina’s leaders to engage constructively in the Government’s formation at all levels, in the interests of all citizens, so that the country moves forward with reforms and progress on the European path. Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU membership application of February 2016 represents a strategic commitment to advance towards the EU, but needs to be translated into comprehensive results on the ground. These results cannot be achieved without functioning institutions. We welcome the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s common message of commitment to the country’s EU path and its determination to cooperate in this respect, a message that was clearly sent during the recent visit to Brussels on 29 and 30 January. We welcome the adoption of some EU—oriented reforms, such as the one on excise duties. However, we share your concerns that much time has been lost on divisive rhetoric and pre-electoral campaigning. This has significantly slowed down the pace of reforms. A number of important high—priority areas remain. We need to do more on the inclusive socio-economic reforms; on the reforms in the field of the rule of law, including the fight against corruption and organised crime; on public administration reform; on the fight against radicalisation and terrorism, and we need to further improve cooperation between all levels of government. We share your concerns over the lack of progress in the area of freedom of expression and the media and we expect Bosnia and Herzegovina to intensify efforts to address the issue.  We regret that no compromise was reached with regard to amending the electoral framework ahead of the October 2018 elections. As pointed out in your resolution, all political leaders now need to assume their responsibilities and find a domestic solution with regard to the Federation House of Peoples. Electoral reform should be approached in a spirit of dialogue in order to move the country towards European standards. Turning to the opinion process, let me welcome the commitment of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina to send very soon the additional answers to the Commission’s questionnaire on Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU membership application. We welcome the results already achieved through the coordination mechanism on EU matters and we encourage Bosnia and Herzegovina to make further use of this important tool. We expect the authorities to remain actively committed to the opinion process at all levels and to provide any further input deemed required.  Let me recall that when preparing its opinion, the Commission will pay particular attention to the implementation of the Sejdić-Finci ruling, acknowledging that the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina lists Bosnians, Croats and Serbs as its constituent peoples, along with the others. The Council reiterates that the principles of equality of all citizens and of non-discrimination should be fully warranted.  We will continue to support the country in its efforts to implement reforms and to advance further on its European path. They should keep to the course. The Council will revert to Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU integration process on the basis of the Commission’s expected opinion on the country’s application for EU membership.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Dear Chairman, first I want to thank the Commission, Commissioner Hahn for his great commitment to Bosnia and Herzegovina; Of course, our reporter, Mr. Predi.  It is true that 2015 was an upward trend for Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is also true that in 2017 this trend has somehow stopped and I really consider that bad. It is also very bad that four months after the elections, not all levels of government were formed. Everything we do for Bosnia and Herzegovina and what is done is due to the interests of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and therefore reforms must be implemented. But it also doesn't matter to the European Union, and especially not to Croatia, what our external border looks like and what the situation from our external border looks like. And that's why we care a lot about Bosnia and Herzegovina going the best way. What I want to emphasize here is that we keep sending messages to political leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina that they have to agree, especially on the electoral law, and today I am obliged to mention it here. So the electoral law has to change and that's something that's the basis of all the beginnings of reforms, etc. Manipulations with elections that are evidently happening must be avoided, and here I refer specifically to the members of the Croatian people and the Croatian people, who do not have equal rights in Bosnia and Herzegovina when it comes to elections. Therefore, we are obliged to note this. I believe that if an agreement were reached on this, everything would take a better path.  Therefore, the new political leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina have a great responsibility and it is their responsibility, and it is up to the Commission and us from the European Union to help them do so.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I really would like to thank the rapporteur, Cristian Dan Preda, for the resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina and I would also like to thank you, Mr Preda, but also some of your colleagues for your tireless work in and with the country. We are far from having some concrete results but I think we share the same interests and need to push the country, not only in the European direction, but with the consequence to improve living conditions of people in the country, because this is exactly what counts, what is relevant and what should be our – once again – tireless aim.  In that respect we welcome the text, which is a balanced one and which is largely in line with the Commission’s April 2018 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. It reflects well the situation in the country, including the challenges and outstanding issues on Bosnia and Herzegovina’s European integration path.  I welcome the support this resolution provides for the EU approach towards Bosnia and Herzegovina. This is particularly essential at a very critical moment in time for the country and its newly elected leaders. A time when the commitments taken before the elections need to be translated into concrete reforms. A time when governments need to be formed across the country and a time when the divisive rhetoric of the campaigning stresses the need for reconciliation, unity and consensus building around the country’s objective, meaning EU integration. This was the main message to Bosnia and Herzegovina’s Presidency members whom President Tusk, President Juncker, High Representative Mogherini and myself had the opportunity to meet two weeks ago in Brussels. This was their first joint trip abroad as newly elected Presidency members, a token of their commitment to advance towards the EU in line with what the citizens of their country demand. And this is in the beginning of a critical year for Bosnia and Herzegovina during which we would like to see irreversible progress towards the European Union. At the same time, we particularly stressed to Presidency members that comprehensive reforms, as done by other countries at similar stages in the process, are required. This is not only about providing answers to our questions stemming from the Opinion Questionnaire – which we expect soon and in a consolidated manner, may I say very clearly – but delivering on rule of law, fundamental rights, electoral reform, public administration, good governance, as well as further harmonisation with EU rules and norms. The capacity of the newly elected leaders to deliver will be the yardstick upon which the EU will assess Bosnia and Herzegovina’s readiness to further advance towards the Union. In this respect the Commission is fully dedicated to advancing Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU perspective. Our upcoming Opinion on the country’s application for Union membership will provide for the first time a comprehensive roadmap of reforms for the country to carry out, for the first time against the entire obligations EU Member States have. We are stepping up our technical assistance in the country with dedicated field support in the key areas of rule of law and fundamental rights, including the monitoring of a number of high—profile cases. The Commission has also now doubled the financial assistance envelope for Bosnia and Herzegovina – EUR 80 million per year in grants for the period 2017-2020 – to support the country implementing a number of countrywide strategies, such as on energy, environment or rural development. And this in addition to the support provided as part of the regional envelope, notably on connectivity agenda projects. To conclude, I would like to stress that the Commission will continue to support Bosnia and Herzegovina as we believe that the future of this country lies in the Union. At the same time, there are outstanding challenges which need to be seriously addressed, requiring substantial efforts from the country’s elected leaders. We, the European Union institutions, can help and provide guidance, but it’s only they who can deliver on their citizens’ aspirations. In this respect I will visit Sarajevo, most likely at the end of March to take stock of the progress towards forming governments and resuming with the necessary reforms.  But the thing that is necessary and which we have to emphasise and to stress again and again is: everybody in the country tells us they are all in favour of the European perspective, but what we are missing, what we lack is really consistent and coherent action on the ground by all political parties and ethnicities really to move in a united, coherent way towards this goal, which is a goal of more than 80% of citizens in this country.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, on behalf of Mr Papadakis, who cannot be here today, thank you very much for the good work done on Cristian Preda. The report is quite complete, very detailed and shows the real situation as we see it. The road to the European Union is open for Bosnia and Herzegovina. I would like to make it clear that we Social Democrats, too, want Bosnia and Herzegovina to find this way into the EU. And precisely because we want it and out of sympathy with the people of the country, I want to make a few critical sentences. We hope that the necessary reform processes in the country will proceed faster and better. The reconciliation process has still not been vigorously pursued. There is still too much separating and too little in common in the country, and the rulers are still not making any attempt to truly bury what divides them. The Dayton Agreement was a great effort and an excellent achievement to end the war, but obviously it does not help to establish a common state. That is why we believe that an initiative for a Dayton II must come from Brussels. Time and again, when I am in the country, I have the impression that more and more people are yearning for coexistence and that the responsible politicians are lagging behind this development. Those in charge in Bosnia and Herzegovina will one day have to face up to the population and explain why they are following old national feelings, rather than bringing a modern new Bosnia closer to the EU.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, in the autumn of last year, an interesting scientific analysis was published in Vienna entitled "Honest broker or competitor to the EU? Turkey and its role in the Balkans." Relations between Ankara and Sarajevo are prominent in this analysis. These are a natural consequence of the close personal and political ties between President Erdoğan and his Bosnian counterpart Izetbegović. With this observation, I come to paragraph 40 of the solid report by my honourable colleague Mr Preda. This is, after all, the growing influence of foreign powers in Bosnia and Herzegovina. My question to the Council and the Commission: think about the title of the scientific analysis mentioned: 'Turkey honest broker or competitor to the EU in Bosnia and Herzegovina?' The creation of a new pro-Turkish, pro-Erdoğan lobbying organisation 'Union of European Balkan Democrats' in Bosnia underlines the political importance of this question. A clear European response is still of greater importance, because growing Turkish influence in the Balkans will inflame tensions between ethnic and religious groups. And we certainly don't want to go down that road. Thank you.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Dear Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues and colleagues, first of all thank you, of course, to Mr. Preda for his good cooperation and for a good report. This is the last report in this parliament and after five years it is an opportunity to evaluate the activities, i.e. the success of Bosnia and Herzegovina along the way. So, some small technical advances were made, the program reform was adopted, the coordination mechanism, the application for membership was submitted, the first set of questions was answered. Similarly, some sectoral strategies have been adopted, but the fundamental problem of the country, namely its dysfunction and internal conflicts and divisions, mainly along ethnic lines, this problem of Bosnia and Herzegovina remains and can even be argued, it is a question of attitude and subjective impression, it can be argued even that the situation today is worse in this sense, in terms of internal relations, functionality of the state, than it was five years ago.  It is certainly a good thing that the European Union, all its political bodies, has adopted a clear position on the importance of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as other countries from this area and the need for these countries to join the European Union. That's a good thing.  The Commission is also doing well, although the reports may be some way more consistent. Often there is a difference between the description and the final score, there is no hierarchy of goals. The Commission could therefore do much better here, but obviously what we have been doing over the past five years is not enough. It will take even stronger engagement from the Commission and much more politically focused action by both the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union to move Bosnia and Herzegovina towards its own stability towards the European Union with faster steps.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – Mr President, So, Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country of many contradictions. A country that has many in common, and throughout its history, various riverbeds have been drawn, just as the River Drina has been through history, and I highly recommend all those who have not read, the book of the Nobel laureate Andrića Most na Drina, because it can be even easier to understand this diversity and at the same time the art of coexistence and coexistence.  Bosnia and Herzegovina has moved towards European integration and, of course, along this path, which is not easy, there are quite a few obstacles to it. We all, of course, want the countries of the Western Balkans to become part of the European family, but of course we also need to go through a certain process of adaptation and, of course, also change and reform, which then justify this path.  There are differences of opinion or different views in this report that you have before you, but it is particularly common that there are many things that need to be done, that there is still a great deal of room for improvement, from, of course, the issue of corruption, organised crime, reforms in the areas of justice, economics, social security, attitudes towards minorities, and there is also no shortage of environmental challenges, including freedom of the media and education.  Above all, I would like to conclude by saying this: especially when we talk about Bosnia, we must also think of the people who live there, of course, their future, and, despite the differences, also have to be aware of this, because, of course, a strong Bosnia means a strong Europe.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the former Yugoslav republics with the most complex population structure. In addition to living here the whole spectrum of different nationalities of the Balkans, a special religious structure of the population has been established over the centuries. In cities, Muslims dominated, in the countryside Orthodox. In a small area in the north-east of the country, the population of the Catholic faith traditionally lives. So-called Serbs, so-called Bosnians and so-called Croats speak all three dialects of the common language, regardless of religion. After a bloody war backed by external forces, two structural units were established in the territory. One of them in the northeast – the Republic of Serbia – and the other is the Muslim-Croatian Federation.  It is completely incomprehensible to me that the European Union has been trying to change this situation from the beginning, regardless of the wishes of the people of the country. After all, the Dayton Peace Agreement sets out certain procedures, and it is not possible to require a change in the state order as part of the negotiating conditions for any country to join the European Union. Bosnia and Herzegovina has a number of problems that are far more important for the lives of local people. First of all, it is about connecting energy networks with neighbouring states, improving rail and road infrastructure, and a clear agreement on the rules of coexistence with important neighbours, in particular Serbia, and, as my colleague mentioned here, croatia. As regards the permanent deployment of the dog head of the Serbian Republic's leadership, the withholding of crimes committed in the war by Croatian and Muslim forces, including the so-called Srebrenica massacre, i am very concerned about these efforts. European Union assistance must consist not only of constantly laying new requirements, but also of practical cooperation in the development of education, the economy, social and health institutions. As the report is unbalanced, I cannot support this text.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, whenever I hear of these discussions and reports on integration and bringing in new nations into the EU, I find myself feeling like I’m in my favourite TV series. I’m a big fan of Star Trek and I don’t know if you’ve ever seen it but there’s an organisation there, a life form called the Borg and what they say, they have a quote they use: ‘We are the Borg. Lower your shields and surrender your ships. We will add your biological and technological distinctiveness to our own. Your culture will adapt to service us. Resistance is futile’. And they travel around the universe in huge hermetically—sealed, hi—tech, temperature—controlled, artificially—lit structures and what they do is they find a way of creating thralls. People who will become part of them and serve them. Now, when we look at this in the terms of the reality here, we have a situation where the EU Empire seeks to bring more people in, but they don’t do it with violence and attacking people, of course, it’s done with grants, loans, trade and the promise of betterment. But the point is, when you continually expand in this manner, especially into very sensitive areas like this, you need to be very careful what you do. You also need to be extremely careful of thinking, where is the money going to come from, because you continue to incorporate more and more nations into this organisation and, constantly seeking to expand, you seem to be forgetting that at some point in the very near future you’re going to be running a lot lower on money because – certainly if there isn’t a deal reached soon with Brexit – you’re going to be tens of billions of pounds short. So, I think you need to be very careful in what carrots you offer to people before you try to assimilate any more of the world.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Bosnia, as this report also makes honest and clear, is a bit of a metaphor for the enormous difficulties that we have in the long and difficult and difficult process of accession to the European Union.  This is a country that has made very little progress since this process began. And we can also ask ourselves whether this European Union, with the limited economic and financial horizons, has done everything necessary to do, or would I say up to the task of leading these peoples and situations by the hand, these countries whose complexity arising from the historical reasons with which we are all familiar, pose to it, and its geopolitical position itself shows that it is , force him to be a crossroads of problems and also of dangers.  And as far as the dangers are concerned, we certainly cannot fail to stress the seriousness of the risk of infiltration of foreign fighters, and therefore of fighters of Islamist terrorism. This is a very serious danger.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, first, my thanks and appreciation to the rapporteur for his devoted and good work on this issue over the past five years. The past months, unfortunately, have not seen major progress in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) on its European accession path. The main message to the political leaders of the country is to finish constituting all the relevant bodies, submit the remaining follow-up answers to the questionnaire and immediately adopt the rules of procedure of the Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee (SAPC). There is an exhaustive list of issues that BiH needs to address. The sense of urgency is as present as ever. Commitment to the reform agenda, and reforms aimed at achieving a fully functioning state with the rule of law at its core, are the main tasks ahead. The EU stands ready to facilitate the difficult discussions on electoral and constitutional reforms. I urge the political leaders of BiH to use this opportunity and offer of EU help. I would also like to commend those in BiH who fight for freedom of expression and against hate speech and religious hatred, and who promote inclusion, such as the high-school students from Jajce who were awarded the 2018 Max van der Stoel Award in recognition of their outstanding courage and inspirational activism. As this is the last discussion on BiH in the current parliamentary term, I want to say that I really believe in the European perspective for Bosnia and Herzegovina, in the power of the voice of Bosnians, and in their power to fight for a European future for their country.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. Chairman, although since 2015 we regularly discuss the annual report on Bosnia and Herzegovina in the European Parliament, rather than the progress report, the political reality is that progress is largely lacking. What's more, there's been a evident backlash lately. This is a lack of political, economic and social reforms, prompting already poor cross-party relations and blockades of institutions. Last year was marked by too long an election campaign, but also by post-election infighting, as elections were held without harmonising the electoral law with that of the constitutional court.  Unfortunately, the parliamentary dimension of cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina does not exist. Post-election events confirm the justified reference to respect for the principle of equivalence, subsidiarity and federalism found in the reports from 2013 to 2014. This is necessary for Bosnia and Herzegovina to complete the transition to an effective, inclusive and fully functioning state of guaranteed equality and equality. Unfortunately, these key elements were omitted from this year's document. I consider this a serious setback, which is why I cannot support this report.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the report shows that the Union is unfortunately cemented in positions that do not respect reality. It regrets that the election campaign focused on what I quote are "problems of division from the past", which proves that Brussels does not understand that ethnic division in BiH is not only a matter of the wartime past, but also of the present and the future. In BiH, shared identity is weak and divisions are a reality that will not cease to exist just because some want it badly. Especially not in the current circumstances that the EU has also helped create. For too long, this wonderful country where I was born was a laboratory for the social experiments of the world's powerful! The European Union, which so advocates democracy and diversity, allows both to be seamed in BiH. Croats were also chosen by another people in this election as the Croatian member of the Presidency, while the EU institutions talk about communion. There can be no communion where there is no appreciation of the basic political rights of one people.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, my colleague, Mr Preda, is still in the Europeanist wind of a Europe that does not work and has never worked. Once again, we are trying to make Bosnia and Herzegovina a post-national state and not to recognize the three nationalities with each of the constitutional rights. This strategy can only lead to the domination of the majority Muslim population and chronic instability. His condemnation of the nationalist discourse is implicitly a condemnation of the Serbian republic. There is always the will of the European Union and NATO to play a strategy of destroying a cultural and spiritual Europe, with its identities and nations. The integration of Bosnia into Europe is always the rejection of the Europe of nations and national identities. This Europe is over, it really never existed. We must build a Europe of the cooperation of nations.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Mr President, I am pleased that today we are discussing the progress report in Bosnia and Herzegovina. If ever, the country needs our help right now.  The recent visit of the three members of the Presidency to Brussels has given hope that, despite numerous disagreements between bosnian, Croatian and Serbian leaders, there is also much in common. Among other things, a consensus on continuing towards a path towards a european union. The promises of joint leadership of Bosnia and Herzegovina are in vain if they do not put them into practice. The conditions that the country must fulfil are clear: to form a government as soon as possible, to deliver answers to additional questions from the Commission and to continue reforms, both in the area of the rule of law and in the social economy. In the last debate in the European Parliament, I would like to draw attention to two more. Firstly, I call on my parliamentary colleagues and the Member States not to forget the enlargement policy and Bosnia and Herzegovina in the year of the European elections, even if this does not yield political points. And secondly, I call on the leaders in Bosnia to use the common objective of rapprochement with the Union to overcome the differences between the various political and ethnic forces in the country.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Dear Chairman, Distinguished Commissioner Hahn, I welcome the agreement reached on Sunday by the leaders of the Croatian and Serbian constituent communities in Mostar to accelerate the formation of a new Council of Ministers in accordance with your recommendations and those of High Commissioner Mogherini, which you made after the elections.  The leaders of the Bosniak constituent community should be encouraged to join these efforts to establish a Council of Ministers because we are very much faced in Bosnia and Herzegovina with a burning crisis, especially in the canton of Bihać where the functional Council of Ministers is invoked and I think it is high time.  I look with worrying zeal at the calls of the Bosniak leader, Mr. Komsic and his threats to the Republic of Croatia. I hope that this will soon cease and that the unconstructive way of addressing one neighbouring country and one member of the European Union will soon cease.  I expect you to get as much help from Brussels as possible and finally move from Dayton to Brussels because Dayton has been broken a long time ago and Brussels hasn't even started yet.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, first of all, I thank my colleague Predi for accepting some of my proposals and they are embedded in the report we are discussing today. But when we talk about the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, it seems that despite the efforts we make and the recommendations we make, everything remains a dead letter on paper. Despite a request from the Council and Parliament, the electoral law has not been changed in Bosnia and Herzegovina, resulting in additional discrimination against Croats who, as a constituent people, are not even able to elect their own member of the presidency. This is only the continuity of systematic discrimination against Croats in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which occurs in all segments of their lives.  Bosnia and Herzegovina's place is in the European Union. I want that with all my heart. But Bosnia and Herzegovina must first become a functioning state because the current institutional and legal framework is unsatisfactory and unsustainable, and that is why Dayton needs to experience upgrading and modification.  On the other hand, I have to draw special attention here to the issue of environmental protection. Despite the adoption of my amendments urging Bosnia and Herzegovina to bring the work of the refinery in Bosanski Brod in line with environmental standards, there is still no progress and the citizens of Slavonski Brod suffer the consequences as a result. We expect Bosnia and Herzegovina as a signatory to international environmental conventions to start adhering to their provisions. We are also concerned about the increase in radicalisation and the return of foreign fighters to Bosnia and Herzegovina, which poses a security challenge for the entire region. Therefore, I call on the authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina to give a real and uncompromising answer to this burning question.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Even 20 years after Dayton, Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet recovered from the consequences of this war. There were many appeals and well-meaning assurances, and far too many, because they were never followed by action. That is why there are still these ethnic tensions. A sense of hopelessness has spread, and external influence is palpable everywhere. The country has become a pawn in geopolitical interests.  There is only one way to get out of this dilemma: a European perspective. But this requires much more than an annual debate in the European Parliament. We need a new dynamic that must come from us. People, especially young people, as the recent protests have shown, are waiting for it. Let me quote a young woman, a student, from Jajce: for our generation, it is not important who has what nationality and what faith, but that we have a good time together.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Almost 25 years ago, I was in Sarajevo with humanitarian aid on the 1000th day of the siege of this city, now, recently, with a visit by the European Parliament primarily to show or monitor the state of security. I must say that I would rather not go back to that situation 25 years ago, to such a war, to these tensions, but unfortunately the situation in this country today is full of tensions and full of threats. It must be remembered that the offer of the European Parliament, the European Union to this country was a mobilising offer. But this mobilizing element stops working. We do not have time to pull such projects, such as those of this type of country in this situation, out of internal crises. We need a gradation of objectives, an extraordinary consistency and, above all, consistency in all the behaviour that flows from the European Parliament to this country.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, Bosnia and Herzegovina stands. Bosnia and Herzegovina is not moving forward. The main blame is on their politicians. I have been following this since 1991, since I have been in politics, I know exactly what is happening in Bosnia and Herzegovina and, unfortunately, I must note that Bosnian politicians are not up to the needs of the people in Bosnia and Herzegovina.  But what pleases me is that religious grandees are even more prosperous and avant-garde than politicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Paradoxically, in the Balkans, but it seems to me that this is the case and there is little hope there. The proportion mr. Hahn is making in his efforts to bring Bosnia and Herzegovina closer to the European Union is something to congratulate, but I want to warn you about one problem, the problem of migrants in Bosnia and Herzegovina, especially in the Una-Sana Canton. Let's worry about that because it's on the border with the European Union.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I want to support Mr Preda's report, which I think is of good quality and balanced, and I thank you for it. I am convinced, Commissioner, that we must, permanently, patiently, offer the Balkan peoples a European future. This means, if we are talking about the fact that the reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina are not very successful, this cannot lead to Europe to ease up and reduce dialogue with Bosnia and Herzegovina. If we do, it will be a huge geopolitical mistake, and the space will be filled by Russia, which now communicates significantly with the Serbian part of the ethnic group from that state. And we just can't afford that. So, please, let us also take these geopolitical views into account, and let us therefore again patiently try to help Bosnia and Herzegovina in reforms that would bring it closer to the European Union, so that at last this country can obtain the status of candidate country. This is extremely important for us, if we do not do so, then Russia, Turkey and other countries will strengthen in the Balkans.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, who lit up the nationalisms in Bosnia and elsewhere to break up Yugoslavia? NATO and the European Union. And the situation in Bosnia continues to be one of the last outstanding issues for the Euro-Atlantic integration of the Western Balkans, amid sharp competition from The Americans, NATO and the European Union with Russia and China. The nationalisms that have been cultivated are not going to stop. They spark conflict and change borders, twenty years later, as now with Kosovo and Serbia, opening the appetite to others who are demanding border changes, such as Turkey. The shameful, NATO-cut, agreement of the Prespas between Tsipras and Zaev is seen as an example of a settlement, not for dispute resolution, but for the over-victory of imperialist interests in the crucial Balkans. For example, the transformation — again — in the last days of the port of Thessaloniki into a NATO base, making it a potential military target of the rival coalitions, which contradicts SYRIZA's myth of stability with NATO and the European Union. Security, peace and friendship of the peoples in the Balkans means one thing: to leave NATO, the Americans and the European Union.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for keeping up the pace of the work, not just in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but even in the region. It’s impressive, actually. I agree with the rapporteur that the pace of reforms in the country has been slowed down by the elections. We are still waiting for the formation of the government, we don’t have formal cooperation with the Parliament and rule of law has not been improved as we had hoped. But there are encouraging signs, both in the long term and the short term. In the short term, there is better economic governance, we have seen the encouraging results in the local elections, we have a decreasing number of returnees from the areas affected by terrorism, and we have seen three Presidents come here and work together. It’s actually the first time in my life that I have seen them together.  So it is extremely important to keep up the pace of the European perspective. It gives the perspective to the country and is a motor for the reforms. Thank you for doing that.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, competition between the United States and Russia in the Balkans exacerbates the contradictions and, of course, the problems that Dayton has not been able to solve, which have to do with the peaceful coexistence of ethnicities and minorities in Bosnia, are intensifying. It is certain that we must repeat what we said in 2017 in this Chamber: that there should be fair treatment of minorities within Bosnia and Herzegovina, that the government must address the enormous problems that exist in relation to corruption and organised crime, that protection must be ensured — especially of the Roma, the application of the rule of law , meritocracy in public administration and, more generally, the protection of human rights. I therefore believe that everything we have said before has not been resolved in Bosnia and Herzegovina's path to the European Union. This is an undertaking which seems to be unable to be achieved.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I welcome the Commissioner. What I want to emphasize is that the security and stability of Bosnia and Herzegovina is essential for the security and stability of the entire European Union. We cannot talk about political stability when one constituent people cannot elect their representative and participate equally in decision-making processes in the institutions of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The electoral law must be changed. This, of course, was emphasized by other colleagues, and therefore I will turn to another area that may not have been sufficiently emphasized, which is our influence in Bosnia and Herzegovina, i.e. the participation of the European Union in the development programs and processes of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Let us ask ourselves how many projects we have financed with guarantees from the European Fund for Strategic Investments in Bosnia and Herzegovina: zero. How well have we used the IPU, is 100% contracted, have we tried to develop some other, additional projects that will help the state in integration? What have we done about joint decision-making, organizing conferences? I think we can do a lot more.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes the expected adoption of the resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina. I would again like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Preda, for his high-quality report. I would also like to thank all the Members who have actively participated in its production and in today’s debate and have shown a keen interest in Bosnia and Herzegovina’s European future. The Commission takes note of this resolution and will take Parliament’s views into account, including those expressed today. We particularly share Parliament’s view that the authorities stemming from the October 2018 elections should be formed as soon as possible, without conditions, and that work on the necessary reforms should be resumed. This is particularly necessary against the backdrop of the upcoming Commission opinion on Bosnia and Herzegovina’s application for EU membership, provided we receive the outstanding answers to our questions. I have also taken note of the call to Bosnia and Herzegovina to ensure the functioning of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement and of the associated parliamentary committee, in line with the EU’s standards and the country’s commitments under the agreement. I will raise this issue with the Bosnia and Herzegovina leadership, and the Commission will review the implementation of the Stabilisation and Association provisions by Bosnia and Herzegovina in the forthcoming opinion.  Finally, I would like to stress that the Commission will spare no effort in supporting Bosnia and Herzegovina on its path towards the European Union. As Ms Maletić and others said, this includes, for instance, identifying and creating new opportunities in terms of programmes and even financing. The Commission will, of course, keep Parliament informed in the coming months on future developments regarding Bosnia and Herzegovina. Once again, thank you for your support.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, once more let me reiterate our gratitude for the excellent work of the rapporteur and also for all the support he got from Parliament.  Romania’s Presidency of the Council has put it as a priority to be a friend of the Western Balkans and is going to do its best to advance the region and the countries of the region on their European path. We are fully decided to help all of the countries of the Western Balkans. Of course, they need to pass the reforms needed and I think that in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina there is an urgent need for formation of the government at all levels and to decisively move with the implementation of reforms. This would help us as well.  I am planning too to go to Sarajevo and I think the Romanian Presidency is going to pay a visit to all the countries of the Western Balkans, before, I think, the crucial discussion we will have in the Council in June. At the same time, one of the events of the Romanian Presidency of the Council is exactly about how to reconcile the region with the past. It’s an event that is focused on the youth of the region and how important it is to overcome the divisive rhetoric and to have a real historical reconciliation in the region.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I will start with the suggestion made by the Minister, Mr Ciamba, because I think it is really a great initiative to work with young people, to talk to them about Europe and to see how this reconciliation could be achieved. As we have seen today, the debate on Bosnia and Herzegovina has gone in all directions: our British colleague brought Star Trek into the debate, the Greek colleague was talking about NATO at the port of Thessaloniki, and I wanted to ask him, if we are talking about the real strategic issues, why was the port of Piraeus given to the Chinese. But with Bosnia and Herzegovina, we are still talking about one of our countries in the Western Balkans. This country is a European country thanks to the action of our Croatian friends: 95 per cent of the Croats in Bosnia and Herzegovina are European citizens and I have always said that there is no Mep, in particular, and no European nation closer to Bosnia and Herzegovina than the Croats. But perhaps the Croats should also think of others, not just themselves. They will be true supporters of the integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina on the day when they will also talk about others and not just Croats, who are already European citizens. Let me also suggest to our socialist friends and our liberal friends to make a small effort and to integrate political parties from Bosnia and Herzegovina into their network because we, the EPP, are very well represented there, but there is no liberal party or socialist party in Bosnia and Herzegovina. How do you help them if you don't have contacts, if you don't work with your friends on the spot? I know it is not easy, but to really help Bosnia and Herzegovina become European, we must move from this rhetoric to real action on the ground.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, February 13, 2019. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments) Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – Bosnia and Herzegovina has submitted an application for EU membership, acknowledging its commitment to the EU, but unfortunately the adoption of EU-related reforms in the country has slowed since mid-2017.
