It is regrettable that the election campaign leading up to the general election on 7 October 2018 was dominated by nationalist and ethnic rhetoric, marked by segmentation and not focused on solving the everyday problems of citizens, which deepens the gap between the three constituent nations. As in many of my speeches, I would like to stress that political leaders must do everything possible to avoid nationalist rhetoric that divides the people of the country and sends a political message that promotes cooperation and balances the relationship between the three peoples in the country. I condemn all forms of discrimination, it is important that all countries wishing to be members of the European Union must respect democratic principles, the cultural and linguistic diversity of nations, ensure equal access to education, employment, the health system for ethnic and national minorities and the possibility of participation of representatives of national minorities in political and public life. Bosnia and Herzegovina must respect fundamental human rights and end open discrimination if it is to be a member of the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. Today, Bosnia seems to be stuck in limbo: on the one hand, the need for change towards democratic consolidation that is loudly demanded by the younger generation. On the other hand, a policy of "preserving" the status quo based on a complex institutional architecture dating back to the 1995 Dayton Agreements and on continuing ethnic divisions and rivalries. This is clearly demonstrated by the results and modalities of the recent 'general' elections held on 7 October, without closing the legal loopholes and making the necessary changes to the electoral law - as identified by the Constitutional Court and the European Court - despite the intervention of EU and US ambassadors in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the participation of the Venice Commission. Despite formal respect for procedures and elections, which have been defined as competitive and orderly, the problem remains of a state system that violates the European Convention on Human Rights. It is clear that greater efforts are needed to implement a reform path focused on the rights of individuals, starting with constitutional reform, as the European Court of Human Rights has also indicated, so that all citizens are treated equally, regardless of ethnic ity.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – Bosnia and Herzegovina is a very important country in the Western Balkan region. As the region continues its push to be integrated into the European Union, the EU understands the volatility of peace in the region, which explains the EU’s extensive support for democracy, freedom, the rule of law, human rights and economic development in that country. Unfortunately, in that country there is an increasing influence of foreign powers and there is a real need for a stronger EU engagement which remains the best way to ensure progress towards European values, stability and prosperity there. The report underlines many issues with which the young country cannot cope, such as human trafficking, the rule of law, corruption, gender equality and respect for human rights. In this context, I call on the EU Commission to increase its financial and political support for that country and to encourage its EU membership. On the other hand, I call on the Bosnian authorities to commit more political will and efforts to the required reforms and to work together in the name of the common future of the Bosnian people and all Bosnian autonomous regions.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President-in-Office of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic, thank you for accepting the invitation of the European Parliament to set out the Italian Government's vision of the future of Europe. Italy is one of the founding countries and we are pleased to be able to start this debate with you on the major issues affecting half a billion people. As you know, the European Parliament is strongly committed to certain issues of great interest to citizens. We want to be the democratic heart of Europe. We are the only institution elected by the citizens and we have fought hard for an increase in the Eu ropean Union budget from 1.1 to 1.3, focusing on the issue of own resources, and we have chosen to engage clearly on the issue of immigration as well. Parliament is in favour of more investment on the African continent to solve the problem upstream. On the issue of refugees, the European Parliament has for months approved a proposal of its own which is on the Council's table and we ask you to be a leading player in the adoption of a text which, in our opinion, can ease the tension, especially in the countries of the south of the Union, in the countries most burdened by the issue of refugees. On the issue of Brexit, the European Parliament places great emphasis on protecting EUROPEAN citizens living in the UK. On major infrastructure, we have voted for a substantial increase in funding so that the European infrastructure system can promote growth. As far as foreign policy is concerned, we are in for a common foreign and defence policy. We recently chose to ask the Member States to recognise venezuela's interim President, Mr Guaidò, under the Venezuelan Constitution. My final point concerns Parliament – and I know that this is part of your government's programme – we want a European Parliament that counts more, that has the power of legislative initiative like all parliaments in the way and that also has the powers of inquiry, which, under the Treaty, already exists but which it has not yet been able to exercise. Mr President, I give you the floor straight away so that you can explain your thoughts and the Italian Government's thoughts on the future of the European Union.

name: Giuseppe Conte
text: President of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic. Mr Tajani, Mr Katainen, honourable Members and Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, it is indeed an honour for me to be here today, and I say this with sincere feeling, before you in order to outline and foreshadow the future of Europe in accordance with the guidelines of the Italian Government.  With a view to the commitment to the future of our continent, I would like to begin by expressing a moving memory in memory of Antonio Megalizzi, an Italian who described himself as in love with the European Union, who, as you know, fell victim here in Strasbourg two months ago to the barbarity of terrorism.  In a globalised world in which the economy seems to have taken over politics and law, and where the weight of an economic choice taken at many longitudes can have a severe impact on our citizens, we must ask ourselves what role the European Union has, the role it can play, given that the nation states, and therefore the Member States themselves, are not in a position to do so. , alone are unable to respond to complex global challenges.  The common European building is going through – we must all recognise this – a particularly critical phase. The European project seems to have lost its driving force. The complex historical situation before us, the representatives of the institutions, challenges us, within the framework of our respective roles and responsibilities, to address issues of crucial importance.  As in the past, others who have preceded us at the same critical stages, we are called upon to make a joint effort, fuelled by a great sense of responsibility. Our task is to relaunch the European project, making it regain its credibility and cohesion in order to increase its sustainability, effectiveness and plausibility.  The challenges of the present time are new and complex, they require vision and, if I may say so, also some dose of creativity, but above all they presuppose awareness of our mission in the world. The big questions we are all called upon to answer are questions of meaning. What Kind of Europe do we want? What Kind of Europe do we need? How do we perceive ourselves and how do we represent ourselves? These are questions that challenge our consciences and deserve the utmost consideration and authenticity of answers. Because we are in the seat of the European Parliament, directly elected by the citizens of the Union, as the substantial and genuine custodian of European sovereignty.  We are – we should be – first and foremost a people: the people of Europe. Has progressive progress on the path of integration really made us a people, a community of destiny, beyond any legal fictio? Certainly, the process of defining and building a European people has experienced significant moments of progress. The history of modern and contemporary Europe has been marked by deep divisions, lacerations and contrasts, which have defined and forged an articulated populism rich in languages, cultural identities and traditions.  However, these societies have experienced irreversible and fruitful cultural, legal and social contamination. We have increasingly integrated our economic systems, our educational models, our social legislation, giving up areas of sovereignty and transferring increasingly important competences from the States to the Union. We have allowed the citizens of the various Member States to move freely within European territory, conceived as a single legal area. The free movement of persons, even more so than the free movement of goods and capital, has been one of the most significant achievements in the process of European integration, if we only consider the load of nationalist hatred and identity retreat that had swept across the continent between the end of the nineteenth century and the first half of the twentieth century, and which was dramatically deflated in the two world wars. Europeans, especially the youngest, do not wish to give up this fundamental freedom of movement, thanks to which, to such a significant extent and with a naturalness unknown to past generations, they have been able to increase their heritage of human, cultural and professional experiences, accepting national specificities increasingly as variations of the same sensitivity, as different ways of participating in a common feeling. The process of creating a European people has also been strongly fuelled by the legal dimension. The ripe fruit of a centuries-old process of civilization, legal culture has in recent years taken on a decisive role in the creation of a single feeling to the point of encouraging the formation of a European demos.  In this respect, the action taken by the European Court of Justice, each within its own sphere of competence, was fundamental. human rights and the Court of Justice, in close liaison with the national constitutional courts. This is why a European legal area has been created in which citizens can identify and find protection through a refined and complete system of multi-level protection of the fundamental rights of the individual, based on a shared heritage of constitutional traditions. This advanced and articulated system of judicial protection, now, I would say, indelible in the legal heritage of the Union, represents an achievement of civilisation, certainly to be defended and preserved, precisely because of the virtuous effects that it is likely to produce in the collective imagination of the European citizen, feeding the awareness of being part of a shared destiny, of belonging to a people in the sense of a community participating in the same fruitful process of civilization.  In spite of all this, however, we have not yet managed to become truly and fully a people; we did not have the courage to build an inclusive model that realistically, beyond all rhetoric, would encourage the creation of a European demos. Especially since 1989, there has been no – there are isolated exceptions, for heaven's sake – a genuinely political vision of the European Union, a long-term, forward-looking perspective, without which every project will run aground, every dream discolored, overwhelmed by day-to-day administration. The prophetic momentum was lacking, but they met the great statesmen of the post-war period.  To exacerbate this lack of prospective vision, Over the last thirty years, European governance has strongly anchored itself in the pure economic dimension, in a perspective unequivocally oriented towards the implementation of liberal guidelines, aimed at promoting privatisations of essential services and goods, reduction of regulation in vital economic sectors, contraction of social support and welfare policies, which have increased inequalities in wealth and opportunities as a whole.  Especially with the deepening economic crisis, European governance has supported strict policies aimed solely at keeping sovereign debts within precise parameters and at keeping the inflation rate of the common currency as low as possible, even in the face of a very sharp contraction in consumption, with devastating social effects.  European policy, faced with an unprecedented economic crisis, has been portrayed, afraid, on the other side of the cold grammar of procedures, eventually gradually losing contact with its people and making the distance, which is not only geographical, between Brussels and the many peripheries of the continent increasingly unbridgeable. Gradually and inexorably, politics has renounced its legitimizing and representative role, appearing in the eyes of distant and oligarchic citizens, unable to understand the real needs of the community. It has become – as the political scientist Jan Zielonka pointed out, a ceremonial parameter covering very complex global operations, largely incomprehensible if not secret.  The powerful oppositional charge that the people of Europe, in their various forms, are expressing towards the elites speaks to our consciences: it reminds us that politics, enslaved to the reasons of the economy, has failed in its task, has abdicated its mission. This is a decisive turning point in the history of a united Europe. We have fundamental decisions ahead of us for our future. This European people, who have come back powerfully on the stage of history, urgently ask to be heard, and call for a decisive change in method and perspective.  It is a precious opportunity, I believe, to make up for lost time, to reverse the process of progressive detachment between rulers and rulers, which, if further fuelled by silence, indifference or even just the attempt to minimize its scope, can lead to the implosion of the world we had known.  We must not be afraid of conflict: we must show ourselves capable of governing it. We must not react to change by opposing sterile conservatism, all of which is protected by the besieged citadel. On the contrary, we must allow the conflict to emerge, to demonstrate, in the forms of democracy, its driving force, to unleash its innovative role, even assuming the risk of abandoning certain security, of reconsidering the balance of power, models of development and growth that have proved inadequate in the face of the new challenges, no longer capable of withstanding the impact of impoverished societies, crossed by precariousness and loneliness. , from disappointment and resentment, feelings that, if still persistently denied, can fuel rebelliousness and protest from unpredictable outcomes, as shown by various phenomena taking place in some European countries.  The Europeanism of the twenty-first century, in my opinion, inevitably presupposes a radical rethink of the forms and institutions that have characterised the history of integration over the last thirty years. They urgently call for genuine conversion, which is also, in some respects, a return to the origins, to the founding reasons for the European dream. Will the Europe we imagine be able to express a driving force, not simply a stabilising force, in the interests of its citizens, the Member States and common interests?  Geopolitics is rapidly and continuously changing. The new strategic balances are characterized by extreme fluidity, also considering that some important powers, while failing to establish real poles of international attraction, see their capacity for influence constantly grow. In this context, no Member State alone can play a significant role. Hence the hope that a united European voice will also find its place in the UN Security Council. This is a battle on which the European Union must move in a coordinated manner and must speak with one voice.  The European Union must be able to speak to the world. A strong, ambitious and cohesive European Union is first and foremost necessary in order to improve its capacity for interlocution with the United States. As I said from my first speech to the Italian Parliament, we strongly believe in the transatlantic relationship with Washington: we must continue to work to preserve the strategic value of our relations, in which the things that unite us, first and for all values and principles, prevail over every possible difference and misunderstanding.  At the same time, a strong Europe is needed to accredit us in dialogue with key global stakeholders. Russia and China are part of any solution to major international crises, starting with those closest to Europe's borders and interests. I cannot see any benefit to the European Union in abandoning dialogue with Russia and China, or in deluding itself that it can promote isolationist policies towards them.  Rather, we will have to promote their all-round engagement.  But how do we achieve this strong Europe, which we all agree on? We must certainly continue along the path of integrating European defence, exploiting all the potential contained in the implementation of permanent and structured cooperation (the CFSP) and the European Defence Fund. A common European defence is not only not antithetical to NATO membership, but can be a useful complement to it, thus giving concrete proof that the European Union remains effective and capable of making progress, not least in order to give more security to its citizens. Not forgetting that a European Union that aspires to be a global player cannot ignore maintaining close defence and security ties with the UK, even after Brexit.  But the essential prerequisite for ensuring a strong Europe in the world is to ensure its solidarity and cohesion first and foremost, through the collective responsibility of the Member States. Migration and economic and financial governance are two emblematic challenges of the urgent need to restore confidence and solidarity in Europe. A substantial change of perspective is essential, and these principles must not become prey to divisive dynamics between Member States on the major issues that should form an integral part of the daily European debate.  Disagreements, including bilateral disagreements – and we have clear confirmation of this these days – are more the effect than the cause of Europe's inability to propose solutions. It is this inability, not disagreements, that weakens the driving force of the European project.  Europe started looking late at migration. It is thanks to Italy that the migration issue has reached the centre of the European Union's agenda. Europe cannot continue to deal with migratory flows from an emergency perspective, but must rely on a structural approach in order to arrive at stable and effective solutions. I also make an appeal in this very authoritative Chamber which I have renewed, you see, at every European Council, at every informal summit in which I have taken part: we cannot postpone beyond the full implementation of the conclusions of the European Council of 28 June last year: without a multi-level European management strategy for migratory flows, the very resilience of a united Europe cannot be compromised. A European strategy must tackle primary movements with the right priority, with a multi-level approach. Otherwise, secondary entries will never really be under control.  Those arriving in a landing country arrive in Europe. Aldo Moro argued that no one is called to choose between being in Europe and be in the Mediterranean, because the whole of Europe is in the Mediterranean. This principle must always be remembered, not only in order to deal with the issue of migration in the right perspective, but also at a time when European security itself is at stake, from support for the political process in Libya, to European support for Africa and the stabilisation of the Middle East chessboard.  Italy, you see, is a convinced driving force for the centrality of the Mediterranean for the future of Europe. This is borne out by my visits to Algeria and Tunisia last November, the Palermo conference of 12 November last, my visits to Lebanon and Iraq last week. Soon I will visit Morocco. This action is part of Italy's overall strategy, which aims to make a substantial and dynamic contribution to the stabilisation of the main theatres of crisis, in line with the commitment of the UN and the European Union, in the interest not only of our country, but of the whole of Europe.  Europe, looking beyond the Mediterranean, must invest politically and financially in cooperation with Africa and Africa, otherwise illegal migration can be temporarily reduced, but never eradicated, nor can returns, which require coordinated action by Europe and the Member States, be improved, including through the incentive of development cooperation and with mutual European recognition of decisions in this area.  The Commitment of the Italian Government in Africa is part of this approach, which I myself am pursuing with the utmost conviction. That is why I also went to the Horn of Africa, a region that we hope will live its spring, and to Niger and Chad in mid-January. If Europe wants to be a point of reference also in terms of values, it must promote a new approach to Africa's problems: it must pursue a new model of cooperation inspired by partnership between equals, in a spirit that wants to increase opportunities and at the same time responsibilities on both sides.  We cannot remain indifferent to the fact that the majority of the African population, men, women and children, live in inhumane conditions of poverty despite the considerable natural resources available to their territories, nor can we remain indifferent to the fact that much of the wealth generated by the African economy is dispersed among a few thousand offshore companies located in artificial havens or otherwise benefits foreign investors.  I am pleased that the priority of cooperation with Africa has been recognised by the European Commission itself. I would like to thank Jean-Claude Juncker for his strong impetus towards this objective, which is so important for our common future. The recognition of this priority must be accompanied by the allocation of adequate financial resources and the development of new methods of intervention. Europe must commit itself to drawing up a catalogue of best practices in order to arrive at a truly equal and sustainable model of cooperation.  Governing migration, a structural phenomenon that will last in the Europe of tomorrow, also requires reflection in the perspective of the next multiannual financial framework 2021-2027. Europe must, of course, equip itself with stable and lasting financial instruments and mechanisms to govern the migratory flows of countries of origin and transit. There is also an urgent need for the three Mediterranean routes to receive political and economic attention of equal intensity and consistency. The European Union has allocated EUR 6 billion to the agreement with Turkey. The Eu ropean Union for Africa trust fund is still seeking funding and has a gap of at least EUR 500 million in relation to its commitments.  No less complex is the European management of the internal dimension of migration. It must be dispeled from the illusion that protection of Europe's external maritime border can be resolved, with a huge expense for thousands of agents of the so-called strengthened Frontex and with an additional burden on the countries of first arrival that would also have an impact in terms of security.  Migratory flows do not govern themselves, we need shared efforts. As agreed at the June European Council, they must cover all 28 Member States. The proposal to reform the Dublin Regulation, approved by the European Parliament in November 2017, is not sustainable in the current European Union: unfortunately, the unwillingness of the majority of Member States to participate in automatic and compulsory solidarity prevails. However, the implementation of the conclusions of the European Council of 28 June, which are based on the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities, which are, moreover, referred to in Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, cannot be postponed any longer. Faced with the loss of human lives abused, sold and broken, we must all fight together against the traffickers and tormentors, who represent an affront to humanity, as well as a threat to our security. Let us stop remaining divided, giving in to nationalist or regionalist logic, and let us try to put into practice genuine solidarity, so as to restore a Europe that is respectful of human lives and its own security.  The need for true solidarity and sharing between Member States, without divisions between the areas and regions of the Union, also applies to the no less priority challenge of completing economic and monetary union, especially at a time when global trade tensions are putting the European economic situation at risk, as confirmed by the European Commission's recent estimates of Member States' GDP.  I hope that more attention will be given to the demand by Italy and other Southern European Member States for an urgent rebalancing of risk reduction and sharing, in favour of effective convergence that does not leave growth behind in the name of rigorism. The reform effort – and I am, of course, referring in particular to the commitment initiated by the Italian Government with the 2019 budget law – is socially sustainable, even before the economic one, if structural reforms do not, however, become a sisyphus effort, which stifles growth and mortifies social cohesion.  With the budget law, Italy has embarked on a path of growth in stability. While keeping the accounts in order, we have worked to ensure a better present and future for citizens left behind and whose urgent expectation of change the Italian Government has intended to represent. At the same time, the boost to public investment, including through reforms aimed at simplifying the entire regulatory-legal framework, testifies to the intention to give dynamism to an economy that plays a central role for our continent.  The economic governance of the European Union must take account of the need to balance growth and stability.  But what does it mean to overcome austerity? It certainly does not mean disoresing the value of financial stability: it means, on the whole, committing ourselves to pursuing the value of social stability and sustainable development as well. I am pleased that Jean-Claude Juncker has recently made a reference to the fact that in the case of the Greek crisis austerity was perhaps reckless. Many of us have been convinced of this ever since. What must be avoided is that someone in a few years' time apologises for a lack of European management of migration or a lack of social Europe.  Europe must look to the future of those who are already at risk of having no opportunities in the Europe of tomorrow. It is essential that the European Union invests more courageously in young people, education and innovation. It must also not discourage public investment geared towards these objectives, considering it as a factor of deficit and instability, rather than as a driving force for the future of our continent.  On the other hand, work and balanced and sustainable economic and social progress are objectives which, in the wake of the Maastricht Treaty, the Treaty of Lisbon has confirmed, but which, ten years after its entry into force, still seem far from being implemented. Criticism of the incompleteness of the European institutional architecture, now also coming from the authorities of the Member States, has been partly accepted by the European Commission and the ECB. They took appropriate initiatives, including the Eurogroup decision of 21 January which, in implementation of the Eurosummit of 14 December, set up a high-level group to examine the implementation of EDIS, the European deposit insurance scheme and the completion of the European banking union.  As far as banking crises are concerned, progress has been made, although the instrumentation requires a fine-tussle which the high-level group is hopefully taking on. The change in the rules for resolving banking crises has led to a step backwards in the endowment of instruments that must be filled before a possible new recession takes back the clock of Italian and European financial and banking stability.  Under the Maastricht Treaty, the task of ensuring the credibility of sovereign credits was entrusted, if you remember, to the convergence commitments towards 60 % of the debt ratio of individual countries, to policies of budgetary rigour and to the implementation of reforms at national level. National. Despite the Commission's watchful eye, the situation has revealed, as the Italian case shows, significant critical issues following the outbreak of the financial crisis in the USA in 2008 and the consequent great global recession.  In order to be able to tackle these problems with a more effective approach, we also need to move decisively towards the creation of common financing instruments at European level, which will enable us to face together the challenges we face, combining responsibility and solidarity in a balanced way. Inadequate and insufficient solidarity within the European Union also explains why Europe struggles late to be fairer, more social.  The new European legislature must pursue the fight against unemployment and support for growth more decisively and as a matter of urgency. A European boost to these priorities, even with bold formulae such as European unemployment insurance, is the best antidote to nationalistic drifts, as well as to lack of work. The gap in unemployment, especially among young people, between some disadvantaged areas of Europe and others with excellent employment rates is widening to the point of promoting nationalistic closures, if it is to be tackled only through national policies. The advantaged areas will try to secure against European policies perceived as a cost, while disadvantaged areas on a national basis will not be able, if at all, to find resources to make real progress.  A fairer and more supportive Europe must also be an objective for the next multiannual financial framework. The complexity inherent in this type of negotiation must not see this priority lost, especially in the face of the existential challenges facing the European Union. An appropriate balance is therefore crucial between the new priorities such as immigration, growth, investment, security and traditional policies, cohesion and the common agricultural policy, which must continue to receive full support, as central to the socio-economic cohesion of the continent.  There are many other challenges to which we are called. We must commit ourselves to promoting fairer world trade, which is better able to protect consumers. We must put in place every useful initiative to contribute with ambitious determination to the international commitment to climate change. More generally, we must continue to play a leading role in protecting old and new rights, all the more deserving of protection in the digital age, even in spite of the fact that rights cost money. I am thinking in particular of the decisive role that Europe can play as a security provider, with specific reference to new hybrid and, in particular, cyber threats. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the question of meaning with which I began my speech is predominant. What Kind of Europe do we want? What Kind of Europe do we need to guarantee the citizens of Europe a future equal to the sixty years of peace and prosperity that the Union has secured? My answer is once again the same: Europe must be close to its peoples. The European Union, in the twenty-first century, must pursue its project by the people and for the people, starting – and I am pleased to say so here today – with a European Parliament with strengthened role and powers, with particular regard to the power of legislative initiative and inquiry, as the only institution that enjoys direct democratic legitimacy.  It would also be important for Parliament to have a power of general accountability in relation to the other European institutions. The European Parliament will be able to play a decisive role in the face of europe's demand for change, after a decade marked by historic events that have changed the geopolitical order of the continent. At the same time, an adequate strengthening of institutions of direct democracy is, also and above all in a European context, an essential development for the restoration of the credibility of the institutions vis-à-vis the citizens.  The European scenario is explicit in indicating widespread distrust and disillusionment of citizens. The Government that I have the honour of presiding over stems from the desire to meet as a priority the urgent demand for change of Italian citizens, with answers that politics has not been able to offer for too long. Even at European level, as I said at the beginning, this demand for change must be understood and properly represented.  If further confirmation of the urgency of putting these principles into practice were needed, just think of Brexit, a central issue for the European Union for the coming years. In the face of this challenge, the European Union has shown that it is able to react in a united and supportive spirit and that it is able to protect the results of over sixty years of European integration, without giving in to punitive attitudes towards a member of the European family who no longer wishes to be a part of it. It is an epochal process, if we think about it, unprecedented, that must be managed in an orderly manner, always having in the first place the objective of guaranteeing citizens' rights and protecting the social and economic fabric from the negative consequences of Brexit.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with courage and rigour we must strive to review what has not worked, including in the implementation of the Treaties, and to combat centrifugal tendencies and European disintegration, daughters, sometimes, as is also the case in my country, of European disillusionment.  If we want Europe to remain our common future, it is time to follow words with deeds, together embarking on a path to a new Europe, a Europe of the people that is more supportive, more inclusive, fairer, ultimately more democratic, the only one in which citizens of today and tomorrow deserve to live. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you to the President-in-Office of the Council of Ministers. Before giving the floor to Vice-President Katainen, I wanted to stress how important it is for us to involve the Member States in the choices in favour of strengthening Parliament's powers. I have taken note, together with all my colleagues, of what you have said. As far as immigration is concerned, we ask you to make a further effort, at future Council meetings, to accept the European Parliament's proposals, perhaps by finding some compromise on the Dublin reform. I think I reflect the feeling of the whole House.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, Italy holds a very special place in the heart of our Union. It has given Europe so much and has been there from the very start, shaping our Union every step of the way. It was Spinelli and Rossi in prison on the island of Ventotene who set out their dream of a free and united Europe. They called on the nations of Europe, so long adversaries, to come together to ensure that the mistakes of the past would never happen again. After the war, De Gasperi became one of the great pioneers of the European Union and in 1957 it was on Capitoline Hill that the Treaty of Rome was signed and our Union was born, with six founding Member States. 60 years on, in 2017, it was once again on those same steps in Rome that the leaders of our Member States stood, side by side, to renew their vows for our Union. This time there were 27 of them from right across our continent. A sign of how far we have come. I say this because Italy’s special history is one of the many reasons that it has such a unique and important place in our Union. But I also say this because it shows that Europe moves forward, that Europe is at its best when it has Italy and Italian people at its beating heart. This history must serve as a guide and as a reminder for our future. To build a successful future for our Union, Europe needs a strong Italy at its heart, just as strong as vibrant Italy needs a strong Europe. We must build our common future together, in unity and in solidarity, always working with and not against each other; talking with each other and not about each other. When it comes to building a true Union of solidarity, Italy is the best place to start. It is where the European Solidarity Corps started its work.  To help Italy rebuild following the tragic earthquakes it suffered in 2016, 230 young European volunteered in Umbria and across the regions hardest hit, in addition to the EUR 1.2 billion of financial support provided to Italy under the EU Solidarity Fund. We all have seen the images of young volunteers from all over Europe helping to rebuild the ancient and beautiful church of Norcia. This is the solidarity that builds our European Union today and that must continue to build our common future. Italy itself has shown the same spirit countless times over the years. President Juncker said many times ‘Italy is one of those who saved Europe’s honour in the Mediterranean at the height of the migration crisis’. And the truth is that some others were too slow to support the efforts of the Italian people.  But it is also true that Europe stood up and supported Italy in every way it could. From the beginning of the migration crisis to the end of 2018, the Commission made almost EUR 950 million available to support migration and border management in Italy. This includes EUR 225 million in emergency support to fund border surveillance and search and rescue operations, to improve reception facilities and to support all of the authorities and people on the ground. Europe has been there for Italy. We should not forget Operation Sofia or the role of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency. Saving lives at sea is a joint effort and here again, we need Italy. Prime Minister, it is also clear that Europe still needs to overcome its differences and find sustainable and responsible solutions. We can no longer rely on ad hoc solutions. We have come a long way since the peak of the crisis, with arrivals down by over 97% in the eastern Mediterranean and 80% in the central Mediterranean. 700 000 lives have been saved at sea but clearly we now need to finish the job and conclude the necessary reform of our asylum system. The Commission has put everything on the table and it is now time to move ahead. We need the full engagement of Italy if we want to succeed. Honourable Members, Prime Minister, Europe stands for peace and prosperity and we are all responsible for defending its values together. That means deciding what we want Europe to achieve and it means deciding where to invest and to have the biggest impact on the daily lives of Italians and all Europeans. This is why, last May, the Commission put forward a fair, modern and balanced budget for our future. A budget that is more efficient and more focused on issues that matter the most to our people. For instance, the Commission has proposed an almost threefold increase in funding for migration and security, to reach nearly EUR 33 billion. An increased, simpler more effective and more flexible EU budget for external action will help build partnership with the countries in our neighbourhood and beyond. This will be especially important for Italy as a country, as it has taken so much responsibility in this area. We will invest in making our economies more competitive, more innovative and productive. Key for Italy will be the 50% increase in funding for research and innovation and the EUR 9 billion Digital Europe Programme that will support Italy’s digital transformation. Investing in our future also involves investing in human capital through education and training. This is why the Commission has proposed a doubling of the budget of EUR 30 billion for the Erasmus+ programme, the EU’s flagship for learning mobility. We aim to increase support to all sectors, including higher education as well as vocational education and training. In 2017, more than 65 000 Italians participated in Erasmus programmes. In the next multiannual budget we will build on the success of investment plans for Europe – the so-called Juncker Plan. Italy is one of the largest beneficiaries of the Plan, with close to EUR 58 billion of investment triggered in Italy’s economy and over 215 000 small and medium-sized businesses supported. The Juncker Plan has significantly increased private investment but also public investment in Italy. It is a positive sign because we should not put too much burden on taxpayers if private liquidity is available. That investment is making a real difference on the ground, right across Italy. EUR 70 million is helping to refurbish the local hospital in Treviso; EUR 200 million is going into upgrading Puglia’s water network to improve quality and access to clean drinking water for more than four million people; and EUR 500 million is supporting the rolling out of high speed internet so that seven million more households in Italy benefit from quality broadband access. The new programme for the next budget in the EU has the potential to go much further by triggering altogether EUR 650 billion for investment. All of this can, and will, make a real difference on the ground in Italy and across our Union. This is especially true at a time when economic growth is becoming harder across some of our major European economies, partly down to global uncertainties but also because of domestic challenges and choices. Economic growth needs confidence amongst households and investors. Trust is like oxygen, you notice it only when it’s running out. Uncertainty is a poison that seriously hampers jobs and growth. Italy’s growth has been weaker than the eurozone average for many years. This is a structural problem. The weaker growth means fewer jobs for the Italian people. At the same time – and I say this at every occasion – Italy is among the most creative economies in the world. The future of your country is in your hands. Do what is necessary to unleash this creativity and offer a brighter future for the Italian people. Honourable Members, dear Prime Minister, it is now two years since we presented the White Paper on the future of Europe, which kick-started the debate we are having now on what we want our Union to achieve in the years ahead. Five scenarios show different possible paths that we could decide today. But, whatever we choose, there are some things that are constant and one of those is Italy’s central role in building our Union. Europe needs a strong Italy and Italy needs a strong Europe. It was no surprise or coincidence that the first lines of the White Paper were about Spinelli and Rossi’s manifesto. As we look at our future, we should all inspire ourselves from those that have gone before us to build a stronger and more united Union for generations that follow, just as they did for us. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Prime Minister to the European Parliament.  Your speech, Prime Minister, started with the perspective of people. I am from Lower Bavaria and when I go to the service in my Catholic church, I meet the farmers and the nurses there. All of us have our neighbours and our neighbourhood and we talk with them every day. When I speak with them, I see the same problems. We have the perspective of young people all over Europe and the question of social fairness in the European Union.  To answer this, I think we have to be a little bit more specific than what we heard from you today because, to give an answer on the economic problems, the fact is that Italy is today the country with the lowest growth rate in the European Union, as Jyrki Katainen mentioned. This is not only a problem for Italy; it is a problem for the whole European Union because we are speaking about the G7 countries, so one of Europe’s economic engines.  What to do? We in the PPE Group believe that we need investments in today’s European Union and in Italy we see a government that cannot even agree on building up a project that has already been approved between France and Italy. In the PPE we believe in a stable currency, which is fundamental for a strong economy to build up trust. Your government discussed for a few weeks at the start of your government whether you should still be a member of the euro area or not.  We believe that only with the will for reform can you win the economic future of your country. The Programme Countries in Europe – Ireland, Poland, Cyprus, Greece and also Spain – showed that if you have the will for reform, you can win the future and you can create jobs for the younger generation. They did the job on the labour market, the judicial system and the tax system. Even in Germany, I must tell you – my country – it was Gerhard Schröder’s reforms, the Agenda 2010, which created the starting point for the economic strength of today’s Germany. So the will for reform is necessary for winning the future and at the moment your government is not really forward—looking and a front—runner on the question of reforms.  Finally, we believe that a stable budget is crucial for a strong economy and we don’t see that either in Italy. We see a growing debt rate. That is what we see. That is a summary. Additionally, regarding the investments from the European Union in Italy, it is a real problem to see that we have such a lack of growth in Italy and, again, it’s your responsibility. It’s not the responsibility of others, it’s the responsibility of the Italian Government. We fully respect that you are elected and the government has been elected. You have a democratic mandate from the Italian citizens, but it’s probably easier to win elections as an anti-elite movement than to stay in government afterwards as an anti—elite movement. Some of you have probably become, in the meantime, the new elites in Italy. I want to underline a second point which is important, namely the migration thing. I want to show you our full solidarity as the PPE Group, that we think that Italy deserves solidarity. We fully understand the anger of the people in Italy that for years and years they had no solidarity and Italy was alone. That’s why we stick to the principle of a binding solidarity mechanism for the European Union, but it is also a problem for us to see that a member of the European Council is here and tells us that his own body, his own institution, is not delivering on this issue. We delivered on this issue. It’s up to the Council to deliver now.  Finally, on external affairs, let me thank you for sticking to our European approach in the answer on Russia. At the moment you were ready, as the Italian Government, to give consent to the sanctions. That was a good thing. We have a common understanding that Russia’s interest is to weaken the European Union.  On the other hand, in recent days we saw the discussions about Venezuela. For us, as the PPE, it’s clear that we have there a socialist dictator, Maduro, an unfair, undemocratic election, and support from the military and the army. They are even stopping the transport of medicine which is so urgently needed in the country. On the other hand, we have a freely elected parliament looking for a fresh start for the country and simply asking for the right to seek early presidential elections for the country.  That’s why Guaidó was right when he asked today, in a letter he wrote to the Italian citizens, why their government was not supporting him. Why is the Italian Government not supporting the democratic forces in Venezuela? I think you should answer this question if you believe in the common European approach. (Applause) Those are some reflections. I thank you for the general will to look for a clear commitment to the European way of life. Two principles to end with: you said today in an agency at European level that Italy is becoming louder and is more present in the public debate. You say that nobody has a problem with a loud voice from a national point of view. Our problem is, in the European decision-making process, whether loudness is the same principle as egoism. What we need in Europe is compromise, the will for compromise. If everybody were loud, then finally there would only be noise and nothing else.  Finally, you spoke about the breach between people and the European Union decision—making process. You’re here in the European Parliament: Lega Nord is here, the Five Star Movement is here, Forza Italia is here, and Partito Democratico is here. All the forces from all over Europe are here. This is the political landscape of Europe. We all represent our citizens. We are all close to our citizens. There are no elites sitting here. We are representatives of our citizens and this is why this is the place for deciding the future of the European Union.  (Applause)

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I thank the Prime Minister very much for coming to the European Parliament today. This is the House of European democracy. This is the House of public debate and of frank language, so please allow me to start with that and to share my worries. I am deeply worried when the Government of a founding member of our European community, the Government of the seventh world industrial power, is driving the Italian nation further into economic and political isolation today – and this against the backdrop of a situation externally where we cannot rely on Washington anymore, as we could in the past, and we have new threats from Russia. We can see your economy shifting towards a recession and we see that industrial production is falling. In this situation, I am deeply saddened by the senseless escalation between France and Italy. What is this? Of what use is this? (Applause) In conflicts such as this – and you know it – there are no gains. Nobody can win. This is a perfect lose—lose for your country and for Europe. People in both countries could end up paying a very high price. Italy and France are one another’s second trade partners – EUR 76 billion is the volume of the annual trade between them. Hundreds of thousands of jobs depend on that. Hundreds of thousands of jobs, not of the elite but of ordinary folk on the ground. The Italian people simply cannot afford to lose any more jobs. This year, Italy will grow by only 0.8%. That is the lowest growth rate in Europe. You may dress the situation up by saying that the goal is to bring back the dignity of labour. I very much wish you had brought back the dignity of labour: 75 000 men and women have lost their work, and many more have become trapped in unstable and low—paid jobs, while countless young people are being forced to leave the country in search of a better life. And as if this wasn’t enough, the livelihoods and life savings of Italian families were recklessly put on the line by a calculated head—on collision course with the Commission over the budget. Why was that so necessary? Was it just one man’s public relations stunt? It has cost the Italian people EUR 1.7 billion during the past couple of months alone. And for what? So that Mr Salvini can blame Brussels. Mr Salvini has a scapegoat for everything, but no solution for anything. This is part of the Italian reality today. (Applause) To distract from the economic mess, Salvini is now even abusing migration. Ich selber war vor zwei Wochen in Catania und habe dort sehen können, wie 47 Menschen 12 Tage lang ein Rettungsschiff nicht haben verlassen dürfen, die Sea-Watch, unter ihnen Minderjährige und Folteropfer, weil sie die Gefangenen einer Ideologie waren, weil sie vorgeführt werden mussten, weil es nicht anders ging als sie zum Spielball einer zynischen Politik zu machen. Das ist nicht das Italien, das wir kennen, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren. Wir kennen ein anderes Italien. Wir kennen das große europäische Italien mit Altiero Spinelli, De Gasperi, die niemals – niemals! – für kurzfristige vermeintliche politische Gewinne ihr Land oder gar Europa zur Disposition gestellt hätten. Ich verstehe sehr gut, und meine Fraktion versteht sehr gut, warum Menschen in Italien enttäuscht sind. Ihre Vorgängerregierung hat Großes geleistet, tausende und abertausende von Menschen aus Seenot gerettet, und Europa hat nicht hinreichend reagiert. Europa hat keine hinreichende Solidarität bewiesen. Aber wer hat sie denn enttäuscht? Doch nicht die proeuropäischen Regierungen, doch nicht diejenigen, die Europa weiter voranbringen wollten? Schauen Sie doch hin! Sagen Sie doch den Menschen in Italien, wer ihnen nicht hilft, endlich die Dublin-Reform zu machen! Das sind doch die Freunde von Herrn Salvini, das sind doch die Kaczynskis, das sind doch die Orbáns und die Menschen wie Herr Kurz in Österreich, die alles blockieren. Das ist doch die Realität! Lassen Sie uns doch die Wahrheit aussprechen! Und es sind die Proeuropäer, die, auch wieder bei Sea-Watch, die Menschen natürlich – natürlich! – gerettet haben, denn genau das gehört sich auch so. Es gibt dieses Europa noch, es gibt dieses Italien noch, wo beide füreinander kämpfen; dieses großartige Italien, diese großartige Nation, das Italien von Spinelli und De Gasperi. Das sehe ich, wenn ich die Fischer in Italien sehe, die Fischer von Lampedusa, die trotz der Bossi-Fini-Gesetze und obwohl sie genau wussten, was auf sie wartet, weiterhin die Menschen aus der See gezogen haben. Das sehe ich bei den Seeleuten der Diciotti – einem Schiff der Küstenwache Ihrer eigenen Nation –, die nicht anlanden durften, und die sagen: Wir haben einen Seefahrerkodex, das ist unsere Ethik, und die steht nicht zur Disposition. Und das sehe ich bei den mutigen Bürgermeistern, die Essen und Wohnungen zur Verfügung stellen, auch wenn die Regierung die Schlafplätze vernichtet hat. Es gibt dieses Italien, das Italien der Menschenwürde, das große Italien der europäischen Werte. Und diesem Italien reichen wir die Hand, weil wir es brauchen. Aber dann sollte Ihre Regierung aufhören, uns die grinsende Fratze der Unmenschlichkeit vorzuführen, denn das hat mit dem Italien, mit dem wahren Italien nichts zu tun. Es ist Zeit, dass wir in Europa aufstehen gegen den Populismus und gegen diejenigen, die unsere Heimat ruinieren. Italien hat unsere Solidarität, und Italien gehört in die Mitte Europas, in das Herz Europas, zusammen mit seinen engsten Freundinnen und Freunden. (Beifall)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before giving the floor to Mr Beazley, i.e. the Committee on The Raffaele Fitto, who will speak on behalf of the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists, reminds the group chairmen that if they go beyond their time, they will take it away from the Members of their group.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by welcoming the Italian President-in-Office of the Council on this occasion. I think it is a very useful and important opportunity to be able to address issues relating to the future of Europe and the role that a country which, as has been mentioned, is from you but also from all those who have spoken, is central to the construction of this Europe and its prospects. I also think it is important to make an effort, in the sense that these debates often risk being very general, if not general, debates, and that they have very profound diagnoses, which are sometimes at odds with the reality we are experiencing. So my speech will be a speech aimed not only at sharing some of the very critical criticisms and assessments that have been made about what Europe has represented in recent years and about the enormous mistakes that this Europe has made on economic issues and on issues such as immigration – and I disagree with many of the things I have heard in recent speeches on these issues – , but I think it is equally important to try to point out some elements of clarity. I shall try to point out to you, and I will give you some very concrete examples, some strong contradictions, Mr President, which I think must be answered, because at a time when we are talking about immigration – which is one of the issues on which your government, especially at the beginning of this national legislature, has taken action which I consider not to be negative as it is told, but rather useful in putting a problem to the fore – Italian fishermen are not at sea trying to to save immigrants, but they are protesting about what European standards are in relation to some of the issues that concern them. I would like to close this parenthesis and say a few things very quickly.  The first is on immigration. We agree, Mr President. But on the Global Compact there is a photograph of what is a total uncertainty concerning his government. You attended the United Nations Assembly, you said you agreed, then you did not go to Marrakesh afterwards and then you abstained. On Venezuela today he has claimed an important role for Europe, saying that there is a need to speak a single language. Well, we must remember that at the meeting of European Foreign Ministers, thanks to Italy's dissent, the only dissent, Europe was unable to speak a clear word in this direction.  As in economic matters, what you have said is true in terms of analysis, but I am sorry, the consequences to which you refer are absolutely wrong. There are no choices of structural reforms in its development policies at national level, quite the opposite. I am not one of those who are alarmed because there is a risk of increasing the deficit a little at a time of economic difficulty. The issue is how we increase it, what we increase it for. We are increasing it for policies that increase public spending structurally, other than structural reforms.  Furthermore, today is a resounding day because – as has been mentioned before – while we are here, while you are talking to us about the development and growth of our country and italy's role in Europe, your Minister for Infrastructure is presenting a fantomatic report to explain to us that the Tav is a mistake and that it must be blocked. These are the facts before us. So I would like you, Mr President, to give clear answers on this point, so that your conclusion can become a reality, that is to say, from analysis, from words to deeds. Unfortunately, the facts are not going in the right direction for Italy or for Europe.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall try to make my speech in Italian, Mr President. (Scattered laughter and exclamations) Because, apart from my country, and again, I am, Mr Conte, in love with Italy and the Italians. For me, in fact, Italy is more than one country: for me, Italy is an entire civilization. Italy is where our European civilization was born and for centuries artists, writers and intellectuals from all over Europe have visited Italy at least once in their lives. Discovering Italy meant visiting Italy, visiting Florence, visiting Rome, visiting Naples and then dying...  (Laughter, the speaker laughs too) Montaigne did it, Goethe did it, and that is why, Mr Conte, it hurts me today to see the political degeneration of Italy. It is true that a degeneration that began not yesterday, not a year ago: at least, I think, twenty years ago. The impression is that this beautiful country has gone from a staunch defender of Europe, a founder of our European family, to a taillight of the Union. That is the impression we have today in this House and also outside it. And let us tell the whole truth: it all began not with Prime Minister Conte, it all started with misrule under Berlusconi. That is also the truth.  (Scattered applause) Misrule has also worsened under your government, that's the problem... (Protests and exclamations) ... under Salvini, under Di Maio, the real leaders of this Government, a government with a behavior, Mr Conte, sometimes anti-European and also an openly odious government against other Member States, which are part of our European family. It is the Italian Government that has prevented the European Union from being united against Maduro and from recognizing Guaidó as the interim President of Venezuela. And you know that because you are under pressure from the Kremlin and Putin. That is the truth.  (Applause) That is why – and someone has mentioned this – we must say enough about the unanimity rule in the Council as quickly as possible. It is the Italian Government, Mr Conte, which is not part of the majority in the Council to reform our asylum and migration policy. Mr Salvini has specialised in blocking ports for migrants but is also blocking the creation of a genuine European border, a real European coastguard and the implementation of a European reform in Dublin at this time. This, for me, is absurd behaviour, because Italy and the Italian citizens are the first to pay for the lack of this European policy.  And in the last year, and this is my third example, your government has also been responsible for stagnation and a tomorrow, I fear, of the recession from the Italian economy, because your government does not have a strategy for growth, does it not? Your government only has one tactic to get you re-elected with gifts and debts. That is the truth.  And the last – and I want to end with this – the last lightness of his government, of Di Maio, who is using and abusing his office to support the gilets jaunes, a popular movement, it is true, that is now dominated by a group of wreckers, wreckers who set fire to cars, break into shops, destroy bus stops. And Di Maio even met Christophe Chalencon. I know Christophe Chalencon, Mr President: it is he who has called, not once but twice, for a military coup against the elected President of the Republic French. (Scattered applause) Well, congratulations! This is irresponsible behaviour and not the behaviour of a Vice-President of the Council of Ministers of an important European country, such as Italy. She recalls that just a year ago, I think, on November 23, 2017, Di Maio wrote an open letter to Emmanuel Macron, expressing his admiration and suggesting that the 5 Star Movement was in fact the Italian movement of En marche. Ridiculous this behavior! So my question for you, Mr Conte, is how much longer will the puppet moved by Salvini and Di Maio be to continue this thing? (Applause and exclamations) I invite you to be inspired by illustrious Italian compatriots: Spinelli, Ciampi, Giorgio Napolitano, Mario Draghi... (Protests and applause) Yes, yes, Giorgio Napolitano, yes! A great European with a great idea and a Member of this House. And let's not forget my good friend Emma Bonino. These are the men and women who make Italy great and its great role in Europe. This is the difference between Mr. Conte and all these great characters he forgot. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would like to remind all the Members who speak that this is not the Italian Parliament, it is not a debate on Italy. It is a debate on the prospects for the European Union to discuss Italy's proposals. My political party does not support the Conte government. I am just trying to have a debate that is not a debate on the situation in Italy. You can say whatever you want, but I'll tell you what this debate is for.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left, I should like to put a few questions to the Italian President-in-Office of the Council, starting with the conviction that what is happening and what is going to happen in Italy is particularly relevant for the future of Europe, on which, in my opinion, two options, both harmful and closely intertwined, insist: the continuation of neoliberal policies and the growing consensus of a reactionary black wave.  Those who speak to you on behalf of this group are committed to building an alternative to both these options in the construction of a third area and an alternative for Europe based on the self-determination of women, men and peoples. And it is precisely on the front line of the possibility of countering the constraints of neoliberalism, constraints against which this parliamentary group is fighting every day in the name of an idea of equality, that the betrayal of the electoral promises of this government, which is completely prone to neoliberal policies, is measured. It has first bowed to the constraints on deficit-to-GDP overruns, it has not made any commitments regarding budgetary balance in the Constitution. With regard to fair trade, which you mentioned earlier, Prime Minister, there is no position of the Italian Government on either CETA or the ISDS clauses. You spoke of cohesion policy, yet the Italian Government is preparing to approve a differentiated autonomy that is the secession of the rich, it is the opposite of the cohesion policies that would be necessary to respond to the southern question as a European issue. This government has given the green light to the Transatlantic Pipeline, which we opposed as a parliamentary group. Finally, it launched a proposal to work, a proposal for income of subjectance, free work and "anti-sofa" rules that offend the dignity of millions of Italian precariouss. Twenty-one Italians have the income of 12 million people, according to Oxfam data, yet you do not make a patrimonial. You make the flat tax, that is, you reduce the progressiveness of taxation and you don't make any plans on the wage issue. No real contrast to neoliberalism.  But it is not only in this area that we are concerned about the future of Europe. This Parliament adopted, on 25 October 2018, also following an attack in my city, Bari, by some Casa Pound militants, a resolution calling on the Member States to actuallye neo-fascist and neo-Nazi groups and any other foundation or association that glorifies and glorifies Nazism and Fascism. I would like to ask you how the Italian Government intends to contribute to its implementation and how it judges, Mr President, the relations between the Italian Minister of the Interior and the representatives of Casa Pound, an explicitly neo-fascist force. And I would like to remind you, Prime Minister, that at the root of all fascism – Hannah Arendt teaches us this – is the process of dehumanisation of the other, the same process that is at the root of the war against people and migrants.  I proudly wear this sweatshirt, the sweatshirt I was wearing, like other MEMBERS of the European Parliament from other political groups, when I was on the Open Arms, just when the European Council was taking place. Well, this is not a uniform, one of those ones that, let me say, buffoonly wear some ministers of your government. This is a sign of solidarity. We received on the Open Arms the news that the Italian ports were closed for those 59 people who had been rescued at sea.  You referred to the conclusions of the European Council confirming the agreements with Turkey, voluntary relocation and the fight against flows. On the other hand, he did not refer to the European Parliament's position calling for a reform of the Dublin Regulation and a compulsory relocation process. You continue, Prime Minister, to give you this graph too, to say that the presence of NGOs at sea would increase departures. You have activating a process of criminalising NGOs unworthy of a civilised country, confusing those who help people with traffickers with a lie. That is why I am asking you, Prime Minister, as mayor Ada Colau has asked, to stop the disgraceful policy of closing ports and blocking NGOs. I would like to ask you whether a minister who is being investigated for kidnapping 177 people can really think of pointing out to the European Union the future with regard to migrant policies. Finally, on 8 March, Prime Minister, throughout Europe and also in Italy, women, feminists and those you forgot to mention in your speech will take to the streets. It is no coincidence, it has done well, because when this government talks about women's rights it only does negative things. I do not know whether you are aware that a delegation from the FEMM Committee went to Italy precisely to address the fact that the presence of medical objectors prevents the right to voluntary termination of pregnancy. I do not know whether you are aware that places of self-determination of women such as the International Women's House of Rome and the Luce and Siesta space are being evicted. I do not know whether you are aware of the fact that women are asking for ddl Pillon to be withered, that women are demanding with the anti-violence plan to finance anti-violence centres, an income of self-determination and a European minimum wage.  It is from these proposals that the future of Europe can really start again. We will continue to be partisan, because in order to save Europe from its sinking, we must oppose these European policies, but also the policies of your Government.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Signor Presidente del Consiglio, benvenuto al Parlamento Europeo. Italy has bad press in European circles. And yet, when we think of your country, it is rather positive images that come to mind. It is in Italy that citizens have voted overwhelmingly in favour of keeping the common good of water in the public fold. It is in Italy, too, that citizens have spoken out against the return to the unpayable and risky energy that is nuclear power. It is still in Italy that the "slow food" movement was born, an antidote to junk food that is slowly killing our societies. And finally, it is Italy that has been able, in particular thanks to its fabric of small and medium-sized enterprises, to create three million green jobs. Yet your government, Mr Conte, confronts us with another reality and sometimes refers us to the worst hours this continent has experienced. Like when your Minister of the Interior, who sees himself as your true boss, affirms his dream of expelling from Italy the Roma and Sinti who live there. Your country is particularly vulnerable to climate change and facing a possible recession. And, in the face of this, your speech has shown us, you are turning your back on the opportunity to make the ecological transition the engine of the Italian and European economy. You might choose to listen to environmental whistleblowers, such as Rossella Muroni, innovative entrepreneurs like Catia Bastioli, or anti-speculation mayors like Matilde Casa. But instead, in the name of mythical growth, your government is tearing itself apart over pharaonic and senseless projects, such as the Tunnel of the Val de Susa or oil exploitation at sea, not to mention the continuous concreteization of your country, one of the most beautiful in Europe. This country has long faced a difficult budget equation. And if the share of responsibility of your predecessors is important, no one can deny that Italy has suffered greatly from the austerity policies imposed in the euro area since the Maastricht Treaty. But rather than seeking to build alliances to reform the euro area, so that our common currency benefits all Member States, your government chooses the path of a confrontation as theatrical as it is sterile which, far from reducing the risks, increases them. Finally, your country is on the front line of the challenge of asylum and migration. You could take the example of the dignity and determination of Pietro Bartolo, the doctor of Lampedusa, or Domenico Lucano, the mayor of Riace. Instead, your government makes migrants the scapegoats for all Italy's ills and closes its ports to ships that save Europe's honour by coming to the aid of refugees. You could seize the outstretched hand of our Parliament, which has adopted by a very large majority, the abandonment of the Dublin rule in favour of the European solidarity that you and your government are calling for. Indeed, the reform, as adopted by our Parliament, meets exactly the requirements of your government. But here, the 5-Star Movement opposed it while the League took refuge in abstention. Instead, your government prefers to associate itself with those who are merely preaching fortress Europe while leaving Italy abandoned to its fate. And if the migration issue is a problem for Italy, Prime Minister, I think it is rather to look on the side of the almost two million young Italians who have made the choice, free or forced, to leave their country in the last fifteen years. Do you really think that it is the confused and contradictory policies of your government that will encourage them to come back, and especially to encourage their brothers and sisters to stay in the country? On the contrary, we believe that it is by making Italy the engine of an ecological, solidarity and democratic transition that you will restore to your country a future that lives up to its history, at the height of its place within the European Union. And on our side, we will be with those who are mobilizing and preparing to launch, around these priorities, an "onda verde e civica per l'Italia".

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, Mr Katainen, Commissioner, colleagues and Prime Minister Conte. This is the 17th debate on the future of Europe, and the risk is that while we are debating the future, the Union no longer even has a present. We continue to regard Europe, which we founded, as our home. But the European Union needs a profound restructuring, because it was built from the roof, forgetting the foundations.  We want to give this house a solid, certain and lasting foundation. We want a fairer, fairer Europe, closer to its citizens, without second-class countries and second-class countries.  We want a Europe that is a leading player on the world stage, that does not get down to its knees by major powers such as Russia, China and the United States. We want a Union, not only in name, but also in fact. I ask you, does that mean being for or against Europe? Many have a habit of looking the straw in the eyes of others, but do not notice the beam that is in theirs.  Does being pro-European mean humiliating Greece and the Greeks, and then admitting - as if nothing had happened - that austerity was a huge mistake? Does being pro-European mean invoking solidarity between states and then leaving only one country to manage the burden of immigration? Does being pro-European mean creating tax havens in your own state? Furthermore, does being pro-European mean fighting with a stupid ideological war the introduction in Italy of the income of citizenship which - look at this - is a reality throughout Europe? These are false Pro-Europeans, who have built Europe, but those of banks and finance, bureaucracy and austerity far removed from the citizens. We still have time to change and we should take an example from Italy, where change is taking place today. In just seven months, we have taken away the life annuities of former Parliamentarians, compensated the defrauded savers of the banks, imposed the Daspo on the corrupt, cut gold pensions, lowered the tax on small VAT numbers and began paying 30 billion in public administration debts to entrepreneurs.  Finally today in Italy there is the income of citizenship. We dismantled the pension reform that Europe, yes Europe, had imposed on us the name of the rigour accounts. Commissioner Katainen, I am Umbrian. You spoke of Norcia, norcia needed only one thing: to unb away investment in reconstruction from the Stability and Growth Pact.  We have promised this to the citizens and we have achieved this because we do what we say. The recent Report "Italy 2019", published by the prestigious Eurispes institute, records an increase in the confidence of Italians in the government: fifteen points more than last year. We are not surprised, because the government of change, listening to the citizens, gives them new hope for the future.  That's why they accuse us of being populists.  Mr Conte, as you have already said, if that means listening to people, then yes, we are populists. All too often, however, in this building, locked in these cages, we forget to listen to the people.  Ladies and gentlemen, how many times have we asked you for a strong signal for the citizens, starting with, for example, the abolition of the dual seat of this Parliament? This structure, where we are today and which we occupy four days a month costs 200,000,000 EUROS every year, and has no reason to exist. And we are friends of the French, and I do not allow anyone to make any allegations about our support for the violent or the 'casseurs', all the more so as some have allowed themselves to call our government a government of lepers. I call for the waste of double seating to be erased: this is not an attack on democracy, democracy is not a privilege! Democracy cannot be a palace! Let us begin by cutting our salaries, our pensions and the monstrous salaries of commissioners, which really are a slap in the face for the citizens.  There is an initiative of ours on the privileged pensions of MEPs that has already been deposited. Mr Tajani, pay attention to our proposal, support our proposal! This has not been achieved today, but we will do so, thanks to the citizens' vote at the next elections and with the other forces of change. We gave an amazing team of drivers to lead Italy. Now we will give an equally capable one at the head of the European Union because, rest assured, as we are changing Italy we will also change Europe.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, welcome, Mr Conte, today you bring to the European Parliament the extraordinary experience of the first real government of change throughout Europe. A government that proudly claims the sovereignty of our country, a government that does not bow its head and has the courage to say no to the boyars in Brussels, to say no to the berlin taxation, no to the manias of greatness of little Napoleon Macron, a government that finally defends the interests of the Italian people.  In recent months, the Lega and 5-star government has shown by its facts that change is possible. Thanks to our leader Matteo Salvini, wild immigration has been stopped.
