The security decree put an end to the business of illegal immigration. With the famous quota 100 we have begun to dismantle the Fornero law on pensions.  Mr Conte, much good has already been done, much more remains to be done. Autonomy must be given to Veneto, Lombardy and Emilia Romagna. There's a lot of tax reform to cut taxes. It must be made clear that Maduro is a communist dictator who must be wiped out and that Italy is one hundred percent with the people of Venezuela who want freedom. Mr Conte, we in the League are already at work, because after Italy we want to change Europe from top to bottom. And we will do so with the consent of the Italian people, who in the European elections will make the Salvini League the first party in Italy and the first party in all of Europe.  No more Europe as a slave to banks and multinationals. No more Europe of spread and austerity. No more Europe of Juncker, Merkel, Macron, who want to command at home and humiliate the Italian people. In Italy, Italian citizens rule, not Merkel or Macron. After the European elections we will have the strength and the numbers to build a new Europe, a Europe of peoples and freedom, a Europe capable of defending borders, stopping illegal immigration, protecting made in Italy, protecting our businesses and our workers.  Mr Conte, we are convinced that our government will last a long time, because we all have a great mission to fulfil: to defend our land from the bureaucrats in Brussels and to defend the freedom and sovereignty of the Italian people. Good job, President Conte!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: For general information, I would remind you that the choice of seats of the European Parliament is not a matter for this House, it is the responsibility of the Member States that have signed a treaty. As far as I am concerned, However, Mrs Agea, I would say to you that I have already given up EUR 500 000 in goodwill as a European Commissioner and I am devoting my pension as a European Commissioner to a community of recovery for drug addicts.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Signor Presidente, onorevoli colleghi, benvenuto Presidente Conte. I would like to say to Mr Conte, Prime Minister of Italy, that it gives me great joy to see him here today. Mr Conte, the determination of your Government to resist the privileged power axis of Merkel and Macron, and indeed to resist the pressures of the European Union elite – on show here today – who have suggested that your Government is racist, fascist, in the cahoots of Putin, even anti-feminist and anti-European – you deserve applause for that. You have inspired democrats across this continent and the world. Your Government has demonstrated that Europe is not an institution called the European Union. It is indeed a continent of ancient nations of ancient peoples: ancient peoples but with modern methods. Sometimes they wear yellow vests, sometimes they vote Brexit, and sometimes – like your Five Star colleagues – they take social media and turn it into political power for the ordinary people. Modern methods for ancient voices. But the fact remains that these voices must still be heard.  The debate today is about the future of Europe. Mr Prime Minister, you and your Government and your colleagues are the future of Europe. Bravo, bravo, bravo.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I now give the floor to the President-in-Office of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic to answer the first questions put to him.

name: Giuseppe Conte
text: President of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic. Thank you, Mr President. The issues that have been touched on are varied, ranging from issues of a clear European nature to other issues, on the other hand, which concern more closely the national policy followed by my government.  I am sorry that I am not going to answer one by one, but I will try to group together the issues that have been touched on. I shall begin with a subject that has been crossed a little and touched on by almost all the speeches: the issue of immigration. Everyone can have their own opinions, but I would like to remind you of what my government has done in practice, how we have dealt with the issue of immigration and what is the reality of the situation, then everyone will suffer the consequences. What we should perhaps not do is to obscure the reality of the situation, of how they unfolded.  From the first moment my government took office, it was fully aware that the issue of immigration was a divisive issue, it was a subject that had overwhelmed our country, with hundreds of thousands of landings in a few years. Italy has not been able, with previous policies, to withstand the impact of migratory flows, given our geographical condition. Some may forget this, but we are in the heart of the Mediterranean. So the routes, especially those in Central Africa, expose us directly to the impact of migratory flows.  Well, aware of what had happened, aware that an indiscriminate reception, as had been achieved in the past, means non-integration. Let us not approach the problem with hypocrisy: indiscriminate reception means non-integration. I am not going to name names, but also some of them, particularly a colleague of mine, a European Prime Minister, who had an attitude on the subject of immigration, as it were, a little detached, he told me, after he visited an Italian city in the North: 'Joseph, I understand now that you have a serious problem', after he saw dozens and dozens of immigrants on the streets.  How did we deal with it? We dealt with it immediately according to a structural approach, we understood that the emergency case leaves us all overwhelmed, we cannot manage it. And so we have drawn up a strategy, based on six premises, ten objectives ranging from the policy to be pursued in relations with the transit countries where the migratory flow originates, where these paths of hope originate, to the countries of transit, to the problem of European borders – including maritime borders, attention, which is not the same as land borders – to landing, to redistribution , to repatriations, and so on. I would like to remind you that Italy, at the first European Council in which I took part at the end of June, took an active part, as it were, with regard to those conclusions reached, where we reasoned for the first time with shared principles and efforts, where the principle was affirmed for the first time that those who land in Italy do not land in a non-European country , lands in Europe.  But there is one point: that once those principles have been affirmed, then the practical translation is still not found today. We have had a number of European Councils, but in fact we are unable to implement those principles accordingly. And certainly not because of Italy, of course, not because of Italy. Italy, then, I have to assume that it is true that it saved Europe's honour in the past, but perhaps some people thought that it would continue to save Europe's honour for the future. But this cannot be the case, it cannot be because any State that finds itself in Italy's position reaches a moment of saturation. Integration mechanisms no longer work, inclusion mechanisms no longer work, we know that there are difficulties with returns, because returns are not effective, because in many countries, it is not even possible to ascertain the identity of migrants, the origin, and in any case it is only possible on bilateral agreements, so objectively they cannot even be repatriated.  And then Italy decided to apply a line of greater rigour than in the past. Of course, we say it with our heads held high, we say it and we say it forcefully, with clarity and transparency: a line of greater rigour because we felt, having drawn up this articulated strategy, that we must not trivialise, no one can afford to trivialise, we felt that this was the only effective way to combat trafficking in human beings.  There is a problem, there is hypocrisy in Europe: migrants become a problem when the spotlight is turned on the Mediterranean, thanks also to some NGOs, then a mass media mechanism takes place, and then it becomes the problem of migrants. But we must ask ourselves the problem of migrants where they leave their village, where they immediately fall prey to the trafficking of these unscrupulous beings. You know how much a path of hope costs, punctuated by torture and personal violence? I've been around Africa a lot, I know what I'm talking about: it costs three thousand to five thousand dollars, and sometimes it's not enough. You think, we're talking about very poor people who can get this money and after a moment they get plundered, defrauded and raped. That is the problem, the problem is not just in the Mediterranean.  With regard to management then in the Mediterranean, I would like to point out that Italy, in search and rescue activities, rescue at sea, has always been inspired, always inspired by the protection of fundamental rights, and even in the case that has been mentioned, mentioned, of the "Diciotti", Italy first took the most vulnerable people, women and children, immediately transported them and brought them ashore. The fact that, as in the last case, there is a ship that comes to where health care, food supplies and so on is guaranteed, and a few days in the Italian port, in the roadstead, this does not mean that there is ill-treatment. But it was right, and I think it is right, in view of the conclusions that all 28 countries reached last June 2018, to demand that a redistributive mechanism work, which does not yet work, which cannot but be – on that I agree – on a mandatory basis. Attention, let us also come to the concrete. The safe haven only works if it is that of Italy, only if the landing is in Italy. This can't go well. Safe harbor doesn't mean nearer port. That is the first point. Secondly, the redistributive mechanism cannot work if there are only three, four, five or six countries, without an automatic mechanism. Everyone must be involved in this solidarity mechanism. Thirdly, there is a third problem, let us not hide it, even those countries that declare themselves willing to participate in the redistributive mechanism are only willing to do so with those who are entitled to international protection. Economic migrants nobody wants them, they stay in the country where they disembark. That is what we are about immigration. As far as the economy is concerned, you have dealt with the subject of the investment economy and infrastructure. Someone said: but Italy does not want to make the necessary reforms. Please inform yourself. During the mediation procedure with President Juncker, Vice-President Dombrovskis and Vice-President Moscovici, I, from the first moment I met them, did not ask for courtesy, to avoid the infringement procedure. I brought a full-bodied book, which I had translated into English, where there are all the reforms that we have already carried out and those that are being carried out. To say that Italy is not prepared to carry out reforms is simply to ignore what is happening in Italy. We have launched, we are achieving, the most far-biggest structural reform plan ever designed.  (Heck and questions from a number of Members) The President shall speak by interrupting the speaker)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: During the next debate you will have the opportunity to ask your questions. Mr Danti, if you wish to speak later, you can speak, if you have to stop now it is not worth it. The more you waste time with interruptions, the less MPs talk. Give the opportunity to answer and then you will ask your questions.

name: Giuseppe Conte
text: President of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic. We have passed an anti-corruption law that introduces the highest anti-corruption standards not only in Europe but internationally. We have introduced a radical reform of bankruptcy. Today in Italy we are no longer talking about bankruptcy or bankruptcy: we are talking about the code of the crisis of companies and insolvency. It's a full-bodied book, a body of articles. We have introduced a delegation law and are now about to introduce delegated legislative decrees to reform and simplify all administrative procedures and streamline all procedures. That is what my country needs, which has never been done in recent years. We have a delegation law to introduce a radical reform of public procurement; we have a delegation law to reform the Civil Code, the Civil Trial Code and the Criminal Trial Code.  That's what we're doing. And when you tell us that we are against investment, perhaps because you follow the public debate and hear about TAV, who is in favour and who is not. But sorry, it's not that the TAV means the infrastructure investment plan in Italy. We have a substantial infrastructure investment plan, to which we have added as much as 13 billion from state-based companies, which have been summoned to Palazzo Chigi. We have a national plan: we are currently presenting a national plan for the security of the territory, a national plan against the risks of hydrogeological failure, for the modernization of our road infrastructure. I would like to remind you that we asked the Commission for flexibility, and we obtained it in the final phase of over EUR 3 billion – EUR 3 billion and EUR 200 million – in addition to the investment plan already planned.  And so, we can have differences of opinion – democracy is beautiful because when there is a public debate everyone can have opinions – but ignoring all this means doing european citizens, not just Italian citizens, a disape. As far as the TAV is concerned, it is true that it is a project that was also recognised as being of European interest and was already launched. , is in its early stages. So, before we committed so many resources, before we build an infrastructure that has such a big impact on the environment, we decided to do a cost-benefit analysis. We have said that we will do so in transparency, we will share the results publicly and we will take responsibility for the resulting decision. As far as the other projects are concerned, they are all being implemented. The TAP, the third pass, the Brenner motorway and so on. And by the way, precisely in order to accelerate investment, we have a plan, which we will make public these days, for all the construction sites in progress. A final joke – excuse me, Mr President, if I am abusing time – but a final joke about foreign policy choices. We are told: political isolation. Italy is in political isolation, Italy has obstructed Venezuela and has remained isolated. Attention: first of all, Italy is not isolated. Italy contributed, I would like to remind you – and this is a fact – to the communiqué by the High Representative, and therefore of the entire European Union, of 26 January. It has been acknowledged, even publicly, that my speech was decisive for that communiqué. Attention: many want to anticipate history. Caution should be exercised. We do not know what the evolution of the Venezuelan crisis will be. Italy has clear ideas and is not alone, it is with many other countries. We have clear ideas that, I would like to remind you, for us the presidential elections of last 2018 are not democratic elections. We didn't recognize them. Clear? We also have clear ideas that we need new presidential elections and that the conditions must be ensured for them to be conducted transparently and to be credible by international standards. We want them as soon as possible. We are aware that there is a population that is suffering and so we are pressing for an emergency and we have already allocated resources for humanitarian aid in accordance with international law. We are aware that no regime can be justified if it adopts violence and suppresses dissent and peaceful demonstrations through violence.  Having said that, we do not believe that we can crown anyone who does not go through free and democratic elections. That's what we're going to work for. (Applause) We are an active part of the contact group; we are also available for a form of mediation and we all warn against the historical responsibility of crowning someone at the expense of the other, when we know full well that the major international crises, historically, have occurred because there has been a rush to crown one leading actor over the other in contention.  Attention: because this polarizes and radicalizes the clash. It is clear that rushing to crown one actor means allowing other global actors to come to the rescue of the other, and we know that this has created the worst crises that are still dragging on in history. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Let's start the debate with catch the eye. We have to finish at 7.45 p.m. at the latest. There are more than fifty Members who have asked to speak: the more you speak, the less the others speak.

name: Lara COMI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Prime Minister, welcome to the European Parliament. You spoke of democracy. You see, you are therefore an institution which is perhaps the most democratic, because we are directly elected by the citizens and every day we respond to the citizens, unlike you who have been appointed. I'm proud to be Italian. I am with Italy, but with Italy in Europe.  Do you think it was a walk to approve made in Italy here? Do you think it was a walk to approve the Dublin reform here, or copyright? And we have not blamed anyone, we have rolled up our sleeves, we have worked, we have made alliances, those alliances that Italy lacks, those alliances that are lacking in the European Council. Because, you see, you talk about Europe, you talk about unity, and then you come here and say that you do not do the TAV. Maybe even part of your government isn't of the same opinion, is it?  You talk about a reform in Dublin, but you yourself approved the optional quotas, which we said was absolutely wrong. So then you go and ask for solidarity, when you have the optional quotas? This is his mistake, and he must acknowledge it out of intellectual honesty. And another aspect, let me: your video with Chancellor Merkel is a disgrace, because I love Italy and I would never want a Prime Minister to speak ill of the Italian Government to a colleague.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, when I am not sitting in Strasbourg or Brussels, I live in Lyon. It is a city that has an ancient link with Italy: to move from Piedmont to Lyon, and the reverse is what the founders of Lyon silk did in the 16th century and generations of Italians after them. I want to talk to you about the Lyon-Turin, which is incredible here to hear that it is still a project. In reality, the Lyon-Turin does not only connect two cities, just as the Channel Tunnel does not connect Dover to Calais, but the whole of the United Kingdom with the rest of the Union. The Lyon-Turin is the central link in the Mediterranean corridor from Algeciras to Budapest. But I am talking about the link between peoples, whereas the Ponti report speaks mainly of money. This report re-reads the calculations made by previous experts and manages to find that the Lyon-Turin would cost the Italian state. It is true that some revenues will be down, such as taxes on fuel and on the proceeds of motorway tolls. Yes, there will be less traffic, fewer trucks, but above all less pollution. My question, Prime Minister, is this: do you not think that the old and fraternal link between our two countries deserves better than this Ponti report, where there is no methodological rigour or environmental concern?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister, thank you very much for what you have said. You have spoken a great deal about the solidarity that Italy is now demanding from the European Union. That is your contribution to the future of the EU, that you demand solidarity, and we know who solidarity should apply to.  But when we talk about solidarity, we must of course also talk about why there has been a situation in the first place where Italy must demand this solidarity. I would like to point out once again that we have had a common currency for 20 years: the euro. And Italy has not had growth for 15 years. Have you ever thought about whether there might be a connection?  Could it be that Italy itself needs to think about whether this common currency is actually suitable for the country, to think about where it comes from, that the Italian central bank is pushing ahead with a target deficit of 400 billion euros, why Italy has increased its debt by a third since the euro was introduced, which is why Italy is constantly violating the rules on its deficit. , violates the Fiscal Compact?  Mr Conte, if you are calling for solidarity, then Italy too must follow the rules. In the asylum system, you are not complying with it either. First of all, you did not register all the refugees who came. Now you suddenly close all the ports and fall into the other extreme. If Italy wants to be a member of the European Union, Italy must comply with European rules, otherwise there can be no solidarity.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr. President. Mr President Conte, why did your Government prevent a rescue ship such as the Open Arms from being able to dock at the Italian port on 29 June 2018? Mr. President, I was on that boat, next to Eleonora Forenza, with Javier López and miguel Urbán. Four MEPs from this Parliament. And we were not given an official response, claiming that the impediment to being able to dock in an Italian port was due to a public order motive. Why have they been blocking Italian ports ever since? Why do you talk about solidarity Europe while you are not complying with any kind of rules, of the rules of European solidarity? But what shocks us most is that the part of the government that could have more democratic ideas is aligned with the far right, with the friends of fascism, with Vox's friends, which is just the opposite of solidarity Europe.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, (off-microphone) ... to the new President-in-Office of the Council who, en passant, has restored dignity to a country, to a people that was not used to seeing its representatives with their backs straight coming to Europe and thinking as you have managed to reason in the delicate phase, and we must acknowledge the great success by running the risk of a country being put in a state of infraction. , and demonstrating instead, by the power of truth and facts, that our country is a great hard-working country, whose financial and economic fundamentals are the envy of other countries, which have often used the weapon of blackmail and political overpowering, dealing with a political class, including a European one, rather subjugated.  I thank you for giving strength to the other component of your government, which aimed – and achieved – to demonstrate to this somewhat reckless Europe that all these sermons about the impossibility of stopping the trafficking of human flesh in the Mediterranean were false and perhaps served rather obscure interests. This traffic has been blocked! I would also like to thank you for your efforts to open up to african countries, with which we must speak with equal dignity. I would simply ask you to add in this effort the openness and involvement of our country's and European small and medium-sized enterprises, only by grafting the good seed of small and medium-sized enterprises and not, as was done in the past, with the parties that were intrallating in Africa and stealing in Africa. This must be done, this will make a serious government, a government of the people!

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Welcome, Prime Minister! You managed to stop the possibility of crossing the Mediterranean – this mass invasion. I would like to thank you for that. It is also no secret that the asylum lobby cannot earn as much as it did before. They must be here today as if they were in a tribunal. But this is not a tribunal. This is the trembling of the old elites, who know full well that they will no longer have the majority in this House in three months' time. Prime Minister, we have in Germany, we have learned in Europe that migrants can also kill thousands of times. Stop the killing! Give the millions of Europeans who are looking to Poland, Italy, Hungary today to hope for a new future!

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I agree with the fact that we must stop trafficking in human beings in Africa, but unfortunately I do not share Italy's position of neutrality on Venezuela, which has blocked the European Union's recognition of Guaidó. I carry Italy in my heart: my daughters are Italian, I have lived for over twenty years in Italy and I am really disappointed by the Italian Government, which does not want to see the urgency of stopping the titer Maduro, who is suffocating the Venezuelan people.  You just said there's no hurry. Go and say it, Mr Conte, to Leopoldo López, to all the tortured, to those who have died, to all the Venezuelan emigrants who are queuing to enter Colombia, to the starving people. As Edmond Burke said: the only thing necessary for evil to triumph is for the good guys to do nothing.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: Mr President, I am speaking to you as a former Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs of France, MEP and President of the Provence Alpes Côte d'Azur region. My region shares hundreds of millions of European euros in cooperation with my Italian neighbours. In reality, we share everything: our borders, the coastline, the mountains, our history, the Mediterranean and even the accent. I have love for your country, I love Italians. But today, the legitimate reminder of our ambassador is a direct consequence of your interference. For the first time since the war, you have just strained relations between our two countries; this is a major diplomatic fault, which shows that your speech, supposedly pro-European, is false. Moreover, wanting to play politics in France is completely unsuited to your convictions, you who continue to advocate Italian sovereignty. So, what are you involved in with us? I have only one question: who paid for this trip to France? If it is the Italian taxpayer, you have just eliminated your French candidates, because it is a crime in France to use a legal person during an election campaign. And Italy is a legal entity. Your allies can thank you: with a friend like you, no more enemies. In fact, your behaviour is inelegant, immoral, indecent, ineffective, irresponsible and illegal. I do not congratulate the heir of the Renaissance that you should embody.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, you will have grasped from the words and attitudes of this House how much esteem and expectation there is for Italy and how much disappointment and concern there is for this Italy which, objectively, has become weaker, isolated, conflicts with the founding countries with which it should rebuild the future and is allied with countries that are against that unity and solidarity that you have called for. I hope that you have grasped this intelligently, and I say this with concern not with joy, because I want my country to be a protagonist in this Europe and not an antagonist. I would like to say one more thing to you, Mr President: how can we believe your words, which oscillate between great dreams and quotations? Please, Aldo Moro let us read it in its entirety: he would not have done what we did in the Mediterranean. But that is not the real problem. Instead, she falls into rebelliousness, into a claim. But where is the consistency that you called for? Where are the facts?  So, you quote a few things, I will not tell you that we did them, because Italy is not born in Europe today, but I tell you how we behaved here. You will tell me whether this is credibility, Mr President, if it is consistency. You mentioned the funds for Africa, but your majority voted against it! You mentioned the billions in the Juncker plan, but the parties that support it – and large parties – voted against it! You mentioned the need for enhanced cooperation, but why is Italy not participating in the initiative of the Nine? She spoke about the negative consequences of Brexit, but do you know that the largest – for now – Italian party that supports her lies in Farage's group? Here, I beg you, let Italy return, for its own good, as a protagonist in Europe.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, it is, of course, with great pleasure that we have heard it here and with great respect for the will of the Italian people. There is, however, one point I would like to stress: you mentioned aldo Moro here at the time and it is a pity that the current Italian Government does not honor Aldo Moro's memory with his Europeanism and his dedication to the European cause. It is not enough to quote it on the Mediterranean, it is necessary to quote it on Europe. Allow me to tell you, as Portuguese, how strange the Italian Government's position on the Venezuelan issue is very strange. Not only because it calls into question the issue of European foreign policy, but because, like there is a large Portuguese community in Caracas and Venezuela, there is also a large Italian community. Does the Italian government not think of the Italians who are suffering the Maduro regime and who are suffering the misery it has imposed on them? This is the question to which the Italian Government should have already answered. It's not enough to answer now. I should have answered in the first hour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, Mr Conte, good evening, thank you for being here. I'm going to be practical. I would like to have time to describe the effort that is being made here in the European institutions to obtain resources for the best projects that are carried out and proposed by the many European countries, including my own. I would like to spend time telling how, above all, we have tried over the years to build serious projects that bring together the connecting needs of our country, the questions of our entrepreneurs. I would like to tell you all this, and I would also like to tell you about the mood of those who do this work and then see their Minister for Infrastructure more attentive to chemical trails than to this work. So, faced with the repeated request from your government to be patient because over time you will see the great capabilities of this government, I propose a provocation. Many Members who support it have often provoked the political environment with particular economic assumptions, especially on salaries. Well, try to do this: if we have to return the resources deserved by this country, make a mortgage – at a fixed rate because variable increases with the spread – and return from your own pocket the resources that we have so hard brought home for our country.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: I have a question, Mr Conte. Since I do not see the Union as capable of becoming a community of solidarity and non-discrimination on migration or budgetary rules, since I do not believe that the income of citizenship, which is also indispensable in Italy, overcomes the defects of the "Hartz IV" subsidy now recognized in Germany, since I see that the extreme right is taking over the 5 Star Movement, imposing its agenda on crucial points , I would like to ask you this, and the question is serious, because I fear the moment when the League will embrace right-wing forces that want the government to fall, bring more and more doors and regime change to Venezuela, I ask you: on what forecasts, on what study of reality do you think, as you said in an interview, that this year and the following years will be beautiful? Thank you for an answer.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Thank you, Mr President. I will then give it to you, Mr Conte, because this list is long and boring, which I summarize in some numbers. Then: Moavero 8 out of 19, Toninelli 3 out of 4, Tria 2 out of 6, Salvini – let alone – 4 out of 4. Do you know what they are? The absences of Italian ministers from meetings of the Council of Ministers. These are the absences of Italian ministers from meetings of the Council of Ministers, when we talk about work, when we talk about young people, when we talk about industry, transport, immigration even! You are never present at meetings, apologize to the Italian citizens! Apologize to the Citizens of Italy and to the citizens of Europe! Europe needs Italy, Italy needs a government that is present in Europe! That's what he needs! This is the justification that you were supposed to give today, Mr Conte, but you are never present! I will end with a quotation, Mr President, you have made one, and I shall make one myself. And the quote comes from the winning song of the Sanremo festival, by Mahmood: "it is difficult to stay in the world when you are without pride". Unlike what you go around saying, Italy without pride is more proud: look at this empty Chamber, Mr President!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Please use appropriate language in this House, please. Otherwise I will be forced to adopt sanctions against Members who use language that is not appropriate for Parliament. Clear? May it never happen again!

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr President, welcome President-in-Office of the Council of Ministers. I hope you can hear me. Thank you for coming here, it was a surprise to me to hear it, and I have to say a positive surprise. But, as they say to us in Istria, "ciacole no fa fritole", so I also wait for the facts. I would like to say, as rapporteur for the Adriatic-Ionian macro-strategy, that we need good cooperation on the Adriatic. I am interested as you see in relations with Slovenia and Croatia and as you see the future of cooperation on the Adriatic. It is also important to me how you see the enlargement of the European Union. I am also interested if your government wants to cut funding for the Italian minority in Istria, for bilingualism in Istria, which I did with my colleagues. I am interested in what you want to do with bilingualism in Slovenia and Croatia, because we also need Italian Union funding in Slovenia and Croatia. Finally, I am interested if you can imagine a recovery of a village that could be dedicated to exiles and also to the peoples of Europe. I'm interested to know if you want to participate in this symbol.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, Mr Conte, you have rightly praised the importance of free movement, which I share, coming from the largest linguistic minority living in Italy, close to the border. However, his government has made a law, the so-called 'security decree' – much discussed for other things such as immigration, but I do not want to talk about this – according to which, if a student or a person who wants to work abroad goes abroad, buys a car and wants to return to Italy, this machine is seized at the border and has to pay 700 euros in fines. Do you think it is right that such a measure should be compatible with the great idea of free movement?

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I am very pleased to hear you here today because your fellow Vice-President of the Salvini Government, who was here in Parliament, was very little present at the meetings where it was decided in the interests of the citizens, because it was far from the cameras. I have the impression that he continues to act in that way within his government: to work little and to appear and chat on TV very often, designating those responsible for Italy's bad situation, namely refugees, Africans, gays, French, Europe itself. Once upon a time, the so-called culprits were the Jews, the Communists, the Gypsies. It is a way of doing politics that clearly recalls fascism, which ruined Italy, which forced thousands of post-war Italian citizens to emigrate in order to give themselves a future. Please don't forget that, please.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Mr Conte, I agree with what you are saying about the course of Europe, but Europe must show solidarity and solidarity must be expressed both in the area of defence and foreign policy, as well as in the area of security. You know that Turkey continues to threaten Greece, continues to threaten Cyprus, constantly violates Greece's airspace, violates Greece's territorial waters and violates the EEZ of Cyprus. I want a statement of yours that supports Greece against Turkey's threats, a statement of yours that supports Cyprus so that it can exploit natural resources, especially at a time when the Italian company Eni also wants to work with Cyprus on the exploitation of natural resources and is threatened by Turkey and Italy and Eni and Cyprus. We want a statement of yours here in the European Parliament in support of Greece and Cyprus and condemnation of the threats made by Erdoğan and Turkey, Prime Minister. The Greek people expect it. Our friends in Cyprus are also waiting for it. We need a statement of support.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is important to remind ourselves that our country is going through a recession and, unfortunately, I have not heard, Mr President, talk about industrial policy or trade policy, nor have I heard you talk about our businesses. The trade agreements that are being implemented in Europe mean made-in, they mean import-export, they mean the growth of a country.  I believe that today Italy needs, I do not know if you agree, that taxation should be reduced, that our companies should be able to reduce labour costs, that they should be able to benefit from tax relief and that subsidy policies should be abandoned, which serve no purpose other than to guess, in some way, how to combat poverty and inequality.  I therefore believe that it is important, Mr President, that you emphasise this and give us an answer.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, as some colleagues, and not only Italians, have already mentioned, we are working here on projects that have the ambition to do good for Italy, but also for Europe, and the high-capacity transport line in the Mediterranean, which is not called Turin-Lyons, because it is not turin-Lyon, is the line aimed at rebalancing the entire traffic system of transport systems to the south. , which is intended to enable all Mediterranean ports to develop.  His government, he has still told us, has prepared a price-benefit analysis report, which does not take into account the time scale of an investment that will last one hundred and fifty years: the current line, absolutely inadequate, has one hundred and forty-nine, in a year we will celebrate the hundred and fifty years. Mr President, I believe that, if you learn to reason as a European and not just to take account of the small Italian slats, perhaps you can tell us something more the next few times.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as an ELECTED MEMBER of Parliament in Sweden, I am proud to be Italian. But I recognize myself less and less in my great country: Italy that works, that has an immense heart, that does not stand by and watch when children are left at sea, that believes in human values and that knows that Europe is our common future. In less than a year, Italy has lost ground, image and credibility on all fronts. It worries the unholy management of the economy, which has led Italy to recession. Young people, Mr President, are asking for work, not begging; dignity, not propaganda: what concrete answers does it intend to give – perhaps you can also listen to me – to the unemployed and to the scourge of debt that impoverishes families and businesses? But even more worrying is the sovereignist drift of his government, which weakens Italy in the world. Europe is the solution, not the problem. The Italians want a country capable of building bridges, not digging ditches. It is all very well to reform Europe, but it cannot be done alone. Italy must be helped more on migration, it is right, but solidarity is achieved through dialogue, not insults. All that is enough is for these absurd slews with our neighbours, no more bad companies like Putin. It is not by isolating one's progress, but by building alliances. President Conte: change course! De Gasperi and Spinelli are watching it.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Mr President, therefore, Mr Prime Minister, you are talking about coyote in Europe, about a solidarity Europe, a Europe without division, and your Interior Minister and our President of Parliament are making statements that rouse the fears that commemorate hatred and atrocities.  I'm talking about what happened a few days ago in Bazovica. It's like all the victims are in vain. In this way, too, Mr President of Parliament, you are tearing down coexistence, trampling the values of the European Union and denying, in fact, history.  This is also an insult to all the victims who were needed so that people along the Slovenian-Italian border can live in peace today. Such conduct and these words must be strongly condemned, and even after what we are getting from our country, I think it is my duty to call on you to resign.

name: Giuseppe Conte
text: President of the Italian Council of Ministers. Thank you, Mr President, some of the speeches have raised political issues. Political debate is the salt of democracy and welcome, even if it is lively, even if the confrontation can be bitter. Other speeches should not be commented on because they have obviously thought of offending not only myself, but the entire people that I represent.  (Applause) There have been those who have had the boldness – I say this very calmly, Mr Tajani – there has even been a group leader, so that he also has a responsibility to represent a group, which has given puppets to those who represent the Italian people. I'm not a puppet, I don't feel. I play and I am proud to represent an entire people. I am proud to interpret the desire for change of the Italian people and I am proud to summarise a political line of a government that is not a puppet because it does not respond to logic, to lobbies, it does not respond to business committees. Perhaps puppets are the ones that respond to lobbies, power groups and business committees.  (Applause) I have been told – and I believe that we are also outside the frank, bitter, political debate – that I should be ashamed of a fragment of illegally eavesled conversation between myself and Chancellor Merkel. I would like to remind those who dared to be publicly ashamed on my behalf that perhaps in the past there has been a member of a party that has far more records than Chancellor Merkel in terms of appreciation. Perhaps then we were not ashamed.  (Applause and laughter) I would also like to point out – and this is the third aspect that I believe is outside a frank, albeit bitter – debate that it has been said that my ministers are not taking part in European ministerial councils, namely that my government is not represented at European ministerial tables. I do not have to teach the grammar of the European institutions, but I would like to point out that the government is also represented by an Undersecretary, a delegate, and we have always manned all European tables. Is that clear? We have always manned all European tables!  I would like to point out, then, in order to be even more frank and direct, that you are a member of a party that has not been adequately guarded in the past with regard to the EMA affair, and we are still paying the consequences.  (Applause and exclamations) However much, Mr President... (The President cut the speaker off to address the House)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I beg you all not to use inconvenient languages. You can say whatever you like, you can support any political thesis, but the important thing is not to offend the other representatives, all legitimately elected by the people, and not to offend even the President of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic who was invited by us here, has not imposed himself. So I ask everyone to have a more correct language, especially to my Italian compatriots.

name: Giuseppe Conte
text: President of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic. Thank you, Mr President, but I come to the political questions that have been raised, some very interesting ones. I would like to answer a specific question: I have been asked for support for Cyprus and Greece. I would like to remind you that on 29 January I was in Nicosia, where we also held a joint final press conference with seven other countries in Southern Europe, took specific positions and therefore support for Cyprus has already taken place. As far as the other issues are concerned, however, shameful things have been said for Italy, for example that we allow children to die at sea. But this is a falsehood of unprecedented gravity! It is a falsehood of unprecedented gravity. I said it earlier: we have a duty to inform ourselves if we speak here. I said earlier that we have always taken action to ensure protection for the most vulnerable people, even in the most glaring and emergency cases we have immediately secured women and children, had them transhipped to other ships or disembarked. If we have taken stock, it was because we really want concrete solidarity, that we move from principles to deeds in Europe and that the other countries also behave accordingly. With regard to the issue with France, I have said it several times: Italy has an ancient link, not only economic but also cultural, with France. To think that the relationship between the two countries is called into question by a disagreement, by a single divergence, is something crazy. We are two culturally and economically integrated systems, so none of this. Vice-President Di Maio, moreover, said that the meeting he had with some members of the gilets jaunes movement was, of course, done in his capacity as leader of a political movement. So we enter into a dimension, that of political dialectics, where choices may be questionable, but they are legitimate.  As far as Venezuela is concerned, something has also been said here that is blatantly false: that Italy supports Maduro, that Italy does not press for the presidential elections, that I said that there is no hurry. But all our statements are the opposite. The Maduro regime is by no means supported by Italy. We have stated that the presidential elections, the whole of the European Parliament, have not recognised them. We have not sent anyone, we have not endorsed them at all, we do not believe that President Maduro has democratic legitimacy. We are calling for free presidential elections as soon as possible – do we write it in large billboards? – free, democratic and transparent as soon as possible, precisely because there is a population that is suffering. And we simply do not believe that this result is achieved by siding with and elevating and recognising as president someone who has proclaimed himself as such. We believe that this, on the contrary, slows down the process leading to a rapid and democratic solution.  The subject of the economy and the fact that we have been asked why Italy is not paying attention to an industrial policy, including a European one, has still been touched on. We have recognised the importance of the Juncker Plan – as I have also said – we have always supported the importance of an EU industrial policy, and we have also stressed the importance of a budget for the eurozone, even with a stabilising function.  Again to stay on the subject of economic and social policy, we were told: but why, do you see that you are not growing? But be ware, but should we discount past economic policies? Perhaps it is still a little early, it is still a little early to assess the effects of an economic manoeuvre that now contains measures, which are now still being implemented, are still being implemented. In fact, I have reasoned for an economic recovery that will develop in the second half of 2019 because, reasonably, our economic policy, our measures will not be able to be fully implemented in these very first months.  And to think that we are not attentive to production and the production system, to think that we are not engaging in the investment plan, is something – as I said before – completely wrong. We are working on this, I will just tell you that yesterday, to give an example, I was in three regions of southern Italy, where economic growth is struggling compared to others, where there is no social development, to sign three development contracts: Basilicata, Molise and Sardinia. This government has a very practical, pragmatic approach, and absolutely seeks to support economic growth with all the measures it has implemented. Citizenship income, you see, could also be a purely welfare measure. There has been a lot of talk about this, I am talking about this measure because it has catalysed the public debate a little. This measure could be merely a waste of resources, a welfare measure. In fact, it was conceived on the basis of a work pact, a training pact and social inclusion mechanisms to recover many people – we are talking about five million poor people who will be directly affected – who at the moment are absolutely outside any social, productive, working mechanism, and therefore in accordance with article 3, second paragraph , of our wonderful Italian Constitution, have no real chance of participating in the economic, democratic, political and social life of our country.  Thank you, Mr President.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr President-in-Office of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic, for accepting our invitation. I apologise for the fact that tones that do not belong to me have sometimes been used, but the Chamber is always lively and when the debates are lively it means that there is interest in the subjects in question, especially with regard to the future of our Union. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. Mr Prime Minister, thank you for the fine words you have just spoken, but above all for your presence here, which allows us to confront ourselves far from the disinformation hood of the Italian context. You will certainly have greeted the supporters of your government today, my colleagues, in Pro-European Italy, while here in Parliament they sit with Farage and le Pen's friends. And on this alleged ambiguity, which is supposed only for Italy, we will vote for the renewal of the European Parliament. Meanwhile, in the grip of propaganda fury, Italy is isolating and it is not understood how we want to be in this Europe. From here, Mr Conte, everything seems meaningless. You have made alliances with countries that will never help Italy on migrants, and you have deteriorated your relationship with France, which has come to recall its ambassador from Rome. Some of your ministers sympathise in the home of others with the most violent fringes of jaunes gilets and cross the border without respecting the procedures laid down for state summits. Dear Premier, where are we going? Where are you taking Italy, and with whom do you intend to build Europe?

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support the criticism expressed here in plenary of Italy's migration, economic and financial policies. And I am proud to see the vehemence with which our bourgeois parties have defended the values and foundations of the EU.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – The EU must sit and speak with one voice in the UN Cs. But Italy is one of the Member States that has dynamited this plan that requires solidarity and cohesion. It's seeing the conflict your government has created with France. It is true that Italy is at the forefront of the inflows of migrants and refugees and has been unfairly and stupidly left alone for a long time. But that started to change in 2015. But instead of demanding more solidarity, his government has devastated all efforts for the EU to manage the inflows and integration of migrants and refugees, notably by boycotting the revision of the Dublin regulation on the basis of Salvini's populist, xenophobic, racist and anti-European discourse. Just as In America Prohibition was Al Capone's best friend, in italy today flourish mafias that are gaining from the inhuman hunt for migrants, refugees and activists trying to help them. With the lack of legal and safe routes in the EU to manage flows of refugees and immigrants, the mafias that traffic them feed are fed. Today, the Al Capone of these mafias seems to be in your government and called salvini.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – I am pleased to see that, now that the migration crisis is in its fourth year, there are finally those who dare to call the problem by its name in the face of political correctness. Now that it is clear from the surveys that this is one, if not the most important, issue for the European electorate, elected representatives are starting to address the issue. Consistently, for years, we have said that the influx of masses can only be intercepted by strict protection of the external borders, and that problems can be solved at the place where they were created. You don't have to bring the people here, you have to bring the help there. It is important that, once we have finally faced the problem, we will really solve it and not just make it worse. The degradation of national border protection powers or the mandatory allocation quota were precisely such sham solutions that would have only exacerbated the crisis. I hope this wave of confrontation is not just another reason for stealth legislation.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – Thank you for your call to restart the European project.  But it is from your country that we hear very dangerous, hostile views. Last weekend in Bazovica, the President of the European Parliament, Tajani, made a profound fuss and scare off Slovenes with revisionist statements justifying fascism. It was intolerable to perish on historical facts for the need to awaken Italian patriotism. The Social Democrats in Slovenia therefore demanded yesterday that the President of the EP resign. Dear President Tajani, your apology was ridiculed. Instead of regretting the statements, you have accused us of misinterpreting you and fueling intolerance. It's not exactly a contribution to peace. With such statements, you have lost all the credibility that a boss of such an important institution must have.  Dear President Conte, how do you look at the representatives of Casa Pound and their provocations against The Slovenes, students, recently in Gorizia? I call on you to devote yourself to a sincere policy of strengthening peace and mutual understanding on both sides of the border. There is no place for fascism in the European Union!

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – Italy's budget has been since the government changed in Italy. In an unprecedented gesture, the European Commission 'failed' the proposal for a State Budget put forward by the Government of Italy, giving it a deadline of three weeks to review the document and adjust it to the rules of the euro and economic governance. This episode reveals in itself once again the deeply undemocratic nature of the European Union and confirms its line of interference and imposition of the rules and constraints of the Stability Pact and the Budgetary Treaty. But when we thought we had seen everything, behold, when everything pointed to the imposition of yet another excessive deficit procedure, France, to solve its internal problems, decided to stick to the deficit rule. There was never any mention of the Italian case. What has been negotiated within the Eurogroup does not know. But what this episode confirms is that, once again, the rules do not apply equally to all eurozone countries where there appear to be children and stepchildren.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Kolejnym punktem porządku dziennego jest wspólna debata nad: – zaleceniem sporządzonym przez Davida Martina w imieniu Komisji Handlu Międzynarodowego dotyczącym projektu decyzji Rady w sprawie zawarcia Umowy o wolnym handlu między Unią Europejską a Republiką Singapuru (07971/2018 - C8-0446/2018 - 2018/0093(NLE)) (A8-0053/2019), – sprawozdaniem sporządzonym przez Davida Martina w imieniu Komisji Handlu Międzynarodowego zawierającym projekt rezolucji nieustawodawczej w sprawie projektu decyzji Rady w sprawie zawarcia Umowy o wolnym handlu między Unią Europejską a Republiką Singapuru (2018/0093M(NLE)) (A8-0048/2019), – zaleceniem sporządzonym przez Davida Martina w imieniu Komisji Handlu Międzynarodowego dotyczącym projektu decyzji Rady w sprawie zawarcia, w imieniu Unii Europejskiej, Umowy o ochronie inwestycji między Unią Europejską i jej państwami członkowskimi, z jednej strony, a Republiką Singapuru, z drugiej strony (07979/2018 - C8-0447/2018 - 2018/0095(NLE)) (A8-0054/2019) , – a report by David Martin, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, the Investment Protection Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Singapore, of the other part (2018/0095M (NLE)) (A8-0049/2019), – recommendation by Antonio López-Istúriz White, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Singapore, of the other part (15375/2018 - C8-0026/2019 - 2018/0 (A8-0020/2019) and – a report by Antonio López-Istúriz White, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the , on behalf of the European Union, the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Singapore, of the other part (2018/0403M(NLE)) (A8-0023/2019).

name: David MARTIN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, well, finally we are here. It’s been over a decade in the making, the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Singapore, but after many twists and turns, we are at last at the final stage. I’d like to begin by thanking the Government of Singapore for its patience and support, and in particular their Ambassador for his good cooperation. I’d also like to thank the Commissioner and DG Trade for an agreement that I believe we can readily support in this House, and above all, I’d like to thank my shadow rapporteurs for what has been great cooperation. My question to those who are still sceptical is: frankly, what is not to like about this free trade agreement? It builds on Canada and Japan and sends the message that the EU is committed to a rules-based trading system. While Donald Trump wants to build walls to separate nations, we are tearing them down, keeping fair and free trade alive. Singapore is a safe harbour for EU trade and investment, and what a harbour! An important market in its own right, thanks to its unshakable commitment to the rule of law, it has one of the highest per capita incomes in the world and now has more than 10 000 EU companies based there. Many of them are looking forward, as a result of this FTA, to expanding their activities and vying for public sector contracts in Singapore. Singapore is important in its own right, but it’s also of key strategic importance for accessing the ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) region, one of the fastest growing regions in the world. Singapore is a major hub, through which a large percentage of our exports pass, and, with the entry into force of the Trans-Pacific Partnership of 11 countries, if we do nothing we will lag behind those nations. So in economic terms this clearly is a win—win trade deal. In addition to the trade benefits, however, I would also argue that the agreement clearly reflects EU values and positions espoused by this Parliament in very many of our resolutions. For example, nothing in this agreement will prevent the application of the precautionary principle or affect the right of governments to regulate in the interest of their citizens. Public services are protected: the agreement uses the positive list for services, always the preferred option of this Parliament. Imports will have to respect EU standards. It contains commitments on the environment, in respect of the management of forests and fisheries, for example, and a commitment to implement multilateral agreements, including the Paris Agreement. I particularly welcome Singapore’s agreement to the early implementation of the Trade and Sustainable Development chapter and the commitment to take concrete steps to ratify the outstanding three core International Labour Organisation (ILO) conventions. They are serious about this. Singapore has already held talks with the social partners, they are already in dialogue with the ILO and they’ve set up an interministerial working group to see how they can bring domestic legislation into line with the three ILO conventions. Moving on to the Investment Protection Agreement, I believe this is the most progressive investment agreement we have so far negotiated, and it should be a model to build on for future agreements. I want to thank the Commissioner and her team for listening to Parliament’s concerns about the old and toxic investor-state dispute settlement system. This investment court system will have a permanent tribunal composed of judges or jurors of recognised competence, not arbiters. There will be a code of conduct for judges, proceedings will be transparent, the system will have an appeal mechanism, it contains a commitment to joint efforts towards a multilateral investment court, and it protects governments’ right to regulate. It is also worth mentioning that this replaces the existing 13 bilateral investment treaties that Member States already have. The last point I want to make is that this agreement has one major weakness, which, I believe, should be addressed in future investment agreements. It gives investors rights but it gives them no obligations. We have to look forward to giving them obligations in the future. With that caveat, I’m pleased to commend both of these agreements to this Parliament.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much, Mr Martin. I have a heartfelt request: we have a delay of 50 minutes, so I ask you to respect the allotted time very carefully, because we should conclude our debate before midnight. For the above reasons, I also ask you not to ask questions by raising a blue card.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you to my colleague, David Martin, and I also meet him for thanking the Ambassador of Singapore, who has certainly been of great help to all of us in drawing up these reports, presenting us with a transparent and always well-informed picture of the realities of Singapore. Fifteen years have passed since the Council authorized the Commission to negotiate an agreement with Singapore, and it was time to complete this procedure. Tomorrow we take a step forward by voting on our consent to the Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation and the Free Trade and Investment Protection Agreements. Today, once again, we send a strong message about the European Union's commitment to international cooperation and multilateralism, to others — we already know who. In a world where international cooperation is questioned, the European Union stands firm and points to the importance of international cooperation. This Agreement with Singapore seeks to institutionalize relationships dating back several decades and is based on a long history of friendship and close historical, political and economic ties. The new legal framework for bilateral relations will provide a strengthening of cooperation between Singapore and the European Union. The objective is to cooperate on issues such as justice, security, climate change, development; issues to which our citizens are very attentive. I remember the geostrategic importance of Singapore. It is an essential player in ensuring regional stability and balance in the Asia-Pacific region. And the security and stability of the region is important for Europe, European businesses and Europeans. Indeed, Singapore is the gateway to the Asian market and a platform for European companies, strategically located among the major economies that are China, India and Japan. These agreements improve the investment climate and will offer greater certainty to European investors. I would like to stress that, within the framework of this Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, we are going to set up a Standing Joint Committee, a committee composed of representatives from both sides at a high level who will have the mission of working on a daily basis to meet the established objectives of cooperation. We will be privileged partners in making decisions on issues such as international security, scientific and technological cooperation; in sectors such as energy, the environment, natural resources and transport, in particular maritime and air transport. We will cooperate on information society issues and, above all, cybersecurity. It is important to cooperate on these issues, because it is a global field that knows no borders, and because our companies lose millions with computer attacks, and together we can anticipate attacks and coordinate that fight. We will also increase – very importantly – existing cultural exchanges as well as education programmes for young Europeans – Erasmus Mundus, among others – and support new business and employment opportunities for our young people. Singapore can become that platform for our young people towards the Asian labour market. I would also like to point out the importance of this Agreement for global security and the fight against terrorism. The only way to combat this scourge that puts our welfare model in check is by establishing bridges of cooperation with other countries, exchanging data and information, stopping funding and thus making terrorist attacks impossible wherever they occur. This Agreement means a window open to all European entrepreneurs and companies so that they can establish trade relations, not only with Singapore, but also with other Asian countries. More than 10,000 companies and entrepreneurs in the European Union are based in Singapore and use it as a hub to serve the entire Pacific region. A stable legal framework is the cornerstone of any partnership agreement. By giving European entrepreneurs and companies legal certainty in their relations with Singapore, we are opening up new business opportunities, promoting their investments, growth and expansion. Whenever our citizens can freely and safely develop their business ideas and projects, we are creating the right environment to drive new jobs. I have mentioned issues such as climate change before, and I want to emphasize this. Singapore's geopolitical importance in responding to natural and humanitarian disasters in South-East Asia is crucial. The European Union will now have a privileged platform to cooperate and participate in Singapore's climate change policy decision-making process, providing our know-how in the fight against change climate policy, a key policy of our Union. Finally, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs in all this work for their help and cooperation in this report, and I am confident that tomorrow we will be able to approve with a large majority this Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation with Singapore. I believe that this is a huge achievement for all of us and, of course, a source of stability, employment and a guarantee of the future, also for our international relations.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the two rapporteurs, David Martin and Antonio López-Istúriz White, for the good work they have done and the long journey that we have travelled jointly, which has brought us to where we are today. Few places symbolise the benefits of trade and investments like Singapore. Singapore’s determination in embracing openness and globalisation has transformed a city state without natural resources into one of the most prosperous countries in the world and has helped its people prosper too. Singapore has become a model of economic transformation and a prime example of how trade, investment and sustainable development can and should go hand in hand. Embracing openness has served the EU well in the past, too, and still shines a light on the way forward as we discuss the issues facing us today. Close partners for decades, the EU and Singapore have decided to seal our partnership through the three agreements that we are talking about today and that you will vote on tomorrow. The new EU-Singapore Partnership and Cooperation Agreement will lay down the overall framework for bilateral political cooperation between two like-minded partners. But we are also very close investment and trade partners. Singapore is currently our largest trade and investment partner in south-east Asia and among our top 20 trading partners for goods, our top five for services and our top ten partners for foreign direct investment. The trade and investment agreements between the EU and Singapore will provide a framework for these already strong flows to develop further. The benefits of the trade agreement are many. Tariffs on bilateral trade will be removed. Non-tariff barriers on EU exports for cars, electronics and renewables we’ll do away with. Access to service procurement markets will be improved, and all this will create opportunities for businesses and for individuals on both sides. The agreement further contains a comprehensive trade and sustainable development chapter that includes obligations in relation to international conventions on workers’ rights and the environment; covers areas like biodiversity, eco-labelling and corporate and social responsibility; and gives a strong role to EU and Singapore civil society groups in making sure that these commitments are put into practice. Ratification of, and compliance with, International Labour Organisation (ILO) fundamental conventions will figure among priority items to focus and deliver on. We need to see sustained efforts in this respect, as of the agreement’s entry into force. And here already the Singaporean authorities have shown good engagement in preparing for the implementation of the agreement’s sustainable development provisions. The trade agreement was also negotiated together with an investment protection agreement that contains the fully reformed investment protection system developed at EU level, which the European Parliament requested and helped to shape – and I would like to thank you for this support. This system addresses the concerns civil society has expressed about vaguely defined rules, lack of transparency, absence of appeal, lack of independence of adjudicators and lack of accountability in bilateral investment agreements that we have today. So, delivering on the negotiating mandate, the Commission has presented for consent an agreement that tightens the standards on investment protection so as to prevent abuses, an agreement that fully safeguards a government’s right to make new laws to protect health, the environment and other public interests. It thus establishes a fully transparent investment court system, a system which, in the very recent opinion of the Advocate-General in relation to a trade agreement with Canada, has been considered fully compatible with the EU Treaties. That is a stepping-stone towards the multilateral investment courts that could potentially cover all 3 000 existing investment agreements worldwide and could play a central role in the future development of investment policy, including a possible evolution to include investors’ obligations, as Mr Martin mentioned. So these trade and investment agreements negotiated with Singapore are state-of-the-art agreements with a privileged bilateral trade and investment partner to the EU. And, beyond being a partner, Singapore is a beating commercial heart of the south-east Asian region so, in that sense, the agreement will constitute a benchmark for negotiation with other Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) partners. Lastly, on the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, this is, of course, a stepping stone towards enhanced political and economic involvement between the EU and Singapore, as well as the whole region. It provides a basis, as the rapporteur mentioned, for effective bilateral engagement with Singapore, strengthening the political dialogue and enhancing cooperation in a variety of areas – human and labour rights, justice, security, connectivity, people-to-people links, the information society, education and cultural exchanges, as well as employment and social affairs. It will enable us to step up scientific and technological cooperation in areas such as energy, environment, the fight against climate change, protection of natural resources, smart cities and transport. Under this agreement, a joint committee will be established comprising representatives of both sides at an appropriately high level to ensure the proper functioning of the agreement and see that it is implemented. It will also set priorities and make recommendations to promote the agreement’s objectives. On regional dynamics, Singapore has advocated regional multilateralism in South-east Asia and is currently the country coordinator for EU-ASEAN dialogue relations. We value that partnership very much and we are committed to ensuring that it will become even stronger. The collaboration with Singapore on ASEAN-related matters has been very fruitful so far. Cooperation between Singapore and the EU is already deep and wide today and, given the challenges that we are jointly facing, the potential for even greater engagement is significant – founded on a shared vision, a rule-based multilateral system and effective multilateralism. So thank you to the European Parliament for the work that has been done here. We are looking forward to strong support in tomorrow’s vote.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, firstly my thanks to rapporteurs David Martin and Antonio López-Istúriz White for their great work and cooperation on this issue, and also to all the shadow rapporteurs. This has been a long time in the making but, thankfully, we’re here at last debating it and hopefully voting on it tomorrow. The value of trade between Singapore and the European Union is, for the European Union exports, EUR 55 billion, and, for the exports from Singapore to us, EUR 44 billion. That trade is set to grow rapidly and enormously with this very good Free Trade Agreement (FTA), and I compliment Commissioner Malmström for her work in that regard. Many areas will benefit. I know that, in Ireland, the agricultural sector will benefit hugely, and that will be very important to them, as they are concerned about what might happen with our exports to the United Kingdom post Brexit. This shows that the European Union is working for them and for us, and is planning ahead. I would also like to say that the removal of tariffs and non-tariff barriers is going to help a whole host of businesses, and the Investment Protection Agreement (IPA), which I must mention briefly, is a wonderful, progressive proposal dealing with the problems around investor-state dispute settlement. Lastly, if we can agree to a Japan deal and a Canadian deal we should agree by an even greater majority to the Singapore deal. If we do so tomorrow evening, we can have a toast with Irish whiskey to this wonderful agreement.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, a few weeks after the vote in this Parliament on the agreement with Japan, we are once again discussing the conclusion of a strategic agreement for the European Union, its citizens, its workers and its businesses. The European Union, after the vacuum left by the United States, is establishing itself as the absolute protagonist on the global trade stage. Our third way to trade, which is antithetical to protectionism and unbridled liberalism, has never been more attractive. Thanks to this partnership we are able to project our standards and values globally. Thanks to the clauses on the protection of workers, consumers and the environment, we are able to protect citizens from the side effects of globalisation.  To name a few, I am referring to singapore's commitments to ratify the World Labour Organisation conventions, to respect the Paris climate agreement, but also to recognise our geographical indications, such as PDOs, OCDs. Not only that: we cannot forget that more than 90% of global economic growth in the coming years will take place outside our borders. These agreements therefore provide a fundamental outlet for supporting employment and growth. Singapore is the gateway to the ASEAN region in South-East Asia, the most dynamic economic region in the world: markets that are increasingly important for our European productions, and I am not referring to the large multinationals: more than 80% of European companies in Singapore are small and medium-sized enterprises. Exports to Singapore have guaranteed 33 billion euros in turnover to our companies.  Will the agreement, by increasing these numbers, create thousands of jobs in Europe and at what cost? No one, singapore's economy is totally complementary to the European economy: from the industrial sector to the agricultural sector, no sector of our economic system is in competitive conflict with Singapore. Faced with these facts, with these numbers, we must have no doubt: these agreements are fundamental for European workers, whose products are sold and appreciated throughout the world and for citizens, who will receive greater protection against the possible adverse side effects of globalisation.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the EU—Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) is yet another example of the EU’s highly successful global free trade agenda – we’ve just heard about the conclusion of the Japan agreement – that is opening up markets across the world for all of the EU’s current 28 Member States. As Britain stands just 45 days away from leaving the European Union, I’m reminded once again of all the disingenuous untruths and false promises peddled by the Brexiteers in the Leave campaign. One of those was that Britain needed to leave the European Union in order to strike optimal trade deals with the Commonwealth and the Anglosphere countries that the EU was neither interested in nor capable of concluding in the UK’s bilateral interest. Yet here we are today discussing an EU trade deal with Singapore, a Commonwealth and ASEAN country, following on from the EU’s FTA with Canada whilst talks on FTAs with Australia and New Zealand are now in advanced stages.
