Far from the UK needing to leave the EU to improve trading links with the Commonwealth, it seems patently obvious that, following 29 March, the EU—27 will enjoy far better opportunities to trade with the Commonwealth than the UK will for many years to come. James Dyson, the British industrialist and leading Brexiteer, has clearly appreciated these benefits as he embarks on building his electric vehicle production plant in Singapore and has moved the company’s headquarters from Britain to that prosperous city—state. My case rests.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me start by saying that cooperation between the rapporteur, David Martin, and all the shadow rapporteurs has been very good. The clear vote in favour on the Free Trade Agreement that we had in the Committee on International Trade (INTA) last month reflects this excellent cooperation. I also want to thank the Ambassador of Singapore and his Government for their cooperation and patience. I strongly support both the Free Trade Agreement and the Investment Protection Agreement. This is a win—win fair deal for both sides and for both consumers and companies. Negotiations between the EU and Singapore were launched in December 2009. Nearly 10 years later, here we are, finally. Singapore is by far the EU’s largest partner in Asia, accounting for almost a third of EU—Asian trade in goods and services. More than 10 000 European companies have their regional offices in Singapore and they operate in a reliable business and regulatory environment. Singapore is also a trade and transport hub to Asia and a gateway to the major growth economies of the world. This agreement can be a model for other Asian countries as it is the first in this region. With regard to the Investment Protection Agreement (IPA), it replaces 13 old bilateral investment treaties between individual Member States and Singapore. Tomorrow, I hope we will vote in favour of a new and modern investment court system. The IPA protects the parties’ right to regulate and to achieve legitimate policy objectives in areas such as public health, safety and the environment. Moreover, there is no protection of investors’ profit expectation. Furthermore, the Investment Protection Agreement defines fair and equitable treatment, preventing forum shopping and parallel claims, among other things. Lastly, I want to recognise Commissioner Malmström’s efforts to improve dialogue, accountability and transparency. Growth in Europe comes with trade and not with more public debt. Given Brexit and Trump, multilateralism today is welcome and we should keep going in this direction.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I have three serious objections to the investment protection agreement with Singapore. This agreement again includes a paragraph on ISDS, investor-state arbitration. Yes, I know you call it different, but that's what it is. We know that companies can make claims if governments make justifiable decisions that threaten their profits. And the taxpayer is paying for that. It undermines the rule of law and democracy. Secondly, the agreement offers exclusive rights to investors, but does not include enforceable rules to achieve the sustainability goals. This puts pressure on the interests of people, animals and the environment. Thirdly, the agreement explicitly allows foreign investors to buy up government bonds. In the event of a crisis, these investors can then block restructuring of public debt. The way in which Parliament and this Commission prioritise the interests of multinationals in general, and the financial sector in particular, over the interests of citizens is unacceptable. Nearly half a million people have signed a petition against ISDS in recent weeks to stop such treaties. My call to you is: stop ISDS. Stop these kinds of trade treaties. And stop class justice for multinationals. Thank you very much.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. What lasts for a long time is finally going to be good, they say in Germany. It has been granted for a long time. I have to say singapore was very patient with us. I congratulate Singapore on finally achieving their goal now that they have the responsibility for coordinating the EU-ASEAN dialogue.  The agreements show that Europe is seeking increased cooperation with Asia in order to realise our values and interests. We need strategic partnership. We also want a strategic partnership with ASEAN to pursue security and development in the Indo-Pacific region. We want to strengthen connectivity between the EU and Asia and we want to work together multilaterally. Finally, we want the full application of human rights, from freedom of expression and assembly, to the abolition of the death penalty, and environmental and social progress. But I must raise a problem, and I am saying this in English so that the Singaporeans will understand: public debt titles should not be covered by investment protection agreements (IPAs). Since the financial crisis of 2007, the EU has had standards and procedures if a government defaults on its debt and the debt needs restructuring. Here, the Singapore IPA creates a loophole. As the German business daily Handelsblatt writes today: 'The IPA increases the threshold for investor consent in debt-restructuring procedures vis—a—a—vis the level that otherwise exists in the EU.' Investors that operate under this IPA would be privileged over other investors. That's unacceptable. That's why we demand that there should be no vote on the IPA tomorrow until Annex 4 on public debt is removed.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, corporations cannot be given the power to sue states. If you have applied for this Parliament, it is because, like me, you firmly believe that you can make a difference to your citizens and if you want to continue to do so, if you want the decisions taken in this House to be truly independent, you cannot vote in favour of the investment agreement with Singapore. This agreement is even worse than CETA and will enable large corporations to sue our governments, our regions, our municipalities. The laws we pass here will no longer be of any value because they could be dismantled by arbitration courts of unscrupulous lawyers as soon as they affect the interests of the great powerful in the economy.  Ladies and gentlemen, I believe in international trade and I always support it when it brings real benefits for our businesses: but here we are not just talking about trade, but about two different agreements and we must make a clear distinction: there is an investment agreement, which will allow corporations to sue states, and a genuine free trade agreement, which only concerns exports and imports. The latter is certainly good for our economy: it will allow us to expand into a fast-growing market such as Asia and, normally, I would have no problem supporting such an agreement that is exclusively commercial. However, I would like to point out that these negotiations have been carried out with a certain lack of transparency and I would like to say that the Commission has only informed Parliament of the problems connected with the protection of certain geographical indications.  For this reason, we will carefully consider how to react to these other crazy things. But one thing is certain: we will oppose the Investment Treaty, because it contains that infamous special court, which only allows the demands of the multinationals to be pursued, something to which we had already strongly opposed with CETA and we will continue to fight here too. That is why the citizens voted for us.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, trade has no enemies, and that is the credo of the Commission, its technocrats and free traders of all stripes. While the European Union has already largely abandoned its borders and eliminated its tariffs on almost all of its tariff lines, this treaty with Singapore, a veritable warehouse and crossroads of international trade, is in addition to all other free trade agreements under way or in the future. This opens our doors to goods from Asia, the Pacific, North America and Europe, which will put our economy at serious risk. And this agreement is all the more dangerous, especially for French and European consumers, as Singapore does not recognise a large part of our European standards. As for the values of the European Union, let us not talk about them anymore, they stop definitively and systematically where the financial interests of multinationals begin. Freedom of the press, human rights or the fact that Singapore is on a grey list of tax havens, none of this bothers the Commission. Trade has no enemy, except that neither France nor Europe benefits from these exchanges, as for multinationals, yes. Except that this ultra-liberal policy of profit, chicanery and procedure, people don't want it anymore. They want to decide what goes into their territory, what ends up on the stalls of their market or on their plate. They are now determined to defend themselves against this globalist policy of blissful Europeanists: what a harmful treaty has done, the people will eventually defeat.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to confine myself to a few points.  Firstly, it is the first agreement negotiated after the ECJ ruling on the sole competence or mixed competence of free trade agreements. In this respect, it is a very modern, progressive agreement on which we will vote tomorrow.  My second point is the first part of the free trade agreement. Singapore has committed itself to the ILO Labour Conventions and has undertaken in writing to ratify them. That is in our interest. It is actually a victory for us and for the Commissioner who conducted the negotiations. In the Investment Protection Agreement, we have agreed on a bilateral court with an appeal mechanism. What we have been calling for here in Parliament for years is now written down. Singapore has made a committed statement. That is also positive for us.  Singapore will be a door opener for trade with the entire fast-growing ASEAN region. That is why the PPE-DE will vote in favour. Thank you for working with all those involved.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Trade for all, which the Commission so often advocates, continues to be a long way off. This trade agreement is once again perpetuating a radical market policy from which only large corporations benefit. Sustainability, workers' rights and environmental standards play a minor or no role in comparison. Singapore has not ratified and implemented the eight core labour standards. We therefore need the possibility of sanctions for infringements. But even these are searched in vain in this text. In the case of the Investment Protection Agreement, ICS is an improvement, but it has not changed in terms of the fundamental problem itself. Foreign investors still have privileged special rights to the national courts. This is not what value-based trading looks like to me. That is why, as in the Committee on Trade, I will be voting against both the trade agreement and the investment protection agreement with Singapore.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I am already sitting in this Parliament for the third term, so I remember well how long it took us to get here, because, especially with the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Singapore, we have been living here since the last parliamentary term. Now that we're finally at the end of the road, I think we can all congratulate each other on that. And it is not just that Singapore is now the technological and logistical center of the world, or at least Southeast Asia, it is also that the EU is so clearly at the forefront of the liberalisation of world trade. It is important that another similar agreement with Singapore is approved here after Japan, and I would just like to remind you that we have one more debt that awaits us, that is similar to the treaty with Vietnam. I want to firmly believe that we will also be able to vote here before the end of this Parliament's parliamentary term.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Malmström and colleagues, goods have been exchanged for centuries and over greater distances as modes of transportation connect ever further places around the world. And now increasingly also, because of digitisation, services can be offered anywhere. An interpreter from Australia can translate a book written here in France or a software coder in India can design a website for someone in Brazil. So, clearly, the EU – or we – do not create trade, but what we can and should do is ensure that rules around trade create a level playing field that is predictable and fair, and that we act with the aim of having higher standards and sharing the benefits. Presidents Xi and Trump show us very clearly what the alternative looks like: with no respect for rules, uncertainty damages markets and people’s livelihoods. I think it’s a little bit ironic in this context that I hear such harsh criticism from some of my colleagues, not so much about trade, for example – trade with China – but rather about the trade rules and agreements that we’re trying to agree on. So I’m glad to see those who are showing leadership. I’m glad, too, for our Singaporean partners, with whom we’ve been in the process of negotiating for no less than ten years. Singapore is a major modern open hub for trade services and investment and a strong partner in the south-east Asian region in general. But this agreement will not make the Singaporeans become exactly like us and neither will we copy them. As always, we are responsible for setting our own laws and standards. I’m very happy to see that we have been able to convince the Singaporeans to replace the outdated 13 agreements that included Investor-State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) chapters between different Member States of the EU and Singapore and replace them with the Investment Court System. We pushed for that and it’s good to see the results. It guarantees more transparency, maintains our right to regulate and creates an appeals mechanism; a greater role for civil society. So those who dislike ISDS like I do should actually support this modern agreement with Singapore. I think together we can send a signal – at a time when nationalism and protectionism and populism are rising – that leadership supports openness and that we stand together with partners for fair and rules-based trade.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, free trade agreements follow one another and are similar. They follow each other at an increasingly accelerated pace, it is the end of the mandate, an almost frenetic pace. And they are similar because they always follow the same logic, which is to systematically prioritize the interests of the owners of the capital or the mega-companies over those of consumers and employees. Therefore, from that point of view, there is nothing new in this agreement with Singapore; no constraints on environmental standards, private courts that will favour companies at the expense of states, no binding social standards, rights for investors, but never obligations. I would still like to temper the enthusiasm of colleagues: we are talking about Singapore, and we hear that Europe shares many common values. First of all, it is not a peaceful parliamentary democracy, it is an authoritarian regime. Secondly, and this is also important to us, I point to the contradiction: it is a recognized tax haven, one of the world champions of financial opacity. There is a contradiction on the part of Europe to say: we are tracking tax evasion and, at the same time, we are happily contracting with such a state. So, Commissioner, you say that this is the best possible agreement, but I think there is still a long way to go.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you have rightly touted Singapore's economic dynamics, but one thing you have not praised in Singapore's example is freedom of the press and democracy. And for good reason, this investment agreement is collapsing, undermining democratic systems. How can you not see that the development of populism, the development of nationalisms is being pushed, fuelled by the transfers of sovereignty that you are constantly organising from citizens to multinationals? These arbitration tribunals where tens of thousands of Singapore-based multinationals will be able to attack European states on the environment, health, public services and now even debt restructuring! It's undermining democracies! Europe is democracy, Europe must be citizens, it cannot be multinationals! Please, ladies and gentlemen, reject this investment agreement, we cannot constantly support multinationals, support tax havens, support authoritarian regimes: it undermines democracy, it kills the European project!

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Mr President, it is very good that somebody else is passionate about a trade agreement. Anyway, Singapore is a success story. Singapore now has a bigger GDP per capita than Germany, but Singapore is not – repeat, not – part of a very large trading bloc. Perhaps the ill—informed UK Remainers will note that basic fact. The EU—Singapore deal is a success for free-trade principles and, by the way, to respond to a point made earlier, this agreement has now been signed 45 years after the UK originally joined the EU. The EU’s method of trade agreements is a bit like Strictly Come Dancing: slow, slow, quick, quick, slow. Under the agreement, tariffs will be abolished entirely on a wide range of manufactured goods, and between the EU and Singapore there will be mutual recognition of professional qualifications. But what the agreement does not require is freedom of movement of people. This demonstrates again that free trade and free movement can be – indeed are – entirely separate. Now to Brexit. The EU grants Singapore the abolition of tariffs but, at the same time, the EU sabre-rattles about a hard tariff border with the UK. For Singapore, the EU liberalises trade in services. At the same time, the EU scaremongers about impeding the existing trade in services between the EU and the UK. One day perhaps, the EU will show the same sound commercial sense towards the UK that it is currently showing towards Singapore. However, I have to say it’s probable that that day will come only when the current President of the Council, Donald Tusk, finds his own special place in hell. For the record, Mr Tusk’s planned and toxic abuse will achieve nothing. It doesn’t befit a senior politician and it is not in the least bit helpful. So I recommend to the EU authorities – and I see a distinguished representative here – that they sign a treaty on Brexit similar to that entered into with Singapore.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have heard how beautiful and beneficial the free trade agreement between the EU and Singapore can be. It seems incredible to me: whenever the EU negotiates an investment trade treaty with some partners outside our borders everything always seems to be in our favour. The truth is that this agreement was negotiated at a time that is now out of date. Singapore, as reported in the proposed trade agreement, is a hub located in the Southeast Asian region. The real risk, ladies and gentlemen, is that the advantage of this Treaty will be felt by other players who are not part of the European Union and who do not respect the parameters set for commercial processing. Statistics show Singapore as the third country of origin of counterfeit products in the world. There are no guarantees of combating this phenomenon, which is very present in Asia and of which Italian industry is one of the main victims. We risk opening our doors to cheap taroccati products, of Malaysian, Chinese or Indonesian origin, which in Singapore see only the last stage of processing. Many doubts also remain about protected geographical indications. The system in force in Singapore does not provide for the existence of a register. Our geographical indications will not be automatically protected, but European operators will have to activate the procedures themselves. Singapore is also a global financial centre and the reciprocal liberalisation of financial services is precisely one of the main aims of the agreement, but it could make it possible to circumvent European financial regulations in this area. Some employee associations place Singapore on a grey list of global tax havens, and the agreement provides little guarantee of tax exclusion and the transfer of profits of EU-based multinationals.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to make a comment on the external dimension. How many times have we talked about this here in plenary: the system of a multilateral and rules-based free trade system, which has grown over decades, is under pressure. Existing partners question what has been achieved together and are instead working through protectionist measures to reverse what has been achieved. That is another reason why I believe that the trade and investment protection agreements between the European Union and Singapore are timely. These contracts go beyond purely economic considerations. They are a strong signal of like-minded partners to defend and promote our rules-based international system of cooperation and multilateralism.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In the EU, we are proud that we are not only advocating free trade, but also for value-based trade. It is undoubtedly part of value-based trade that we, like our trading partners, guarantee a minimum of workers' rights. That is why, in all negotiations, we always attach great importance to the ratbeing and implementation of all core ILO labour standards. Singapore is adamantly refusing to do so. The recent letter from the Trade Minister to the chairman of the Trade Committee also shows that Singapore is unwilling to reconsider its anti-employment stance. Instead of concrete implementation plans, the letter contains only white ointment. That is not acceptable. Those who seek privileged trade relations with the EU must also guarantee a minimum level of workers' rights. This is not only important for the protection of the employees there, it is also a question of excluding labour and wage dumping from becoming a competitive advantage.  It is a question of credibility. Anyone who is serious about value-based trade should reject the agreements with Singapore.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, how brilliant to see everyone so excited about doing a trade deal with a dynamic, low-tax, global-facing, island economy! It’s wonderful to see this, and I’ve got good news for you: there’s another one, a hell of a lot closer that you could do a deal with as well, when you finally wake up to reality. The great thing is, that when the UK leaves the EU, Singapore has already provided the mood music to say they’re ready to do a deal with us, because dynamic island economies that love to trade with the whole world like to get things done quickly. They don’t take 10 years of monolithic plodding to get to a point where they’re just about to put a report forward. What they do is to talk about trade. They talk about ways to make one another wealthier, and to get products and services moving between them. That’s how it works. They don’t try and impose rules and regulations and nonsense on one another that takes a decade. I’m looking forward to the same kind of excitement about a trade deal with the UK. You’re going to love it!

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: Mr President, to reach an agreement with Singapore is to give China a first white-seing. Leaving the Malaysian Federation in 1965, Singapore, due to its 75% Chinese demographic component, is an advanced platform for China. Today, more than 65% of Singapore's exports are actually products from China, which are ultimately re-exported. It is therefore opening up the market economy to China, which, in principle, is not a bad thing but which opens the door to a serious, if not fatal, imbalance for our economies, both in terms of quantity and quality of products, whose standards are obviously virtually non-existent compared to ours. Moreover, given the dense and opaque nature of Singapore's banking and financial activities, there is cause for particular concern. We therefore urge you to reject this agreement in the name of the economic protection of the nations of Europe, and of France in particular.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs. The strategic nature of this agreement with Singapore, which is actually the most important trading partner of the Association of Southeast Asian Countries and the third largest exporter, after China and Japan, in the region, has already been underlined here. But I would be more interested in underlining the commitment, as other colleagues have made, for free trade, in favour of fair, rules-based trade, in these times of protectionist temptations. I would like to congratulate the Commission on its excellent trade policy. It is true that these agreements could have been concluded earlier, but, as Commissioner Malmstrom says, many times, in these times of globalisation, it is not just about exports and imports, but about increasingly complex production chains where raw materials and components are assembled into a planetary production chain. Therefore, more and better jobs, greater opportunities for our citizens and more opportunities for our companies.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, Singapore is a trusted and strategic partner of the EU and it’s right that we seek to deepen our relations. As the first ASEAN country to finalise agreements with the EU, these will be models for the region and so they matter. Trade is a powerful tool for human development, but trade agreements are not per se a public good if the rules of the game they set benefit the few rather than the many and these trade and investment agreements create a framework of rules in which fundamental workers’ rights are dependent on political promises made in the 11th hour, while international investors are guaranteed new legal rights to sue our governments.  I can’t support creating new corporate privileges, especially while labour activists like Jolovan Wham face tough justice when we should be delivering trade justice.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. We are finally coming to an end to this long process and i hope that we will approve this agreement tomorrow as the European Parliament. In principle, the agreement has been in place for many years. We then decided to use this agreement as an example to have matters resolved before the European Court of Justice. There is no agreement that has been so closely scrutinised not only by us, but also by the European Court of Justice.  With Singapore, we are finally able to do what we have done with Japan, have done it with Canada and want to do it with many other countries: namely, to establish rules for global trade, so that the biggest and strongest of us do not always prevail, as many colleagues have said, but so that the power of law applies and we have a clear framework for trade relations. That is why I would like to ask all those Members who want to reject this agreement: what will be better if we do not do this agreement? We miss many opportunities, we leave the market to others, we miss to open up markets for our workers in the region.  We will not improve anything if we do not agree to this agreement. I would therefore ask all those Members who have spoken critically today to reconsider their position by tomorrow.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this European Parliament must approve, without further ado, the three important agreements with Singapore that are finally before us. The partnership and cooperation agreement, because it does justice to the strategic importance of our relationship with Singapore.  The investment protection agreement, because it is another step in the eradication of private arbitration systems and because it will derogate from thirteen obsolete bilateral agreements. And the trade agreement, because it facilitates trade relations with a relevant partner in Southeast Asia, because it promotes sustainable development and because it contains clear commitments from Singapore for the ratification of the Conventions of the International Labour Organization. Let us also adopt a progressive resolution, such as the one proposed to us by our colleague David Martin, and let us vote in favour without further delay.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Finally, a free trade agreement with Singapore, one of the world's most free-to-trade countries. It should be quite simple, yet it has taken ten years. It's not their fault, it's our fault. Not least many my colleagues in this house, who have done everything they can to send gravel into the machinery – not least around issues of investment, and you hear that now that they want to continue to do so. This has damaged the EU's trade policy. We've treated Singapore badly. You have to be honest with that. But this is a good deal. It is very good agreement with a dynamic economy in Southeast Asia. And tomorrow we should vote for it. Unanimously. Nevertheless, there are many in here – too many – who want to rally the extreme right and the left together with many from the Social Democrats and the Greens to try to withdraw European trade policy, to leave room for China, for Europe to follow the example of the United States. That would be the worst thing we could do in this day and age. I therefore hope that we will have a broad support and that we can restore the confidence this process has damaged.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I rise as a member of Parliament’s ASEAN delegation and strongly believe in this region’s geo-strategic importance for the EU. I’ve had an opportunity to discuss this Agreement with a variety of stakeholders in Singapore, including NGOs and independent trade union representatives, and they all support a stronger partnership between us and their country. It’s especially important given that global trade is in a state of flux. The US is rewriting the rules and can no longer be relied on as a stable trading partner.  I am fully aware that some of my colleagues have reservations, especially around the ratification of the ILO Conventions and sustainability. I, for one, am thoroughly reassured by my colleague, David Martin, one of the rapporteurs, who has done an outstanding job and has succeeded in getting the Singaporeans to address many of our concerns with a letter on behalf of the Prime Minster making commitments on the ILO Conventions and an inclusion in the Agreement that sets benchmarks on sustainable development which go beyond other agreements. It’s not just a feather in your cap, David, but also one for the S&D Group and this Parliament. Well done to both the rapporteurs. I would urge my colleagues to support ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, tomorrow we will vote to enhance free trade and maintain the international competitiveness of European companies. We will vote to promote not only economic growth but also norms and values that will help address today’s complex global value chains, achieving a level playing field while promoting social inclusion and environmental protection. Even though sometimes it is challenging for European companies, we are proud to set standards and to be an example in the global world. In return, our businesses grow. The trade agreements have contributed to the significant growth of EU exports. We now have the largest web of preferential trade agreements in place worldwide – around 70 in total, spanning five continents – and we have to remember too the European jobs that are created through these agreements. Once again, trade agreements with countries like Japan, Singapore or Vietnam have an effect and we too benefit from them. We should take advantage of them in the future as well. Tomorrow I hope we will vote in favour of this agreement, and I will encourage everyone to do so.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, these agreements are essential for a European Union which does not want to be closed on itself, but seeks to open up to the world and thus contribute actively and positively to the regulation of the great phenomenon of globalisation. This agreement of partnership and cooperation in particular, which we are appreciating here today, is a good starting point for greater political and economic involvement of the European Union in a key region of the globe such as Southeast Asia. It will certainly provide the basis for improving the bilateral relationship between the EU and its Member States with Singapore, strengthening political dialogue and enabling better cooperation in a wide range of areas. This agreement covers the European Union's standard human rights policy clauses with regard to the International Criminal Court, the issue of weapons of mass destruction, small arms and light weapons and the fight against terrorism. It also covers key areas such as health, the environment, climate change, energy ... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Thank you very much, Mr President-in-Office, and thank you to my colleague David for his excellent report. Partnership and cooperation between the European Union and Singapore not only concerns trade and investment protection, but involves a political partnership that will allow for deeper sectoral cooperation in key areas. The partnership provides a legal framework for stronger and broader cooperation, focusing on the themes of environmental protection, international stability, justice, security and development.  The agreement also offers new opportunities for cooperation, such as human rights, justice, freedom and security and restrictions on nuclear weapons, as well as scientific and technological cooperation in key areas including health first. This agreement will allow us to work together to fight cancer. And this agreement sets a precedent for deeper cooperation between the European Union and Singapore and the wider Region of Southeast Asia.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, this Agreement is well balanced. As far as I know, the Singapore Trade Minister has promised to ratify the remaining ILO Conventions as soon as possible. But what I find particularly relevant is the monitoring of its application by the EU. While it’s true that Singapore ranks very high on Transparency International’s Corruption Perceptions Index, paradoxically it also ranks very high on the Financial Secrecy Index.  To prevent Europeans from using Singapore as a bank secrecy paradise, the EU needs to put measures in place and make them applicable to individual Member States. Recently, a protocol on bilateral avoidance of double taxation between Latvia and Singapore entered into force to boost cross—border investment. The question remains as to whether enhanced rights for investors are compatible with human and environmental rights and visa transparency standards. The Agreement has good potential for the European Union, but a lot depends on the EU’s capacity to require its strict application.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We started in 2014 with questions to the Court of Justice. We received a response in 2017, it is 2019 and we will join countries such as Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam today with a new agreement – which is very welcome – another country from Asia, very important for us, Singapore. I would like to add that I was equally pleased with the agreement between the European Union and Canada. In my opinion, the protection of investments, the elimination of double taxation, these various customs barriers serve not only our partners, of course, but above all us. That's what you should be happy about. I would add, however, that the procedures we use are unfortunately very cumbersome. They put the European Union at risk of unnecessary waste of time. On this occasion, it is worth considering what to do, what to do to make these procedures simpler, faster and more transparent.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, I welcome the EU—Singapore Partnership Agreement and I congratulate both negotiation teams on their sustained efforts during bilateral negotiations. Singapore has, for a long time, been a reliable political and economic friend of the EU, currently hosting more than 10 000 of our companies and sharing our fundamental values on a free and competitive economy and the rule of law.  As Singapore is one of the founding members of ASEAN and a major hub in the region, I personally perceive this partnership as a solid geo—strategic foundation for the future region—to—region relationship between the European Union and ASEAN member states, one of the fastest growing economies in the world. The EU—Singapore Free Trade Agreement will create new opportunities for new businesses to export to Singapore. This Agreement will give an estimated boost to the EU economy of EUR 550 million over the next 10 years.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I want to express my huge admiration for you for completing the work on this free trade agreement. We should be a leader who supports the principles of free trade around the world, unlike the current US administration. I'll just give you one thing. We should be more ambitious in negotiating similar agreements in the future and simply reduce the negotiation time. I have known here for almost ten years that there has been an opinion from the European Court of Justice and other circumstances, but let us really think about what to do to negotiate such agreements more quickly in the future. I personally hope that this agreement will lead to a multilateral agreement with the whole ASEAN in this area. So please just keep going, free trade is supposed to be an ideology that the EU will spread in the field of international trade around the world, and let us think about how to do this more effectively.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I, too, want to know my belief in trade without hindran being barriers, i.e. free trade, which is, of course, based on common values. I think that singapore and I share a number of common values, whether it is support in the liberal-conservative direction of the state, in the rule of law, in trade, which is based on fair principles. Here I would like to commend the rapporteur, his negotiating team. We must not waste any more time, I think that the mutual respect of the two sides has found a balanced position in the negotiated agreement. And I think these are opportunities, especially for our businesses, opportunities for our citizens, of course institutions. I do not know what other agreement would be on the table, if there are repeated objections, there is no other agreement on the table, we are wasting our time only because of the progress of the EU institutions. I am fully in support of this proposal.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the strengthening of relations with Singapore must certainly be seen in a favourable way. It opens up an important market area and offers the possibility of improving dialogue in the areas of human rights, the environment, climate change and taxation. However, the agreement we are debating contains some of the dangerous measures that I already highlighted in the case of TTIP: a form of ISDS, an instrument of international public law that guarantees a foreign investor the right to initiate dispute settlement proceedings against a foreign government. Giving corporations the power to sue governments for protecting the environment, health and human rights is deeply wrong. On the contrary, we should replace it with a system that obliges companies to pay for their violations of rights and the environment, and immediately. The EU-Singapore Treaty is only the first. It will be a model for future agreements in China, Mexico and other major economies around the world.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the European Union-Singapore Economic Cooperation Agreement leads to a further increase in trade and this of course means huge imports of cheap products from Singapore into the European Union. Because, in practice, Singapore is china's bridge. This is where Chinese products are imported in the A or B way, which will then be imported into the European Union. But also with regard to products manufactured in Singapore, we all know that labour law is not respected there. We have a classic wage dumping and we have, in fact, a process that violates any notion of fair trade. Singapore is a region that is used by the major business groups of the European Union and other countries to generate super profits. I am, of course, also against the logic of the ISDS that exists, which — in practice — protects investors at the expense of the States. Finally, the European Union seems to have forgotten that human rights are not respected in Singapore, the rule of law is being violated, all democratic expressions are being violated and the death penalty is still in force.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me answer a few questions. Public debt is excluded from this. The Investment Protection Agreement (IPA) is very clear on excluding the EU sovereign debt restructuring from the investment protection, so here you can be calm. Investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) does not exist anymore in the European Union. We have replaced it – very much at your demand and with your help, cooperation and push, and I thank you for that – with a new modern system that the Advocate General declared perfectly compatible with EU laws. It does away with many of the flaws of ISDS. There are full—term arbitrators with a code of conduct, there is full transparency, there is an appeal mechanism, there are very clear limits on what can be brought to the table, and it says that states have the right to regulate. Singapore is not on the list of non—cooperative jurisdictions for tax evasion.  On geographical indications (GIs), it is true that this still remains to be done. Singapore is about to establish a register to protect the GIs to which the European Union countries can apply for protection of the 196 geographical indications that were on the consulting list and the Free Trade Agreement (FTA) will enter into force only when there is satisfactory compliance with this. It is true that Singapore still has to ratify three ILO Conventions, but hard work is ongoing inside the Government of Singapore and cooperation with the ILO to make sure that legislation is in compliance with these three Conventions and that they are eventually ratified. As was referred to, there has been a letter from the Government of Singapore on this process.  If – and I hope you will – this House votes strongly in favour of these agreements tomorrow, you will vote for an ambitious FTA, which will be a reference for many other upcoming agreements in the ASEAN region. You will vote in favour of an Investment Protection Agreement that follows the approach that you have helped to shape.  You will also help to frame the broader cooperation between the EU and Singapore, giving our relations a solid and broad foundation in areas such as security, people—to—people contact, research etc., through the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and it will be the first agreement that is endorsed by this Parliament following the new modern architecture.  With this we are expanding the circle of friends that we are setting up with like-minded countries, countries who believe in multilateralism, countries who believe in global rules and norms, and countries who believe that we can make mutually beneficial, fair and sustainable trade agreements with friends and with whom we are contributing to shaping globalisation. Thank you very much for this debate and thank you again to the two rapporteurs.

name: David MARTIN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I won’t take two minutes because firstly, the Commissioner has kindly answered many of the questions, but also as I look around the room I can’t see a single person who made a critical comment still in the room, so there’s nothing to answer. I just want to repeat that, in terms of the free trade agreement, this is good for jobs, it’s good for investment and one that we should support in terms of investment. This is the most modern investment agreement that we have ever achieved. And I conclude with the point that the Commissioner made: we are trying to engage with like-minded countries to ensure that in trade the rule of law applies while some other countries want the law of the jungle to apply, and we must stick by the rule of law and continue our work in promoting bilateral and multilateral trade agreements.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: My understanding is that those colleagues who were critical and left were probably convinced in the course of the debate. I have no other explanation than that. The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 February 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement is the first such bilateral trade agreement between the EU and the ASEAN Member States. The agreement focuses mainly on removing non-tariff barriers such as the recognition of standards, product labelling and access to public procurement; also focuses on strengthening the protection of workers and the protection of the environment. An investment protection agreement and a partnership and cooperation agreement will also be concluded between the EU and Singapore, which will contribute to the protection of EU investment, given the growing economic interest of EU businesses in the region. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement will also contribute to creating a more favourable political and economic environment, both in the interests of the EU and contributing to the promotion of certain areas in Singapore.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on experiencing backlash in women’s rights and gender equality in the EU, tabled by João Pimenta Lopes, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (O-000135/2018 – B8—0005/2019) (2018/2684)(RSP)).

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, allow me, first of all, to signal the work and cooperation with all the colleagues who have contributed to the construction of this question and resolution.  Evidence of the rollback of women's rights in the European Union does not allow omissions. In the last decade, women's labour, economic, social and cultural rights have been severely compromised. Right-wing policies, sponsored or imposed since the European Union, have led to an increase in the precarious employment of labour relations. Low-wage policies, the deregulation of working hours, the raising of the retirement age, which impose multiple discrimination on women. At the same time, social responses and public services have been degraded. The degradation or absence of public services that guarantee care and care, whether in childhood or in situations of disease or in old age, constitutes an ignoble disresponsibility of states in the responses to the needs of populations, contributing to situations that keep women from the labor market. The protection of motherhood, determined by law, is compromised by the enormous pressure on workers to give up their rights, a direct consequence of the precariousemployment of employment ties. The degradation of the public supply of health services and the offensive against the right to sexual and reproductive health is another element of attack on women's rights.  Attempts to reverse or prevent the consecration of rights in the voluntary termination of pregnancy and to ensure proper reproductive health care are known and unacceptable. Global levels of poverty and unemployment, which particularly affect women, remain at unsustainable levels. The gender pay and pension gap persists at unacceptable values. The increase in violence against women, which has been seen in the same period, cannot be disconnected from the cutting of rights and the degradation of the socio-economic conditions of the population. Nine women and one child have been killed in my country since the beginning of the year. These figures are a brutal and growing expression in the European Union of the multiple forms of violence against women, be it domestic violence or sexual violence and harassment, violence and harassment in the workplace, violence and exploitation in prostitution. The consecration of equality and the fight against violence in law, whether in the national or international field, of which the Istanbul Convention is an example, are important and necessary steps, but it is not enough to enshrine it in law. There can be no place for make-believe policies in equality policies or quick terms of combating all forms of violence.  The success of preventing, combating and eradicating violence against women in its multiple forms is inseparable from the realising of women's rights in law and in life. It is necessary to establish specific programmes for the protection and monitoring of victims, measures to strengthen social support, access to justice, shelters, mental health care in the fields of prevention, treatment and rehabilitation, responses that ensure economic autonomy and ensure, in practice, the confidence and security that the law actually protects , women who are victims of violence at various stages until they remake their lives. The path of economic and social emancipation of women is decisive in the construction of equality and combating all forms of violence. This requires putting work as a central element to address inequalities between men and women. Equality in life that requires combating unemployment and labour precarity, valuing wages and eliminating wage discrimination, women's equal participation in all sectors of activity, the right to be a mother and worker with rights, the social protection of motherhood and paternity in the personal areas of health and social security, the creation of a public network of child support equipment , young people, the elderly, people with disabilities and victims of violence, access to the National Health Service and protection in sexual and reproductive health, the protection of women who are victims of prostitution and trafficking for the purpose of sexual exploitation and moral or sexual harassment in the workplace. Combating equality and against all forms of violence is a fight for all, a fight that requires states to take responsibility and to claim, in fact, as an irreplaceable element of consecration of equality and combating all forms of violence.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Europe is confronted with increased populist and extremist trends which also manifest themselves in sexist and racist hate speech and in backward trends regarding women’s and girls’ rights. The Commission, with the support of High Representative Mogherini, has put gender equality at the centre of the EU’s internal and external action. The Strategic Engagement for Gender Equality for the years 2016-2019 has been our framework for the promotion of gender equality and gender mainstreaming in the EU and beyond. In 2019 we are taking stock of progress, identifying gaps and preparing the setting of priorities for the future. In this context, the views of the European Parliament are very welcome. I also warmly welcome the agreement reached on the work—life balance proposal. This will offer more choices for parents and carers in terms of reconciling family and professional life. In November 2017, the Commission adopted an action plan to tackle the gender pay gap, which comprises a broad and coherent set of more than 20 concrete actions. The majority of these have been implemented and the remaining measures should be concluded this year. Reliable data are essential in order to monitor trends in gender equality in the EU. That is why Eurostat is currently developing an EU survey on gender-based violence, with the aim of having updated statistics, following on from the EU—wide survey by the Fundamental Rights Agency in 2014. Eradicating gender—based violence has been a key priority for the Commission. We have just finished a second year of targeted action and awareness raising. We are continuing to push ahead on EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on gender—based violence. With regard to ratification by the Member States, as of today 20 Member States have ratified this Council of Europe convention but, as you know, ratification is being seriously challenged in other countries. The political and public debate around the Istanbul Convention is a good illustration of the impact of the current backlash against gender equality and women’s rights in Europe. Misleading arguments about the convention and its measures are being used in public debate. We must confront these and explain that the sole purpose of the convention is to prevent and combat violence against women and domestic violence against children, women and men, without any hidden purposes or effects. This situation is paralysing some Member States in the process towards ratification of the convention and the EU’s accession to it. Time is running out if we are to conclude that process before the end of this Parliament’s term. Gender equality is not only a core value of the EU but it is also central to the Union’s external action. I am glad that this Parliament has welcomed the good progress made on implementing international cooperation and development under the EU Gender Action Plan. This plan focuses on the enhancement of women’s integrity, economic and social rights and on participation and the elimination of gender—based violence. The Council has welcomed a new and ambitious EU strategic approach to ‘Women, Peace and Security’, which explicitly combines internal and external policies and requires analysis of, and response to, the gender-related root causes of inequalities, violence and conflict. Lastly, we need to continue our sustained efforts. This is one of the reasons why, in September 2017, the EU and the United Nations jointly launched the Spotlight initiative with the objective of eliminating all forms of violence against women and girls worldwide. Backed by an initial contribution of EUR 500 million, our ambition is to see this initiative being transformational for the lives of women and girls worldwide, in particular for young people and those living in the most marginalised and vulnerable situations. The Commission will continue its engagement in the field. I count on Parliament’s and the Council’s continued commitment to make this happen.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, in societies which have a good welfare state, democracy, openness and respect, women usually do well, and vice versa when women do well, societies do well on these aspects. That’s why the backlash on the women’s position is a canary in the mine, not only on the question of women but on the whole state of society. And there are lengthy experiments and research showing that when women suffer, societies are on the way to limiting democratic rights, limiting the welfare state and limiting other aspects of freedom. Women do not have the choice or the liberty to ask whether they are discriminated against as women or for other reasons – because women make up more or less half and half of workers, entrepreneurs, emigrants or disabled people. So women face multiple discrimination. And yes indeed, we in Europe have seen a backlash throughout the last years, especially in some Member States. Women are human and human rights apply to women and women’s rights, including sexual and reproductive rights, are a part of human rights, so we need the Commission to tackle even more strongly this backlash and challenge our Member States in their activities in all fields of life.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, we are talking about the setback of women's rights in Europe. In 2014, five years ago, we were discussing sexual and reproductive health rights here, and I said at the time, "Let's not let our daughters have fewer rights than our mothers." Well, that threat today is closer than ever. Poland, with its abortion law; Hungary, eliminating gender studies in universities; Bulgaria, refusing to ratify the Istanbul Convention. And do you know the latest occurrence of this new ultraconservative wave? The leader of the People's Party in Spain decides that, in order to ensure the sustainability of pensions, women have to give birth; we have to have children to be able to pay pensions, and that is done by going back thirty-five years and recovering the abortion law of 1985. Look, women charge fewer wages, fewer pensions; we have difficulty joining the labour market; we are the caregivers of dependents; every day there are women killed by sexist violence, victims of sexual violence and trafficking in human beings; even women, many times, are afraid to return home alone, and before that we cannot remain impassive. There are many reasons today. There are more than a thousand reasons. That is the campaign launched by women's organizations to mobilize the feminist strike on 8 March, and we, this Parliament, must serve as a loudspeaker to fill the streets with a demand for equality. Because this is not a matter of women. This is a struggle for a feminist Europe that advances, does not give up and works.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Of course, I am in favour of women's equality, but unfortunately I strongly disagree with the main assumptions and key elements of this resolution, firstly, because it seeks to restrict freedom of expression by calling for condemnation of criticism of the Istanbul Convention, secondly, because it condemns the orientation of equality policy towards maternal and family policy, which is the crowning proof that you believe that motherhood is a crutch at your feet. , which interferes with a woman's professional development, which I absolutely cannot agree with, and thirdly, because it contains an outrageous call to consider the protection of life conceived as disinformation. So you would like to limit the activity of prolife movements that recognize that abortion is the killing of an unborn child. I strongly disagree with the resolution's premise that abortion or the rights of sexual minorities can be understood as a deterioration in women's rights. I therefore propose an alternative motion for a resolution in which I stress the need to reduce the wage and pension gap. I draw attention to the need to combat violence against women. I condemn forced marriage, female genital mutilation. I would like to points out the need to increase women's participation in public life. I pay attention to the problem ...   (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for a really fruitful cooperation on this resolution.  Women throughout the European Union continue to face discrimination, harassment, are denied equal access to participation in public and political life, and suffer sexual and gender-based violence and abuse in public places and at home. We are now seeing a backlash against women’s rights, a backlash that hurts us all. We need to be alert. The advances of the last few decades are fragile and should by no means be taken for granted. Ultra-conservative, anti-feminist and religious groups systematically call gender equality into question and use religion, tradition or culture to legitimise violations of women’s rights. This includes organised lobbying against abortion, reproductive health rights and sexual education reforms. These attacks provide a powerful illustration of the extent and the nature of the backlash against women’s rights and gender equality in Europe.  In this resolution we call on the European Union to put words into action. I call on the Union and the Member States to commit to the realisation of women’s human rights, accelerate the implementation of all women’s rights instruments, keep women’s rights on the highest level of the political agenda at all times and, finally, invest in women’s and girls’ rights and in women’s organisations. We also need to ensure that national and regional budgets include increased dedicated investment to secure women’s rights. Equally, women’s organisations and experts should be included in all regional and global discussions on all issues and in national delegations to the intergovernmental meetings.  Finally, I salute the frequently under-funded but absolutely vital work of women’s human rights defenders. These activists are often targeted because of their efforts to promote gender equality.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Women's rights are a central part of democracy. That should be a given in 2019. Yet we stand here today and state the obvious: that we are actually having a setback, a backlash. It is ideological or political in the way people talk about women and men and equality. Conservative and nationalist far-right forces hate and threaten our rights. It is also actual or material in the sense of increased poverty among women, unemployment, reduced access to public services and women's organisations and women's activists becoming targets of attacks. The fight for equality and women's rights has not been a law of nature, as my mother always said: 'It will just keep getting better, Malin'. No, it's been a fight and victories have been won. It has been the right to vote, it has been the right to abortion, it has been economic independence. And now we're standing here again today, I feel. We won't avoid, we just won't avoid and take a step back. We will demand that we move forward. This feminist struggle will never, ever yield. We will not let the conservative forces here or anywhere else take control of our lives.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the In Bulgaria, the population is being incited against the Istanbul Convention with false information. Parliament then halts ratification. In Poland, sex education is to be taught in schools, that masturbating leads to addiction and that Catholic women should only be prevented with the ovulation method. In Germany, instead of finally abolishing the ban on information on abortion, a study costing EUR 5 million is being commissioned to prove the negative effects of abortion. The backlash is in full swing. Across Europe, the achievements of democratic societies that have been won are being fought against, and above all, this concerns women. Control of the female body is at the top of the list of neoconservative, far-right and Christian fundamentalist movements. But this also includes smear campaigns against the Istanbul Convention and hatred and incitement against LGBTI people and other minorities. Not only with their ideas, but above all with money, US anti-choice organizations and Russian oligarchs are showering Europe to turn back the clock. And what did we do? We have waited far too long and have done nothing. This must now be put to an end once and for all! We open our mouths and oppose the movements that despise women and minorities, which want to restrict our freedom. And if they try to restore some racist and patriarchal natural order, they can be prepared for our resistance. And where do we start? Here in this Parliament! President Antonio Tajani announced his participation in the summit of reactionary groups in Verona in March. I say that if the President of this Parliament feels any kind of attached to this House, he will cancel this participation. We are fighting for a free and equal Europe ....  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ms. Lopez worries here that she is seeing a hostile attitude towards women's rights. These are, of course, such observations that are completely worthless, as are all this talk, this nonsense about inequality and discrimination. What you are really watching is perhaps such impatience with your constant chatter, such a healthy response from a society that is inundated with this deceitful propaganda, stinking, preaching some kind of sick gender war, presenting a vision of a world where the most important thing is that the X and Y chromosome ratios are the same all over the place. This is a healthy and normal impatience of society with people creating problems where they are not. And if you have been lubricating these pharmacoses, these dyrdyals, resolutions, reports, appeals, programmes, and you have not seen any meaningful results for so many years – you yourself here say that perhaps even on the contrary – that is, you are doing it wrong, i think that means it does not work. So what's the conclusion for feminists? More of the same, more resolutions, more debate, more chatter, more programmes, further appeals and so on, and further upsetting people.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! Women's rights have always been and are part of fundamental European values. There is no more pro-female political organisation than the European Union. Yet this resolution does not appear by accident. The right-wing and populist wave that is sweeping through Europe is bearing fruit in the form of a significant deterioration in women's rights. Backlash concerns in particular the most private sphere of life, namely women's health and reproductive rights. Emergency contraception prescriptions are back. There are proposals for laws banning abortion. Pro-women organisations are denied funding. They are plagued by relentless checks. He looks suspiciously at everything he has in the title of gender, gender equality or feminism. It's hard to believe that we live in the 21st century. Commissioner, it is high time that the European Commission took a more thorough look at its intervention options and used all means to stop the backlash and strengthen the pro-women direction of national policies in the European Union.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – Mr President, despite the legislative recommendations adopted, the reality in the field of gender equality is that we are only halfway towards gender equality and progress is so slow at the moment, and in some areas the situation of women's rights is even deteriorating. First of all, we are still unable to overcome violence against women, which is one of the worst violations of human rights, because so far eight Member States have still not ratified the Istanbul Convention. And what does this mean that there is no violence against women in those countries? Is it that governments lack the political will to ratify this important international document? It is a pity, but progress is still not being made to reduce the gender pay gap for the same work, and at the same time pensions vary by as much as forty percent. Finally, there is still no way to beat the glass ceiling in policy decision-making, because women still have to fight to participate in that decision-making with men on an equal time. And the biggest shame I have to admit is that in my country, lithuania, the government at the moment there is no one...

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, discrimination against women and systematically preventing them from realising their full potential is something we must fight, always and everywhere. I've been the victim of sex discrimination myself, so I know exactly what it's like. In this sense, the social climate must change permanently and be stimulating for women, to develop in an area wherever they want. Some social groups have problems with this and we must send them a clear message that they are free to choose what kind of life they will live, but not impose their choice on others. This is not only about ultratraditionalists, but also about feminists who also have little respect for women living a different way of life.  We must also say that I do not view the growing awareness of the right to life as a backseament in human rights. Unborn children are the most vulnerable group, unique in that they cannot fight for their rights on their own. This fact does not give us the right to ignore them, but, in fact, asks us to stand up for them in particular.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, we come from an economic crisis which has led to a very clear setback in women's rights. Austerity has been directly associated with a return of patriarchal patterns and a more unequal society. And now, with the emergence of far-right forces, which have a very serious effect on the agenda of certain democratic forces like the popular ones, we see a very clear attack on women's rights. In some countries we even question the very existence of laws against violence against women, as had just happened with the government agreement in Andalusia. Or the president of the popular Spaniards, who asks to return to abortion law of the year 85. But what is this? What are we talking about? In a society that is still deeply unequal, come up with this offensive attack on women. The only answer to that, Commissioner, is an ambitious equality agenda, more ambitious than ever. Unlock everything we have standing in the Council, go on the offensive with the ratification of the Istanbul Convention and mobilize on the street. And I hope that this next 8 March will be a mobilization success for equality and women's rights.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have reached the final stages of this parliamentary term and we want to sum up. We have worked hard in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality in the European Parliament, but we are not satisfied, because Article 8 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union has not been applied in all Member States.  Despite the efforts, the EIGE's Gender Equality Index shows persistent disparities, with only marginal progress from 2005 to 2015. This is a fact that saddens us and tells us that significant improvements are still needed in all Member States. And it is above all in work that there is a substantial decline: women are particularly affected, unlike men.  The campaign against the Istanbul Convention is all the more regrettable. On such an important issue there are still obstacles to definitions, it is not clear how there can still be a rejection by some governments in the Council...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Anna HEDH
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In my nearly 15 years in the European Parliament, gender equality and women's rights have been one of my most important priorities. Equality between women and men is one of the eu's fundamental values and is absolutely crucial for Europe to function. All Member States have undertaken, in accordance with the EU Treaties, to respect, guarantee, protect and implement fundamental rights and women's rights. The fact that this is not being done in the EU or in the Member States me off, to say the least. The ten-year period in which we now find ourselves is marked by a conspicuously organised frontal attack on gender equality and women's rights. It's going backwards, not forwards. A number of Member States are restricting access to sexual and reproductive health, organisations working for women's rights are being given reduced opportunities to operate and we see in black and white in this report that only very marginal progress has been made in this area from 2005 to 2015. For me as a feminist, this is deeply, deeply serious.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, a 16.5% pay gap of 40% in pensions; one in three women who have experienced physical or sexual violence or both; only 36% of women in this House, and so on. The figures are very clear: we are still far from achieving effective equality between men and women. And yet the right dares to question, in an increasingly uncompressed and more infamous way, indispensable measures to ensure the protection of women's rights. This ultra-conservative wave is also present in the Spanish State. The neo-Franco right even dares to question the existence of sexist violence. They tell us about "domestic" violence and exaggerate the number of cases of false allegations. But despite these growing attacks on women's rights, the feminist wave is getting stronger every day. It was seen last March 8th and we'll see him again in a few weeks.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, strengthening women's rights and gender equality is a fundamental right of the European Union and I would agree with all those who say that there is a backlash against certain women's rights. It is true that populist and extremist trends contribute to this, as does hate speech that is evident in many of our societies. I also agree with those who say that a democratic society is strong enough and developed enough if women's rights are sufficiently developed and strong.  And so I agree with the statement that came from the left: "let us not let our daughters have fewer rights than our mothers had," whatever anyone by that means.  Violence against women today is present in society, we do not eradicate it poorly. Regardless of the ratified convention on women's rights in some countries, on combating violence against women, violence persists. We should keep fighting. I think this is the biggest problem of today's society, we have brought a lot of documents, and we still do not have equality in the truest sense of the word on the ground.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Dear Chairman, the fact is that even today, in Europe, we have not established gender equality and ensured equal opportunities for women. Progress has not been made in creating institutional and policy frameworks for the establishment of equality such as social and labour protection, education, healthcare, preventing violence against women and we need to work on that.  Women today are discriminated against in different ways and forced to choose between career and family, rather than making it easier for them to have both. This is a real problem that requires an actual solution, and this report does not offer an answer to these important questions. I cannot agree with the definitions of backs downs and progress as seen and proposed by the rapporteur. Women's rights must not be subject to redefinication depending on time or ideology, on the contrary - they are timeless and therefore belong to all women.  As a person who advocates the protection of every life and human dignity and respect for the principle of subsidiarity, I am disappointed in the content of this report and cannot support it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, the fact is that promoting equal rights, equal chances is a long-term task. Discrimination is unacceptable, so we should support at this European level all measures that promote the position of women in society and enable them to make free choices, decent motherhood and professional careers. I therefore also support the directive proposed by the Commissioner, which will allow for a better balance between professional and family life. Sadly, this oral question has been used to criticise conservative politics. As a member of the Christian Democratic Party, I say that this policy protects women, protects unborn lives, protects every life, so we should also support this policy that protects motherhood and parenthood in the interests of life.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, it’s important that the European Parliament addresses the current backlash against women’s rights and gender equality in Europe, particularly because some of the forces driving this backlash are represented in this House. Conservative forces are becoming stronger. They’re well organised and they have managed to convince more and more people that they’re on the right side of history. This is very dangerous. Attacks against sexual and reproductive health rights are becoming more frequent in Europe, with some countries even restricting access to contraceptives. Anti-gender campaigns push against the rights of LGBTIQ+ people. The ratification of the Istanbul Convention is slow and painful despite it being the best legal tool we have to fight against gender-based violence. Meanwhile, domestic violence continues to be widespread and normalised. I’m worried that some people are not aware of this backlash. They think that feminism is a fight of the past, but we need to continue to speak up for women’s rights and empower those that are growing up now to take up the fight.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. It is the authorities of the European Union, not the critics of the Istanbul Convention, who mislead the public. I say the authorities of the European Union, because the Commissioner has been here officially. Article 14 of this Convention foreshadows the use of education to spread non-stereotypical gender roles. The Charter of Fundamental Rights guarantees parents the right to object to such experiments on children. Article 12 says that schools are to eradicate traditions and customs that perpetuate stereotypical roles of women. Probably the Odysa will have to be banned, because Penelope waited too long for her husband. How can we say that countries that have not adopted the Convention tolerate violence?! Commissioner, your country does not tolerate violence, it is in Germany – and not in the Czech Republic – that forced marriages take place. Please do not mislead the public.
