Please respect european Union countries such as Bulgaria, which have constitutionally said that they do not want this convention. You have a duty to defend them.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are experiencing a contradiction on this continent: an increasingly strong feminist movement, combating patriarchal sexist violence, and an institutional framework that is in danger of falling back heavily.  I am thinking, for example, of my own country. I do not know whether the Commissioner is aware that in September, as the FEMM Committee, we audited certain feminist spaces, spaces for women's self-determination, such as the Lucha y Siesta women's home, such as the International Women's House. Spaces that are under attack by local institutions, spaces that are not recognised and that have been recognised in this Parliament through the report on gender mainstreaming.  In Italy, the presence of objectors, as the FEMM Committee itself was able to find in a delegation, is difficult in relation to the voluntary termination of pregnancy. We have Ddl Pillon questioning family law. In Italy there is a retreat in women's rights which the strike on 8 March will once again bring into focus.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me conclude by saying that I am grateful for the dedication and support of Parliament for advancing gender equality and women’s rights. Let me just react, because I know we are running late, to two speakers.  First to Ms Matera: I am not satisfied either. I expected better or bigger progress when I started in this position of the Commissioner responsible for gender equality. However, we have to be aware of the wider context we are in. Somebody called this era the ‘era of anxiety’. We see a lot of uncertainty and nervousness in our society, and in such an atmosphere, people tend more to come back to old traditions and things which have somehow proved to work over the time before. So this period is not very favourable for new concepts, for new trends which will be accepted by wider society. That’s why we spoke about the results, that there is very little progress, but I wanted to mention this as one of the reasons why we have such little progress. Just an illustration: recently we had one government which didn’t have any women in it, that was Hungary. Now, as Ms Blinkevičiūtė mentioned, it’s Lithuania where there is no woman in the government. The people in these countries, the women in these countries, do not seem to mind, reactions are quite weak, and I believe that the people in the Member States have to express what they think about this and how they feel about such inequality, about seeing that there is no woman in their government. So we have to trust the people, that they will express how they want to live. I was always against, for instance, a regulation that will order people how to combine their roles. That’s why I was happy about the work—life balance initiative, which opens up the choice, which gives the opportunity to combine roles at work and at home for working parents, for women and men.  And I think that this is the way Europe should continue, by offering choices, enhancing equality, not tolerating discrimination – this has to be very much emphasised – and continue the smart policy which will combine regulation where needed – but I don’t believe regulation here works too well – but campaigning, awareness—raising, funding, training and so on. The second comment from Mr Jurek: I know very well what I said about the Istanbul Convention. We respect the right of sovereign states to ratify or not to ratify the Istanbul Convention. I just want to repeat here that I will continue to explain some of the misunderstandings and misleading arguments which appear around the interpretation of the Istanbul Convention, because I think that it is important to understand what the Convention is and what it isn’t.  Mr President, I wanted to speak briefly but, as you see, I didn’t manage it.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I have received two motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed.  The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 February 2019.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on policy challenges and strategies against women’s cancers and related comorbidities, by Daniela Aiuto, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (O-000134/2018 – B8—0006/2019) (2018/2782(RSP).

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, every day thousands of women face their battle against the evil of the century, cancer. They do so while courageously continuing to look after their family, while trying to continue working despite everything. For them and for all, we strongly demand easier and cheaper access to diagnostic and preventive examinations and treatment.  The figures that Eurostat presents to us every year are alarming: one in three Europeans develops cancer during their lifetime. Some 600 000 European women die of cancer every year, of which more than 90 000 are breast cancers, in addition to cervical and cervical cancer, to name but a few.  We know that cancers are devastating for everyone, men, women and unfortunately also children, but it must be recognised that when they affect us women, they often affect us in our femininity, attacking our bodies and depriving us of those parts that physiologically make us feel like women, such as the breasts or the reproductive system, and which have enormous psychological repercussions that are often set aside or underestimated in comparison with the severity of the disease itself. Compared to the figures of those mortally affected by evil, fortunately many more are the women who manage to overcome it. More than 80 % of Europeans affected by breast cancer, for example, survive after treatment. And it is also these women that we must protect, them and their families. After the disease, in fact, their lives change radically, both because of invasive treatments, such as radiotherapy or chemotherapy, and as a result of the surgical operations they are forced to undergo, with not only physical devastation – think a hysterectomy or a mastectomy – but also psychological.  We therefore call on the European Commission, together with the Member States, to implement health policies and planning, taking into account a much wider range of facets that lie behind this terrible evil.  There are three main points I would like to highlight. The first is the prevention, monitoring and access to treatment. There is no doubt that the high incidence of mortality from cancer is due to the fact that it is often intervened in an already evolved phase of the disease, rendering any possible cure in vain. We are aware that if a disease is diagnosed in time, the healing rate is much higher. Prevention is essential through constant and accessible monitoring, also from an economic point of view, with both generic and specific screenings. It is true that prevention is not always easy to implement, as follow-up visits are often onerous and waiting times are very long. We therefore call for work to be done on this issue in order to defend everyone's health.  The second aspect is linked to the specific nature of the care needed in the event of women's illness. We are talking about cancer diseases that affect purely female organs, such as the breast or uterus, which can affect the femininity of the same woman. Care must take into account that we intervene on organs and parts of the body that represent our femininity and should, as far as possible, also take into account aesthetic as well as functional aspects.  Lastly, but that is what I would like us to dwell on, is the psychological and welfare aspect. This is linked to the need to ensure adequate support and assistance for women. At a time when the woman's body is being attacked to combat the disease and, surgically, the most essential parts of our femininity or reproductive capacity, often irreversibly, are being permanently damaged, psychological assistance, even in the period following surgical treatment and treatment, is absolutely necessary and must become everyone's right. Leaving these women alone means making it much more difficult for them to carry on their role as mothers or wives, roles that certainly do not stop with the disease.  I will conclude by asking the Commission to commit itself to developing a uniform European strategy for all Member States, through cancer screening programmes, combined with increased investment in both research programmes and health infrastructure.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, there were three very comprehensive questions, so, if you will allow me, I will take a bit more than three minutes because I need to address all the very sensitive questions.  Let me begin by thanking this House and especially Ms Daniela Aiuto for raising this crucial issue of women’s cancer on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. When it comes to cancer, the statistics are startling. It is Europe’s second leading cause of death. In 2015, cancer cut short the lives of more than 580 000 women, and it is increasing in prominence; almost four million new cases are expected this year alone.  But this disease is not only about statistics. Cancer damages our families, communities and economies and our healthcare and cure systems, and so on. Since the first Europe Against Cancer programme in 1980, science, research and public policies have led to new initiatives, more effective prevention and promotion schemes and improved screening, treatment and care. I am proud of what we have achieved together to fight cancer.  Legislation on tobacco and on carcinogens, the European Code Against Cancer and the implementation of national cancer plans are a few examples of concrete achievements. I am now going to outline other examples as a reply to your specific questions. Question No 1, about preparing a strategy at EU level. Let me stress that the Commission and the Member States are already collaborating to strengthen national cancer plans and ensure that patients, including women, benefit from high quality programmes. This will encompass all aspects of the cancer management cycle from fighting against the main carcinogenic risk factors that cause cancer to early prevention and early detection of cancer, survivorship and rehabilitation, and concrete cancer types.  This is in line with the 2017 European Guide on Quality Improvement in Comprehensive Cancer Control, which includes recommendations on screening, integrated cancer care, quality improvement in aftercare at community level and survivorship and rehabilitation. At the same time the Joint Research Centre provides evidence-based European Guidelines for breast cancer, covering the entire pathway of care and the latest information indicators quantifying the cancer burden across Europe. These data are enabled by the European Cancer Information System, which allows the use of patterns of incidence, mortality and survival.  In addition, the Commission is supporting Member States’ efforts on vaccination, including against the hepatitis B virus and the human papillomavirus that causes liver and cervical cancer in women, and I ask you all to be very active in fighting against vaccine hesitancy because it is about prevention of cancer.  I should emphasise that since the adoption of a Council recommendation on cancer screening, we have seen a continuous improvement in national screening programmes for breast and cervical cancer. Twenty-five EU countries now have population-based programmes for breast cancer and 22 for cervical cancer. Of course it would be good to have all Member States together but it is much more than when we started with 18 and 17 countries 10 years ago.  Over the past decade the EU’s average proportion of women targeted for breast cancer increased from 54% to 58% – as always, prevention is a very difficult task, to motivate people to follow a prevention idea – and screening for cervical cancer rose from 54% to 60%. This has a concrete impact on breast and cervical survival rates and reflects both early detection and effectiveness of treatment. Second point, does the Commission plan to prepare standards for cancer screening programmes, and so on? I would like to recall that the European Commission Initiative on Breast Cancer provides the European Breast Guidelines, which cover the entire breast-cancer cycle from screening to end-of-life care, and they are tailored to the needs of the different users.  In addition, the European Guidelines for Quality Assurance in Cervical Cancer Screening have been updated also, but guidelines, recommendations and best practices need to be translated into practice through implementation of concrete solutions in Member States and we are doing a lot to encourage Member States to really provide on the ground those programmes in regard to implementation.  This will drive change and improvement on the ground. In this context a new Steering Group on Health Promotion, Disease Prevention and Management of Non-Communicable Diseases bridges those gaps between knowledge and funding in a practical way, advising Member States with concrete examples of what they can do, because we have only one tool, once again to cooperate. It advises the Commission about evidence-based best practices in Member States that can be transferred, scaled up and implemented more broadly with support from the EU health programme and as an EU financial instrument. The new framework programme for research, Horizon Europe, is introducing the concept of mission driving initiatives in research – it just proposed it – and cancer in, for example, children, girls, and so on could be considered. The third question is: will the Commission and Member States plan a cancer-prevention awareness campaign? A very good question! A timely question! Let me assure you that prevention is the cornerstone of our efforts. We know very well that prevention is better than cure, but how can we disseminate that message to the public? The Commission continues to work with the Member States and the World Health Organisation, including the International Agency for Research on Cancer, and with non-governmental organisations in order regularly to update, and to promote implementation of, the European Code Against Cancer. This Code is a very powerful tool: simple, understandable and powerful. The Code contains 12 messages to reduce the risk of cancer, highlighting areas like tobacco use, exercise, diet, alcohol intake, nutritional issues, and so on, in a very simple way but using very strong messages. In addition, the Code recommends taking part in organised cancer screening programmes, including for breast and cervical cancers, and urges people to vaccinate children against hepatitis B and the human papillomavirus. Such initiatives providing information in a citizen-friendly, easily understandable way are essential to get the message across on how cancer risk can be reduced.  But I encourage Member States to do more in the spirit of cooperation, such as organising cancer awareness campaigns about available screening programmes and in public spaces. I saw an excellent example when I used to take the plane from Brussels to Poland a lot: I saw a stewardess who informed women on the plane, telling them about the possibilities for using breast-cancer screening. It was an excellent example of cooperation. Let’s do more. And, of course, in the context of the European elections, this topic should be kept very high on the political agenda and in public debate. We have achieved progress but we must continue to do more in the field of cancer. We need to research and be innovative, and to improve treatment, care and quality of life for cancer patients. We must continue to prevent cancer by promoting positive lifestyle choices – a healthy choice, an easy choice – this is also a cornerstone and it is part of an integrated approach to fighting cancer. Finally, I want to take this opportunity to welcome the MEPs Against Cancer election manifesto, in particular its focus on prevention, and I look forward to working with you to prevent and control cancer, including in women.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, isn't it a frightening fact that a quarter of deaths in the European Union are the result of cancer? According to research by the University of Washington, the Republic of Croatia, the youngest member of the European Union, is among the 10 countries in the world with the highest mortality from cancer. According to data from the World Cancer Research Fund in 2018, there were more than 2 million new cases of breast cancer, the most common cancer in women and the second most common form of cancer in general. According to the same study, Belgium is the first place for women with breast cancer, followed by Luxembourg and the Netherlands.  The disease does not choose gender, age, nationality, origin, social status, we are all equally exposed. Therefore, it is extremely important that the awareness campaign reaches everyone. It is important that preventive checks are made possible for everyone, including rural residents. It is important to ensure treatment for all patients without exception. It is equally important to educate and provide adequate support to the families of the affected. We must insist on research and the creation of a strategy based on the specific needs of women and men.  This is a fight together. Cooperation at European level is key to developing a European cancer strategy, with European funds at their disposal. However, it should be taken into account that member states have competences over the health system.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: On behalf of the S&D. – Dear Chairman, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent resolution and opening up an important topic that we need to talk about. In Europe, one million and 300,000 people die of cancer every year, more than a quarter of the deaths. On the other hand, for some cancers, such as breast cancer, the probability of survival is 80 percent, but with a key condition of early detection. We need to put in place a better system of controls and screening for all cancers, and better and more affordable healthcare for all patients. Every woman should have universal and equal access to health services, in particular early cancer screenings, treatment and free and high-quality post-treatment support, regardless of place of residence, social status, occupation, culture or any other factor. Women who survive cancer may encounter particular difficulties when returning to work, education or family life. Preserving reproductive health during therapies is particularly problematic. Cancer diseases are very worrying and much more can be done to save lives by pooling resources, knowledge and existing technologies. In my amendments, I stressed that research into all types of cancer must be invested. Also, there is a need to react to worrying differences in cancer deaths between Central and Eastern Europe compared to the European average. I call on the Commission to act, in particular as regards the prevalence and mortality of ovarian cancer and cervical cancer. It is also necessary to promote a healthier lifestyle. Patients need to be provided with quality care, but also support for their family. Member States should set up quality treatment centres that can be funded by the Structural and Cohesion Funds. The great promises made that Europe will be the one to find the most effective way to treat cancer must be accompanied by adequate resources, not just a list of good wishes left.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. – Thank you very much, Madam President. There are about thirty thousand new cases of cancer in Slovakia every year. Despite the fact that it is one of the diseases that kills the most, we do not currently know the exact number of positively diagnosed in Slovakia. For several years now, there has been no functioning national cancer register. However, this situation should come to an end this year and data collection should finally be resumed. Likewise, after years of efforts by many doctors and patient representatives, screening for cervical cancer, colorectal cancer and breast cancer is finally being launched these days. It is the latter type of cancer that is the most common malignant tumor in women in Slovakia. Unfortunately, many women are already diagnosed with an advanced form of cancer, so on average 300 women a year die completely unnecessarily in our country. I therefore very much welcome the introduction of screening, which will also recommend screened mammograms to invited women. It is extremely important that examinations are done competently and also that the myth of the harmfulness of mammograms is refuted. Because mammography is really the only method at the moment that can also capture the early stage of breast cancer. A screening examination takes several minutes in a woman's life, but it can save a life. In this way, I would like to appeal to women not to be afraid and to undergo preventive examinations.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner Andriukaitis, ladies and gentlemen, there are many challenges in our policy to improve the life of a woman with cancer. For me, this starts with prevention at European level. The first challenge we need to tackle is harmonising the quality of screening across Europe. Earlier screening in at-risk groups can already drastically reduce the number of patients. The quality of life is strongly affected by any type of cancer. For example, women have to fight against depression, anxiety, sleep disorders, loss of appetite and lack of zest for life. In addition, the side effects of cancer therapy can lead to an early menopause, which means that for young women becoming a mother becomes almost impossible. That is why I support the "Transforming Breast Cancer Together" initiative. With this initiative, we will be working with stakeholders across party borders and borders to discuss how to improve the lives of women with breast cancer. Cancer also has a negative effect on a woman's professional career, with the result that she may be absent for a long time and may even lose her job. Even after healing, patients still suffer consequences. That is why I am a strong supporter of the 'right to be forgotten' initiative. After healing, it should be possible to take out insurance or to enter into financial transactions such as loans as if one had never been ill. Thanks to research and innovation, there has already been a lot of progress in cancer prevention, treatment and care for cancer patients. I therefore support the demand for a harmonised and progressive European cancer policy. Thank you.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I believe that we cannot allow in this 21st century European Union that the interests, in addition to commercial, of large pharmaceutical companies and companies engaged in the health business should be put before the surveillance by the public authorities of the health of citizens. As we read in the press, as the ombudsman says, as the last report of the European Observatory says, it is impossible to disguise the infinite number of meetings between lobbies and the Commission. Or the countless events, within this House, sponsored by companies also in the healthcare sector. This collusion is observed, for example, in the case of defective breast implants manufactured by a French company, which has been the subject of constant public denunciation in recent years. Despite this scandal, other manufacturers still do not adequately warn of the risks and adverse effects of silicone gel. That is why in the coming weeks we will return, again, to discuss this issue in the Committee on Petitions. The same is true of cancer treatments, which need a strong, undeniably universal and public health system, and with as many means as possible and appropriate to gender specificities. We must ensure that the Commission promotes the exchange of good practices in the prevention, detention, treatment and monitoring of the cure of diseases, as in the case of breast cancer. Second, States implementing public health measures should raise a holistic view, not only with adequate funding of their health systems to make them accessible and quality, but also in the framework of monitoring high-risk health products, assessing their effect on women's health. Finally, both institutions and countries must make efficient use of the Structural Funds and all existing financial instruments at European level to invest in research, development, specialised medical centres and appropriate staff.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! Civilization diseases, including cancer, are largely the result of the environmental contamination that surrounds us. Industrial production of food, pollution of water, soil, air, carcinogenic building materials take their toll in the form of cancer. Therefore, in addition to medical care, the fight against cancer requires very broad action for the whole civilization around us. It is very good that this report has appeared, this resolution that we are discussing today. It is very good that there are very specific methods, how to prevent cancer and how to treat it effectively. And I very much welcome what I have heard from the European Commission that the European strategy recommended in this resolution, the European approach to the matter, is already being implemented in part. We need such a strategy. We need common solutions, common funding and, above all, access to the best standard, so that every woman living in Europe – whether she lives in Eastern Europe or Western Europe – has the same chance of being cured when her cancer happens.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. One in three Europeans will have cancer in their lifetime, and more than 1 300 000 people die every year in the European Union, which is around 26% of all deaths. The main forms of cancer that affect women are breast, uterine and cervical cancer. Breast cancer is the most common fatal cancer in the female population. I agree that a European strategy to combat cancer is very necessary. Unfortunately, there are significant differences between cancer diagnosis and standards in Central and Eastern Europe compared to Western Europe. We should take action to compensate for these disparities, to promote a healthy lifestyle, to pay attention to the need for screening and early diagnosis.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, the statistics are clear, relentless, cancer is simply a killer and in the EU up to 26% of deaths are caused by cancer. Fortunately, the European Union is aware of the potential for cooperation between Member States and has come up with a number of initiatives to address it. I would like to thank the Commissioner, who listed them here and listed them also with great personal bias. It is clear that he cares very much about this and that he understands the work he is doing for citizens and, in particular, for women. Breast cancer is one of the most common forms of cancer in the EU. It accounts for 13.4% of all cancer cases. In order to prevent cancer in women, a healthy lifestyle, a healthy diet and, of course, screening and diagnosis must be promoted. I hope that the European Social Fund, which will integrate the current health programme, will also help to improve the situation.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: – Sinjura President, bla ebda dubju qed nitkellmu, kif smajna anke fil-bidu ta' din id-diskussjoni, fuq marda serja ħafna li ħafna li ġiġet deskritta hawn bħala dik tas-seklu. Jekk inħares lejn Malta, pajjiż żgħir, qed nitkellmu fuq elfejn każ ġdid ta' kan大er fis-sena, disa' mitt mewta. Minn dawk l-elfejn każ għandek tliet mija u ħamsin li huma l-kanħer tas-sider. Irrid ngħid li għandna rata tajba ta' kura għaliex ir-rata tagħna hija ta' 87 % u allura aktar mill-medja Ewropea u hawnhekk tara l-effett ukoll ta' meta jkollok population based screening. Però fl-Ewropa rridu naħdmu wkoll biex ikollok rata ta' a大大ettazzjoni aktar għax jista' jkollok programme ta' screening imma mhux kulħadd and ħ大etta volontarjament li dawk jagmilħhom.  Irrid nirreferi wkoll għall-ħidma tal-NGOs - dawn huma kru大jali. Jiena ġibthom hawn biex jagħtu anke l-vu大i tagħhom f'dan il Parlament. Irridu nitkellmu dwar medi大ina iktar effettiva u li nagħtu r-riżorsikollha meħtieġa favur dan il-qasam. Fuq kollox il-prevenzjoni anke marbuta ma' kwalità ta' ħajja aħjar u ikel aħjar.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Madam President, like Mrs Aiuto, I believe that we still have reserves in the European Union in the fight against cancer. Early screening for cancer, affordable effective treatment, dissemination of scientifically based information on lifestyles and factors that can help prevent cancer, as well as helping families with cancer – all of this must become a European standard to be respected in all Member States. Unfortunately, this is still not a given today. There are still differences in both incidence and mortality rates between Central and Eastern Europe and the rest of Europe, not only for ovarian and cervical cancers, but also for other forms of cancer. We must not tolerate this. However, we must also not forget the fact that cancer is a disease that does not choose its victims by gender. I will therefore support both the motion for a resolution tabled and Mrs Petir's amendments.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, 4 February was World Cancer Day and it was an opportunity for all of us to raise awareness of cancer and show our support for the victims and their families. As a Member of the European Parliament, it’s my responsibility to highlight areas where the European Union can do better to both prevent cancer and support the victims. I therefore want to highlight the misery caused to women suffering from industrial-related diseases, which are completely preventable. In both the cleaning and beauty industries, women are particularly at risk of exposure to carcinogenic substances. The chemicals used in their day-to-day work are known to increase the chances of cancer. So politicians across Europe should reflect on what we can do to prevent workplace cancers. We must ensure that workers have adequate and enforced protection from substances and conditions that are known to cause cancer. Women should not be at greater risk of cancer just because of the work they do.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, cancer is reaping and this concerns both men and women. 26% of deaths are due to cancer. For women it has been shown, both from the debate and from studies, that cancer is basically about breast cancer, uterine cancer and cervical cancer. Of course, prevention is possible and that is what we need to focus on. To have access to diagnostic tests for women and to have the possibility of treatment — and even low cost — because otherwise access to treatment for women is prohibitive. Of course, the next stage is psychological support, because the interventions that are being made, in particular the treatment of breast cancer, can lead to a survival rate of 78% for women, but from then on support is needed.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, cancer is a disease that makes no difference and affects many women in Europe causing enormous physical and psychological suffering. For all these women, for many of our families, our support. To fight cancer all women must have universal and free access to public health services, which should not be reduced by austerity policies. This Sunday, in my country, 40,000 people were demanding public services. Early detection, treatments, support for survival and rehabilitation also with European funds. Early detection of cancer is critical with mammograms. And also the human papilloma vaccine, as a team from Mexico has just indicated. Fundamental research is very important for this awareness, as is awareness among girls.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to applaud the Commissioner's speech and it is clear that our entire debate is about the reserves it has on this one-off EU issue. I think it's obviously about prevention and promotion, lifestyle and also about helping those affected families. I would like to share here one story from the Czech Republic about Lucie Bittalová, who was diagnosed with cervical cancer. She was 28 years old. I think she became a heroine in the Czech Republic because she was not afraid to talk about this matter publicly. She said, "Don't be stupid, go on a tour!" – a campaign that was conducted in the Czech Republic. She motivated thousands of women to join the preventive examination with the moon of Cancer. I know it's a bit of a non-systemic solution, but it's definitely a solution that can remind women of the role of prevention and the need for preventive checks. This is a specific story from the Czech Republic and I would like to appreciate it here.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Madam President, women live longer, but live worse. They more often manifest that they do not have their medical needs met. The investigation, in many cases, does not contemplate them. One in eight women in the European Union will develop cancer, while screening for early diagnosis, between the age of 50 and 69, varies between countries between 30 and 90%. Other cancers specifically affecting women will cause infertility and many psychological damage. That is why it is not only necessary that the next research programme of the European Union be clearly based on the gender dimension in health problems, but that the European Commission itself leads the comprehensive approach of cancer in women in the different countries of the European Union, from research to early detection, treatment and also to reparation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Madam Chairman, this topic is too important and I am sorry that we are discussing it in the late hours. There is a real epidemic of cancer around the world, especially in the European Union. We have heard different statistics in support of this thesis and it is important to note and recall that here in this Parliament our group, Anti-Cancer MPs, led by Ms Peterle and in which many of us have become involved and it is the fruit of our work that you have been talking about, Mr Commissioner. I think this manifesto is important for the fight against cancer and we definitely need to have a uniform European solution.  People living in Western countries don't have the same access as those who live in the eastern countries of the European Union and I think that's one of our battles too, the fight for equality. So equality access to treatment. Some can access smart medicines, some can't. So it's not the same access everywhere and that's what we have to level and that's why I thank you for this report today.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened with great interest to this discussion and I am grateful for your invaluable interest and engagement. Let me react a little bit. Some people raised issues about medical devices, prosthesis and so on. Now we have a new Medical Devices Directive; now we are carrying out a health technology assessment because it’s about innovation in cancer treatment. Let’s go forward. It is in our hands to regulate the environment, speaking about multinationals and so on, and it’s about transparency. Let’s take carcinogens. We included a lot of new carcinogens on the list when we talked about safety at work. Acrylamides, endocrine disruptors, the fight against tobacco, a tracking and tracing system, the possibilities of strictly regulating pesticides. We did a lot in those four and a half years together and thank you. We are cooperating in cancer prevention. That is the comprehensive answer, of course. Sitting on top of cancer requires investment in research and innovation. Through each framework programme for research, the EU has invested some EUR 2.8 billion since 2007 on prevention. Altogether this is OK – we are moving forward. Some EUR 440 million have been devoted in the last ten years to cancer that specifically affects women, mainly targeting breast cancer and cancers of the reproductive organs. Secondly, access to data also empowers patients. In this light, I would like to inform you about the adoption last week of the recommendation of the creation of a secure system that really enables citizens to access their electronic health files across Member States and can help us to support those who are suffering from cancer. Finally, I would like to underline that cancer treatment is no longer just about survival. We therefore need to ensure that the reintegration into education, employment and daily life for women having suffered from cancer is as easy as possible. It is the responsibility of employers and trade unions, and it would also be good to raise questions about cancer at the Council of the Heads of State or Government. In 1980 it was raised at Council level and now there is not one word from the European President. It’s time to show political will to move forward and encourage all Member State’s governments to do more.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 February 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – It is to be welcomed that we are discussing this important issue with the Commission today, because some cancers, such as breast, uterine and cervical cancer, are mainly or exclusively female. In addition, not only in the EU, but also in the world, the world's largest number of women with cancer die from breast cancer. According to the available data, we can see that the percentage of women's survival can reach almost 80% after early diagnosis and timely treatment. This shows how important quality prophylactic screening of the whole population for cancer is. However, even if women manage to overcome cancer, the fight does not end, as they often have serious and usually underestimated psychological problems, especially if they have undergone a hysterectomy or mastectomy. Women and their family members should receive special counseling assistance. In addition, it is essential that women can easily participate in screening programmes, receive affordable and equal treatment and access to affordable and equal support, and provide them with tailor-made support and information on lifestyle-related factors that can help prevent cancer. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Member States to make use of EU funds, such as the European Structural and Cohesion Funds and the European Investment Bank, including with a view to establishing quality screening, prevention and treatment centres that are easily accessible to all patients.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. – I support parliament's report's position that research, screening, diagnosis, monitoring, treatment and post-treatment support should be increased in order to combat cancers. One in three Europeans will develop cancer in their lifetime. Men and women have the types of cancer characteristic of each. In Finland, the most common cancer among women is breast cancer. Every year, more than four thousand women develop breast cancer in Finland. Different approaches and targeted policies are needed to diagnose and prevent cancer diseases in men and women. In Finland, a great example is breast cancer screening. People aged 50 to 69 receive an invitation to screening every couple of years. This is aimed at detecting breast cancer at an early stage, when treatment is more effective. In Finland, the breast cancer prognosis is good: 89% of sufferers are alive after five years of diagnosing the disease. Mortality is lower among women who have participated in screening, thus preventing dozens of breast cancer deaths every year. Screenings and other early diagnosis measures should therefore be the subject of a European treatment recommendation.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the oral question to the Commission on the rights of intersex people, tabled by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000132/2018 – B8—0007/2019) (2018/2878(RSP)) – the oral question to the Commission on the rights of intersex people, tabled by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000133/2018 – B8—0008/2019) (2018/2878(RSP) – the oral question to the Commission on the future of the LGBTI List of Actions (2019-2023) tabled by Malin Björk on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group, Tanja Fajon and Daniele Viotti, on behalf of the S&D Group, Sophia in 't Veld, on behalf of the ALDE Group, Roberta Metsola and Sirpa Pietikäinen, on behalf of the PPE Group and Terry Reintke, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group (O-000006/2019 - B8—0014/2019) (2018/2878(RSP).

name: Claude MORAES
text: author. – Madam President, we are now moving to the question of discrimination against lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) people and it’s important that this item has been placed on the agenda today. I know that many people today in the Chamber care about this issue, and I particularly thank Parliament’s LGBTI Intergroup for ensuring that this has been brought to the agenda. In particular, I want to raise one aspect of the fight against discrimination against LGBTI people, and that is to highlight the fact that this is the first time a specific aspect of this issue is being debated in this Parliament – having been debated in the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe and, indeed, in the UN. This will be the first time that the daily discrimination faced by intersex people – the ‘I’ in LGBTI – has been discussed here in the European Parliament. And that is significant and important. So, to focus on the oral question and resolution put forward by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, which touches upon this issue not often discussed but extremely important. Why important? If we are going to measure our values in the European Union by the way particular communities are treated and their vulnerability, then clearly the position faced by intersex people, not only in the European Union but also worldwide, is of significance. And it’s worth mentioning that human rights violations experienced by this community are significant, and we need to put them on the agenda today. Intersex people face violation of their bodily integrity. Very often intersex is still considered as a disease, as something wrong, to be fixed, and ‘normalising’ surgery is often applied. Medical treatments are carried out on intersex newborns in at least 21 EU Member States. Secondly, throughout their lives, intersex people are victims of stigma, verbal discrimination including in the workplace, harassment, and lack of adequate medical care, legal recognition and access to justice, and of the invisibility of their bodies in our society. However, there is still no legal protection against discrimination based on such sex characteristics: no legal recognition of intersex people. So today, we call on the Council and the Commission to ensure a de-pathologisation of intersex people and to prohibit unnecessary sex-normalising treatment and surgery. We know that in some Member States there has been progress, but in too many Member States there is insufficient progress. We ask for gender and sex characteristics to be recognised as a ground of discrimination. We ask for provision of adequate, impartial psychosocial counselling; for the mainstreaming of flexible birth registration; and for legal gender-recognition procedures to be facilitated. The key questions we’re asking of the Commission are very important ones. Today, almost 10 years on – and while I know the Commissioner is strongly committed to this, as she said in the LIBE Committee – we still do not have our cross-cutting anti-discrimination directive. So the base, which I know the Commissioner and the Members here are committed to, has not been put in place. And really the question is: what can we do to advance this anti-discrimination directive in a wider way? Secondly, specifically with the intersex community, what are we doing to ensure that sex characteristics as a ground of discrimination, hate crime and hate speech are recognised? Today, in the EU, only Malta and Portugal have outlawed medically unnecessary treatments on intersex children, and only Malta, Portugal and Greece have explicitly recognised sex characteristics as a ground of discrimination, hate crime and hate speech. It is intolerable that people in Europe continue to be discriminated against because of who they love, the body they are born with, and their personal sense of their gender. It is important today that we have put this on the agenda. And, I repeat, if we are to have values across the EU that we can respect, then they must entail caring for the most vulnerable minorities in our society; facing up to such discrimination; and showing that we are not afraid to stand up against it. For that reason, I am very proud that this oral question and resolution are being presented to you today.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: author. – Madam President, in ‘LGBTI’, what does the ‘I’ stand for? It stands for intersex people, not for ideology. Behind that unknown letter, there are people who suffer from discrimination and violence, and have suffered since childhood. I’m proud to be the author for the PPE Group of what is the first-ever resolution on the human rights of intersex people – the forgotten letter ‘I’. Children are being subjected, without informed consent, to medical treatment and surgical operations which damage their health and reproductive rights. Think! What if it was your child? In this time of populism on both sides of the Atlantic, the human rights agenda is under attack. We are seeing a normalisation of sexist and homophobic rhetoric, in which the LGBTI community has become an easy target of the extreme right. Discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation or gender identity should not have any place in our modern societies. I want to agree with you, Mr Moraes, that the anti—discrimination directive, on which I am the shadow rapporteur for the PPE Group, should move forward. It’s unacceptable that it has been blocked for years in the Council. Too often, LGBTI people are victims of bullying, hate speech, homophobia, stereotypes and stigmatisation, at school and online. The European Union must stand up for open societies and take the lead in respecting fundamental rights globally, living up to our core values of tolerance, equality and diversity. While legislation, including on access to justice, is a necessary step, it’s not enough. We have to join forces to change the rhetoric and the attitudes, and, with our joint resolution, we should secure the future of the LGBTI List of Actions that expires now. So, we are calling on you, Commissioner, and on the Commission to adopt a clear strategy and an action plan to make sure that we will promote and protect LGBTI people in Europe and beyond, recognising that LGBTI rights are human rights.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for LGBTQ people face discrimination, hate crimes, threats. The families of LGBTQ people are not recognised – no free movement here, indeed. Transgender and intersex people are subjected to abusive and even genital mutilation. LGBTQ refugees are locked up and deported – in 2019 in Europe. In some countries, fighting and solidarity between different groups have progressed, but in other countries things are going in the wrong direction. Nationalists and conservatives are attacking our rights. They organize themselves and say we're unnatural. We're freaks, we're unwanted. It's over. It is time to fight back and we intend to do so together with other movements that want to see a better Europe and a more humane and equal future – queer solidarity, my friends – refugee solidarity movements, women's movements, functional rights movements and many others who want to see a humane and equal future. We demand political action. Imagine that ministers could not even agree on a few small lines on LGBTQ rights, because then Orbán and Poland and others said no. Here we colleagues have managed to agree on a strategy for the rights of intersex people. We're advancing the positions. We also call for a comprehensive strategy for LGBTQ rights against discrimination, a new discrimination law. We need to put an end to hate crimes and threats against LGBTQ people. We need to support all LGBTQ kids around Europe. We need to stand up for the rainbow families. We're not going to go away. I myself thought I would come back here as an MEP after the elections in May and then it will be a political workshop, may you believe. Then we're going to move the positions forward. For our bodies, our lives, our dreams, our desires are not only a reality, but they are also a chance for anyone who wants to violate gender-conservative beliefs to see the greatness of what it means to be human with different families, different dreams, different lives and different bodies. Take that chance.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, allow me to say an initial word about the fact that these two questions, which are likely to close the work of this parliamentary term, are also the completion of work done with the many colleagues within the European Parliament's LGBTI intergroup, and so this fills me with pride.  Through this resolution, Mr President, the European Parliament intends to call on the Commission to ensure that the rights of LGBTI people are a top priority in the work programme from 2019 to 2024. It is crucial to ensure a comprehensive and strong follow-up strategy on the list of actions to further improve the protection of the rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex people, and to promote equality. To date, the rights of LGBTI people are not protected uniformly across Europe. Unfortunately, the European Union does not yet have global protection against discrimination based on gender identity, sexual orientation or sexual characteristics. Same-sex unions are not yet recognised in all Member States, sterilisation is a requirement for legal recognition of this kind in eight Member States, and 18 Member States require a mental health diagnosis. In 21 Member States, intersex children undergo 'sexual normalisation' interventions.  In the meantime, the list of actions remains limited in terms of priorities and commitment, and the European Union's innovative responses, such as the pillar of social rights, are not being integrated. Only by restoring credibility to this policy document, by protecting the rights of intersex people, by protecting European citizens from all forms of discrimination through the horizontal anti-discrimination directive, which has been blocked for ten years now, as has already been said, and by taking concrete measures to guarantee the freedom of movement of families, including LGBTI families, will we respond in accordance with the demands of the Court of Justice. This is a fight against transphobia, homophobia, which is also cured through culture...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: author. – Madam President, I will not repeat what has been said by all my colleagues because I think we are all on the same wavelength. I would just like to make a couple of remarks about what the EU institutions are doing. First of all, like my colleagues, I’m pleased and proud that we have our very first resolution on intersex people on the agenda. I think that is a strong political signal. At the same time, we’re also looking at the resolution on the LGBTI list of actions that was adopted by the Commission at the start of its term of office. In my view, these two resolutions should be a kind of legacy to the next European Parliament, and also to the next Commission, and a call for stronger action – even stronger action than has been taken in the past five years – because I think that a lot still needs to be done. A lot has been achieved, but if I look at the Council, for example, I note that at one of the last Council meetings the Member States couldn’t even agree on a joint statement on LGBTI rights. Hello! We’re still in the Middle Ages. Some countries are blocking it. I also note, like other colleagues, that the anti-discrimination directive has been blocked for more than 10 years now. But I note, too, if I look at our own House, that the President of our House, Mr Tajani, is one of the keynote speakers at the World Congress of Families, which is probably one of the most homophobic, anti-choice events that you will find in the world. One of the co—organisers is an organisation called CitizenGO, which is also one of the champions of the so-called Nashville Declaration, which is the most homophobic declaration in the world. It has also been signed by some people in this House. I do not feel represented by Mr Tajani showing up at such an event and then arguing here for LGBTI rights. That is hypocrisy if ever I have seen it.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: author. – Madam President, the European Parliament strongly condemns sex-normalising treatments and surgery. That is a very simple yet very meaningful sentence – and sentences that change history are often not complicated but rather simple. Tomorrow this House will have the chance to make history when we vote for the first intersex resolution here in this Parliament. And yes, we will not be able to make up for all the suffering that the binary-gender ideology has wrought in so many people’s lives: the involuntary treatments, the forced sterilisation and surgical procedures, the stigmatisation and the discrimination. But we can say tomorrow, loud and clear, that we will fight for a future in which the rights of intersex people will be upheld in this Union. This message is long overdue, but it comes at a very crucial moment because the rights of all LGBTI people are currently under attack. After decades of progress, we are in danger of going backwards. To prevent that from happening, the EU must adopt a strategy on how to prevent it. A new list of measures on LGBTI rights is the least that the Commission can do in order to stand firm with those who are fighting to love and to live as they want to. The specific measures that we want the Commission to take are: to unblock the cross-cutting equality directive proposal in the Council; to make LGBTI rights a priority, including in the forthcoming work programme; to follow up on the Coleman case to enable freedom of movement for LGBTI citizens of the European Union; and to ensure that all possible measures are taken to fight discrimination against LGBTI people throughout the European Union. We have to do this for European citizens.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank the European Parliament for the opportunity to discuss such an important subject here today. I will focus particularly on the rights of intersex people, which should be protected in all Member States and which are the subject of one of your questions to the Council. I would like to begin by stating very clearly that violence and discrimination have no place in European society. We should not forget that Romania’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union has as one of its priorities combating discrimination of any kind. The principles and values enshrined in the EU Treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and EU legislation are not up for negotiation or bargaining. In Europe, the commitment to decency, tolerance and equal treatment is the very foundation of the idea of a just society. This is a source of pride for Europeans, and for good reason: our society is becoming more inclusive and diverse than ever before. Together, we have taken steps to guarantee equal treatment for women, ethnic minorities, sexual minorities, persons with disabilities, religious minorities and citizens of all ages. And we continue to work on that. I believe that all three EU institutions fundamentally agree on the direction of the journey – towards even greater emancipation and tolerance. I am proud to say that the Council has already adopted legislation that clearly prohibits discrimination on the grounds listed in Article 19 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, but, as you well know, the anti-discrimination law book remains incomplete. We have better protection, at EU level in respect of discrimination on some grounds rather than others. As many of you have often reminded us, the Council has not yet exhausted its legal capabilities in that regard. I would like now to turn to the specific issue of violence and discrimination against intersex people. For, indeed, you speak of real suffering in the questions you have put to the Council and the Commission today. I am proud to point out that, in June 2016, the Council responded positively to the Commission’s list of actions to advance LGBTI equality. It was the first time that the Council had adopted a declaration devoted to the advancement of equality for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex persons. So it was a historic moment. In its conclusions the Council invited the Commission to promote the measures outlined in this list of actions and to report on a regular basis on the progress achieved. The Council also invited the Member States to take their own actions to combat discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity. It is, of course, the responsibility of the Member States to hear that call.  Honourable Members, the advancement of equal treatment is a joint effort to which we all must contribute. When it comes to cooperation at EU level, the Commission’s list of actions, including the exchange of good practice, is to be welcomed. The Commission has also undertaken a campaign of awareness raising. The Fundamental Rights Agency is also making important contributions by mapping out the situation of intersex people, including the problems they face in terms of birth registration as well as the matter of non-necessary surgery – which you mentioned – and the closely related problem of informed consent. This is, first and foremost, a question of medical ethics, for which the Member States are responsible and accountable. The issue of birth registration is also a national matter. Indeed, when it comes to the more specific issues identified in your question, it is the Member States that have the key competences. However, this does not mean there is no European dimension or solution. Of course there is. As you know, the category of intersex is not included on the list of prohibited discrimination grounds in the Treaties, but I believe it is obvious that extending the right to equal treatment for intersex people is entirely within the spirit of our common European values and our common campaign for inclusiveness. As we pursue, improve and defend our values, we all benefit from constructive exchanges, including the one we are holding here today and the vote you will have tomorrow. Thank you for your attention. I would like to remind you, as I said at the beginning, that the Romanian Presidency of the Council has as one of its priorities the fight against discrimination, and this is one of the opportunities that we are proud to have.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first start by thanking Parliament for tabling this debate on the discrimination against LGBTI people. The Commission is committed to the advancement of equality of LGBTI people and welcomes that Parliament has ensured, through the report, that these issues, and particularly the situation of intersex persons, are kept high on the political radar screen.  It is exactly for this reason that we published a list of actions to advance LGBTI equality, in December 2015. In the coming months we will present a third report on the implementation of the list of actions. I will come back to this list of actions at the end of this opening remark.  Let me say a few words on the problems related to intersex people who, as we all know and as you mentioned many times, are having serious problems because they do not fit into the main gender categories – female and male. The unnecessary surgical operations and treatments that intersex children may undergo are especially worrying since they are not able to give their fully informed consent due to their young age.  However, according to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the definition of health policies and the organisation and delivery of health services, fall under the responsibility of Member States. The Commission respects the principle of subsidiarity in the area of ethical accountability for the surgical treatment that intersex young people and children undergo. The possibility to provide a third gender option at birth or in public documents are also competences of the Member States.  Regarding transgender people, Member States have to ensure that the relevant laws are applied in accordance with the latest international human rights standards. The European Court of Human Rights ruled that the condition of compulsory sterilising surgery or treatment for legal gender recognition violated Article 8 of the Convention.  So I will now come back to our list of actions which aim to advance LGBTI rights. Within the framework, or based on this list of actions, the Commission has carried out several activities to raise awareness of the difficulties that transgender and intersex people experience. It recently published a new report on trans and intersex equality rights in Europe.  We also financially support civil society organisations whose work also includes promoting transgender and intersex equality. We have released awareness raising videos and we organised a good practice exchange between the Member States on these topics.  Upon the request of Parliament, the pilot project Health4LGBTI was carried out, which also focused on the specific health issues transgender and intersex people face.  As part of the list of actions, the Commission also monitors and enforces existing rights of LGBTI people under the Free Movement Directive. The Commission welcomes the recent ruling by the Court in the Coman case and the Commission will monitor Member States’ compliance with the EU free movement acquis as regards issues related to sexual orientation.  The Commission will continue to implement the list of actions to advance LGBTI rights in 2019. This year a new Eurobarometer on discrimination, including relevant questions for LGBTI equality, and the second Fundamental Rights Agency LGBTI survey will take place. These surveys will provide us with important data that will help us to target our future actions. This year is the year of evaluation and preparatory works for the future, updated LGBTI list of actions which should be adopted by the newly established Commission and endorsed by Parliament.  The Commission is committed to successfully and positively handing over its work to advance LGBTI equality to the next Commission, which will have to decide how it will continue these policies. But I will strongly recommend that my successor involve the European Parliament and civil society organisations in the design of its future LGBTI list of actions, as also suggested in the motion we are debating today.  I want also to react to the debate we have heard up to now. The Commission continues to promote the adoption of the horizontal equal treatment directive. As you rightly pointed out, I will call it a shameful situation that it has been blocked for years in the Council. You are aware that this piece of legislation requires unanimous adoption. That’s why we need to have all the Member States on board.  When I indicated that after so many years of having this blocked, the Treaty offers the option of enhanced cooperation, you will not be surprised that the Member States – at least in the reactions I got in the Council meetings, but also in many bilateral meetings where I raised this issue – confirmed that they need more time and they do not want us to go for the enhanced cooperation, because this is about fundamental rights. So I just convey this information to you and I will continue to keep pushing because we regularly discuss the prospects of this directive, which I would like to see in a positive way. My last comment: you also raised the issue of hate speech online and hate speech in general. The Commission is continuing very intensive work, together with the IT sector, to achieve a radical decrease in hate speech online and a decrease in hate speech from the social networks. We are reasonably successful. The IT sector is doing what it committed itself to do in the Code of Conduct and we will continue to do this exercise in the future until the end of my mandate.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, after the Me Too movement thousands of LGBTI people shared on Twitter stories of discrimination and homophobic bullying under the hashtag MeQueer, many of whom are our fellow Europeancitizens. In the 21st century, the European Union still needs comprehensive protection against discrimination on grounds of gender identity, sexual orientation and sexual characteristics. LGBTI people remain excluded from genuine freedom of movement and the Union's social inclusion strategies, such as the European pillar of social rights, and asymmetries persist in the different Member States regarding the protection of their civil rights and access to key public services such as education, health or social security. Against this backdrop, Commissioner, the Commission needs to develop an inclusive strategy for LGBTI people that includes promoting civilian recognition of intersex persons, includes the implementation of homophobic and transphobic violence prevention projects in member states' education systems and also ensures the necessary protection for LGBTI asylum seekers.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, when we talk about LGBT people, intersex people are often forgotten about. They have been dehumanised for centuries and discriminated against because of their bodies. This been presented as a health issue, when in fact there is nothing unhealthy about being intersex. The forced mutilations practiced on intersex children are an abomination. It is truly unacceptable that in 2019 such awful violations of bodily autonomy are still taking place in the EU. The fact that we are so prone forcibly and permanently to change the bodies of children who cannot give consent shows how far we are willing to go to reinforce ridiculous gender binary. Intersex people are proof that there is more to humanity than men on one side and women on the other side. Intersex people are proof that categorising people on the basis of their sexual features is simply narrow minded and does not reflect reality. I will stand with all intersex people, especially children, and I will tell them: ‘You are not alone.’

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, even now LGBTI rights are not guaranteed in the EU. There are major differences between EU Member States. There is still no comprehensive protection against discrimination based on gender identity, sexual orientation or gender characteristics. Many EU countries do not recognise marriages between two men or two women, which is possible in Belgium. Prior sterilisation is still a prerequisite for legal change of gender in eight Member States, while 18 Member States require psychological research. In 21 Member States, "gender normalisation surgery" is performed on intersex children. The question is whether this is in line with the European Charter of Fundamental Rights. I support the Commission's call to ensure that LGBTI rights are a priority in its 2019-2024 work programme, among other things, and to strengthen cooperation between the various DGs, with the aim of better mainstreaming LGBTI rights, such as in education and health. The Commission should also adopt a new strategic document to promote equality of LGBTI people. It is also important for Europe to continue raising awareness about LGBTI people and their families. In addition, Europe must also guarantee freedom of movement for all families, including rainbow families, across the EU, in view of the recent case—Coman at the European Court of Justice. In short, it is unacceptable that LGBTI people in many EU countries are still treated as second-class citizens.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today, for the first time, we have a resolution on the rights of intersex people on the table. This was really time, because the taboo of this issue still makes it easier to lock people into a dark space of lawlessness. And what is supposedly right for them is then determined by others who believe that the wrong and the deviation must be eradicated by surgically missing a gender even for infants. Whatever we are saying today, please, let us agree on one thing: we should make every effort to ensure that such operations, such medical treatments, are banned in infants, everywhere, because they can have terrible consequences and because they are by no means medically necessary. Intersex people are simply not sick people to heal, but ordinary people who want to decide on themselves and enjoy respect. Doing everything to ensure that no one has to be afraid, ridiculed, patronised, threatened and put themselves in doubt – I think that is what it is all about – that is why discrimination because of the lack of recognition of intersexuality must also be prosecuted, we need support actions, publicity, positive publicity and the normalisation of the debate – whether it is a question of appropriate gender designations on identity documents, or of finally understanding that human life is not a road.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, an oral question is an instrument of control over the Commission which encourages the Commission to act on the basis of the resolution which we will vote on on Thursday. I have participated in all the debates that have to do with the discrimination suffered by European citizens in their fundamental rights, and particularly the most vulnerable people and groups. This is the case for people who have been discriminated against, or abused, and even criminalized, for their sexual orientation. Depending on who they decide to love. The LGTBI collective, the transgender collective and the intersex people as well. That is why I think it is important that we look at the best practices of those Member States which are distinguished by having a vision, first of all, that does not treat intersex or transsexuality or sexual orientation as a pathology, but which, moreover, does not impose a forced gender on transgender people through medical, surgical or pharmacological practices. I remember the Lunacek report, which we voted on in 2014. It proposes a global view of people's rights based on their sexual, transgender and intersex orientation. This is the path we invite you to follow.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too consider it very important, as has already been said, that there should be this debate, a joint debate on the rights of LGBTI people, and the resolution on the rights of intersex people. As Mr Viotti said, I believe that this debate is also the result of what has been done by the LGBTI intergroup to which I am happy to have been able to contribute. Just as I am glad that the feminist movement calls itself more and more transfeminist movement precisely because it considers the liberation of women and the liberation of LGBTI people to be indissoluble. I believe that, in particular, as Mrs Ernst pointed out, we must condemn any form of surgery that wants to bring intersex children back to gender binaryism. So I'm really very happy with this discussion.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There is absolutely no reason in the European Union to worry about the rights of people with so-called LGBT and QXYZ sexual dysfunctions, and so on. Already at the moment, it is a group that we pay too much attention to, especially in comparison with its importance in society, and enjoys even certain privileges. Because recently in the UK it happened, for example, that the police raided the house and arrested a woman just because on the internet she called a guy, well a guy who had previously cut himself jewels and changed sex in papers. If someone thinks that cutting it out and experiencing something else changes gender, then of course they have the right to think like that, but someone else on the other side has the right to think something else. And he has the right to express such views online and not only. And what you're trying to do is intimidate people. What the european union's ruling moral left is trying to do is censorship, suppression by force of criticism and terrorise society.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I spoke for too long earlier, so I will be brief now. I want to thank you for the debate. Parliament has again shown very strong commitment and I will try to do the same: to express my preparedness to work on our next steps on this important agenda. One concrete thing that we should do together with the LGBTI Intergroup is to carry out some assessment of how the List of Actions worked: what are the achievements, and what things should be changed in the future LGBTI action plan. We will have the new data from Eurobarometer, and it will be important that we meet and that we work together. So, this is my invitation, and I’m sure this will be an important event, where we can work together on this issue.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you so much and thank you once more for this exchange. I think it has shown how much work remains to be done. At the same time, I think we can be proud of the forward strides we have taken in this field. As I recalled earlier, the Council reacted positively to the Commission’s List of Actions in support of the whole LGBTI community. I look forward to its further implementation. When it comes to fighting discrimination and violence, the fine words of our treaties and our declarations and our political debates are quite clear. Europe is on the side of progress, tolerance and light. It is our responsibility as politicians to turn words into action.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 February 2019.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on use of cannabis for medicinal purposes, tabled by Dubravka Šuica, Guillaume Balas, Urszula Krupa, Catherine Bearder, Estefanía Torres Martínez, Martin Häusling and Piernicola Pedicini, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000122/2018 - B8-0001/2019) (2018/2775(RSP)).

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Rapporteur. – Dear Chairman, over the past year a large part of my work in Parliament has focused in particular on public health, the fight against cancer, raising public awareness and access to medical services and medicines.  Tonight we present the European Parliament resolution and the oral question on the use of cannabis for medicinal purposes. We discussed this topic a lot at the ENVI Committee, and when drafting this resolution we wanted to focus on supporting quality research into cannabis-based drugs, as well as on distinguishing between cannabis-based drugs that have undergone clinical trials and have been regulatorily approved, and medical cannabis itself. This term is largely undefined from a legal point of view and therefore I consider that it remains unclear and open to interpretation. In addition, an important aspect of this resolution was to make a strict distinction between the use of cannabis for medicinal purposes and its misuse.  European Union countries vary widely in their approach to cannabis regulations, including cannabis legislation for medicinal purposes, for example, on the maximum levels of permissible concentrations of THC and CBD. Even in those Member States where medical cannabis is legal, the conditions for access, prescribing, purchasing, pricing, reimbursement, as well as the level of knowledge of healthcare professionals about the use of such medicines vary greatly and are a problem for patients. That is why, in our oral question, we asked the Commission for justification: what the Commission has undertaken to support quality research, what it plans to do about future research, how much funding it plans to allocate to research in this area under the Ninth Horizon Europe Framework Programme, and whether the Commission considers that the regulatory environment in the European Union supports quality research on medical cannabis. Likewise, does the Commission consider that it should improve patients' access to medical cannabis? Also, does the Commission intend to establish standards for non-pharmacoceutic medical cannabis to ensure user safety?  In the resolution, we called on the Commission and national authorities to work together to ensure a legal definition of medical cannabis and to make a clear distinction between cannabis-based medicines approved by the European Medical Agency or other regulatory agencies, medical cannabis not supported by clinical trials and cannabis for other applications.  As we know, the cannabis plant is made up of a number of cannabionides that can have a neuroprotective effect, can contribute to reducing some symptoms in patients such as inflammation or bacterial infections, and can also promote bone growth. Also, a comprehensive, evidence-based regulation of cannabis-based medicines would entail additional resources for public authorities, limit the black market, ensure product quality and accurate labelling to help control selling points, limit access to the substance for minors, but also provide legal certainty and safe access to patients who would use it for medicinal purposes with specific precautions for young people and pregnant women.
