It is important to point out that the review of existing scientific literature on cannabis use gives conclusive and satisfactory evidence that it has therapeutic effects in the treatment of chronic pain in adults, for example in the case of cancer, which we talked about at the last point, as well as in the case of epilepsy, Alzheimer's disease, arthritis, asthma, Chron disease, glaucoma, as well as symptoms of spasticity described by patients with multiple sclerosis and are effective in treating patients with anxiety disorder , PTSD and depression.  I would not want to go too far with this theme, so here I will conclude that the work of european institutions and agencies to raise awareness of the importance of research and the legal definition of this medical cannabis is of the utmost importance and can only help patients who really need these drugs, of course, with strict regulations and thorough analysis.  It is up to us politicians, public figures, professors, activists to unite in the fight to improve health in every way. In any case, I would just like to emphasize that we want to strictly part the use of cannabis for medicinal purposes from the one used for recreational purposes and it is very important to emphasize this so that any abuse with this desire of ours is addressed.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, over the past decade, we have seen growing public interest in the development of therapies derived from cannabis and its components and in the use of cannabis for medical purposes. The therapeutic use of cannabis has been discussed in relation to a wide range of medical conditions, from multiple sclerosis to post—traumatic stress disorder and anxiety. I would first like to highlight the distinction between non—pharmaceutical medical cannabis and medicinal products derived from cannabis. When it comes to the regulatory point of view, the EU angle is limited. This is a Member State competence, which means that each national authority will decide whether it is legal in its territory. On the other hand, the EU pharmaceutical legislative framework is clear and robust and includes cannabis—derived medicinal products. A marketing authorisation is granted for a medicinal product only after its quality, safety and efficacy have been evaluated, and a positive benefit/risk balance related to its use has been concluded. Once placed on the market, medicinal products continue to be monitored through pharmacovigilance activities, which also apply to cannabis—derived medicinal products. So, how exactly can the EU contribute to this discussion? Well, early dialogue and scientific advice for medicinal-product development are examples of EU added value. Furthermore, coordination between the various EU agencies is crucial. Let me now address each of the questions you raised. As a starting point, let me stress that more research is needed on the safety and efficacy of cannabinoid—based therapies. Opportunities to support this type of research will be available through the upcoming Horizon 2020 calls for research proposals in 2019 and 2020. As for previous framework programmes for research and innovation, the EU has funded a number of relevant projects and fellowships. More than EUR 40 million has been dedicated to research on cannabis and cannabinoid—based compounds. Our mission is to encourage research and innovation in Europe and we will continue with that approach. In the new framework programme, Horizon Europe, the Commission will continue to support research, including in innovative areas including novel therapeutic approaches. Turning now to your second series of questions, let me say that the healthcare—related issues are complex, and decisions are taken by the Member States. The EU regulatory framework for pharmaceuticals provides for the authorisation of medicinal products derived from cannabis when their quality, safety and efficacy have been proven. Any other use of cannabis for a medical purpose falls within the competence of the Member States. However, that is not to say that the EU is not contributing to this discussion. In October 2016, the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction launched a new service on cannabis, providing updates on cannabis policy models. In December 2018, the agency published a report on medical use of cannabis and cannabinoids, as well as questions and answers for policy making. This was in response to the growing interest in the topic. On your third set of questions, I want to take this opportunity to stress that non—pharmaceutical medical cannabis lies outside EU competence. At the same time, the Commission is aware of the discussion in the World Health Organisation Expert Committee on Drug Dependence about the pharmaceutical preparation of psychoactive substances. If applicable, the relevant conclusions will be considered in the framework of the pharmaceutical legislation on a product basis.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The medical use of cannabis makes sense. Cannabis products can help patients who are not or do not help well enough from other drugs. We must beware of two extremes in the debate. One extreme, as with Pavlov's dog, is to hear the word cannabis and react: Oh, this is something dangerous, horrible, illegal drugs, we have to be against it. If used medically in a controlled manner, this Pavlovian reflex is not appropriate.  But on the other hand, we also have to be careful that patients do not develop an attitude, as I was once told as a doctor by a patient who said: Yes, against my back pain only helps if I smoke in a joint. Without it, this had really been examined well beforehand by a specialist, who might have given him quite different tips on what to do against back pain. So, you have to do it within a regulated framework. You have to be careful. I also expressly agree with paragraph 14 in the resolution that, as with other medicines, this must be done under the rules of authorisation. Surely we cannot impose high burdens on the industry on other matters and say that if they use cannabis, we can simply do it somewhere. The resolution finds the right framework for this, and that is why we will hopefully support it tomorrow by a large majority.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: on behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, Commissioner, I had muscle pain one day and in my country, France, I went to see a neurologist and the only thing he said to me was 'smoke hashish'. First, the problem is that smoking is bad for your health and then hashish is prohibited in my country. Do not believe that in all of Europe today, we can use medicinal cannabis, that is, the CBD molecule, this is not true. So we need a European framework and from that point of view it is very important that the Commission can give clear indications to the Member States. I would also like to say that the resolution presented here is clear on the fact that it is the doctors who will control the prescriptions and that is very important. It is not a question of saying today that anyone can use cannabis, but that it is the doctor, the only judge, who can say that CBD cannabis can be used in the resolution of a number of pains for patients. But in this regard, a number of amendments have been tabled, including by Conservative MPs, which say that only the form of drugs could be useful. However, this is not entirely true because, as we know, mild prescribing methods, for example, herbal teas, ointments or others can sometimes be much more effective and much more targeted in some patients who do not tolerate drugs. So be careful. Of course, we need medicines and they need to be controlled, but we must also trust doctors to prescribe other methods of administration, and that is in particular the meaning of the amendments that my group will table, which are more appropriate methods for certain pathologies and profiles. Let us not close the debate, there is no possible drift, we are only talking about medicinal cannabis, the CBD molecule, and not recreational cannabis, I say once again, and we need to be open because pharmaceutical lobbies should not be the winners in this case.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I support not only the search for new medicines of natural origin associated with a reduced number of side effects, but above all prevention, which should be fundamental in health care, covering much broader specificity than just eliminating risk factors. So far, this has been highlighted in the resolution. Official data on medical marijuana research and funding are minuscule. The documented therapeutic effects of marijuana-based pharmacological preparations concern only the reduction of spasticity in MS, analgesic and antiemetic effects after chemotherapy in cancer. Before disseminating medical marijuana, clinical trials should first be conducted on the effects of thc and CBD in particular, and the introduction into general use of marijuana known as medicinal with very high percentages of THC and minuscule CBD seems to be not very responsible. Such varieties should be tested in clinical settings and only possibly used for treatment in individual disease units prior to introduction into open medicine, but only if the proceeds of administration of the drug are greater than the side effects. Experimenting with drugs, with their recommendation in so many disease units and ailments without prior reliable research, denies prevention, especially since drug treatment is characterized by adaptation to them, the need to use increasing doses, stronger drugs and complications.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I support most of this resolution. We must create the legislative architecture to support the legalisation of medical cannabis across the European Union. We need to see an end to the situation whereby people such as Vera Twomey and her husband Paul must, in spite of getting a licence to treat their daughter’s debilitating illness, travel six times a year to the Netherlands to get this medicine. They should be able to source this medicine locally, either that or the importation of this proven medicine be delivered to their house.  Freedom of movement of goods is meant to be one of the cornerstones of this Union. Let’s make the freedom of the movement of this medicine a reality. Vera Twomey and her husband Paul have woken hundreds of thousands of people up to the fact that medicinal cannabis can help. Their nine-year-old daughter is now seizure-free and the constant trips to the hospital have become a thing of the past. Ava now has a future. We need this future to be made available to all who need it. This resolution will go some way to achieving that.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for this interesting debate and let me just briefly conclude by assuring you that the Commission will continue to support activities that increase scientific understanding and help develop clear and constructive advice in this area.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5). The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 February 2019.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: in writing. – It is important to differentiate between recreational use and therapeutic utility of cannabis. It is obvious that cannabis is not a panacea, but it does have therapeutic properties for the symptomatic treatment of some diseases. For example, chronic pain, which in my opinion is often medically neglected. Cannabis uses it as a complement to painkillers and other drugs that do not manage on their own to alleviate pain. We must not, on the other hand, trivialize the risks of cannabis use. According to the WHO Committee of Experts on Pharmacodependence, its consumption can cause adverse effects such as dizziness and motor disturbances and cognitive function. It is necessary to carry out a greater number of pharmacological, preclynic, toxicological and trial research, which ensures the control of the quality, safety and efficacy of the medical use of cannabis and its cannabinoids, as well as studies that allow to know the possible risks associated with its consumption. It would also have to study its legalization for therapeutic uses in medicine.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – As a Maltese representative I am proud to say that by passing progressive and necessary legislation, Malta is at the forefront of European progress in the field of medical cannabis. A common European approach will impact and shape national health policies, research and education and bring this beneficial treatment to those in need. This resolution is timely as it calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive strategy for the sector, emphasising the all-important need for the standardisation and unification of products containing cannabis-based medicines. This should also cover CBD where a lack of regulation has allowed low—standard products to enter the market across Europe. We need to ensure EU—wide standards and requirements that will ensure patients’ safe and reliable access to high quality products. However, it is worth noting that without a structured doctors education programme, it doesn’t matter what the law says if doctors do not have the necessary expertise to prescribe the medicine. Education must go hand in hand with the legislation and proper balanced guidelines are essential for the way ahead.

name: Czesław HOC
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Paracelsus, called the father of modern medicine, is the author of the famous thesis "only the dose determines whether a substance is a poison or a drug". In my opinion, we can say the same about marijuana – only the right proportion of thc dose to CBD and the route of administration determines whether marijuana will be medicinal or recreational ("drug"). The two main substances contained in dried or fermented female cannabis inflorescences (Cannabis sativa) are THC (delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinoid), which has a 'narcotic' effect: it makes it euphoric, gives a feeling of "full backlash", changes sensations, while CBD (cannabidiol) has anti convulsive, antipsychotic, anti-inflammatory, anticancer effects, and probably also prevents neurodegenerative changes. So for medicinal purposes we want CBD with a small admixture of THC. And all wisdom and... Art. And because medicine is a knowledge and an art, so it should be trusted. The EP dossier adopted gives the green light to the controlled and scientifically supervised use of marijuana for medicinal purposes. If there is or will be scientific evidence that marijuana reduces pain, vomiting, improves appetite and well-being caused by chemotherapy, or reduces the number of seizures in patients suffering from drug-resistant epilepsy and rare epilepsy syndromes, reduces muscle spasticity and pain in patients suffering from multiple sclerosis, and moreover has a beneficial effect on the immune system – why should we officially prohibit it!?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on: – the oral question to the Council on human germline genome modification, tabled by Miroslav Mikolášik and by Peter Liese, on behalf of the PPE Group (O—000012/2019 - B8-0011/2019) (2019/2568(RSP)); and – the oral question to the Commission on human germline genome modification, tabled by Miroslav Mikolášik and by Peter Liese, on behalf of the PPE Group (O—000013/2019 - B8-0012/2019) (2019/2568(RSP).

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Author. – Commissioner, Madam President, colleagues, the question we are asking ourselves today, which we are asking ourselves to the Commission and the Council, is of great importance for the further development not only of our society, but also of humanity as a whole. The modification of the human genome does not only concern a narrow group that wants to determine the direction of scientific and research progress, it concerns all of us. Somatic cell genetic editing technology is an asset with revolutionary potential to advance the treatment of individual patients' diseases. However, it is necessary to distinguish it carefully from the genetic editing of embryos and gametes, which carries the risk of serious side effects, not only for the individual, but also for his offspring. Hereditary genetic changes would thus lead to changes in all future generations. The irresponsible and unethical experiment by Chinese scientist Che Yiandej, who created the world's first genetically engineered children using genetic editing technology, requires a serious international response. This answer cannot be an easy call for the introduction of safety and efficiency standards for such 'inherited children'. The problem is not only how it was done, but above all what has been done. Germline genetic adjustment is internationally prohibited precisely because of its contradiction with the value of human dignity, human rights, integrity, but also equality. The consequences of reproductive genetic engineering give rise to serious societal and ethical risks. The scientific community cannot have the exclusive competence to decide such a serious matter with far-reaching consequences. Public confidence in new technologies is part of human progress. There is a need for a community-wide debate based on a correct interpretation of scientific knowledge in a social context. We therefore call on the Commission to take a clear leadership stance in support of a global ban on the genetic modification of humans and to create a platform for public engagement in this debate.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for the opportunity to discuss the human germline genome modification review and to thank the two honourable Members who prepared this question for their long-standing and well-known dedication to the subject of ethical consequences stemming from our increased knowledge about human DNA.  I am well aware of the recent unfortunate event that is referred to in the question and which has triggered widespread awareness of the consequences emanating from the possibility to adjust the human genome. The honourable Members refer to clinical trials where genome editing is used in treatments affecting an individual who is suffering from a serious medical condition.  Based on that reference, I understand that we agree that increased knowledge about the human genome, and in particular about genetic causes of illness, could contribute to alleviating human suffering by opening the way to new therapies against such diseases. On the other hand, I am strongly convinced that we are all very concerned about the risk associated with manipulating the genome of future generations. In this context, I allow myself to recall that the debate on the ethical consequences of knowledge about and the possibilities to manipulate the human genome has been ongoing for some decades now. Politicians and scientists are well aware of the situation. This has resulted in legislative and other initiatives to strictly regulate manipulation of the human genome and in particular to prevent human germline genome modification. I would like to point to the legislative framework at Union level, in particular the legislative acts concerning pharmaceuticals and medical devices. We set strict rules for interaction with the human genome for somatic purposes and prohibit germline modification. This said, I would like also to draw everyone’s attention to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the first principle of which is human dignity, and which clearly prohibits eugenic practices in the fields of medicine and biology. To the best of my understanding the act of germline genome editing to which the honourable Members refer would therefore be illegal in the Union. I read your questions as dealing with future directions in this field. It must be noted that the Treaties, and in particular Article 168(7) of the Founding Treaty of the European Union, give Member States, and not the Union, the competence for medical care, including the corresponding ethical considerations. The use of gene editing as a means of medical care should be regulated at Member State level. I am convinced that the Commission, which has the sole right of initiative concerning Union legislation, is following this issue and will, if it deems it necessary or appropriate, prepare legislative proposals. The Romanian Presidency, and I believe the incoming Presidencies, are ready to give our full priority to the examination of any such proposals and I thank you for your attention.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission is indeed aware of the ethical and legal implications of the latest developments in the field of human germline modification. At global level it participates in dialogue with international communities and institutions such as the National Academies of Sciences for Engineering and Medicine and the OECD Working Party on Biotechnology, Nanotechnology and Converging Technologies. The latter has been looking into the ethical and legal debate on germline genome editing. We are also involved with the World Health Organisation in considering the governance and oversight of human gene editing. At the level of the European Union, the EU Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the EU clinical trials and legislation for medicinal products contain specific requirements prohibiting these types of research activity. In addition, the EU has a robust regulatory framework on medicinal products, which is underpinned by the principles of the Council of Europe’s Oviedo Convention on protecting human rights in the biomedical field. Regulation 1394/2007 on advanced therapy medicinal products provides for strict controls in respect of quality, safety and efficacy and for a centralised authorisation system. However, decisions on the application of germline editing techniques for in vitro fertilisation purposes and on funding of national research projects remain the prerogative of the Member States. Furthermore, the Commission is working with national authorities to strengthen oversight on novel technologies in the field of tissues and cells. The Independent Advisory European Group on Ethics and New Technologies is currently working on an opinion on genome editing, which will explore, inter alia, the ethical implications of germline genome editing. The Commission is also exploring how to build on existing surveys of EU public attitudes towards genome editing; how to launch calls for research proposals on public outreach and acceptance of new technologies, such as genome editing, for health applications; and how to organise an event on the ethical, social and legal aspects of genome editing therapeutics.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Modern genetic engineering offers great opportunities, and we must take advantage of them. But there must be ethically motivated boundaries that we respect. Not everything that is technically feasible can be carried out. Researcher He Jiankui's experiments, presented at the Hong Kong conference in November, are irresponsible – and not just in the case of individual cases. Interventions in the human germline are generally irresponsible.  I am very grateful that there has also been a great outcry in the scientific community. But this outcry must now be sustained. We really need to draw clear boundaries, which are also respected.  I would like to express my thanks to the Council for interpreting the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which I consider to be entirely correct. However, it is important that we also bring this into our heads, that the Charter of Fundamental Rights also excludes this abuse of genetic engineering. We must all continue to work together to ensure that this really does not happen again.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. Madam President, let us indeed be rigorous. The first element is that we do not know exactly what is happening with the research that has been conducted by this Chinese scientist: nothing has been scientifically proven today as to the conclusions he claims to have reached. So I really call for caution, today we can't chase the announcement effects. The second element is that we already have a Charter of Rights in the European Union and one day there will have to be a legislative framework adapted to this, which prohibits and frames a number of practices that can be extremely dangerous. The third element, finally, and this is a little bit ironic, is that this Chinese scientist claims to have used the CRISPR-Cas technique. However, this technique, now denounced for the human genome, is being used by ourselves for new plant hybridization techniques, which we are told are not a problem and cannot pollinate nature in an evil way. I think we should be consistent and look at what we ourselves are doing in relation to these techniques before embarking on the announcement follow-up.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I, too, would like to stress that every technology, innovation is welcome, but if it takes place within a shared framework of universal values, which, I think, also have a reflection in EU law, as confirmed by the Council representative. I would like to stress that when editing the genome of embryos and gametes, there is a risk not only of a given individual, but also of his descendants of very serious harmful effects. Hereditary genetic changes would then lead to changes in all future generations, as my colleague Mikolášik also talked about here. Moreover, this procedure also seriously threatens human dignity, and modifications to the hereditary germline are also prohibited by international agreements, not just EU law. I welcome the clear statement made here by Commissioner Jourová. I ask: What measures does the Commission intend to take in the light of the Chinese experiment carried out? There are still some doubts about his guarantee that it was actually carried out as claimed. I firmly believe that the Commission can also direct Chinese scientists to respect these internationally valid commitments.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Madam President, great scientific advances have always provoked great debates from the point of view of ethics, and that is precisely the limit of these great scientific advances, the ethical limits, so that it is a quality science. Choosing embryos, the traits they should have, selecting embryos on demand, of course, is scientifically inadmissible, but clearly it must also be separated from the advances and opportunities that the next revolution, such as gene therapy, can bring to us for the treatment of possible monogenic diseases, or even stem cells, which are already used in cancer treatment today. Therefore, always against the inappropriate use of science, but not to block the opportunities that, as I say, in the near future will be able to bring us genetics. I welcome this debate precisely because that is what we need: to discuss the ethical framework that will have to regulate this new discipline which today comes to give way to numerous treatments and numerous opportunities.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Dear Chairman, the actions of a Chinese researcher who claims to have designed GMO children deserves every condemnation. This act is also against the ethics of science that should have a noble purpose and be in the service of man.  Modifying the genomes of human embryonic cells is a first-class ethical issue, and it is up to us, as legislators, to set boundaries and create laws that will ethically unacceptably disable and thus ensure that science does not transcend ethics. Science really allows us to better understand and explore both the world around us and man himself. Scientific research can help cure various diseases in a noble way, but it is important not to lose sight of the fact that not everything that is scientifically possible and reachable is ethically acceptable. Alteration of the genomes of human embryos and gametes is certainly unacceptable because the introduced genome changes will be hereditary and passed on to future generations.  People can't be made to order. The European Union must clearly stand by the global ban on human embryonic cell modification and stand up for this to be a standard that scientists around the world will respect.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I fully endorse the words of Mr Mikolášik and many of my fellow Members who have spoken before me. If confirmed, the trial carried out by this Chinese researcher last November on the modification of the human germline genome certainly violates the principle of human dignity, which is enshrined, among other things, in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, and raises very sensitive issues, including scientific, social and primarily ethical issues. Biomedical research has led to undoubted and important advances in understanding serious pathologies, aimed at alleviating human suffering, but it is essential to distinguish between editing the somatic genome and modifying the germ genome, that is, DNA. The modification of the germline genome is unacceptable because, as has been said, it entails serious risks of potentially harmful, unintended effects, not only for the individual but also for his descendants, causing heritable alterations whose possible consequences we do not know about in future generations. The European Union, precisely in view of its leading role in international scientific research, on the basis of its principles of its values, must unequivocally reiterate that there is a red line that cannot and must not be crossed because it would open the very dangerous breach... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for your views on this ethically and scientifically highly sensitive issue. As I have stated earlier at the start of this debate, the Commission will keep exploring the subject, which will surely reappear in the near future.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I wish to thank you for raising this issue. The Council has taken good note of the question and of everything that has been said today and I can reassure you that it will stay high on our agenda.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – The fact that recently a Chinese scientist dared to modify DNA in children's germ cells has caused great concern worldwide. In this debate, we should, in particular, address two fundamental ethical issues that have serious political consequences. The first is that the mere existence of, in principle, available technology for editing genetic information in germ cells threatens both human dignity and the fates of families and entire generations. The DNA changes thus caused are hereditary. But there is also a second problem: it turns out that part of the scientific community cannot resist the temptation to "play God". Her self-regulation failed. There is only one answer to these two problems, namely regulation in the form of a ban. It must be strictly controlled and its possible violation punished. Not just in the Union, but anywhere in the world.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "It's not just the Chinese economy that is growing at a dizzying pace. It is no secret that for years in this country a huge amount of money has been invested in the development of science, including in the field of medicine. It is also a fact that many of these alleged discoveries or new treatments for various diseases are difficult to verify through the wider world of science. This is also the case with chinese researcher He Jiankui's announcement that embryonic genome editing was used for the first time to eliminate the possibility of CONTRACTING HIV and that twins were born as a result. The failure to confirm this experiment does not change the fact that the whole world has begun to look with concern and outrage at research conducted in China that exceeds all established limits of ethics. I am pleased that the European Parliament has taken up the debate on this issue, because it is high time to move the discussion from the world of science to the world of people. Changing the human genome and experimenting with humans is no longer science fiction. There is a very fine line between the search for life-saving treatments in the field of genetic engineering and human design. We will not escape this difficult discussion, so we must start and disseminate it to our citizens as soon as possible. Health, human dignity and the future of future generations are at stake.
